PUB-DATE: May 9, 1997,

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 608 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stock Market Ends Higher, But Early Gains Are Pared
After a big drop the day before, the stock market roared back, only to give up much of its gains late in the session. The Dow industrials, up nearly 130 points during the day, closed up 50.97 points at 7,136.62.
The Nasdaq composite closed up 7.92 points at 1,330.83. Technology stocks did particularly well, with I.B.M., Intel and Microsoft all gaining. [Page D6.]
 
Mutual fund investors, apparently unfazed by the stock market's rampant volatility, added some $13.5 billion to equity funds last month. And in recent days, it appears that investors have further stepped up their fund purchases. Market Place. [D6.]
 
Treasury prices rallied, with the 30-year bond yield falling to 6.93 percent from 6.96. [D13.]
 
Retailers Report Sluggish Sales
Running counter to recent buoyant economic statistics, retail sales have been sluggish. The Goldman, Sachs Retail Composite Index rose 3 percent in April from a year earlier. Companies operating low-priced stores, like Ross and TJX, did better than owners of expensive stores, like Saks Holdings and Neiman Marcus. [D4.]
 
China May Buy Hong Kong Stake
China's two state-owned telecommunications providers are interested in acquiring 15 percent of Hong Kong's largest telephone company, investment bankers said: 7 percent from Cable and Wireless, the company's majority owner, and 8 percent from Citic Pacific. [D2.]
Possible U.S. Trade Victory
The European Union's ban on hormone-treated beef is illegal, a World Trade Organization panel has decided in a preliminary ruling, potentially giving the American cattle industry a victory but turning over new ground on issues of national sovereignty. [A1.]
 
Thousands of banana farmers in the Caribbean find themselves at the center of another trade dispute between the United States and the European Union. The World Trade Organization has issued a preliminary ruling that a policy of guaranteeing Caribbean banana farmers special access to the European market is an unfair restriction on American companies like Chiquita that produce bananas in Central and South America. [A6.]
 
Sony Reports Tenfold Profit Surge
Sony's quarterly earnings surged more than tenfold, helped by the weak yen and sales of its Playstation video game. [D2.]
 
A Recommendation Against Drug
An F.D.A. advisory panel recommended against approval of Cephalon's drug, Myotrophin, for the treatment of Lou Gehrig's disease. [D2.]

Bre-X Gets Court Protection
Bre-X Minerals was granted protection from creditors as it prepares for liquidation after being accused of perpetrating the biggest mining fraud in history. [D2.]

Simmons Rejects Settlement
Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas investor, said that he had refused a $50 million settlement proposed by two of his daughters, who have sued for control of his corporate empire. [D6.]
 
I.B.M. to Buy Out Sears in Venture
I.B.M. said that it would buy the 30 percent stake in Advantis -- a networking services joint venture with Sears, Roebuck -- that it does not already own, for $450 million. [D13.]
 
United Paramount Chief to Leave
Lucie Salhaney, the chief executive of United Paramount Network, a fledgling television network, said that she had decided not to renew her contract this fall. [D3.]
 
Small Retreat on Privacy Policy
Giving ground on the Clinton Administration's computer-data privacy policy, the Commerce Department said that it would begin in some cases to allow export of the most powerful data-scrambling technologies when used for securing transactions. [A17.]

INTERNATIONAL A3-13
 
Clinton Promises to Soften Law on Deportations
President Clinton met with the leaders of seven Central American and Caribbean nations in San Jose, Costa Rica, and said he would seek to suspend the deportation provision of a new American immigration law. The Central American leaders had told him they feared mass deportations of their citizens could wreak havoc on their fragile economies. A6
 
The President will go next to the Caribbean, where small banana farmers are worried about American efforts to overturn a trade agreement that gives them special access to the European market. A6 

Changing Lebanon Awaits Pope
Christians in Lebanon hoped Pope John Paul II would use his visit this weekend to protest the extent of Syria's influence in the country, as well as address other anxieties they have about their dwindling role in Lebanon's political order. The Pope is expected to praise the country's spirit of reconciliation after a civil war between Christians and Muslims. A1
 
Mobutu May Return to Zaire
The leaders of six African countries, including President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire, met in Gabon and suggested that Zaire's transitional Parliament elect a leader who would assume power if Mr. Mobutu resigned. Diplomats doubted that the rebel leader, Laurent Kabila, would consider the proposal, and one said the chances were increasing that Mr. Mobutu would return to Zaire. A3
 
Separatists Seize Venice Tower
A small group of men raced two vans with Venetian flags through Saint Mark's Square in Venice and broke into the Campanile, the square's historic bell tower, to demand a separate state in northern Italy. The police said the men were armed, but no shots were fired and no one was injured during the takeover. A5
 
Wiesel Declines Swiss Fund Job
Elie Wiesel, the Nobel Prize-winning Holocaust survivor, indicated he would turn down the post of international chairman of a fund set up by Swiss banks and businesses to compensate Holocaust victims. He said he was not "a person who can quantify." A12
 
Colombian Prosecutor Resigns
Alfonso Valdivieso, a popular anti-drug and corruption fighter in Colombia, resigned as chief prosecutor and said he would run in next year's presidential elections. The current President, Ernesto Samper, took office in 1994 amid charges that he had received millions of dollars in drug money for his campaign. (Reuters)
 
Gandhi's Widow Joins His Party
Sonia Gandhi, the Italian-born widow of former Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi of India, joined his Congress party. Since her husband's assassination in 1991, Mrs. Gandhi, 50, had spurned repeated offers to enter politics and instead led a reclusive life. But her name is often invoked during power struggles in the party, which has been beset by scandals and electoral misfortune. (Reuters)
 
NATIONAL A14-32
 
G.O.P.'s Turn to Admit Taking Illegal Foreign Gifts
The Republican National Committee announced it was returning more than $100,000 in illegal donations from a Hong Kong company. It was the Republicans' first admission that they had used substantially the same practice as the one that has embroiled the Democrats in scandal. A1
 
Bill to Combat Juvenile Crime
The House voted overwhelmingly to offer states $1.5 billion to fight juvenile crime if they change their laws and require young people -- ages 15 or older -- accused of violent crimes to be tried as adults and, in some cases, jailed with them. A1
 
Flood Relief Backed, With Rider
The Senate endorsed an emergency $8.4 billion spending bill intended for flood relief in the Dakotas, but two Republican Senators insisted on including a provision intended to prevent future Government shutdowns over budget disputes. President Clinton has threatened to veto it because of that provision, which faces an uncertain fate in the House. A26
 
Letter Read at Bombing Trial
A prosecutor at the Oklahoma City bombing trial read a letter in which the defendant, Timothy J. McVeigh, told a Michigan woman that his mindset had shifted from "intellectual" to "animal" and made vague references to "patriot" and "militia" activities. A15
 
Abortion Bill Based on Viability
Senator Tom Daschle, the Democratic leader, proposed banning all abortions after a fetus is viable, except if the pregnancy threatened a "grievous injury" to a woman's physical health. The measure is intended as an alternative to a measure banning a procedure known as partial birth abortion to its opponents; they called Mr. Daschle's health exception a huge loophole. A26
 
3 Die in Chemical Plant Fire
An explosion and fire heavily damaged a farm chemical distribution plant at West Helena, Ark., killing three firefighters and injuring 16 people. A hospital, nursing home and subdivision were evacuated because of the fire, which involved chemicals used to make a pesticide. A28
 
NEW YORK/REGION B1-10
 
Giuliani, for First Time, Proposes More Spending
Mayor Giuliani proposed a $33.5 billion election-year budget that, for the first time in his tenure, calls for a modest increase in spending and in the size of the municipal work force. Most of the new spending would go to education and services for children. A1
 
Housing Experiment Is Dropped
The New York City Housing Authority abandoned a plan to seek a waiver from Federal regulations that restrict the rents it charges, the kind of people it houses and the way it spends huge but shrinking Government subsidies. The plan had faced strong opposition from tenants even though the authority said it planned no rent increases or evictions. B1
 
Landlords Woo Elderly on Rent
New York City's largest landlords' group began mailing brochures to about 200,000 elderly residents of rent-regulated apartments, seeking to reassure them that they would not be affected if the rent laws were changed. A leader of the group said it wanted to let the elderly know they would be protected even if other rent regulation laws are repealed, as the landlords want. B6
 
For Violinist, a Labor Sentence
An immigrant who was charged with smuggling rare 18th-century violins into the country from Germany in hopes of reselling them was sentenced to play his own violin at ceremonies to swear in new citizens. The immigrant, Bernard Zeller, a concert violinist and music professor, pleaded guilty to making false statements to Customs officials. He also faces a fine. B4
 
OBITUARIES B12
 
BUSINESS DAY D1-17
 
Beef Restriction Is Rejected
A panel of the World Trade Organization ruled that the European Union's ban on hormone-treated beef is illegal because it has no scientific justification, American officials said. The ban applies equally to European and non-European farmers, but in practice bars American beef from the European market because American farmers routinely use five hormones to make cattle grow faster and produce more milk. A1
 
Greenspan Defends Rate Rise
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, aggressively defended the central bank's decision six weeks ago to raise interest rates. He said that if the Fed had waited for clear signs of inflation before acting, it would have been too late. D1
 
Cutbacks at US Airways
US Airways said it would end jet service to nine cities, close some unneeded operations, ground 22 planes and lay off some pilots. The airline had warned its workers that it would have to start shrinking if it couldn't cut its labor costs. But officials said these cuts were needed anyway. D1
 
Business Digest D1
 
SPORTS B13-24
 
Bird to Coach Pacers
Larry Bird will return to his native Indiana to coach the Pacers, N.B.A. executives said. Bird had been an adviser to the Boston Celtics since retiring in 1992, but chose to leave when Boston hired Rick Pitino as its new coach. B13
 
WEEKEND C1-36
 
An Updating for Art Fair
The annual International Fine Art Fair opens today in New York, with a chronological frame that has been pushed well beyond Old Master terrain; one work making an appearance dates only from 1945. C34

PUB-DATE: May 9, 1997,

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 1253 words

HEADLINE: GIULIANI'S BUDGET PLAN: THE OVERVIEW;
GIULIANI PROPOSES A RISE IN SPENDING IN HIS NEW BUDGET

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
With New York City benefiting from the boom on Wall Street, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani proposed a $33.5 billion election-year budget yesterday that, for the first time in his tenure, calls for an increase in spending and in the size of the municipal work force. Much of the new money would go to education and other services for children.
Mr. Giuliani said the rebounding local economy was generating new tax revenues that helped him shape a budget that was less austere than those earlier in his term. He detailed his plan in a presentation at City Hall that gave a glimpse of many of the themes that he is expected to stress in his re-election campaign. 
 "We have changed the direction of the city," he declared, maintaining that his fiscal management had contributed to the economic recovery. Later, he added, "Remember where we were three and a half years ago, and take a look at where we are now."
He proposed that the city increase its spending by roughly 2 to 3 percent -- or $700 million to $1 billion -- and called for $284 million in new tax cuts, including the elimination of the city's 4 percent sales tax on clothing under $500.
The Republican Mayor also relaxed his effort to trim the municipal bureaucracy, which had been a hallmark of his agenda. After cutting the work force by nearly 23,000 people in his first three years in office, he proposed an increase of 2,644 employees, to 202,730, mostly because of hiring at the Board of Education and the Administration for Children's Services.
Mr. Giuliani has vowed to overhaul and increase financing for both of those agencies, seeking to demonstrate that he is a champion of the city's children.
He proposed spending more than $170 million on new programs for the Board of Education from the city's operating budget, and close to $1 billion over the next few years from the separate capital budget to buy computers, renovate schools and build temporary classrooms.
The capital spending would help create space for 40,000 students, which would lessen, though not solve, chronic overcrowding in the school system. For the last few years, the school population has grown at a rate of about 20,000 students a year, many of them immigrants.
Education is certain to be one of the most contentious topics during the mayoral campaign, and yesterday, Mr. Giuliani's Democratic rivals trained much of their criticism of his budget on this area.
They asserted that he had ignored the public schools throughout his tenure and had repeatedly cut projected spending at the Board of Education, adding that the new programs could not make up for his past neglect.
The Mayor contends that he did not feel confident enough in the leadership of the school system to devote more resources to it, but now that Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew is in charge, he is more willing to raise school aid.
In presenting his plan, Mr. Giuliani said the surplus from the current fiscal year, which ends on June 30, is projected to be $856 million, a record amount caused largely by higher-than-expected tax revenues from robust profits on Wall Street. He said for the first time that he wanted to use $99 million of that money to help the city adapt to the new strict Federal welfare rules by paying for child care, job training and other programs.
Yet, even as he was proposing how to handle the surplus and promoting an array of tax cuts, the Mayor was also calling for $660 million in new spending cuts, spread across most city agencies. Mr. Giuliani said the cuts were needed to help close a projected budget deficit for the next fiscal year of more than $1 billion.
He could have allocated all of the surplus to forestall the spending cuts, but instead he chose to use the surplus money to make up for revenue lost from the proposed tax cuts and to pay off some of the city's growing long-term debt.
And beyond the 1998 fiscal year, the city still must grapple with projected budget deficits in the next four years that climb to more than $3 billion annually by 2001. Some independent budget experts, in fact, said the Mayor should have allocated all of the surplus to close those projected shortfalls.
Most of the proposals that Mr. Giuliani announced were first disclosed in his preliminary budget, which he issued in January, so he used much of the presentation yesterday to look back on his tenure.
As a result, he often sounded as if he were making a campaign stump speech, filled with references to initiatives from his administration that he said had bettered the lives of city residents. He spoke of tax cuts that he had pushed and new ones that he was proposing, the declining welfare caseloads and the growth in private-sector jobs.
Mr. Giuliani's predecessors did not usually highlight the city's murder rate at the annual briefing on the budget, but yesterday that, too, was a focus. "I couldn't do a budget presentation without showing you how crime is going down in the city," he quipped as he pointed to a chart.
Part of the speech was devoted to an unusual attack on the way that the state has historically treated the city. Mr. Giuliani said the city deserved more state aid, and he said he would try to pressure Gov. George E. Pataki and the Legislature to insure that when the state divides its surplus, the city gets its fair share.
The state wields great power over the city's finances, and approval from Albany is required for nearly all of the Mayor's tax reduction plans before they can become law. What's more, Mr. Giuliani wants $47 million in new state aid -- jumping to more than $700 million in 2001 -- to make up for lost revenue from some of the cuts.
Technically, the $33.5 billion budget reduces spending by $500 million compared with the current fiscal year because of an accounting maneuver.
It works like this: the city now has an $856 million surplus, but accounting rules require City Hall to spend the money in the current fiscal year.
The Mayor, though, wants to use the money in the next fiscal year. So he is paying for some of next year's expenses this year. In other words, he is prepaying an anticipated expense.
That artificially inflates spending for the 1997 fiscal year, and deflates it for the 1998 fiscal year. Therefore, in reality, Mr. Giuliani is proposing a spending increase of 2 to 3 percent for 1998, administration officials and independent budget experts said.
In his first three budgets, Mr. Giuliani proposed reducing city spending, both technically and in reality.
But after negotiations with the City Council, he agreed to restore funds to some programs, and is likely to do so again this year. The Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, a Queens Democrat, said he was generally pleased with the budget, particularly the proposals for tax reductions, though he said he would fight some of the spending cuts.
"That, obviously, is something that is a concern for all of us," Mr. Vallone said.
The Democrats running for mayor, though, were more critical. "There is no structural change in the funding of education, no real commitment to the future of New York," said one candidate, Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President.
Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, who is also running for mayor, said Mr. Giuliani had done little to cure the city's long-term budget problems, noting that the future projected deficits remained large.
"This is not moving us toward structural balance," Ms. Messinger said. "And he has been talking about that for four years."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani presented a new budget that calls for a slight increase in spending. (John Sotomayor/The New York Times)(pg. A1)
 
Chart: "Budget Highlights"
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's proposed $33.5 billion budget would raise total city spending by 2 to 3 percent. But it also includes an array of spending cuts totaling $660 million, which are spread among most city agencies. The budget features $284 million in tax cuts. Here are some details:
 
USING THE SURPLUS
The Mayor's plan would use a projected $856 million surplus for the current fiscal year for three purposes:
 
43 percent to reduce the city's long-term debt.
39 percent for new programs.
18 percent to make up revenue lost to proposed tax cuts.
 
NEW SPENDING
$125 million to improve reading scores.
$99 million for child care, job training and programs to help the city respond to new Federal welfare rules.
$25 million for arts education.
 
SPENDING REDUCTIONS
$114 million cut in the Health and Hospitals Corporation.
$15 million cut in the Department of Cultural Affairs.

HEADLINE: GIULIANI'S BUDGET PLAN: SERVICES;
More Money for Schools and Child Welfare and Less for Police

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG 

 BODY:
After shearing more than $1 billion from the Board of Education's projected spending in the first two years of his administration, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani yesterday proposed increasing the board's budget next year. He wants to add $172 million for new programs, and nearly $1 billion over several years for new classrooms and computers.
The Mayor did not explain his reasoning yesterday, but he has done so many times in the last eight months, in announcing many of the plans that he bundled together yesterday in his proposed budget for the coming fiscal year, which begins on July 1. The reason is his confidence in Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew. 
 Whatever Dr. Crew's influence, critics have been quick to note that this is a mayoral election year, and they contend that the Mayor has been responding to polls showing that voters give him low marks for his handling of education issues.
Since schools opened in September, the Mayor has repeatedly referred to his intention to add money to the board's budget. The Mayor said yesterday that he wanted $125 million to go to a reading program for elementary school students and $25 million to restore some arts programs, and he said he would provide $22.7 million for technical support and staff development as more classrooms are equipped with computers.
Mr. Giuliani estimated that the budget would ultimately grow by 0.7 percent over the current fiscal year, to $8.3 billion next year. School enrollment, however, is expected to grow by 1.4 percent, or 15,000 students, to 1.09 million.
The proposed increases in capital spending are far more drastic. The Mayor has proposed spending $500 million to create thousands of new classrooms. The Mayor and the City Council have also agreed to spend $275 million to refurbish aging school buildings and $150 million on computers and wiring.
The Mayor's proposed spending drew praise from the Chancellor, but his operating budget drew criticism from the city teachers' union and parents' groups. Sandra Feldman, the president of the United Federation of Teachers, called the new programs "mostly one-shots that sound suspiciously like election-year promises."
And John Fager, the executive director of the Parents' Coalition, a citywide group, accused the Mayor of "micromanaging" the school system, and argued that school administrators, teachers and parents should decide how the money is spent.
 
Social Services
Advocates for the poor found nuggets of hope yesterday in Mayor Giuliani's proposed social services budget. While they said there was not nearly enough money for day care, there were 93 new positions for the child welfare agency, $75.9 million to support elderly and disabled immigrants expected to lose their Federal cash benefits and $900,000 to help finance a telephone line for public assistance recipients bewildered by changes in the Federal welfare law.
But to finance these initiatives, among others, Mr. Giuliani is relying, in part, on several assumptions.
He expects, for instance, that a state proposal will save the city $77 million by decreasing the amount of money the city must contribute toward public assistance for single parents with children. But the proposal has yet to be voted on by the State Legislature.
Mr. Giuliani also fails to include the potential costs of developing and running a new voucher program proposed by Mr. Pataki. The plan would replace the state's cash-assistance program for single adults and would offer the poor vouchers for food, shelter and clothing.
And in totaling the dollar figure needed for the city's legal immigrants, the Mayor is also hoping that the Federal Government will pay for many of them.
Under Mr. Giuliani's plan, the Administration for Children's Services, the child welfare agency created last year, would get $492.1 million in city money, $145.6 million more than was first forecast. Most of the increase is from the budget of the city's day-care agency, which was integrated into the children's agency.
But city financing for the Human Resources Administration would decline. Mr. Giuliani said he planned to spend $3.059 billion in 1998, a $587 million decrease from 1996. About 21 percent of that was the day-care budget that moved to the new children's services agency.
Already, day care seems to lack the necessary money. Mr. Giuliani plans to spend $4.4 million for 8,700 more day care slots in 1998 and $13.3 million in 1999 for 13,000 more children.
The city now helps pay for day care for about 75,000 children.
But the city estimates that about 15,000 single parents will enter the workfare and work-related programs in 1998, and many will need child care.
 
Police
The Police Department, long a sacred cow, will have less in 1998. The proposed budget has $89 million less than the last fiscal year, bringing the operating budget to $2.399 billion. When anticipated Federal money and private grants are included, officials said, the department faces a $29 million cut from last year.
Police Commissioner Howard Safir said there would be savings from such efficiencies as expanding new technologies, speeding arrests and cutting overtime. He also plans cheaper paint jobs and decals for police cars. The police also plan to stop patrolling the five city-owned tow pounds, and to award a contract to a private security company.
"We are not skimping in any way with officers on the street or operational equipment," Mr. Safir said.
In some areas, spending will go up: $1.3 million for the Intelligence Division, which will maintain an up-to-date crime data base and share information with state and Federal law enforcement agencies. And the police will open a new crime laboratory in January 1998.
 
Sanitation
The city's on-again, off-again recycling program appears to be on again, but not at levels desired by some private environmental groups.
The proposal noted that "the frequency of residential waste collection services has not been reduced," but critics of the administration said that this simply leaves the collection schedule almost everywhere in the city at every other week -- leaving residents to deal with 14-day accumulations of newspapers and other recyclable material.
In the 1998 fiscal year, programs for collecting metal and mixed paper like junk mail are scheduled to be expanded to the last boroughs without them: Brooklyn and Queens.
The budget calls for the first significant expenses related to closing the Fresh Kills Landfill in 2001. The city will begin sending some residential garbage, from the Bronx, to disposal sites outside city limits.
 
Cultural Affairs
For the second year in a row, the 33 city-owned cultural institutions financed by the Department of Cultural Affairs are facing a large cut.
Mayor Giuliani's budget for the 1997-98 fiscal year calls for aid to the department to be cut by $15 million, to $79.5 million. Of that, $63.8 million would be allocated to the 33 institutions, a 15 percent decrease from last year. Those that focus on children's programs would face smaller cuts than most others. The news came as a surprise and a disappointment to the Cultural Institutions Group, an informal organization of the 33 groups.
"There have been these two years of real cuts, but because of inflation we never recovered from the cuts in 1990," said Rochelle Slovin, the director of the American Museum of the Moving Image. The group plans to lobby for a restoration to the 1990 level, she said. "This Mayor really is a mayor who completely understands cultural life and cultural institutions," she said, "So it's very disappointing."

HEADLINE: A Budget Fit for Fantasyland

 BODY:

To the Editor:
While a balanced budget for the year 2002 has been created with fairy dust, our President and Congress expect us to be elated (front page, May 3).
Kudos to you for bringing us back to reality by noting in your news analysis that the 2002 forecast assumes a longer recovery than the nation has ever experienced -- and that even a small, unexpected economic slowdown could spell disaster for budget balancing. 
 Using Congressional Budget Office data, I calculate that a downturn similar in magnitude to the United States' two most recent recessions would generate a deficit of between $100 billion and $150 billion in 2002.
The budget spectacle is entertaining, to be sure. But Washington should leave the fantasy worlds to Disney.
 
CHARLES J. WHALEN
Ithaca, N.Y., May 6, 1997
 
The writer is a senior economist at the Institute for Industry Studies, Cornell University.

HEADLINE: Madrid Journal;
If Puppets Step Offscreen, They'll Get Torn Apart

BYLINE: By MARLISE SIMONS 

DATELINE: MADRID

 BODY:
It is rehearsal time for Spain's most irreverent television show and, in one studio, 10 bullfighters are lining up to debate the state of the nation. The toreros are on two rival teams, representing the country's two main political parties.
On another set, Bill Clinton is taken off the shelf and dressed in a gray business suit and baseball cap to get ready for action. For a third skit, the Prime Minister's wife gets a black party dress and heavy jewelry because she is preparing to go to Washington. 
 These characters will be part of "The Puppet News," which through cheerful caricature and burlesque has become the most talked about program in Spain. Using latex puppets, the show, which is on five nights a week, pokes fun at local politicians, sports heroes, journalists and foreign figures, including Pope John Paul II and Woody Allen.
Its favorite targets are the austere Prime Minister, Jose Maria Aznar, and his chief opponent, former Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez, the voluble Socialist leader.
Many viewers believe that the puppets, which first appeared 18 months ago, are lightening up Spain's vengeful political scene, where old ideological battles of left and right and personal rivalries are fought out with unrelenting passion. But now the puppets themselves are under attack. It appears that they have been bruising a number of official toes.
Two leaders of the governing Popular Party have recently complained that their conservative group is being singled out for abuse. The party's secretary general, Angel Acebes, said darkly in April that "the worst part is that the program is made for purposes other than humor," serving rather to promote "certain political opinions."
Then, in a scene that has reminded some of a famous episode in which Don Quixote draws his sword and smashes the puppets he takes for real people, the conservative newspaper ABC struck out against the puppet program with an attack that covered its entire front page.
In an editorial ABC said the show was an example of Socialist propaganda, in which all right-wing politicians are depicted as "fools and illiterates." The time has come, the editorial said, to respond with "counter-puppets" that are "objective."
Channel Plus, the commercial network that broadcasts "The Puppet News," denies it is biased.
"We try to treat the daily headlines with humor," said Rafael Garcia Mediano, the station's programing director. "It's meant to be a news program, and Aznar and his Cabinet by definition are more in the limelight. Felipe Gonzalez is now of less interest and, of course, former Socialist ministers are not news."
A recent opinion poll found that viewers saw no prejudice. In fact, Mr. Garcia Mediano said, some viewers said they found several of the characters more lovable and charming as puppets than as people. "We want to be affectionate rather than cruel, and this translates into public affection for the show," he said.
Still, the puppet-masters have welcomed the publicity generated by the recent attacks because, in April, they lifted the puppets' ratings to a peak of almost half a million viewers.
Critics of the Aznar Government see the controversy as further evidence of its sensitivity to criticism and lack of confidence. Some see this reaction as part of the growing pains of Spain's relatively young democracy, where, after almost four decades of dictatorship, politicians are still unaccustomed to the seesaw of power and the barbs of a free press.
Several Cabinet ministers were quick to say they found it amusing. Among them was Finance Minister Rodrigo Rato, who has been much in the news of late, praising Spain's economic upturn, the declining inflation and a continuing privatization program. The other night his rubber version appeared with an "economic package," a box that opened and let out only thick smoke. Anyone buying this package, the Rato puppet said, would get a special gift. The gift was a cuckoo clock with Mr. Aznar popping out.
For all the ado, the show's satire is less caustic than that of Les Guignols in France and "Spitting Image" in Britain, both of which served as inspiration. While "Spitting Image" used the British royal family as a mainstay, the Spanish show does not even have a puppet of King Juan Carlos among its 45 characters.
"Well, the King does not generate much news," said Antonio Martinez, one of the show's two writers.
Mr. Gonzalez has been getting off easier since leaving office, although an aide recalled some "wicked" skits in which the leader appeared as a glib Mafia boss plotting to liquidate a close associate or posturing in a Superman costume.
Jordi Pujol, the Catalan nationalist leader and power broker, appears regularly. Because the Aznar Government does not have a parliamentary majority, it negotiated a shaky pact with the Catalans. In one skit, Mr. Pujol appeared as circus ringmaster, ordering people to jump through hoops and to perform astonishing tricks. In another that caused great hilarity, he and Mr. Aznar were locked in a deep, long kiss.
The butt of many jokes is no doubt Mr. Aznar, whose thick-witted puppet obsessively repeats the phrase "Spain is doing well." On a recent night before Mr. Aznar left for Washington, the show had the Prime Minister practicing for his meeting with President Clinton. He started off by telling a children's joke. As his wife shrieked in horror, Mr. Aznar explained that his script told him to use a little humor to break the ice.
Such is the show's impact that some of its signature language has caught on. For example, the puppet-anchorman often repeats words and syllables as in "Catalan, talan" and "buenas noches, noches," which have crept into daily conversations.
It is said that even Mr. Aznar's children now say, before going to bed, "Buenas noches, noches, Papa."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Spain's Prime Minister, Jose Maria Aznar, is the butt of many jokes on "The Puppet News," the country's most irreverent television show. In this skit the puppet of Mr. Aznar appears with that of his wife, Ana Botella. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Observer;
News From America

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER 

 BODY:
The mail brings a sad letter from an angry man who wants to know how he can join one of those agin-the-government outfits whose members thirst for war with Uncle Sam.
Until now he has never understood how any American -- surely the most privileged species on earth, except for their lousy health-care system -- could hate the government enough to appear in public wearing a camouflage suit. 
 Now he knows. A few weeks ago he mailed his state income tax forms and tax payment to the collector right on deadline. Last week the envelope, unopened, was returned by the post office.
The message read, "Insufficient Postage." He was short by 23 cents.
The prospect of paying a late-filing fine because some postal functionary thought it wiser to collect 23 cents than to speed a large sum of money to the state capital -- well, he is fit to be tied. Even to walk around town in camouflage.
A Manhattan woman sounds almost as overwrought about those water towers that sit on top of high buildings all over town. She hears that these distinctive features of the skyline are going to be covered with advertisements.
This woman has apparently missed the news about the comeback of laissez-faire economics all over the land, and all over the sky too. She resents having everything in New York turned into advertising and wants me to stop it.
My first impulse is to advise her to join one of those agin-the-government outfits and start walking around Manhattan in a camouflage suit. But it is not the government, the accursed government with its rubber "Insufficient Postage" stamps, that puts ads in the clouds. It is American business obeying the commands of a free market.
Business is acting in obedience to the commands of the free market. Should one suit up in camouflage to scare the free market, without which America would not be incomparably superb, except for its lousy health-care system?
My advice, Madam, is to stop grousing, thank Heaven for a free market and start doing something that will keep the Dow Jones flying.
Fighting preservation, for instance. Found a Desecration Society. Imagine all four faces of the Washington Monument covered, ground to peak, with ads; the Capitol Dome ringed with neon of many colors urging the purchase of beer, automobiles, anti-perspirants, toothpaste.
Across the White House I see an ever-changing assortment of house ads flashing in electric lights: "For the very best in camouflage suits, call the Pentagon"; "Why take the chance of having your tax return sent back for Insufficient Postage? Buy another 23-cent stamp and feel safe," et cetera.
Here is a Washington woman writing to ask what the world is coming to when a country's health-care system is so lousy that a person can't even go to the dentist anymore without getting a mouth full of Krazy Glue.
She is referring to the man in Silver Spring, Md., who was directed to a woman dentist famous for charging low prices. When the patient complained about a tooth that felt too big for his mouth, the dentist extracted it, filed it down for a more comfortable fit, then cemented it back in his jaw with Krazy Glue.
The patient's dissatisfaction brought government's usual trouble-making officials into action, and when last observed by The Washington Post the dentist had been hauled in for practicing dentistry without a license, among other things.
The burden of this woman's complaint seems to be that any country with a half-decent health-care system would provide people suffering from ill-fitting teeth with competent dentistry, thus eliminating the danger of ending up with your tongue glued to your back molars.
I have spent several days agonizing about what advice to give this woman. On one hand, I am tempted to tell her to start wearing a camouflage suit and picketing the Capitol with a sign saying, "Fix our lousy health-care system, you clods."
Other times I am tempted to advise her to quit whining and get down on her knees to show she is grateful for a free-market system that encourages even the unskilled to succeed through imagination, daring and Krazy Glue. Even if the health-care system really is lousy.

HEADLINE: Bond Rally and Dollar Drop Send Market Indexes Higher

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks ended the week higher, as a rally yesterday in bonds lifted bank shares and a sharp drop in the dollar bolstered exporters.
The Dow Jones industrial average gained 32.91 points, to 7,169.53, and was up 1.4 percent for the week. The Dow swung in a 100-point range on the day, rising 59 points early and sinking about 40 points around noon before recovering. 
 Caterpillar Inc. led the Dow higher, while Nationsbank led regional banks, the top-performing industry group in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.
The Standard & Poor's 500 index jumped 4.52, to 824.78, a one-week gain of 1.5 percent. The Nasdaq composite index rose 4.22, to 1,335.05, and 2.3 percent on the week.
Stocks and bonds rose early yesterday after investors interpreted comments made Thursday night by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, to mean that the Fed would leave interest rates unchanged at its next policy meeting on May 20.
Still, some investors were not convinced that Mr. Greenspan had tipped his hand.
"His comments were pretty innocuous," said Gene Grandone, director of investment counseling at Northern Investment Counselors, which oversees $7 billion. "It sounds like a 50-50 chance" the Fed would raise rates, Mr. Grandone said. Either way, the instability in stock prices "is symptomatic of a market that's reached a high valuation relative to profits," he said.
The dollar, meanwhile, suffered its biggest one-day fall against the yen yesterday since September 1995, dropping to 120.35 yen.
A declining dollar "would help the earnings of a company like Caterpillar that does a lot of exporting, particularly to Japan," said Robert Brody, who runs the American Growth fund, with $100 million in assets.
Caterpillar, which makes about half its sales outside the United States, rose 2 3/8, to 96 5/8.
Financial stocks were helped by the decline in interest rates and by optimism that the Fed would leave rates unchanged. Nationsbank climbed 1, to 60 1/4, while First Union rose 1 1/2, to 85 5/8. Citicorp rose 2, to 117, and Chase Manhattan gained 2, to 97 7/8.
Cephalon Inc. shares plunged 7, to 13, after its drug for treating Lou Gehrig's disease failed to win the backing of a Food and Drug Administration advisory panel. Chiron, a research partner, fell 7/8, to 19 1/8.
Premier Laser Systems, a maker of dental lasers that remove tooth decay and prepare teeth for fillings, jumped for a third day after the F.D.A. approved its treatment for use. Shares rose 3, to 14, and were the second-most active in trading.
McDonald's slid 1 1/8, to 53 1/8, after the world's largest restaurant chain said a new low-priced menu doubled sales of its Big Mac, though only "incremental" profit gains were expected.
Chrysler workers ended a four-week walkout at a Detroit engine plant, pushing shares up 3/4, to 31 1/4. Auto makers are seen as beneficiaries of a weaker dollar, because their cars would cost less compared with Japanese rivals. Ford Motor rose 1, to 36 5/8, and General Motors rose 1 1/8, to 57 7/8.
American depository receipts of Lucas Varity P.L.C. rose 3/4, to 31 5/8, after Goldman, Sachs & Company added the stock to its recommend list. Each A.D.R. represents 10 shares of the British car parts maker.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 33; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1188 words

HEADLINE: Dollar Plunges Against Yen In Big Setback

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The dollar plunged yesterday against the Japanese yen, ending the week with a 5 percent loss in value, its biggest setback to date in its rally from a record low just over two years ago.
The decline of the American currency against the yen also sapped its strength against the German mark and other European currencies. For the week the dollar was off 2.5 percent against the mark. 
 The immediate cause of the fall against the yen was comments from Japanese officials who hinted that the Government was ready to intervene in the markets to bring down the value of the dollar.
These comments had special resonance because of the agreement in February between the United States and its key industrial allies that the dollar had strengthened enough from the record lows it reached against the yen and mark in April 1995. That accord was affirmed last month when representatives of the Group of Seven countries -- the United States, Japan, Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada -- met again in Washington.
If the dollar's slide continues, especially against the yen, it could help American automobile manufacturers, which have seen their Japanese competitors cut into American market share this year, when the stronger dollar made their prices more competitive. In April, the Big Three's share of American sales dropped 2.1 percentage points, to 73.3 percent.
Conversely, a weaker dollar would make imports more expensive, adding to inflationary pressure here. And American tourists expecting bargains overseas this summer would be disappointed.
But whether this week's decline represents an end to the dollar's two-year climb, which lifted it 58 percent against the yen and 28 percent against the mark, is open to debate. Analysts are split over the yen, with some arguing that the dollar may have reached its peak. But they agreed that the dollar could rebound against the mark.
There has not been a dollar plunge like this since the end of May 1995, when the dollar was just above its record lows against the yen and the mark. The 5 percent drop of the dollar against the yen is the biggest weekly decline in the 1990's.
The dollar settled in New York at 120.35 yen yesterday, off 2.8 percent for the day, and it is now weaker than it was in February, when the United States and the other nations first indicated it was too strong. While not back to its February level against the mark, the dollar is at its weakest since early April. It settled at 1.6869 yesterday, down 1.3 percent on the day.
If the dollar has indeed reached its top against the yen and retreated, then it will mean that the United States and its allies have been able to brake the dollar's rise without having to intervene in currency markets.
In an appearance on CNBC before a meeting of the Business Council in Williamsburg, Va., yesterday, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin would not comment on the dollar's plunge, saying only that the Administration's policy "has been right."
But some analysts make the case that the dollar will rebound against the yen and the mark on its own. They point out that the American economy is growing faster than either Japan's or Germany's and that some expect the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates again to slow American growth. Interest rate increases in Europe or Japan, if there are any, are not expected until much later in the year, and they presumably would not be big enough to dent the dollar's strength.
This means that "the interest rate differentials will shift in the favor of the dollar in the near term," said Kermit Schoenholtz, the chief economist at Salomon Brothers in London. And the higher rates here should keep the dollar attractive.
"If you characterize the economy as growing at a challenging pace that will force the Fed to raise interest rates, then it is unlikely that the dollar has seen its highs for the year," added John Lipsky, chief economist at the Chase Manhattan Bank.
Mr. Lipsky also said the flow of investment from Japan to the United States was still strong, providing another support for the dollar.
But Jim O'Neill, the chief currency economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company in London, disagreed. "It's very tricky," he said of the outlook, but "there is a pretty strong case to make that the dollar has reached its high against the yen."
His argument is threefold. One, Goldman, Sachs is now forecasting that Japan's trade surplus with the United States is going to grow much faster than expected, meaning that Japanese companies will have more dollars to exchange into yen, which will push the American currency lower. Goldman just raised its estimate of Japan's current account surplus for the fiscal year that began April 1 to 1.8 percent of Japan's gross domestic product from 1.3 percent.
His second argument is that currency traders are "starting to think that the Bank of Japan will tighten this year." He said that the speculation had gotten so intense that there was a rumor yesterday that the Bank of Japan would raise official interest rates this weekend.
Last, Mr. O'Neill argues that the United States and its chief industrial allies still want to rein in the dollar, a goal that was re-emphasized in the statement issued after the April meeting of the Group of Seven.
That statement emphasized concern that a strong dollar could lead to a surge in Japan's trade surplus with the United States. A big surplus has led to dollar weakness and Japan bashing in the past.
But Mr. O'Neill predicts the dollar will rally against the mark, both because the interest rate and economic growth differentials favoring the dollar should remain intact and because the uncertainty about the European move to a single currency is still lifting the dollar.
A combination of events caused the dollar's slide this week, with the fall against the yen infecting the dollar generally. Before this decline, over the last 12 months the dollar had risen 21 percent against the yen to a four-year high of 127.10 on April 30 and almost 14 percent against the mark to 1.7329 on May 5.
A rally in the Japanese stock market pushed the dollar lower on Tuesday as did a sharp rise in Japanese interest rates as the bond market fell. Comments by Japanese officials then accelerated the dollar's tumble. First, the director general of the Ministry of Finance's International Finance Bureau suggested that the dollar could fall as low as 103 yen.
Then the Finance Minister, Hiroshi Mitsuzuka, suggested that the Bank of Japan might intervene to support the yen by selling dollars. This threat, when the dollar was already declining, carried extra weight.
Finally, there appeared to be selling because many traders interpreted a speech on Thursday night by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Fed, to mean that the central bank would not raise interest rates at its next policy-making meeting, May 20.
That interpretation is open to debate, and, in any case, analysts who see the dollar rebounding expect the economy's strength to force the Fed to raise its short-term interest rate target later this year, even if it does not move on May 20.

HEADLINE: Less of a Grinch: Some Softening For the Image Of Greenspan

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 9

 BODY:
In nearly 10 years as chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan has developed a reputation as the Grinch, an economic killjoy railing against "irrational exuberance," willing to sacrifice jobs and the nation's full growth potential to spare Wall Street millionaires from the merest whiff of inflation.
Mr. Greenspan's image has been softened only slightly by the widespread acknowledgment that his quest for price stability has provided the foundation for more than six years of steady expansion and a current unemployment rate of 4.9 percent, the lowest in 23 years. 
 But now economists and other students of the central bank are starting to offer a revisionist view of Mr. Greenspan, one that paints him as far more flexible in his approach to fighting inflation than his reputation -- and his own public statements over the years -- may suggest.
Over the last year in particular, Mr. Greenspan has prodded the Fed to consider whether sweeping changes like the huge investments by businesses in technology might have given the economy greater capacity for noninflationary growth than conventional theories might hold. And as growth surged, ebbed and surged again over the last year, he held off against considerable pressure from colleagues within the Fed to raise rates earlier and more sharply than the Fed ultimately did when it increased rates a quarter of a point, to 5.5 percent, on March 25.
"The image of Alan Greenspan as a chairman who cares only about beating down inflation no matter what the cost in terms of growth and employment is wildly at variance with the actions of the Federal Reserve under his leadership," said Alan S. Blinder, a former Fed vice chairman who is now an economics professor at Princeton University.
No one is arguing that Mr. Greenspan has gone soft on inflation, and the long series of rate increases he engineered in 1994 and early 1995 are evidence of his willingness to take unpopular action to squelch any threat from rising prices. Indeed, Mr. Greenspan can probably afford to be open minded about the nation's capacity to grow without inflation only because he has built such inflation-fighting credibility in the financial markets.
And the limits of Mr. Greenspan's pragmatic approach may be disclosed on May 20, when the central bank must decide whether growth remains so strong that it justifies another rate increase, even though, as Mr. Greenspan himself put it in a speech on Thursday night, "There is scant evidence of any imminent resurgence of inflation."
But some economists consider it a telling sign of Mr. Greenspan's pragmatism that the Fed would even be debating whether another rate increase is necessary, given that unemployment is so low and that growth was 5.6 percent in the first quarter and 3.8 percent in the preceding quarter, well above what most economists see as the economy's "speed limit" of around 2.25 percent.
"He's not a monetary theoretician, he's a detail man, and that's what makes him open to this kind of shift," said David Jones, chief economist at Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, an investment firm. "My sense is that he's willing to continue this experiment and perhaps be more moderate in any tightening steps he takes and to spread them over a longer period of time."
As he has surveyed the economy over the last few years, Mr. Greenspan has expressed doubts about the widely held notion that there is a fixed rate of employment below which inflation will inevitably begin rising. He has asked whether official statistics might be understating improvements in productivity, a critical component in measuring the economy's capacity to grow without igniting inflation. And he has frequently argued that the primary inflation gauge, the Consumer Price Index, significantly overstates increases in the cost of living, meaning that price pressures could be even more quiescent than they appear.
"Greenspan to his credit is trying to deal with a world that may have changed," said Mickey D. Levy, the chief economist at Nationsbank Capital Markets in New York.
Even Mr. Greenspan's well-known unwillingness to speak in plain English is giving way to new clarity. Although Mr. Greenspan still hedges his bets in publicly assessing the likelihood of interest rate changes, he has responded to Congressional criticism that the Fed is too secretive by more frequently laying out in relatively unambiguous terms his view of the economy and his rationale for policy shifts.
One constant theme in Mr. Greenspan's thinking has been how to explain the low growth in productivity -- output per hour of work -- in light of the huge investments that companies have made in computers and other technology to make themselves more efficient. Although economists have measured significant improvements in manufacturing productivity, there has been no corresponding improvement in service-sector productivity, at least in macro-economic statistics.
Yet narrower indicators of improving productivity, like a continued rise in corporate profit margins six years into the business cycle, suggest that companies are becoming more efficient, enabling them to hold down costs and therefore to avoid inflationary price increases.
"This cyclical pattern is contrary to our experience and it suggests there may be an undetected delayed bonus from technical and managerial efficiencies coming from massive advances in computer and telecommunications technology applications over the last two decades," Mr. Greenspan said in his speech on Thursday.
Although most of his colleagues on the Federal Reserve Board subscribe, to one degree or another, to the theory that there is an unemployment rate below which strong growth will inevitably ignite inflation, Mr. Greenspan has emerged as a doubter. Mr. Greenspan's position probably helped keep the Fed from tightening monetary policy last year as the unemployment rate fell steadily, analysts said.
"He's been unwavering in his pursuit of low inflation, but the research he's directed, the statements he's made and the decisions he's made have reflected understanding and flexibility about very difficult issues of potential growth and productivity and unemployment," Mr. Levy said.

HEADLINE: Once Again, A Landmark Faces a Suit To Foreclose

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
A Japanese bank filed a lawsuit today charging the owner of the Chrysler Building, one of New York's most famous landmarks, with failing to maintain its mortgage payments, and said it would try to foreclose on the property.
The suit, filed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan by Fuji Bank Ltd., charges that the building's owner, Jack Kent Cooke Inc., which also owns the Washington Redskins football team and The Los Angeles Daily News, missed about $5 million in payments for debt and service fees that were due on April 30 and May 1. 
 The Cooke company, which purchased the 77-story building and the adjacent Kent Building at 42d Street and Lexington Avenue in 1979, said in a one-paragraph statement that its Chrysler Properties subsidiary intended to "restructure its debt arrangement with Fuji Bank, notwithstanding Fuji's institution of foreclosure proceedings."
Calls to the company for elaboration were not returned. People who answered the telephone at the Chrysler Properties office in New York also declined to comment, as did a lawyer at the firm representing the bank, Shearman & Sterling. Officials at Fuji Bank could not be reached.
The lawsuit also asked the court to bar a separate foreclosure move by any other entity with an interest in the building. It named, among others, the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art, which owns the land beneath the building, and New York City and State. The lawsuit said the building's owner may owe taxes.
Officials at Cooper Union declined to comment.
Jack Kent Cooke, who was better known for his role as the Redskins' owner, died last month at the age of 84. The company's statement made no allusion to Mr. Cooke's death, but it did say that other possessions in his financial empire would not be affected by the debt restructuring.
The Chrysler Building, with its Art Deco silver spire, has been one of the city's most prominent skyscrapers since its construction in 1929. But as a commercial real estate property, its history has been far less lofty. Mr. Cooke bought the building after the previous lenders, the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company, foreclosed on the property, taking it from its previous owners, Sol Goldman and Alex DiLorenzo.
Mr. Cooke's company later refinanced the $250 million mortgage in 1987, or, as the company's statement today described it, "the height of the New York real estate market."
Many companies that refinanced commercial mortgages at that time got into trouble later, as real estate values plummeted during the recession of the late 1980's and early 90's. But foreclosures have become much less common as the city's property markets have come back and as the amount of vacant commercial space has declined.
Many Japanese banks, including Fuji, have also stumbled in the 1990's, as a recession has hit the Japanese economy and its real estate market.

HEADLINE: V.I.P.'s Aplenty Flock to Bill Gates's 'Summit'

BYLINE: By CAREY GOLDBERG 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, May 9

 BODY:
Forget Davos. Forget the Bohemian Grove Retreat. Bill Gates, the richest man in America and considered by some the most important man in the world, has put in his opening bid to become the host with the most -- the most ability to pack the most chief executives and political heavyweights into one party of his creation, that is.
The Microsoft "C.E.O. Summit," held here on Thursday and today, drew Vice President Al Gore, Steve Forbes and Reed E. Hundt, the chairman of the Federal Communications Commission, as well as more than 100 other V.I.P.'s representing 25 countries and a constellation of businesses and industries. 
 The digital-era do featured a dinner on Thursday night at Mr. Gates's futuristic mansion-in-progress on Lake Washington -- the first high-profile entertaining he has done there -- that brought a buzzing pack of maritime onlookers in boats and on Jet Skis. Guests arrived by cruise boat.
The formal purpose of the conference, Microsoft officials say, was to explore how technology is changing the world of business and to share Mr. Gates's vision of the future.
"There was a common search for just what should be the dimension of the C.E.O.'s competence in knowing enough about technology to deal with how to integrate technology into the organization," said Paul Hazen, chief executive of Wells Fargo & Company.
But in practice the conference, which was almost entirely closed to the news media, provided participants and distant observers alike a new glimpse at a subject of endless fascination: every aspect of the world according to Bill Gates.
Guests toured the offices of the Microsoft Corporation, the company that Mr. Gates co-founded in 1975 and that earned more than $2 billion in 1996. Even better, they got a rare inside look at the Gates techno-mansion, designed in many ways as the house of the future.
One guest said Mr. Gates had given a tour of his library, which includes a famous notebook of Leonardo and voluminous papers of Napoleon. The library, the guest said, is a room with a rotunda, and around the rotunda is stenciled an inscription from "The Great Gatsby." Mr. Gates's wife, Melinda, joked that the couple were such fans of F. Scott Fitzgerald that they might install a green light on the end of their dock, as in "Gatsby," the guest said.
The house, said another guest, Mr. Hazen, is so full of beautiful wood and detail that those touches seemed to upstage high-tech features like the huge video screen that took up a full wall in the dining room. Among the futuristic treats Mr. Gates has said the house will include are other giant screens, which will display changeable digitized images, and climate control that follows a guest from room to room.
In his speech to the gathering, Mr. Gates largely covered ground already set forth in his best-selling book, "The Road Ahead" (Viking, 1995). He warned that people tend to focus too much on how technology will change in two years and not enough on how it will change in ten, and he spoke of a need for companies to create systems that transmit information so quickly that they are like "digital nervous systems."
"Fulfill your wildest dreams," he told the executives in a Willy Wonka moment, declaring that computing power would continue to increase at a pace allowing them to do so.
If there was one particularly intriguing aspect to the Gates gathering, it was the guest list, which was supposed to be secret but was posted by Hotwired, the on-line offshoot of Wired magazine. The list included no one from I.B.M., for example; it included Wells Fargo but not Citibank or the Bank of America; there was Ford but no General Motors or Chrysler.
Many of the omissions or inclusions could be explained by enmities and alliances of Microsoft, but the guests did appear somewhat less comprehensively chosen than the ranks of those who attend the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, each year, or the close-knit Old Guard that goes on retreat with the Bohemian Club of San Francisco, invitees who have included Ronald Reagan and George Bush.
Technology companies were heavily represented, but it was nonetheless somewhat surprising when Vice President Gore welcomed the presence of Gen. Kenneth Minihan, the head of the National Security Agency, the supersecret Government eavesdropping service.
Mr. Gore, in his own speech to the conference, discussed how "two changes, globalization and the revolution in information technology, have combined to create a new age with an entirely new business reality."
Both he and Mr. Gates struck a powerfully positive chord: that among the effects of changing technology was a great new value placed on workers themselves, the human capital without which the technology is worthless.
"Knowledge workers," Mr. Gates said, "are not like factory equipment."

Mr. Gates answered questions from those assembled at a hotel on Thursday, then joined his guests for dinner at his futuristic mansion on Lake Washington. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Varied Reasons Found for Welfare Rolls' Drop

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 9

 BODY:
Armed with a complex mathematical model, the Council of Economic Advisers today tried to shed light on the perplexing question being asked in welfare offices across the country: why are the rolls falling so fast?
They answered with statistical precision. 
 In the view of the President's economists, 44.1 percent of the sharp decline stems from the nation's recent economic growth, and 30.9 percent comes from the variety of state welfare experiments approved during President Clinton's first four years.
The remaining 25 percent were lumped together in the economists' catch-all category: other.
For all its precision, the advisers' report essentially ratified the conventional view that the unprecedented welfare decline stems from a combination of both good times and tough laws.
The report was silent on the question of what has happened to the former recipients. Are they keeping jobs and climbing an economic ladder? Or losing benefits and falling deeper into poverty? "We have no way of knowing in the data we looked at what happened to the women who left the rolls," said Janet Yellen, the council's chairwoman.
From January 1993 to January 1996 the welfare rolls fell by 20 percent and an unprecedented 2.75 million people left the rosters of public aid. That reduction followed an equally explosive growth in the previous four years, when the welfare rolls shot up by 25 percent.
The report covers the decline that had already occurred before last year's landmark welfare law. That law, which establishes new work requirements and time limits, is still being phased in.
But in the preceding four years, the Administration had approved 43 waivers that allowed states to conduct a variety of welfare experiments. Some imposed new work rules or time limits. Others offered more generous incentives to welfare recipients who took jobs. Still others increased the financial penalties on welfare recipients who failed to seek work or training.
In attributing 31 percent of the decline of the rolls to changes in welfare policy, those were the programs the report had in mind.
Bruce Reed, the President's domestic policy adviser, pointed toward the numbers as vindication of the increasingly strict laws being enforced around the country. "I think this is further proof that welfare reform works," he said. "We see that what's behind the welfare reduction isn't just 'the economy stupid' -- it's welfare reform as well."
But Wendell Primus, a former Federal welfare official who resigned last year to protest the new Federal law, offered a different interpretation. Pointing to an appendix in the economists' report, Mr. Primus noted they had produced a range of estimates of the welfare waivers' effects -- from as little as 13 percent (in what the council said was a less sophisticated model) to as much as 31 percent (in a more sophisticated model).
In either event, he said, the economy was more important. "Other reasonable people could look at this and say the economy was the dominant factor, and downplay the waivers," he said. Mr. Primus also said that welfare recipients were being lured from the rolls by the recent expansion in wage subsidies and medical insurance, which make entry-level jobs more attractive.
Asked about the caseload reductions in a January news conference, President Clinton said: "About half of this decline comes from an improved economy, and about half of it comes from intensified efforts to move people from welfare to work."
Noting the President's words, Mr. Primus added: "When the President said it was 50-50, there are some limitations on the C.E.A.'s ability to find something different than that."

HEADLINE: Prices of Treasury Securities Gain After Greenspan Remarks

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities gained ground yesterday as some investors interpreted comments by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, as a hint that the Fed would not raise interest rates this month.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 1 7/32, to 96 23/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 6.89 percent, from 6.93 percent on Thursday, but off its early low of 6.88 percent. 
 Mr. Greenspan, in a speech at a dinner on Thursday night in Manhattan, defended the Fed's rate increase in March. He did not say whether he would push for another rate increase when the Fed policy makers next meet on May 20. Still, analysts said that Mr. Greenspan's speech suggested that the Fed saw an economic slowdown this year, which could forestall any additional rate increases.
"Although the view of an immediate rise in short-term rates is not universal, it appears that the momentum generated by the bulls clearly overpowered" those who expect the Fed to raise rates on May 20, said Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at the Banc One Investment Advisers Corporation in Columbus, Ohio.
Mr. Chan said some investors were impressed with the amount of time the Fed chairman spent justifying the previous rate increase and that they said someone on the defensive was less likely to raise rates soon.
Early gains, however, were pared, as some investors sold on the belief that the market had overreacted to Mr. Greenspan's comments.
For the week the yield is up a basis point, coming off a disappointing quarterly debt refunding by the Treasury that drove the yield up to 6.96 percent.
Jack Ablin, director of fixed income and senior fund manager at the Private Bank, Bank of Boston, said he saw the Fed chairman's comments as more aggressive and leaning toward a rate increase.
"We're still in the camp that there is a better than 50 percent chance they will tighten in May," Mr. Ablin said, "even though we see no reason they need to."
April retail sales due next Tuesday, Mr. Ablin said, are expected to show a tapering off, with the wild cards for the market obviously the inflation numbers, the Producer Price Index on Wednesday and the Consumer Price Index on Thursday.

HEADLINE: Internet Commerce Pioneer Files for Bankruptcy

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
A pioneering company in the field of Internet commerce led by Jim P. Manzi, the former chairman of the Lotus Development Corporation, filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday.
Mr. Manzi's company, Nets Inc., ran an on-line shopping mall for manufacturers selling basic industrial goods from ball bearings to glue guns. Mr. Manzi, 45, joined the company in January 1996, six months after Lotus was acquired by the International Business Machines Corporation for $3.5 billion. Mr. Manzi pocketed an estimated $78 million from the I.B.M. deal. 
 Business-to-business commerce on the Internet is expected to grow to $66 billion by 2000 from $600 million last year, estimates Forrester Research Inc. of Cambridge, Mass. But the early growth has come mainly from big companies selling directly to their industrial customers on line.
The Internet middleman role assumed by Mr. Manzi's Industry.Net service, analysts say, is developing more slowly. The company has had thousands of mostly small and medium-sized manufacturers and distributors sign onto Industry.Net. But the transaction business that was to generate most of the company's revenues has come along far more slowly than Mr. Manzi and his staff had hoped.
Nets, analysts say, made a mistake in trying to be a broad-based industrial mall rather than trying to nurture on-line business communities in a few selected fields.
"It was a mile wide and an inch deep," said Stan Dolberg, an analyst with Forrester. "To work, an on-line marketplace has to be targeted and run by people who really understand the industries they are in. Manzi didn't."
Nets is a private company that does not publicly report its financial results. Yet the company, one analyst estimated, had revenues of less than $20 million a year -- well below its once-ambitious business plan -- and losses of nearly $10 million.
Nets filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code shortly after 4 P.M. yesterday in a Federal court in Boston.
All but about 15 of the company's 200 employees in Cambridge and Pittsburgh were laid off. The remaining employees will stay to maintain the company's Industry.Net site on the World Wide Web, while Mr. Manzi tries to put together a reorganization plan and decide whether the company can be revived.
In an E-mail message to employees, Mr. Manzi portrayed the company's problems as mainly a financial pinch. "As I said on the day I made my initial investment in this company, there is a great business concept here with great potential," Mr. Manzi wrote. "However, on that first day, I also said the company needed much stronger financial support than it had received in the years prior to my joining it."
Industry.Net was founded in 1990 by Donald H. Jones, a Pittsburgh entrepreneur and lecturer at Carnegie Mellon University.
In his E-mail missive, Mr. Manzi explained that Wall Street's recent disillusion with Internet stocks meant that new venture capital money was difficult to attract. He had managed, he said, to get "substantial commitments from some long-term investors in Japan," but that was simply not enough.
Recently, Mr. Manzi added, "I alone had been funding the company for the past few weeks at a cost of some $500,000 a week."
Still, analysts say Mr. Manzi has not put a large share of his personal wealth into the company, estimating his investment at $5 million or less.
"This is still a great business idea," Mr. Manzi added, "and over the next several days we will evaluate how much of the dream we can continue to pursue."

INTERNATIONAL 3-6
 
Bosnian Federation to Get Heavy Artillery Pieces
The United States said it would provide the Bosnian Federation with 116 heavy artillery pieces. The move is meant to strengthen the Muslim-Croat Federation so American forces can withdraw from Bosnia within a year. The arms shipment would still leave the Serbs with far greater numbers of heavy guns, though the precise military balance is impossible to determine. 1
 
Iraqis May Be Deported
At least 13 Iraqis seeking political asylum in the United States have been jailed in California because they are suspected of being Iraqi spies or potential terrorists, and they may be expelled from the country. The men collaborated with the Central Intelligence Agency after the gulf war in a failed attempt to undermine Saddam Hussein. 1 
 
U.S. Envoy in Vietnam
Pete Peterson, a former prisoner of war, arrived in Hanoi to become the first United States Ambassador to Vietnam in 22 years. Mr. Peterson said he hoped that a trade agreement would be signed soon but that he would also push for the fullest possible accounting of the 2,124 Americans still listed as missing in Indochina. 1
 
Clinton Praises Costa Rica 
President Clinton stood in the rain at a rain forest to praise Costa Rica's innovative environmental practices. He said that he would lead the American delegation to a United Nations environmental summit meeting this summer in New York in an effort to raise the meeting's international profile. 6
 
Venetian Rebels Arrested
The police arrested eight Italian separatists who had raised the flag of the republic of Venice over the Campanile after storming St. Mark's Square. The separatists, wearing ski masks, bore automatic weapons and were escorted by a tractor clad in sheet metal. No shots were fired. 5
 
Mobutu Delays His Return
President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire stayed in Gabon and did not return home. Laurent Kabila, the rebel leader whose forces control more than three-quarters of the country, was reported to have agreed to another meeting with Mr. Mobutu. But in Geneva, the United Nations accused the rebels of blocking an investigation into reports that they have killed thousands of Rwandan Hutu refugees in eastern Zaire. 3
 
Israel Is Criticized
A United Nations committee in Geneva condemned Israel for using interrogation techniques the panel described as state-sanctioned torture. The committee rejected Israel's contention that physical coercion was necessary to elicit information about future terrorist acts, and it demanded that such practices "cease immediately." Israel rejected the conclusion. 6

The Council of Economic Advisers said welfare rolls were shrinking because of good economic times and tough laws.
