Dow Average Up for Week, Bolstered by Bond Rally
Stocks ended a seesaw week on the up side, as a rally in bonds lifted bank shares and a sharp drop in the dollar bolstered exporters. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average gained 32.91 points, to 7,169.53, and was up 1.4 percent for the week. The Standard & Poor's 500 index jumped 4.52, to 824.78, for a one-week gain of 1.5 percent. The Nasdaq composite index rose 4.22, to 1,335.05, and was up 2.3 percent on the week. [Page 34.]
 
Greenspan's Remarks Buoy Bonds
Prices of Treasury securities advanced as some investors took comments by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, on Thursday night to be a hint that the Fed would not raise interest rates this month. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 17/32, to 96 23/32, pushing its yield down to 6.89 percent, from 6.93 percent on Thursday. [34.]
 
Hong Kong Telecom Stake Sold
A company controlled by China's central Government, China Everbright Holdings, has bought a 7.74 percent stake in Hong Kong Telecommunications, one of the world's most sophisticated telecommunications companies and a major subsidiary of Cable and Wireless of Britain. It paid $8.6 billion (Hong Kong), or $1.11 billion (United States). [35.]
 
Questions on Budget Agreement
Was there, in fact, a budget agreement between President Clinton and Congressional Republicans on May 2, and what did it contain? Those questions have reverberated around Capitol Hill this week as one problem after another has hampered the process of translating the oral agreement into writing. It was clear that, eager for a deal, the two sides made their announcement before critical loose ends were tied up. News Analysis. [1.]
 
Sallie Mae Dissidents Cite Gains
Dissident shareholders of the Student Loan Marketing Association said that they were making gains but were still short of votes in an effort to keep Sallie Mae's focus solely on the student loan business. Under a plan approved by Congress, Sallie Mae, a Government-sponsored corporation with $47 billion in assets, will be privatized by next spring. The dissidents oppose the company's proposal to branch into other businesses like consulting, software development and insurance. [36.]
 
Judge Rejects Barney's Request
A Federal bankruptcy judge, as expected, rejected a request by Barney's Inc. to offer $10 million in breakup fees to attract a new potential bidder. The judge also said that he would appoint a mediator to oversee the bidding, possibly as early as Monday. The upscale retailer has received a $240 million bid from Dickson Concepts, a Hong Kong retailer, and a $290 million bid from Saks Holdings, which operates Saks Fifth Avenue. The Neiman Marcus Group and several other international retail concerns have also expressed interest. [35.]
 
Bill Gates in Role as Host
Bill Gates, the richest man in America, has put in his bid to become the host with the most -- the most ability to pack the most chief executives and political heavyweights into one gathering. The Microsoft "C.E.O. Summit" in Seattle included Vice President Al Gore; Steve Forbes, the former Presidential candidate, Reed E. Hundt, the F.C.C. chairman, and more than 100 V.I.P.'s from 25 countries and a constellation of businesses and industries. Microsoft's formal purpose was to explore how technology is changing the world of business and to share Mr. Gates's vision of the future. [7.]
 
Wheat Prices Rise on Lack of Rain
Grain prices rose on the Chicago Board of Trade as persistent dry weather in the western Plains threatened to reduce wheat yields needed to replenish lean inventories. Wheat for July delivery rose 4.75 cents, to $4.1375 a bushel. Soybeans also rose. On other markets, gold and platinum surged. [36.]
 
Seagate Loses in English Court
Seagate Technology said that the High Court of Justice in England had awarded Amstrad P.L.C. $93 million in a lawsuit over reportedly faulty disk drives sold by Seagate. Interest and other costs could increase the award by $60 million, resulting in a charge of a like amount to Seagate's current quarter. Seagate said it planned to appeal the decision. [35.]

HEADLINE: The Tax Pipeline to Albany: Does It Flow North or South?

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 9

 BODY:
The Mayor bitterly protested that the people of New York City, the state's great economic engine, sent more to Albany in taxes than they got back in services. The city, he said, was always shortchanged, forced to subsidize upstate regions.
The Mayor was Fernando Wood, and the year was 1861. But the speaker could just as easily have been Fiorello H. La Guardia, Edward I. Koch, David N. Dinkins or, of course, Rudolph W. Giuliani. Mr. Giuliani resurrected the debate when he presented his budget on Thursday, all but calling state leaders an upstate cabal trying to rob the city of its due. 
 But just as the Mayor's refrain is treated as conventional wisdom in the city, the opposite is an article of faith in much of the rest of the state: that New York City is as much Gomorrah as Gotham, a pit of welfare, corruption, socialism and crime, bleeding the state dry.
So, does the city get robbed of its fair share? The answer, according to several authorities, is . . . sort of. It is clear that the metropolitan area -- meaning New York City and its suburbs -- contributes far more to the state than it gets back. But whether that is true of the city alone is less clear.
A 1992 study by the Center for Governmental Research, a nonprofit group in Rochester, found that the metropolitan region sent far more money to Albany than it received in services. New York City just about breaks even, the center found, but its suburbs pay much more than they receive.
The study, which several experts said was the most recent good look at the issue, found that New York City, with 41 percent of the state's population, paid 39 percent of the state's taxes and got 39 percent of the services.
Mr. Giuliani calculates that the city contributes 45 percent of state taxes, not 39 percent.
The difference lies in how commuters are counted. How should credit be assigned for the income taxes paid by people who live in the suburbs but work in the city? The Center for Governmental Research study, like most previous studies, said commuters' taxes count where they live. Mr. Giuliani says they count where they work, so when calculating the total of tax revenue New York City sends to Albany, the Mayor factors in the state income taxes many commuters pay on salaries earned in his city.
"That is the question it all hinges on," said Abraham Lackman, finance director for the State Senate and Mr. Giuliani's first budget director. "There are other uncertainties involved, but they are much smaller." However the question is answered, he said, that answer is open to attack. Mr. Lackman, by the way, will not say which method he prefers.
Advocates for the city have long argued that suburban and rural politicians tilt things against the city, and some elements of their case are indisputable: New York City schools have 37 percent of the students, but get 34 percent of state education aid. And East River bridge and tunnel tolls, paid mostly by New York City residents, are divided between the city transit system and the suburban railroads, under a 1969 formula that favors the suburbs more with each passing year.
But other parts of the dispute are fuzzier, and some, like welfare and Medicaid, cut both ways. New York City's huge share of the welfare and Medicaid caseloads means that the state spends an enormous amount on city residents who participate in those programs. On the other hand, New York is one of the few states that requires local governments to contribute to those programs: localities in New York have to match state spending on Medicaid and welfare, which creates a huge financial burden for the city.
Mr. Giuliani has raised a number of specific grievances, including the school aid disparity. He contendsthat the city would get little of the benefit from Gov. George E. Pataki's relief plan on the property tax, and that the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, a state agency, heavily favors the suburbs. He notes that in recent years there have been budget cuts and sharp fare increases at the Transit Authority but spending increases and more modest fare rises at the commuter railroads.
The Governor said during an appearance at the New York Sheraton today that he had proposed correcting the imbalance in school aid for New York City, albeit over a period of several years. He called his proposal "a fair and balanced approach."
The 1992 study said that the relatively affluent suburbs of Nassau, Suffolk, Westchester, Rockland and Putnam Counties, with 21 percent of the state's population, paid 29 percent of the taxes and received just 16 percent of the benefits. All told, it concluded, the metropolitan region subsidized upstate New York by $3.3 billion a year.
Mr. Giuliani's argument is, if anything, stronger now than when the 1992 study was conducted. Personal income tax collections are up sharply, mostly driven by the bull market on Wall Street; the city's welfare caseload has declined steeply, at a great savings to the state, and the Pataki administration has shifted some spending, in areas like transportation, from the city to other parts of the state.
Nearly everyone who has taken a serious look at the balance of payments between the city and the state says it is difficult, at best, to define the question, much less answer it. That may be why serious attempts are rare. The Citizens Budget Commission, a nonprofit group that closely monitors the city and state budgets, last analyzed the issue in 1988, and before that, in 1969.
"It's not a straightforward task," Cindy Green, vice president of the commission and co-author of the 1988 study, said. "Any answer you get is going to be badly flawed and easily criticized."
That 1988 Citizens Budget Commission analysis, using 1985 data, found that the city came out significantly ahead in its balance of payments with Albany, but that report did not look at the suburbs.
"We don't even try to answer this question," said Dennis Tompkins, spokesman for the State Comptroller, H. Carl McCall. "Any way you look at it is right and it's wrong at the same time."
Some elements of the calculation are simply matters of judgment. State prisons provide thousands of jobs in upstate towns, a benefit to that region, but if most of the inmates come from the city, are the prisons also a service to the city? Does state support for the Long Island Rail Road count solely as aid to Nassau and Suffolk Counties, or as a benefit to the city as well?
The debate does not always address the limiting political realities. The animosity toward New York City around much of the state, and the Republicans' reliance on votes from outside the city, have always limited what the city could receive from Albany. The tug-of-war moves only very slowly, as Mayor Wood's 1861 lament attests.
Analysts say that the wealthier areas of a state inevitably subsidize the poorer ones, and that metropolitan areas -- unless they are badly depressed -- always end up supporting rural regions. New York City is unusual in having such extreme concentrations of both wealth and poverty. But it is still the primary generator of jobs and income in the state.
The Republicans who control the State Senate argue that the city does just fine, getting back in welfare and Medicaid what it might not get in transportation and education.
Ms. Green asserts that the debate itself is wrongheaded. "A region should get services based on what it needs, not because of what it puts in," she said. "New York City should get more school aid, not because of the taxes it pays, but because it gets less per student and it has more students who are low income, who do not speak English at home."

HEADLINE: The Contest Is Toe-to-Toe and Pawn-to-Pawn

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

 BODY:
After the I.B.M. computer, Deep Blue, won Game 2 against Garry Kasparov, the world chess champion told friends he had been stopped on the street by a Baptist minister who told him to buck up, that help was on the way.
"Really?" Mr. Kasparov said. "From who?" 
 "From our Lord."
"Well," Mr. Kasparov replied, "Currently He seems to be helping my opponent."
Three days later, Mr. Kasparov probably needs all the help he can get. For him, today is D-Day, and maybe for everyone else as well.
After four games -- a victory for each side followed by two grueling draws -- the score is 2-2 with two games to play, and the uncertainty about the outcome is profound. The champion has clearly been shaken and at times irritated by his opponent.
"I think he's still angry that he didn't have any of Deep Blue's games to study," said Owen Williams, Mr. Kasparov's manager. "He's got to sit there at the table figuring out how the computer thinks as the game is going on."
On the other hand, the Deep Blue side is showing great confidence, though not necessarily during the games. In fact, to watch the programmers and their chess advisers hovering over a chess board and analyzing the moves that are being made without them is more or less to witness Dr. Frankenstein at the mercy of his monster. Asked during the fourth game how Deep Blue was faring, Joel Benjamin, a grandmaster who assisted in the programming, shrugged.
"The proof of the pudding is in the eating," he said. "If we win, we'll know it played well."
Meanwhile, as the chess world waits for the decisive weekend, it is bracing for a comeuppance.
"There's a tragic sense here; it's the dying of an age," said Bruce Pandolfini, a chess teacher and the author of dozens of chess books. "Man may no longer be the king of this universe. That's clear, and this is really the last stand."
The drama is especially high because Game 5, which begins at 3 P.M. today at the Equitable Center in Manhattan, is Mr. Kasparov's best chance for a breakthrough. Not only will he have the advantage of playing White and moving first, he will also have had two days to formulate his attack. If he wins, then he will only have to draw in Sunday's final game to win the match.
Most experts, familiar with Mr. Kasparov's brilliance and his history of responding heroically to desperate straits, believe he will prevail today. But the pressure is certainly on. If he draws, then he will be staring down heavy odds on Sunday, having to win as Black against a formidable foe, a task on the order of having to break serve against Pete Sampras.
"It's completely stunning," said Yasser Seirawan, a grandmaster. "Garry needs Game Five if he's to win the match. If Deep Blue can hold him to a draw, the advantage slips into its favor."
Even if the match itself ends in a draw, Mr. Seirawan said, "that would be extraordinary."
Even those who believe Mr. Kasparov has fared well thus far sense that danger is nigh and that Deep Blue has done what few, if any men, have -- reduced the world chess champion to the stature of a mere mortal. The strength of the computer is such that it has turned Mr. Kasparov's chief advantages -- his will, his emotions, his psychological wherewithal -- against him. He has admitted it is wearing him down.
"I think Garry is dominating the match," said Ken Thompson, a computer chess expert. "He was close to winning the last two games, but he is freaked out. If he loses or draws as White, the pressure will be on him in the last round, and he may have to attack when there just aren't attacking chances. And he could lose pushing something that isn't there."
Is Mr. Kasparov really holding the human race on his shoulders? In a sense, he is. Chess players have taken to lamenting that they have been singled out for obsolescence. Already, all the classically forceful chess openings -- out to 10, 15 or even more moves -- have been programmed into Deep Blue, and a database exists that can tell a computer how to play perfectly in every possible endgame with six pieces left on the board. (That's about three billion possibilities.)
"What we're seeing is chess getting squeezed," Mr. Seirawan said, "so that more and more the original moves are all occurring in a window of opportunity called the middle game."
Anyone other than a chess player might say, so what? After all, no one thinks the computer is intelligent, at least according to the conventional definitions of intelligence, which encompasses creativity and learning from experience, things that humans use to play chess. But Deep Blue's behavior has been intelligent; that is, it has been achieving results by calculations that are similar to what a human might do by thinking.
"What we are seeing in this match is a real experiment that is illustrating the evolution of computing power," said Monty Newborn, the chairman of the chess committee for the Association for Computing, and the author of a book about the first Kasparov-Deep Blue match. "Chess has been chosen to raise the issue of whether complex problems are issues of intelligence."
The next step is to ask: If chess expertise can be replicated by a machine, what else can? If you calculate long enough, are abstractions reducible to pure numbers?
"That's a good question," Mr. Newborn said.
Indeed, many people have suggested that after chess, other fields of endeavor -- architecture? economics? (gasp) newspaper reporting? -- are sure to follow.
"Composing symphonies, for example," said Frederick Friedel, who is Mr. Kasparov's computer adviser.
Computers already compose in a rudimentary fashion, he said, "but what if you've got every single piece of music by every composer mapped out in little chunks and the computer is putting them together in different ways, and what if you couldn't tell these from the works of Beethoven or Mozart?"
Would it matter? Beautiful music is beautiful music, and people will not stop composing it because a computer can, any more than chess players are going to stop playing chess.
"The point is," said Mr. Friedel, who has a degree in philosophy, "in the future, we're going to have computers performing like the best human beings in all sorts of ways. We're going to know they're doing something incredibly primitive to achieve this result. But we're going to have to deal with it."
Dealing with it is what the Deep Blue team does in the war room, a cramped television control booth with a couple of video screens and the detritus of a never-ending lunch scattered around. During every game, the programmers, along with Mr. Benjamin and Miguel Illescas, another grandmaster, mostly spend their time trying out the moves that Deep Blue tells them it is mulling over.
The computer itself is in an adjoining room, but its thought processes are being reproduced on a screen in the corner, lines and lines of minute, coded numbers incessantly scrolling upward. The process it follows is to look ahead in the game three or four moves, analyze all the possibilities numerically, and select the one with the highest score. And though this is only an initial suggestion, it tends to send the programmers into nervous, hand-wringing action, moving pieces around the chessboard, often accompanied by head scratching and mumbling.
Meanwhile, Deep Blue has begun to look further into the game along the trees of possibility suggested by the selected move. And sometimes, the initially selected move shrinks in appeal as the search proceeds deeper. In that case, it will return to the beginning and look for a move that will yield a better result. This can take up to a few minutes, but the computer is programmed not to take more than a third of its remaining time for any one move.
So if initially, taking a Kasparov pawn with a rook yields a rating of say, 50, and that number shrinks to 27 by the time Deep Blue has examined its consequences 10 moves hence, it would try other possibilities.
(A pawn advantage for Deep Blue would register as 100, so a score of 50 would indicate Deep Blue's advantage is the equivalent of half a pawn.)
In any case, the trying of various moves and the resulting scores appearing on screen naturally heats up the human activity in the room.
"I don't like that," Mr. Illescas said, at one point, to himself. "Garry has chances." A few moments later, he reversed himself.
"We have better chances," he said.
All of this lends the match a palpable eerieness, which is perhaps most evident watching the champion himself in the match room. During each game, Mr. Kasparov has engaged in his customary brow-furrowing, chin-clenching, eyebrow-raising, jaw muscle-bunching and occasional nervous pacing that has unnerved many a human opponent.
The discombobulating element is that against Deep Blue, his fierce combativeness has no target. Across the board sits someone with a placid expression, a calmness that has to be infuriating. He is not a chess expert; he is just doing what he's told, a robot's robot.
Joe Hoane, one of the three I.B.M. researchers who have been the arms of Deep Blue in this match, said the three hours he spent sitting across from Mr. Kasparov on Tuesday gave him the first chance he had had in months to think about chess, and not computers.
"I don't play well," Mr. Hoane said, "but this was a real chance to observe the beauty of what was going on."
And how did he feel out there, not only across from the legendary champion in the champion's milieu, but, in some sense, on the frontier?
"For some reason," Mr. Hoane said, "I was terrified."

HEADLINE: Ex-Leaders of Harlem Agency Defend Development Record

BYLINE: By MATTHEW PURDY 

 BODY:
Former officials of the Harlem Urban Development Corporation, responding to criticism from the Pataki administration that their organization was rife with mismanagement and did little in 23 years, are mounting a defense of their record and have dismissed the attacks as politically motivated.
Donald J. Cogsville, the former president of the defunct Harlem corporation, which for a generation was the prime hope of redevelopment in Harlem, called the criticism from a Pataki administration official a "hostile, even careless, screed" and said he was proud of his corporation's record. 
 Mr. Cogsville was reacting to a series of audits of the Harlem corporation released 10 days ago by the Empire State Development Corporation, the state's main public development organization. The audits raised questions about financial controls in the Harlem corporation and some of the findings are now under investigation by the Manhattan District Attorney's office and by the State Commission on Investigation.
On a tour of Harlem this week, Mr. Cogsville pointed to new and renovated housing along 110th Street, rehabilitated housing along Frederick Douglass Boulevard and commercial development on 125th Street, including the Apollo Theater and Mart 125, an indoor market. He said those were among the projects his agency helped bring to fruition.
Mr. Cogsville bitterly rejected the analysis of Empire State officials that the Harlem corporation had little to show for the $100 million in state money it spent over more than two decades. He said his group's role was to help private developers with design and planning and to grant seed money.
"I never said I had a construction crew out there," Mr. Cogsville said.
The former Harlem corporation officials also said they helped to create more than 4,000 new residences and to rehabilitate an additional 2,400.
Mr. Cogsville's 12-page response was issued this week by the office of Representative Charles B. Rangel, who was the most influential member of the Harlem corporation's board before it was dissolved by the Pataki administration in 1995. The corporation was replaced by the Harlem Community Development Corporation.
Mr. Cogsville said the release of the audits by the Empire State officials was intended to "discredit the elected leadership of Harlem," particularly Mr. Rangel.
Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, dismissed Mr. Cogsville's response as "a pathetic attempt at revisionist history by a former H.U.D.C. official who is trying to claim credit for the success spearheaded by others in Harlem."
Mr. Cogsville and other former agency officials disputed the allegation by Empire State officials that 20 to 30 percent of the agency's expenditures were not properly documented and that three-quarters of the money was spent on overhead, personnel and consultants.
Although some of the annual audits of the agency revealed problems with internal financial controls within the Harlem corporation, they did not expose the extreme levels of mismanagement that the Pataki administration is now alleging.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Dry Weather in Plains States Brings Surge in Grain Prices

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Grain prices rose yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade as persistent dry weather in the western Plains threatened to reduce wheat yields needed to replenish lean inventories.
Soybeans also rose. On other markets, gold and platinum surged. 
 Farmers, traders and Government officials touring western Kansas have indicated that crops will suffer if Kansas, the nation's top wheat-producing state, does not get rain within 10 days. Yields could also be reduced in parts of Colorado and Nebraska that are dry.
As it stands now, crop scouts on the annual Wheat Quality Council tour predict that Kansas will harvest 336.2 million bushels this year, 31 percent more than last year's relatively poor crop.
The estimate was below most trade expectations, and could fall further if forecasts for dry weather through the end of the month hold true.
A robust crop is needed because United States wheat reserves are expected to fall to half their normal levels by the end of May.
Wheat for July delivery rose 4.75 cents, to $4.1375 a bushel.
Corn and soybean futures prices rose on forecasts for cool Midwestern weather early next week that could delay planting.
July corn rose 3.5 cents, to $2.88 a bushel, and July soybeans rose 5 cents, to $8.89 a bushel.
Precious metals futures prices advanced on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange.
Gold futures posted their largest one-day jump since Feb. 27 as the Japanese yen strengthened against the dollar, making gold cheaper for Asian purchasers, said Tim Porter, an analyst with Refco Inc.
Platinum and palladium futures rose on worries that shipments of Russian supplies will be delayed for a fifth month.
Russia's huge Norilsk nickel mine is the world's largest producer of palladium, but virtually none of the mine's output has reached international customers since the end of last year because of persistent labor troubles and economic problems in Russia.
June gold rose $4.60, to $349.40 an ounce. June palladium was up the $6 limit, to $163.90 an ounce; July platinum rose $9.70, to $389.20 an ounce.

LENGTH: 2999 words

HEADLINE: Designing a War Against Crime

BYLINE: By KIT R. ROANE 

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY

 BODY:
The corner of Armstrong Avenue and Martin Luther King Drive is conspicuous these days, mainly because of what is absent.
On the sidewalk, where clusters of drug dealers once did business, there is only a sturdy brown trash can. Down the street, burned-out buildings have been razed, some replaced with bright prefabricated town houses. Boom boxes for the most part no longer boom. And nighttime shootings, when they occur, usually occur at least a couple of blocks away. 
 "Now my kids can come out and play," said Carolyn Young, who lives across from a fenced-in lot that once was a crack house. "The bums aren't hanging out and it's quiet at night."
"Before, there was drug activity everywhere," she said, scooting her boys, aged 5 and 12, down the street.
Like many other areas of the city, this section, part of what the police designate as the southern district, was far more forbidding before the decade began. Gang members ruled the corners, drunks took up park benches and thieves preyed on commuters and old ladies walking home from the bank. Typical of police methods of the time, officers remained sealed in their cars waiting for crime to happen, and they seldom got to know anyone in the community except the people they repeatedly arrested.
But in 1990, motivated by overwhelming drug crime and with a chance to get Federal grants to combat it, the Jersey City Police Department decided it was time for a fresh approach. The police force bought its first computer system and hired researchers in an experiment to literally create a map of crime in selected parts of the city. The result has been a dramatic drop-off in criminal activity in the targeted neighborhoods, and a new sense that the streets are safer and the bad guys are on the run.
Once, crime fighting was based on educated assumptions, not empirical evidence, knowledge that was carried in the minds of individual officers.
That had to change, the department concluded, and with it the mindset of a traditional police force whose members had long been accustomed to responding to crimes after the fact.
As the researchers gauged the moves of criminals and the countermoves of the police, officers slowly began to emerge from their cars and onto the streets, quantifying who was doing what to whom and why. The result was a flowing picture of crime -- captured on computer spread sheets. It is called problem-oriented policing -- tailoring specific responses to each type of crime and location.
Drug dealers watched as city workers fenced in their favorite hangout or tore down the abandoned building where they stashed their drugs. Panhandlers and public drinkers began showing up at their preferred meeting sites to find that the police had removed the benches. And husbands who repeatedly beat their wives found that 911 brought not only officers but also counselors.
The results were extraordinary, the police say. According to a 14-month study that ended in August 1995, the new techniques decreased overall crime in target areas by 16 percent while crime jumped 42 percent in comparable spots left to traditional patrols.
A snapshot of the entire city showed nearly 700 fewer violent crimes in 1996 than in 1993, and more than a thousand fewer nonviolent crimes, the police said.
"For 100 years we have been using police methods that have never really been studied," said Deputy Chief Frank Gajewski. "And essentially, we were making arrests but no gains."
"Now we are trying to treat the causes behind the crime and study what works and what doesn't," he added, noting that the city had overcome the notoriety, gained in 1989, of being No 2, behind Oakland, Calif., on the list of large cities with major drug problems. At the time, Jersey City recorded 2,754 drug arrests per 100,000 residents (the population was then about 220,000). Last year, Chief Gajewski said, the number was 1,621. "This philosophy is new for us and something a lot of the country is still ignoring. But, so far, it has worked wonders here."

THE PLAN
'X' Marks the Spot
Jersey City, once a gritty but thriving railway and waterfront town, has seen its tax base diminish as manufacturing jobs disappeared in the last 25 years. But there have been signs of hope for the 235,000 residents who make up a multi-ethnic mix of immigrants, old-timers and young professionals. Pockets of gentrification have reclaimed old row houses and a new waterfront financial center has brought 10,000 jobs to the city. Still, the very poor southern and western sections of town account for roughly half of all crime, as well as the majority of drug activity and violence.
The mapping program has allowed the police to direct their response more precisely, with a few computer keystrokes pinpointing centers of car theft, drug selling, robbery, burglary and arson, among others crimes, as well as differentiating between variations of the same crimes. Most communities don't have this ability and even New York City's own mapping system postdates that in Jersey City, according to Anthony A. Braga, a research associate at Harvard's Kennedy School of Government who has studied Jersey City's experiment. He said the Jersey City system is so advanced that the police can pinpoint "hot spots" down to a single corner.
Since research has shown that 6 percent of the city's streets are home to 30 percent of its crime, being able to focus on these areas with tailored solutions can greatly increase overall quality of life through redeployment of officers rather than with the huge expense of new hiring, he said.
The idea was first proposed in 1979 by Herman Goldstein, a law professor at the University of Wisconsin, who wrote in the journal Crime and Delinquency that communities would be better served if police departments stopped merely reacting to crime calls and began looking at the underlying reasons why crime was drawn to certain areas.
He called this problem-oriented policing, a philosophy that later underwent fine-tuning in studies conducted in Minneapolis and Kansas City during the 1980's and then was applied more broadly in New York City and Jersey City.
Jersey City became involved after criminologists at Rutgers University offered to help the Police Department compete for several experimental grants being administered by the National Institute of Justice, a branch of the Justice Department that has helped to finance policing studies.
The city was successful, getting a $837,423 grant to develop a drug-market analysis program in 1990. This computer database is now used to map all types of crimes throughout the city. Several other grants followed from a variety of agencies. While some helped to pay for more officers, many furthered the change of philosophy in the department, allowing studies in preventing crime in housing projects, targeting violent places and reducing domestic violence.
Though the department has yet to train its entire force in problem-oriented policing and the use of computer mapping, Chief Gajewski said he believed that in a few years all 859 officers in the city's four precincts and three substations would be trained to study and identify the root causes of crime in their districts, then take steps to battle it.
Crime continues to be a boilerplate issue around the country, and is at the heart of an increasingly shrill mayoral campaign here. Jerramiah T. Healy, a Democrat and former judge, who is trying to unseat Mayor Bret Schundler, a Republican, in Tuesday's election, has taken out full-page ads in The Jersey Journal asserting that crime is the worst it has been in years. The Mayor has counterattacked, calling the allegations baseless and misleading.
Chief Gajewski said he was hopeful that his policing model would not fall victim to politics. He added that it has already survived one mayoral change and several police chiefs.
The structure of the department is being altered to respond to the new model, with specific officers assigned to neighborhoods and linked with city workers (from departments like housing or sanitation, for example) and community representatives to tackle not just criminals but the trash or dilapidation that often attract them. At the same time, radio cars are freed to respond to emergencies. And lesser burdens, like calls to report accidents for insurance forms, which have tended to take hours of police time, will soon be taken over by civilians hired by the department.
In the end, Chief Gajewski said, the department's new philosophy and assignment of officers to specific locales and tasks will save not only time but money. He also hopes that more areas will see the changes that the side streets off Armstrong and Martin Luther King have come to expect.

A CORNER
Trash, Drugs, Ruins
One of 12 violent-crime "hot spots" in the south district to benefit from problem-oriented policing is the area around Armstrong Avenue and Martin Luther King Drive. In the policing experiment, underwritten by the National Institute of Justice, the intersection has become an island of relative tranquillity in a general sea of decay, where crumbling facades and iron-barred stores are separated by vacant lots, and aimless young men rule the night.
Managing it turned out to be relatively simple.
Officers assigned there began videotaping the area, making a record of where trash had built up, what buildings were abandoned and where the men congregated. They also left business cards in residents' mailboxes so people could not only complain but also offer information without being seen by the drug dealers and loiterers who had taken over the intersection.
The residents called, pointing out their major concerns, telling where drug dealers were stashing their drugs and which buildings were attracting crime.
Officers began arresting the dealers, as well as searching out the people who owned the abandoned buildings and warning local liquor stores not to sell to obviously intoxicated people. Signs were pasted on corners telling drug dealers that the area was under constant video surveillance -- although it often wasn't -- and officers would sometimes ride past drug spots holding video cameras, usually without any film.
Young children, who were blamed for setting up basketball hoops in the middle of the street and playing loud music until early in the morning were offered a deal: Keep the street clean and keep it quiet after dark, and the hoops won't be confiscated. Some drug dealers also began keeping brooms nearby to sweep up, a thin hope that the police would walk on by if their corner stayed tidy.
Discussing the way the department sought to control the drug problem, Lieut. William Costigan explained that each dealer usually has a set location, often for years. They have regular customers, regular hours and regular hiding places. When you disrupt their corner and tear down their operating centers, both clients and dealers get confused and unsettled, and doing business becomes a highly speculative proposition.
"If you have a favorite restaurant, you go there," Lieutenant Costigan said. "And it's the same way with dealers. If you get good drugs one place you come back," he said, warning off a loitering user with the advice that "this corner's been shut down, homey."
"We didn't just arrest the dealers here, we hounded them," Lieutenant Costigan said with a smile. "People would call in and say, 'He just stashed his stuff here or money here,' and we'd pick it up. We'd arrest his subordinates and pull out a camera whenever we saw him on the street. When you're losing hundreds of dollars a day to us, you get discouraged."
By the end of the program last year, three of the six abandoned buildings near the corner had been knocked down and the property fenced, while the others were placed on a list to be razed. Code enforcement officers were sent to one particularly trouble-prone apartment building and the owner was given three months to correct 32 violations. Eighty-nine drug arrests were also made and the roughly 30 loiterers who once made the four-corner intersection their base were reduced to about 5.
Tapping the garbage can that now holds a permanent spot on this corner, Lieutenant Costigan counted the number of loiterers in the area with a smile. "It used to be that you never saw a mother with her children come by here," he said, moving out of the way so several groups could pass. "There were too many people hanging out drinking and selling even to get by, and there was always a loud radio and bottles in the street. Now people can get to the store and the nearest drug corner is four blocks away.
"I'm not saying that we solved the problem here," he said, "but we've certainly disrupted it. And with their favorite places torn down, I don't think it will ever be as popular as it was."
Residents tend to agree, though they fear the police may one day let up or become lax about the outreach or the patrols that have made their block suddenly safe. "The police cracked down a lot but if they let up, those people will be right back," said Tyia Smith, a 25-year-old postal worker, as she lugged a bag of groceries from Sister and Brother, a corner grocery store where workers once seldom ventured out from behind a huge Plexiglas shield.
"I feel safe inside," added Lillian Tillman, 54, who was new to the neighborhood. "It's quiet but I don't know."

THE COPS
Overcoming Doubt
Officers were once as skeptical of the program's effectiveness as residents are now of its future. Persuading young officers that the old ways must give way to the new continues to be an obstacle.
"It's gotten better but I remember when we started this thing in 1990 that many officers had this attitude of 'whatever you're going to try, it ain't gonna work'," explained Chief Gajewski. "They didn't even know what we were going to try but there was a lot of resistance to change."
Lieutenant Costigan was one of those resisting. A 16-year law enforcement veteran, he had become a firm believer that the only way to manage a tide of crime was by increasing arrests and he had little interest in taking time out for anything else. "I was against it, mainly because it was new," he said sheepishly. "I just didn't see anything changing."
Then he began hearing from residents, and the words weren't the usual complaints, but praise. Some days, he said, they would thank him for arranging to fence-in a vacant lot or tear down an abandoned building that served as a drug hangout. Other times it was just for coming to their community meeting or walking on their street instead of riding through in his car.
They didn't know anything about crime mapping or police philosophy but it became clear things were beginning to change in their neighborhood. And for once, for the better.
"Some of it didn't have a direct effect on crime but really increased the quality of life in an area," Lieutenant Costigan said. "I changed when I figured out that I was going home knowing I had done something concrete for these people, that I was making a difference."
"Every time I got a crack house razed or made an apartment building put up security lights, I was putting rent money back in the hands of an old lady who used to get robbed on the way to the bank," he said. "I wasn't just locking people up anymore, I was protecting and serving. It was a good feeling a lot of us had lost on the street."
The criminals also began to look at the police a different way, said Officer James Waiters, who has been living and working as a neighborhood policeman in south Jersey City for the past three years.
"When I first became a policeman, it was horrible," he said. "They would sell drugs right in front of you and just run away when you told them to halt."
"I'm not a big man," said the wiry 34-year-old officer. "But now the bad guys give respect because they know they can't hide. You get a real pump keeping them down."
That was just what Officer Waiters was doing on April 25, the night he and other neighborhood police officers led a posse of his fellow officers, county prosecutors and Federal drug enforcement agents through what was said to be the largest drug raid in the city's history. Called Operation Joint Venture, it resulted in 450 arrests and $69,000 in confiscated drugs and money.
While this was old-style policing, Officer Waiters credited its success to problem-oriented policing in the south district -- where the idea began and where the raid was conducted -- the new cooperation of residents in offering information and the wealth of data on the dealers that had been dutifully collected, then fed into the department's computer.
Officer Waiters lived among some of those who were arrested, less than a block from one, on speaking terms with most. Some felt betrayed later under the moonlight when he showed up at their doors, a slew of fellow officers cutting off their exits, a warrant for their arrest curled in his hand.
"I know nearly all these guys because I went to high school here," said Officer Waiters, writing up some paperwork on a dealer known as Fat Cat, as he talked of the importance of sweeping things clean before the summer drug-selling season began and Fat Cat complained that Officer Waiters should have told him what was up.
To stay effective, the officer said, he would have to be back out grooming the streets the next morning, even as Fat Cat and others cooled their heels in jail. There would be crack houses to raze, phone calls from neighbors to return, blocks to walk and advice to give.
"We've got good families out here but then we also got whole families who deal," he said. "It's the easy money, the fast money, making more in a day than a working man does in a week. You can't change that overnight, but things are getting better. And every day I'm out there with the people, it's making that money come a little harder and the good people's lives a little easier. I've never been so popular in my life."

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY & CO.;
New Signs of Wear at a Nuclear Plant That's For Sale

BYLINE: By KIT R. ROANE 

 BODY:
The sale of the Oyster Creek nuclear plant, a possibility floated by its owners last month, could be complicated by reports of unexpected signs of wear in a key safety component of the reactor, industry analysts say.
Reports sent to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission in January, detailing the company's inspection of the plant last September, say that small vertical cracks have developed in the core reactor shroud. 
 The shroud, a cylinder of welded stainless steel plates stacked on top of one another, helps to keep the core aligned and provides a floodable container to circulate coolant. Cracking can interfere with the reactor cooling process and fool other safety devices that track the core's health, according to nuclear energy experts.
This is not the first time that cracks have been found in the shroud. After horizontal cracks were discovered in 1994, they were repaired by tie-rods to compress the shroud, a procedure that sandwiches the plates together; however, the Nuclear Regulatory Commission has never approved a procedure for fixing vertical cracks.
That fact, combined with the reactor's small size, high running costs and age, could leave few bidders in the year 2000, when General Public Utilities said it would probably either sell or close the plant. Oyster Creek, which opened in 1969, is the third oldest reactor in the country.
"These vertical cracks hasten its demise," said Edward J. Tirello, a utility analyst with NatWest Markets, a New York-based brokerage firm. "The company has already decided that they can't make money with this plant once the energy market is deregulated and with nuclear already having a bad stigma in America it seems unlikely any American companies would buy it."
Without a buyer, G.P.U. would be left with the choice of continuing to run the plant at a loss until its license expires in 2009 or closing it. Closing the plant would require approval from the state Board of Public Utilities, which would take into account how the shutdown would affect the company, its 200,000 customers and the economy of Forked River, where the plant is situated.
Opponents of the use of nuclear power said the discovery of the cracks in the shroud raised questions about the overall safety of the reactor; they say this is particularly troubling because plant officials have not provided a conclusive accounting of how many welds were checked for cracks. Ron Eaton, the N.R.C. project manager, said he knew of only two.(The Ocean County reactor went back on line Monday after being closed for 12 days for repairs to its control rods.)
Paul Gunter, the director of the Washington-based Nuclear Information and Resource Service, said he was concerned that the push to keep the plant operating was hampering the ability of inspectors to check all safety components.
"The cracking of the core shroud is just one indication of a general deterioration in safety components," he said, noting that dozens of such items are made of the same material as the shroud.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
In West Windsor, Toll Wins a Mt. Laurel Wrangle

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
IN the wake of an earlier decision that linked a town's zoning with market conditions in fulfilling the town's obligations under the state's Mount Laurel housing doctrines, a developer has won subsequent court approval to build 1,165 residences at a site in West Windsor. Subject to an expected appeal by the town, the project would rise on 300 acres of farmland at the corner of Bear Brook and Meadow Roads in the Mercer County township.
The decision last month by Superior Court Judge Philip S. Carchman -- who also made the linkage ruling in October -- settled for now a four-year legal battle between the town and the developer, Toll Brothers of Huntingdon Valley, Pa. 
 The plan calls for 400 detached homes, 130 town houses and 635 rentals -- up to 175 of them for families with low and moderate incomes. The plan still must be approved by West Windsor's planning board.
The latest decision stems from an earlier ruling by Judge Carchman that Toll had proved that the township's zoning did not present a "realistic opportunity" under the state's Mount Laurel doctrines to provide sufficient residences for people who earn 50 to 80 percent of the area's median income of $57,690 for a family of four.
Such disputes are not new. But the Toll case represents the first time that a court has come back to see whether an approved plan works. It also is the first time that a court has used market conditions as a factor in determining the constitutionality of a town's Mount Laurel plans.
"It's a winner of a ruling that forces towns to be realistic," said Douglas C. Yearley Jr., a Toll vice president. He said his company stayed the course because the land, close to Route 1 and an N.J. Transit train station, was a "terrific site." Mr. Yearley said Toll expected to start building the $100 million project next winter.
The West Windsor Mayor, Thomas P. Frascella, called the ruling "unworkable." He said linking zoning to market conditions "leaves developing towns like us exposed to real estate cycles and developers' whims." Mr. Frascella, who is running for re-election, said the township intended to appeal.
But Judge Carchman called for expediting the approval process. "The objective," he wrote, "is to bring West Windsor into compliance with the Mount Laurel doctrines and from a practical standpoint to do all within the power of the court to insure low- and moderate-income housing will be in the ground in West Windsor in the foreseeable future."
To that end, the court has appointed a "master" to monitor the pace of the approval process. The Mount Laurel doctrines say that each of the state's 566 municipalities has an obligation to provide its share of affordable housing. While West Windsor's zoning did provide an opportunity it was not sufficient to meet the township's obligation for 929 Mount Laurel units, the court said. It noted that from 1982 to 1992 the number of houses in the township more than doubled to 6,115, and of the 3,208 new homes only 139 were affordable to families with low or moderate incomes.
West Windsor must submit a township-wide plan to provide the mandated units, which it is in the process of doing. Only after the court approves the plan can the township appeal.
Mayor Frascella said he was optimistic that the overall plan would be approved. And in it he sees a silver lining. He said it allowed the township to meet its Mount Laurel obligation in a way that produces fewer market-rate housing units, which in terms of population is "a huge opportunity for us to manage our growth."
To date some 230 towns have had or are in the process of having their plans approved by the courts or the Council on Affordable Housing, created in 1985 as an alternative to the courts in monitoring compliance. Of the 86,000 low- and moderate-income Mount Laurel units the state says it will need through 1999, 17,676 have been built, according to the council. An additional 4,676 units have been renovated and towns have rezoned land for 12,000 more, the council says.
Toll bought the West Windsor site in 1993 from a group of lenders that took control of it in lieu of foreclosure in 1990 from the Lanid Corporation. Lanid, in a settlement of a Mount Laurel suit filed 7 years earlier, was to build 1,500 multifamily units. Delays in approvals and the recession derailed that project and Lanid filed for bankruptcy.
AS the new owner, Toll originally sought to build 650 detached houses and 115 rentals affordable to families with low or moderate incomes. It offered this plan because it felt that one where condominium apartment houses predominated was not marketable. But West Windsor maintained that the Toll project did not comply with its zoning and would have forced it to rezone another site to make up the 200 Mount Laurel units that would have been built under the Lanid plan.
Toll sued. After three and a half years of legal maneuvering, Judge Carchman agreed with Toll that the rezoning for its site and some of the 11 others in the 80's violated the Mount Laurel doctrines.
The developer successfully argued that the rezoning was unrealistic because it overstated the potential housing density of the sites, many of which had wetlands. Moreover, the court said, the town's open space and sewer ordinances made the sites economically unfeasible for development.
The court also broke new ground when it said market factors must be dealt with in judging whether a town's zoning is adequate to provide affordable housing.
It is not clear how many other Mount Laurel zoning disputes the ruling will affect. But it "opens up a viable course of action" against towns that fail to adjust their zoning to meet market conditions, said Henry Hill, a Princeton lawyer who argued on behalf of Toll and has long represented developers in Mount Laurel cases. He said cases would be decided town by town and would be dependent on existing zoning.
But Robert Burchell, a professor at the Center for Urban Policy Research at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, said:
"The essence of zoning in a community, which already to a degree reflects market conditions, should be based on the way residents want to see their town developed, not a market test."
That multifamily housing is again marketable in central New Jersey shows the folly of "making zoning contingent on market analysis," he said.
Others said there was no doubt about the ruling's import. It insures that communities will review whether the zoning on Mount Laurel sites is realistic and take measures "to expedite rather than retard the production of affordable housing," said Art Bernard. He is a partner at THP Inc., a housing consulting firm in East Brunswick and a former executive director of the Council on Affordable Housing.
Along with approving Toll's current plan, which Mr. Yearley said made it economically feasible to build the 175 Mount Laurel units he feels the plan will generate, the court also resolved other issues in the case. Among them are the type of sewage system that will be used at the site and the amount of land to be left open.
Beyond objecting to the linkage between market conditions, which Mr. Frascella said "flies in the face of good planning," the Mayor said several issues remained unsettled. For instance, he said, it is unclear if the 1988 agreement for 1,500 units is still valid and if the 1,165 units the court just approved would fit on the site.
Despite a possible appeal, Mr. Yearley said his company would "seriously consider moving ahead with the development because we feel the judge's ruling is correct."
Toll will present its plan to the West Windsor Planning Board for approval within the next few weeks. As now envisioned the detached houses will start at 2,000 square feet in size, sit on 5,000- to 10,000-square-foot lots and cost from about $200,000 to more than $300,000. The town houses will start at 1,700 square feet in size and the "mid-to-high $100,000" range in price. The high end has yet to be determined. Mr. Yearley said the size and leasing rates of the rental apartments have not yet been set.
The court granted Toll 15 years after securing township approval to build the project. Mr. Yearley said he expected it to be completed in five to seven years.

HEADLINE: Traversing the Regulatory Maze

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
THEY weren't the world's worst delays -- 30 to 60 days, maybe. And not all of the 23 two-family homes with the undulating facades along Chester Street in Brownsville, Brooklyn, were mired in what one builder brands "bureaucratic limbo." Only about half.
But families were waiting to move into those spanking new rowhouses with their ornamental pre-cast concrete coping stones and lintels -- evocative of the petticoat-and-parasol era of 1890's Brooklyn. And these were moderate-income people who had never owned their own homes before. 
 A city inspector was insisting that the architect's original sidewalk renderings be redrawn, now that the city had planted tree seedlings by the curb.
"The process is sometimes subjective," said Jeffrey Levine, who as president of Levine Builders had worked with the New York City Housing Partnership to develop that row of subsidized homes near Sutter Avenue. "Very often a Highways Department paving plan is filed, with the work prescribed by the architect. And after construction, his interpretation is subject to modification after site inspection. That can require refiling, reinspection and a loss of valuable time."
Without that final go-ahead last December, certificates of occupancy for those Chester Street homes -- "which is the period at the end of the construction sentence," Mr. Levine said -- could not be granted. With a certificate of occupancy in hand, a developer can usually pay off the construction loan, get permanent financing at a lower rate and start using the property for its intended purpose.
"We had to delay those closings," said Mr. Levine, who has built about 3,000 homes in the city in the last 15 years. "I've had people threaten to back out of deals."
For decades, developers in New York City -- from single-family home builders on Staten Island to the titans of Manhattan tower projects -- have railed against a regulatory system they variously describe as a multilayered labyrinth pocked with pitfalls, a "Minotaurian maze" with lurking bull-headed beasts and a minefield laced with permit requirements imposed by too many agencies protecting their own turf. All of which, they say, runs up costs, exacts hair-extracting delay and creates incentive-chilling uncertainty for builders.
"It could be months of delays," said Jerome Belson, president of Associated Builders and Owners of New York, one of the city's leading developer groups. "Before you can build, you've got to get your financing in line, draw down the money to buy the property, and then you can't move ahead because the Buildings Department doesn't have the electrical and highway approvals. You're in a state of suspended animation."
But in recent years -- as Mr. Belson will concede -- there have been marked improvements in the system, with several innovations commonly called "one-stop shopping," "express permitting" and "self-certification" streamlining specific parts of the process.
At the same time, however, the procedures by which a developer must gain approval for his or her grand strategy -- the use of the land, the "envelope" of the building and the environmental consequences of the project -- remain lengthy and costly.
And so, with a panoply of competing interests exerting influence, each with its own creditable purposes, the path to development is a balancing act with a multitude of steps across a long tightrope.
With the innovations, some steps have become simpler for those negotiating the bureaucracy. "There have been a lot of minor accommodations," Mr. Belson said.
Another developer, Vincent Riso, was more upbeat. The attitudes of the Buildings and Planning commissioners under Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani "have gone a long way in convincing their personnel to be more user-friendly," said Mr. Riso, president of the Briarwood Organization, which has built close to 20,000 homes and apartments in the city since 1912. "I can't say everything is worry-free, but for the first time, honestly, I see it going in that direction."
Gaston Silva, the city's Commissioner of Buildings, said his predecessor, Joel A. Miele, "revolutionized the way the department operates." Mr. Silva took over last August when Mr. Miele became Commissioner of Environmental Protection.
"Joel made it possible for architects and engineers to self-certify their plans for compliance with the codes," Mr. Silva said, "so an architect doesn't have to stand in line to have his or her plans reviewed."
"Another thing Joel started was express permitting," Mr. Silva said, explaining that, in addition to lining up for various permits from the Buildings Department, a builder had to go to the Department of Environmental Protection for sewer approvals, to the Transportation Department for pavement approvals, to the Fire Department for alarm approvals. "Now, the staff from those agencies are with the Buildings Department, in our borough offices."
A reform introduced by Mr. Silva allows builders to file forms by computer disk, rather than stacks of paper. And he has decentralized the Bureau of Electrical Control. "When they were centralized in Manhattan, each inspector had a route that took two weeks to cover," Mr. Silva said. "Now, they go out from the borough office, return that night, and the information goes right into the computer." Inspectors will soon be equipped with hand-held computers to further expedite the process.
THE attitude of the Giuliani Administration, said Carole Slater, a city zoning official under four mayors and now a private land-use lawyer, "has been, 'Let's get it built and let's get it occupied.' And that's filtering down to the staff."
Perhaps surprisingly, leaders of groups that frequently contest development plans -- environmentalists, preservationists, community board activists -- express qualified support for the tactical improvements in the permitting process. But they strongly caution that the shift of responsibilities away from government, particularly if it were to seep into those grand-strategy areas of land use and environmental impact, could have grave consequences. And they point out that, cumbersome though the existing checks may seem, they often expedite construction by avoiding problems that could cause lengthy litigation.
"You want to streamline the process, not defang it," said Brendan Sexton, president of the Municipal Art Society, a private group that seeks to promote and protect architectural standards. "Something that is environmentally wrong or historically insensitive should not go forward."
And yet, Mr. Sexton agrees that "the zoning code is too complex, the land-use review process too lengthy and difficult, and the multiple environmental reviews are more confusing than they have to be, by far."
There are, essentially, two paths to development in New York City, as one land-use lawyer, Sybil H. Pollet, pointed out while offering a truncated version of "Zoning 101."
The first, called "as-of-right," means that a developer consults with a land-use lawyer to determine what size and shape of building is allowed on a particular lot. "Your architect draws a plan," Ms. Pollet said. "You go to the Buildings Department and if the examiners conclude that the building, as drawn, complies with the codes, you get a building permit."
Usually, that is the clearer -- though rarely crystal clear -- path to development.
Far more of an obstacle course is the procedure for receiving "discretionary approval" of a project that does not comply with the city's three-volume 1961 Zoning Resolution, with its block-by-block, lot-by-lot maps and corresponding texts. "That's the Minotaurian maze, where you know there is potentially a beast waiting for you," Ms. Pollet said. Under "as-of-right," she said, the bull-headed beasts are hidden.
Zoning is divided into two basic components: the use to which a property may be put (manufacturing, commercial, residential) and bulk (the size and configuration of a building).
There are 18 "Use Groups" in the zoning code, ranging from Group 1, which includes single-family homes, through Group 18, which would include a sewage plant. Superimposed on the maps are special districts where the city seeks to preserve certain aspects of a community -- for instance, the Special Garment Center District and the Special Lincoln Square District.
The maps refer to portions of the text that describe, among other things, the allowable square footage for the building, height and setback requirements and the angle of the building from street to sky.
Until 1916, the city had no zoning code. But then a behemoth of a building -- the 40-story Equitable at 120 Broadway -- raised an uproar at least as large as the seven-acre shadow that it cast.
In response, the 1916 Zoning Resolution divided the city into residential, business and unlimited districts. "The idea was to keep nuisances away from desirable uses -- the pig out of the parlor," Ms. Pollet said. And it addressed the bulk issue by requiring setbacks in a wedding-cake profile.
The 1961 Zoning Resolution, rather than relying on the wedding-cake format, introduced floor-area requirements to check overly bulky buildings. The framers preferred the International Style, where a tower rises from a plaza. To compensate for the decrease in bulk, the code allowed a builder to increase the height of the tower.
The 1961 Zoning Resolution also allowed for waivers from as-of-right development by requiring "discretionary approvals" through what is now called the Uniform Land Use Review Procedure -- ULURP to insiders.
By way of illustration, Ms. Pollet sketched the plans of a hypothetical company, Dynamic Development, to build a residential building in a commercial district. The zoning allows Dynamic to construct a building with a floor area six times the size of the lot. To make a profit, Dynamic needs more floor space. So it seeks a zoning map amendment to allow 10 times the area of the lot.
In addition, Dynamic ascertains that a landmarked church across the street has unused development rights to an additional 20,000 square feet of floor area. So it seeks a special permit to acquire those development rights, contingent on the company creating a longterm maintenance program for the church. The application is reviewed by the Planning Department and certified as complete by the Planning Commission.
Now, community concerns and political interests get into the mix.
In Ms. Pollet's simplified scenario, the local community board, which has 60 days to review the project, holds a public hearing and votes against Dynamic's application, citing concerns that increased traffic will endanger Little Leaguers who play in the church schoolyard. The community board cannot veto the proposal, only make a recommendation to the Planning Commission.
But its concerns carry weight with local politicians, who bring their influence to bear on the Borough President, who has 30 days to also make a recommendation to the Planning Commission and, perhaps, hold another hearing. The commission then has 60 days to hold its public hearing and to approve, modify or disapprove the application.
If the Planning Commission also disapproves, the project is dead -- unless the Mayor files a Certificate of Necessity with the City Council. If, however, the community board and the Borough President disapprove while the Planning Commission approves, the issue goes to a vote by the City Council, which holds another hearing.
Whatever the Council's decision, the Mayor can veto it within five days; but that veto is subject to a Council override by a two-thirds vote, within 10 days.
"That's an outside total of 215 days, not counting the six months it might have taken for the City Planning staff to certify the application as complete," Ms. Pollet said. "It could be a year or two from the time Dynamic first purchased the land, and it is paying off the mortgage, taxes, soft costs" -- such as legal and architect fees.
If obtaining discretionary approval is a tortuous process, as-of-right can also be fraught with peril.
MS. POLLET cited the case of a warehouse at Third Avenue and 80th Street in Manhattan that Toys "R" Us, along with the developer Ian Bruce Eichner, purchased in 1994 to convert into a store, with a condominium apartment building rising above.
The area had been rezoned from commercial to residential. But the Department of Buildings ruled that, because the previous owner, Morgan & Brother Manhattan Storage, continued to use the building as a warehouse, Toys "R" Us had "grandfathered" rights to retain the loading docks.
Neighborhood residents launched a two-year legal battle. In December, the state's highest court, the Court of Appeals, ruled that the grandfathered rights had been forfeited because only a bare amount of goods had been stored in the warehouse. And so, below a luxury apartment tower on a fashionable East Side block, the ground-level commercial space remains boarded up.
"Whoops! You buy a building believing, based on an official opinion or permit, that you can use that property for a toy store, only to find that the proposed development can't be realized," said Ms. Pollet, who represented Chase Manhattan Bank, holder of the underlying mortgage on the old warehouse. "Even though a developer gets an official opinion, it can't always be relied upon."
Ponderous though the land-use process may be, the parallel environmental impact procedure remains to be reckoned with.
Michael Gerrard, an environmental lawyer and co-author of a reference manual, "Environmental Impact Review in New York" (Matthew Bender & Company, 1990), said that, "from start to finish, between first telling the government you want to do a project and getting the final approvals," an Environmental Impact Statement typically takes 18 months to complete.
"A small E.I.S. may cost tens of thousands of dollars for, let's say, a small apartment building," Mr. Gerrard said. "A good-sized E.I.S. will cost several hundred thousand dollars, but it could be more than a million."
To begin with, the developer must fill out an Environmental Assessment, a long form provided by the city, summarizing the potential impacts of the project. The lead city agency designated to review the assessment -- usually the Planning Department -- then decides whether the impacts are sufficient to require a full Environmental Impact Statement. If not, the project may proceed without a full E.I.S.
A full statement, prepared by companies that specialize in the field, will address the project's impact on traffic, air pollution, water consumption, noise, sewage generation, open space, energy and light. It might assess the effects on wetlands and endangered species.
"The classic example, of course, is Westway," Mr. Gerrard said, "and I was involved in that for years. The E.I.S. was misleading about the project's impact on fish in the Hudson River. As a direct result, the project was eventually killed."
Impact statements for the redevelopment of Times Square, Mr. Gerrard said, required the hiring of sociologists to assess whether the sex industry would vanish or be pushed to other parts of the city. "Another obscure one: old burial grounds, like the Revolutionary War-era merchant seamen's cemetery at the Brooklyn Navy Yard."
The completed preliminary draft of the full E.I.S. is submitted to the lead agency. It makes comments and corrections. Several drafts are usually required. The lead agency eventually certifies the full E.I.S. as complete, though that does not mean the project is approved.
Most certified drafts then require a public hearing, after which the lead agency prepares a final E.I.S., including all comments gathered at the hearing and responses from the developer. After publication of the final E.I.S., the lead agency and all the other involved agencies make final decisions on approving or disapproving the project, explaining their reasons. "That's the end of the environmental review process," Mr. Gerrard said, "and frequently the start of the litigation process."
Is all of that necessary? Or, conversely, is there danger in compressing, or privatizing, the process too much? Parties to the debate call for an appropriate balance.
No one contends that a major overhaul of the regulatory system would solve the city's chronic housing shortage. "Without public subsidies, given the cost of construction in New York," said Kathryn Wylde, an expert on affordable housing, "the impact of streamlining is extremely limited." Ms. Wylde, former president of the New York City Housing Partnership, said the costs of land, labor, taxes, transportation of materials and connections to infrastructure are very high for developers in New York City.
And so, whatever costs are saved during the regulatory process, developers argue, could contribute to the city's -- and their -- economic health. "The public can be protected and the development community can get a fair shake," said Mr. Riso. "It's extremely important for the city's economy that money not be wasted during development."
CAUTIOUSLY, some of those who sometimes oppose development projects do not entirely disagree. "There's room for streamlining, coordinating, collapsing or even deleting some steps," Mr. Sexton of the Municipal Art Society said. "So far, the improvements are being accomplished incrementally and intelligently. But, ultimately, we need the ability to stop the commission of terrible errors."
Innovations like self-certification are a good idea, said Ronald Shiffman, director of the Pratt Center for Community and Environmental Development, "but it needs to be audited very carefully."
Citing the case of the Parker Meridien Hotel in midtown Manhattan, which did not comply with its agreement to maintain a public plaza, Mr. Shiffman, a former member of the City Planning Commission, said, "We used to kid that we need a Planning Police Department. To discourage people from staying in the plaza, the hotel actually took out the benches."
Of graver concern, said Mr. Gerrard, the environmental lawyer, contamination from a previous use might be unearthed during construction at an industrial site. "There are responsible developers who will call the government and say, 'Look what I found, let's solve the problem,' " Mr. Gerrard said. "Others will say, 'Bury it, I don't want to know.' "
Commissioner Silva pointed out that a bill allowing developers to self-certify for the certificate of occupancy was introduced in the City Council last year, "but there's resistance to the notion."
Asked if the entire process would some day be privatized, Mr. Silva said: "We will never go there. The question is to find the right balance of regulation by the municipal agency and reliance on the professionals."
In the estimation of Mr. Belson of the Associated Builders and Owners, there are "two words" that sum up problems with the review process: "community boards."
"There's no hard and fast map to follow in terms of what will be accepted by the local board," Mr. Belson said. "They have their own needs. In many instances, unfortunately, their needs are in conflict with the greater good."
But Eric Goldstein, a lawyer for the Natural Resources Defense Council, said community boards view with legitimate concern the efforts to revamp the review process. "Proposals for change usually come from the developers, and the basic worry is that since they have so much clout, neighborhood representatives will be outgunned," he said.
"No one thinks the system is working perfectly now," Mr. Goldstein added, "but the fear is that reopening these issues is like buying a discount plane ticket to a destination selected by the airline."
Mr. Belson was philosophical about the prospects for further change. "We have a participatory democracy," he said. "It's great for us to say, 'I want to go shopping at Office Depot and I want to be able to park my car in a 250-car lot. But it's certainly going to negatively impact on the local hardware store.
"So there are these needs that have to be weighed and counter-balanced," he said. "You need the wisdom of a Solomon."

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Maria Kozloski and Lance Crist

 BODY:
Maria Chiara Kozloski and DeLanson Douglas Crist, international investment specialists in Moscow, were married yesterday in Chevy Chase, Md. The Rev. John J. Mudd, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at Woodend, the headquarters of the Audubon Naturalist Society.
The couple, who received M.B.A. degrees from the University of Pennsylvania, are investment officers for the International Finance Corporation, an affiliate of the World Bank. The bride arranges loan packages for Russian financial institutions, the bridegroom for Russian industrial projects. 
 Ms. Kozloski, 32, is keeping her name. She graduated from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and received a master's degree in Eastern European studies from Johns Hopkins University. She is a daughter of Teresa and Henry Kozloski of Agawam, Mass. The bride's father is a biology teacher at West Springfield (Mass.) High School. Her mother is an associate professor of European history at Bay Path College in Longmeadow, Mass.
Mr. Crist, 31, is known as Lance. A graduate of Cornell University, he is a son of the Rev. Jean C. Thompson, the pastor of the Rio Grande Presbyterian Church in Albuquerque, N.M., and of DeLanson R. Crist of Chevy Chase, Md., an associate professor of organic chemistry at Georgetown University in Washington. The bridegroom is a stepson of Sandy Crist.
