HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
Passing the Apartment To the Next Generation

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
NOW that he is retired, Robert B. Neuwirth says he would consider moving from his rent-controlled apartment at West End Avenue and 71st Street to a place outside Manhattan where living expenses are lower.
"Some people call this apartment a steal because they think it's cheap," said Mr. Neuwirth, who pays $1,250 a month for a modest-sized two-bedroom on the 16th floor. "But in relation to my income, it isn't." A lawyer who was working in rent administration for the state, Mr. Neuwirth took early retirement two years ago at the age of 55 and pays about a third of his income as rent. 
 His housing history shows how the laws of succession under rent regulation benefit more than one generation in a family. He exemplifies the operation of the succession laws as they were clearly intended to operate -- for the permanent benefit of a family that has continuously occupied a regulated apartment as a primary residence.
At the same time, his situation calls attention to the equity issues inherent in a system that has in effect created an entitlement for a family that chooses to remain in place for a long time in a location that has become more affordable to many outsiders hoping to get in than it is to those who are already there.
When Mr. Neuwirth's parents moved into the apartment in 1941, he was 17 months old. It has been his primary residence ever since. When his mother died at 81 in May 1993 -- a month after the death of his father, who was 86 -- he inherited the apartment. Now his wife, Amada Gonzalez, whom he married four years ago, has the right to inherit it should she outlive him.
He does not feel chained to his apartment, as many long-term regulated renters do. "We could leave the city," he said, "or if rent regulation continues we might be able to get the apartment next door and expand into another three rooms." Brokers say that if vacant and decontrolled his apartment would probably rent as is for at least $2,500 to $3,000 a month.
The succession rules are among the aspects of rent regulation whose future is in question now that that State Senator Joseph L. Bruno, the Republican majority leader, is warning that the entire package of rent laws will expire this year unless a phase-out plan for rent regulation can be negotiated with the Assembly. Owner organizations want the law changed to restrict succession rights drastically, perhaps by allowing only spouses to "inherit the apartment."
But interviews with lawyers for both the tenant and landlord sides suggest that even without this outcome, courts are already interpreting the laws quite strictly, making it difficult for tenants to "inherit the apartment" in the many gray-area situations that arise.
Samuel J. Himmelstein, who has represented tenants in many cases for years, said he takes some recent outcomes in court as a "judicial expression of the backlash against rent regulation."
"I advise tenants that they had better have good documents to back up their claims," Mr. Himmelstein said. "I tell them maybe you'll need the equities on your side as well as the law."
THE very complexity of the rules abet the natural tendency of tenants and owners alike to use the rules to their advantage.
The general rule -- for both rent-controlled and rent-stabilized apartments -- is that a "family member" (as explicitly though broadly defined) who has occupied the apartment with the tenant as a joint primary resident for two or more years prior to the death or departure of the tenant, is entitled to succeed to that tenant's occupancy rights. If the co-occupant is 62 years old or older, or is disabled, the period of joint occupancy only has to be one year.
When the duration of the relationship or tenancy has been less than two years (or one year for the elderly or disabled), the co-occupying family member still can inherit the apartment, provided co-occupancy began at the start of the relationship or the tenancy. That means, for example, that the rent-regulated tenant can marry or remarry and the new spouse will immediately have succession rights.
Inherent in these rules are actually two concepts: The co-occupying tenant must meet a certain test to be entitled to get the apartment, and the tenant must be in a position to give it. If the tenant has "permanently vacated" the apartment, succession rights cannot be passed on. If the co-occupying family member has not been there at least two years (or at least one year if the family member is over 62 or disabled), the co-occupant cannot inherit.
Since a Court of Appeals decision in the case of Braschi v. Stahl Associates in 1989, "family member" is deemed to include "nontraditional" families -- often but not necessarily gay partners. The court gave a specific list of the evidences of close economic and emotional interdependence that would constitute a nontraditional family for succession rights purposes, and the list was made part of the state's rent regulation code.
Families will naturally consider a low-rent apartment an asset and when possible assert their rights to inherit it. But their motivations do not undercut their rights.
At the 165-unit co-op at 85 Barrow Street in Greenwich Village, the late Patrick Sullivan, a tenant since 1940, took ill in the 80's. The family decided that his grandson, Daniel Sullivan, then 23 years old, was the logical choice. Daniel's sister was away at school at the time and his brother was "not interested in the apartment."
"As well as helping my grandfather out, it was a better place than I was in in Brooklyn," Mr. Sullivan said in a deposition before the trial. "It was near where I worked. Both inside and out the neighborhood is safer, the apartment is larger." After Patrick Sullivan died in 1990, the management tried but failed to evict the grandson, whose right to stay on was affirmed in appellate court (Z.H. Control Company v. Sullivan).
On the other hand, lawyers say that the appellate court is taking a strict view of succession rights.
The outcome in the case of Peck v. Sutton last year suggests that people who begin to live much of the year out of town in retirement will have difficulty passing on succession rights even to family members who have lived with them for longer than two years. People cannot have dual residences and expect to keep the apartment in the family, said Sherwin Belkin, the lawyer who represented the owner.
In that case, a renter couple in a 51-unit co-op on West End Avenue and 74th Street had begun to live part of the year in Florida, and subsequently attempted to turn their apartment over to their daughter and son-in-law. They conceded to the court that the apartment was no longer their primary residence.
After Judge Arlene H. Hahn found that their children could not succeed them them as prime tenants, the couple accepted a six-figure settlement to drop their claim and move out in June. Safe from further litigation, the plaintiff -- the sponsor who converted the building to a co-op -- will be free to sell the apartment or rent it out. The couple was paying $2,300 a month; the rental value is said to be about $6,000 a month.
Building managers say that people will often come into an apartment as a sublessee, or perhaps a roommate, and hope to inherit it if the primary tenant turns out not to be returning. The primary tenant, on the other hand, often leaves the apartment not knowing for sure whether the departure is permanent or temporary, but hoping not to lose the right to return.
"They come to us asking to sublet," said Norman Buchbinder, a principal in Buchbinder & Warren, which manages about 100 buildings downtown. "But our policy is not to allow sublets unless we're sure the tenant will be returning." The law is that the right to sublet cannot be "unreasonably withheld."
Laws aside, nagging problems of equity enter the equation when families are endowed by government with the right to control the occupancy of other people's property indefinitely. For Mr. Neuwirth, the former rent administrator living for 56 years in a rent-controlled apartment, the answer lies in social policy -- how should society treat housing.
"It's a social policy to keep the middle class in the city," he said. "Succession rights keep families together. Isn't this an era of family values?"

HEADLINE: FUNDS WATCH

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:

Twice the Power, In Only Six Years
Despite all the talk about the impact of individual investors on the stock market, the huge shifts in market share among financial companies have been widely underappreciated, argues H. Bradley Perry, a consultant and the former chairman of David L. Babson & Company, investment counsultants in Cambridge, Mass. 
 In six years, the portion of financial assets managed by commercial banks and savings institutions has fallen to 37 percent from 49 percent, and the share controlled by life insurance companies has slipped a bit. The portion managed by mutual funds, meanwhile, has nearly doubled, to 21 percent from 11 percent.
The funds' rise has been fueled by individual investors and the rapid growth of defined-contribution retirement plans, especially 401(k) and 403(b) plans. As a result, mutual funds hold 12 percent of individual investors' financial assets, up from just 6 percent six years ago.
What does this mean? Consolidation among financial services companies will probably gain momentum as banks, insurance companies and investment firms that have focused on institutional money turn their sights to the rapidly growing individual-investor sector, Mr. Perry said. So combinations like that of Morgan Stanley and Dean Witter, Discover and that of Bankers Trust and Alex. Brown should proliferate.
 
Advice for Women
The Mutual Fund Education Alliance, a trade group for funds sold directly to the public, is devoting part of its World Wide Web site to women and investing (www.mfea.com).
The site, with direct links to 42 no-load fund companies, covers the basics of fund investing and offers personal commentary from women in the industry, sample investment portfolios and an investor survey.
A two-book education kit with a supplement for women is available from the alliance for $21.50 ($23 for Missouri residents). To order, send a check or money order to Women's Kit, Department 0148, Box 419263, Kansas City, Mo. 64193.
 
Starting Early
Most Americans say the best time to start consulting with a financial adviser is in your mid-20's, even if you have little money, according to a survey on financial preparedness released by Alliance Capital.
About 1,000 Americans were surveyed in early January by Louis Harris & Associates, and more than three-quarters of the respondents said people aged 25 to 30 should see a financial adviser. When asked how much money someone should have to invest before talking to an adviser, the median response was $9,000.
 
New Manager
Robert Amman, former co-manager of Founders Discovery, has become lead manager, replacing David Kern, who left the firm. Mr. Amman relinquished his role on the three-person team managing Founders Special.
 
New Funds
Third Avenue Small-Cap Value seeks capital appreciation by investing in companies with market capitalizations of less than $1 billion. It will be run by Martin J. Whitman, who manages Third Avenue Value, and Curtis Jensen, a research analyst with the firm.
 New York Opportunity Equity will invest in issues in New York State, which the fund sponsor, Pinnacle Investments, calls the world's 10th-largest economy, representing 8 percent of the United States economy. The fund plans to own 35 to 40 companies with headquarters in New York or significant business in the state. The initial portfolio will have 4 percent of its assets in each of these companies: Bank of New York, Bristol-Myers Squibb, Citicorp, Corning, Eastman Kodak, General Electric, I.B.M., Travelers and Xerox, and 3 percent in Texaco. The maximum sales charge is 4.75 percent.
 
In Brief
Ivy International, managed by Hakan Castegren, closed to new investors on April 18, though prospective investors who communicated their interest in buying shares in the preceding 30 days have three months from April 18 to do so. Existing shareholders can add to their positions. The fund sponsor plans to begin a new fund, Ivy International II, under another manager who has not yet been named.
Two Royce funds will disappear. Royce Equity Income will be swallowed up by Royce Total Return, and Pennsylvania Mutual is taking over Royce Value.
T. Rowe Price OTC has been renamed T. Rowe Price Small-Cap Stock.
Fidelity Investments has lowered the expense cap on four Spartan bond funds to 0.38 percent of assets from 0.65 percent. They are Spartan Ginnie Mae, Spartan Investment Grade Bond, Spartan Limited Maturity Government and Spartan Short-Term Bond.

LENGTH: 1259 words

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS;
Some Regulatory Rain On the Managers' Parade?

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT

 BODY:
THE mutual fund industry, the guardian of the retirement money of millions of Americans, has enjoyed a remarkable run in the last year.
A law enacted last fall exempted funds from oversight by state securities regulators -- something the industry had long sought. The Securities and Exchange Commission has moved to adopt rules that will make it easier for fund companies to sell shares by allowing them to use streamlined documents on disclosure. And, thanks to a roaring bull market and a continuing shift in how corporations provide for retirement benefits, the amount of money invested in money market, stock and bond funds grew more than 20 percent in the last 12 months, to $3.7 trillion. 
 But patches of clouds are appearing in these blue skies. As the officials of the 600 mutual fund companies that make up the Investment Company Institute, the industry trade group, prepare to convene on Wednesday in Washington for their annual meeting, the industry's chief regulators are circling.
Some of the regulatory attention is an outgrowth of the fund companies' gains in size and influence. Still, increased scrutiny often produces unflattering results -- usually as sanctions against fund companies and their managers.
"In recent years, there has been a marked increase in enforcement activity" by the S.E.C. against the fund business, said Thomas R. Smith Jr., a partner at the New York law firm Brown & Wood who specializes in mutual fund law.
He added, "I would contend that the threshold for action has gone down."
Commission officials say that they are not singling out the fund industry, but that they are simply following the money and individual investors. Nevertheless, the S.E.C. is preparing a report based on a broad examination of how fund companies and others account for and disclose to investors their "soft dollar" arrangements, in which brokerage firms provide indirect compensation to money managers, usually in the form of research, in exchange for transactions and the accompanying commissions. The S.E.C. is expected to take action soon against some specific companies and, after analyzing the information gathered, to consider new regulations on soft-dollar payments .
In recent statements, S.E.C. officials have outlined other mutual fund practices that the agency is studying closely: how management fees are set, how securities are allocated to various funds and how a fund portrays its performance in advertising.
The subject that has drawn the most attention, though, is soft dollars. The S.E.C.'s office of compliance inspections and examinations has just completed a study of 250 investment advisers, including fund managers, and 75 broker-dealers, to determine common industry practices on the use and disclosure of soft-dollar arrangements.
Soft-dollar payments, when made in exchange for investment research that benefits a money manager's client, are legal. But in 1986, the S.E.C. ruled that money managers who accept such payments must inform clients that their commissions might be used to pay for research.
"Research" can be broadly interpreted, to include services other than financial analysis. For instance, a money manager might allow a brokerage firm to pay for the money manager's office equipment or phone bills, if the client benefits. Those arrangements, too, must be disclosed, including specifics about what is provided.
Failure to disclose such arrangements has led to several enforcement actions recently. For example, the S.E.C. settled a case in February with Oakwood Counselors, a Morganville, N.J., firm with $46 million under management, after finding that Oakwood had collected almost $300,000 in soft-dollar arrangements that it had not disclosed. Oakwood, which neither admitted nor denied any wrongdoing, agreed to remit a total of $444,763, including fines and interest, to settle the matter.
Gene Gohlke, associate director of the S.E.C. inspections office, said a number of commission reviews had recently been referred to the enforcement division for further investigation. Along with failing to disclose soft-dollar arrangements, some firms may have engaged in outright fraud, Mr. Gohlke said, by converting soft-dollar benefits to their own use or by billing several brokerage firms for the same services.
After compiling its data on soft-dollar trends, the S.E.C. staff will consider whether to recommend changes in its 1986 rules.
Other recent enforcement actions have involved what the S.E.C. judged to be inflated claims about performance, and favoritism in allocating securities to various accounts.
S.E.C. officials also say they have begun to examine whether certain fund companies and their boards are negotiating management fees in ways that are not in the fund shareholders' best interests.
Few topics are more of a hot button in the industry than the management fee, the amount of money a fund company charges shareholders to pick securities for them. The management fee is usually the biggest portion of a fund's expenses, but it is largely arbitrary and subject to approval by the fund's board.
Simple economics suggests that as the amount of money managed by fund companies increases, the incremental cost of managing assets should fall. But in a study released last year, Morningstar Inc., the Chicago fund tracking company, found that the fund industry has, over time, raised management fees.
Mutual funds that were begun in the last two years charge an average management fee of 72 cents for every $100 invested, Morningstar found. That number, based on the fund's reported minimum fee, has risen steadily over the last 60 years from about 40 cents for every $100.
Commission officials declined to comment on the specifics of their inquiry into management fees. But one official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said the agency was particularly interested in funds that had consistently underperformed their peers while maintaining higher-than-average management fees.
With that general criterion in mind, Morningstar generated a list of 12 high-cost, poorly performing equity funds that charge management fees of at least 1 percent of assets and that have a minimum of $100 million under management. Funds were deemed to be poor performers if they ranked in the bottom 10 percent of their peer groups over the last three years.
There is nothing to indicate that these specific funds are the subject of an S.E.C. inquiry. But they should be of interest to investors, since their assets have reached a point where management fees might be expected to start falling.
No fund family dominates the list, though two funds each from American Century and Crabbe Huson show up.
American Century specializes in growth and momentum stocks, which have lagged behind the market in the last year. Its funds also charge a flat 1 percent fee for all expenses, so their total expense ratio is lower than the average fund's.
Crabbe Huson's funds generally use a contrarian investment approach, which recently has fallen out of favor. Also, Crabbe Huson began capping the expense ratio on some funds last year, thereby cutting its management fees to less than 1 percent.
Interestingly, the list contains no funds with management fees of more than 1.1 percent of assets, although Morningstar reports that nearly two dozen general American stock funds carry management fees of 1.5 percent or more.
Presumably, these funds are not at the bottom of their peer groups, which might make some of their high-priced managements rest a lot easier.

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Trying to Stoke the Campfire Again at Coleman

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD

 BODY:
IT'S Jerry W. Levin to the rescue. Again.
Eight years ago Ronald O. Perelman, the takeover artist, recruited Mr. Levin to run a newly acquired prize, the Coleman Company. Coleman was a venerable camping equipment manufacturer that had become an icon of the middle class, illuminating campsites and warming trail dinners for several generations, but had overexpanded and found itself floundering. Mr. Levin sold off nearly a third of the company and refocused on the core businesses. 
 Mr. Levin went on to turn around Revlon for Mr. Perelman, and then, several months ago, took on his latest assignment: refocusing Coleman, which had overexpanded again -- this time on Mr. Perelman's watch.
Attacking quickly, Mr. Levin has shut down a number of plants, cut 700 workers and sold some unneeded businesses. He is also closing down the company's new chalet-style, multimillion-dollar headquarters -- complete with log facing and two fireplaces -- near Denver, in Golden, Colo.
Partly as a result of these measures, the stock is up from about $12 in late December to $17.375 at Friday's close.
Though investors are naturally pleased at these signs of a turnaround, several analysts said there might be little opportunity in the stock because it already reflected expectations of a moderate improvement in profits in coming years. Only a sale of the company, the analysts speculated, will bring investors a price of much more than $20 a share in the near term.
"A lot of things have to come together now to justify this stock price," said Peter Barry, who follows Coleman for Deutsche Morgan Grenfell.
There is also skepticism over the ultimate plans of Mr. Perelman, who owns 83 percent of Coleman.
"I suspect that the ultimate exit strategy for Perelman is to sell it, and that is what we're thinking about," Mr. Barry said. "But I think they want a higher price than it's selling for now."
There may also be concerns over the fact that another company controlled by Mr. Perelman, Marvel Entertainment, filed for bankruptcy last year -- which some regard as a sign of his wavering interest in managing some of his companies. Some minority shareholders in Marvel have accused Mr. Perelman of putting his own interests ahead of theirs, while he says he has acted fairly, and the dispute is now tied up in court. Worries that serious business troubles and disputes might also arise at Coleman might possibly affect its stock.
"The stock price could be held back by that kind of thinking, although it is hard to quantify," said Beth Burnson, an analyst with the ABN Amro Chicago Corporation. "But at this stage I don't think Coleman is going to go the way of Marvel. It is definitely improving."
In an interview, Mr. Levin was adamant that Coleman was not for sale. He also said that Coleman was financially secure and that the company's new strategy would benefit all shareholders equally.
The company does have a large debt load -- about $570 million in long-term debt -- but it is refinancing nearly $500 million of high-yielding debt with an issue of new securities. Mr. Levin also said that, while he was perceived as a short-term chief executive when he moved over to Coleman in February, he now intends to stay for a couple of years, at least to carry out his longer-term strategy.
"We have a very high level of confidence in Jerry Levin," said Steve Eisenberg, an analyst with Oppenheimer & Company. "We're more positive because he's there, but we still need a few more quarters of evidence that he's really turning it around."
Last week, the company announced first-quarter results that were slightly better than expected. Revenues rose 8 percent from the year-earlier period, to $295.5 million, while net income, before some special charges, was $3.1 million, compared with $15 million in the first quarter of 1996. Along with the announcement of Mr. Levin's staying on, the earnings news gave the stock a $2 lift last Tuesday.
"They suffered a series of self-inflicted wounds," Mr. Levin said, explaining Coleman's recent troubles. "A number of little things went wrong, some of them out of their control. But growth was their mantra. They never got the infrastructure in place to handle the growth. The administrative expenses were out of control."
Mr. Levin emphasized, as did the analysts, that Coleman's strong suit remained a famous brand name and a loyal middle-class following that still equates the Coleman name with its signature green camp stoves, lanterns and ice chests.
"In the middle market, which they dominate, can you even think of the No. 2 company?" Ms. Burnson asked. "I can't imagine what it is. They are still very, very strong and they can build on that."
In the interview, Mr. Levin described a two-pronged battle plan: emphasizing growth overseas, especially in the fast-growing economies of Asia and Eastern Europe, and relying more on innovative products than on the old camp stoves and the like.
He said that Coleman currently received about 25 percent of its revenues overseas, and that the figure would rise steadily in coming years. The overseas push is already being helped by Coleman's acquisition last year of Camping Gaz, a French company that is strong in Europe.
Coleman is also benefiting from another acquisition, the Eastpak backpack company. Although Mr. Levin said that, in general, Coleman was going to reduce its number of products, the backpack line was expanding well both domestically and overseas.
Mr. Levin said that one of the first things he did when he rejoined Coleman was to look for innovative products that could help lead the company into the future. He said he found three.
They are a 22-pound, gas-powered electrical generator that is about one-third the weight of competitive products, a lightweight camping stove that uses a new technology for feeding the liquid fuel to the burner and a catalytic converter developed by Camping Gaz that burns fuel without a flame. Coleman is trying to turn the burner, which is currently very expensive to make, into a mass-produced consumer product.
"These things will drive the rest of our business," Mr. Levin said of the new technologies. "If we're going to succeed we're going to have to get innovation back into the equation."
And, not least, a consistent management focus.

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
It's My Party and I'll Spend if I Want To, Spend if I Want To . . .

BYLINE: By GERALDINE FABRIKANT

 BODY:
BABY boomers are breaking into their 50's at the rate of one every seven seconds, but few are likely to celebrate with as much elan as Josie Natori, the diminutive sleepwear designer. On Tuesday, May 20, at 7 P.M., Ms. Natori will raise her hands above the ebony and ivory at Carnegie Hall in Manhattan, where Churchill once thundered, Tchaikovsky once wept and Frank Sinatra once crooned, and plunk out Schumann's Piano Concerto in A Minor for 2,800 of her closest friends.
"I have chutzpah," giggled the Philippine-born entrepreneur, whose birthday was actually on Friday but who chose May 20 because that is the 25th anniversary of her marriage to Ken Natori, who is also her business partner. 
 "I can't believe it myself," she said.
As she talked about the event over lunch in her office at the company's headquarters on East 34th Street, she fiddled endlessly with a yellow wool scarf wrapped casually around her neck -- the only visible sign that she might be nervous.
On her big day, Ms. Natori will don a long silk dress of her own design and take center stage at Carnegie with the 85-member Orchestra of St. Luke's, which she has hired to perform for an array of guests including family, friends, customers, investment bankers and the news media.
Ms. Natori has a lot of company among the rich and famous who, in middle age, suddenly decide to enact a fantasy. Maybe the events that were supposed to be milestones in their younger days -- their Sweet 16 parties, senior proms, even weddings -- lacked pizazz. Or maybe they just want a rocking good time, and now they can afford it.
Consider Frank Marshall, the producer of Steven Spielberg's Indiana Jones and Back to the Future films and an amateur magician and guitarist. For his 50th birthday party last October, he invited 500 friends to U.C.L.A.'s 10,000-seat basketball arena to watch him perform.
The extravaganza -- the guest list included Goldie Hawn, Kurt Russell, Jeffrey Katzenberg, Michael Ovitz and other Hollywood heavies -- centered around music and magic. There were jugglers, fortune tellers, palm readers and even the actor Mark Harmon's celebrity baseball team. Bert Fields, the Hollywood lawyer, backed by the U.C.L.A. marching band, serenaded the birthday boy with a round of "Happy Birthday."
Mr. Marshall even got his buddy Jimmy Buffett to join him in warbling Mr. Buffett's trademark tune, "Margueritaville." But the high point of the gala for Mr. Marshall was a particular magic trick: "You haven't lived till you have sawed someone in half," he said.
Make that you haven't lived till you have sawed your better half in half. Mr. Marshall's wife and business partner, Kathleen Kennedy, was the one who succumbed to the blade.
After the job was done, somebody in the crowd shouted out, "Don't put her back together," he recalled.
Some people just can't wait until they hit 50 to celebrate themselves. Ethan Penner, who earned $23 million in 1995 from Nomura Securities, where he oversees real-estate loans, has a weakness for celebrities and has hired Elton John (whose own recent 50th birthday costume ball was festive, to say the least) and the Eagles rock group to entertain clients at business conferences.
So, on his 35th birthday, Mr. Penner's wife and friends gave him the thrill of his life: they paid Wilt Chamberlain and Julius Erving, two of the greatest professional basketball players of all time, in the neighborhood of $35,000 to join Mr. Penner and his pals for a game at Iona College in New Rochelle, N.Y. They played for four hours, and "I really had a great time," he said.
OTHER people celebrate later in life, and in a more sedate fashion. To mark his 60th birthday in January 1994, James Wolfensohn, who then headed his own investment banking boutique and is now president of the World Bank, took over Carnegie Hall, where he entertained about 500 friends by playing the cello with pals including the violinists Isaac Stern and Itzhak Perlman. At that time, Mr. Wolfensohn had already stepped down as chairman of Carnegie Hall.
Certainly, no one undertakes such an effort for business reasons alone. But it doesn't hurt. Ms. Natori's guest list will include notables of the fashion world like Allen I. Questrom, outgoing chairman of of Federated Department Stores; Philip B. Miller, chief executive of Saks Fifth Avenue; Michael Gould, chief executive of Bloomingdale's, and James E. Preston, chairman of Avon, which handles Ms. Natori's perfumes. And, of course, there will be a clutch of other designers, including Adrienne Vittadini, Pauline Trigere and Vera Wang.
Though Ms. Natori is associated with her ultra-feminine sleepwear and lingerie, she was a piano prodigy in the Philippines, where she had performed before 800 people twice by the time she was 19.
"But I grew up knowing I wanted to be in business," she said. "I never considered music for a minute. I didn't have the temperament."
She also had no qualms about wanting to be self-sufficient.
"My father was an entrepreneur in the real estate business," she recalled. "My mother and my grandmother both encouraged me to be independent. The Philippines is a very matriarchal and very entrepreneurial society."
NOR did her family mind sending her to New York in 1964, when she was only 17, to study. She enrolled at Manhattanville College in Purchase, N.Y., graduating with honors in economics. From there, she went to Wall Street, opening an office in Manila for Bache & Company before switching to Merrill Lynch and rising there to become the first woman vice president in investment banking.
Nine years of high finance would be enough. By 1977, she had married Ken Natori, a director at Shearson Lehman, and she longed for both the autonomy and the opportunity for self-expression that she believed she could find as an entrepreneur.
"Wall Street lacked an artistic element," she said. "Some people say deals are creative, but I don't know if that's true."
So she visited her native land, looking for products that might be a hit in the United States.
First, and bought a bunch of hand-woven baskets, figuring that she could sell them to big American retail chains. She couldn't. Next she went into Philippine-made blouses, only to be told by a buyer from Bloomingdale's that she ought to make them into nightshirts.
She did, and her business took off. In 1986, Ken Natori quit Wall Street to join her as chairman, focusing on the financial side. Today, they share an office in their Manhattan headquarters.
From nightshirts, the business expanded into undergarments for women -- and her very inexperience in the garment trade gave her an edge, she believes. "When I first came into this business, lingerie was still considered one of two things -- kinky or something your grandmother wears," Ms. Natori once said. She sought to change that. "I treated lingerie like clothes because I didn't know any differently," she recalled. "I wasn't brought up in the fashion business."
For all her success on Wall Street and on Seventh Avenue, Ms. Natori never forgot music. She continued to play it at parties and attended concerts. Then, in 1994, she became serious about giving a concert as part of her 50th birthday party.
With help from her teacher, Robert DeGaetano, she has been practicing about five or six hours a day on the weekends.
"I really try to concentrate, but last week, I had a very bad week, and Robert had to be on my case. He called all the time to make sure I am practicing," Ms. Natori conceded ruefully. She said she chose the Schumann A minor concerto because it was "romantic and also something I could handle."
When she first got the idea to give a concert, she figured she would invite about 500 people.
But "me and my big mouth, when I saw people, I kept saying, 'Come to the concert,' " she said. Her husband did the same. The list grew.
"I see my life passing in front of my eyes," she said. "All our worlds will be at the concert: Wall Street, fashion" and about 100 family members from the Philippines, Seattle and Japan. (Mr. Natori is Japanese-American.)
"My father doesn't know much about music," she said. "He once began to applaud before the concert was over, but he wants to sit in the front row, and so he will."
LUCKILY, Ms. Natori can handily afford the event. The Natori Company, which now includes fragrances, generated about $80 million in sales last year. The price tag for the evening is about $500,000 -- including the hall, the orchestra, the airplane tickets and all the extras. And, as long as the guest list brims with enough clients and business acquaintances, a good chunk of it may well be tax deductible.
Mr. Marshall, the movie producer, did not even want to know how much his party cost. His business manager paid the bills.
"You're only 50 once," he said cheerfully. "I just wanted to have a great event."
"The party sort of started small and then mushroomed into a 50th birthday party reunion. It turned into a celebration of turning 50 for a lot of people," he said. "When I started going through the guest list, I thought, 'I can't invite this person without inviting that person.' Pretty soon the numbers were swelling. It ended up being about 500."
Ms. Natori hit a much higher number, in part because she will be celebrating two events -- her birthday and her 1972 wedding, which, with only 70 people attending, was a relatively tiny affair. The night after the concert, the Natoris will renew their vows and hold a dinner for the family.
That will be the icing on the cake, so to speak. In the meantime, Ms. Natori had butterflies last week about the concert. "I can't believe I am doing it myself," she said. "Now it is too late to back out."
And however friendly the audience may be, she will still be playing to a tough crowd. At a time when a lot of women her age are reaching for the concealing cream to hide their wrinkles, she is flaunting her age before a crowd of fashionphiles.
"I think it is terrific," said Mr. Questrom of Federated. "She is not afraid of being 50. She is celebrating it. She is giving it a new spin."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Josie Natori, above, hopes they won't laugh when she sits down to play at Carnegie Hall on May 20. Not to be outdone, rock star Elton John, right, en route to his 50th birthday gala last month. (Robin Graubard for The New York Times; Associated Press); Frank Marshall, the Hollywood producer, being hoisted mosh-pit style, top, by guests at his 50th birthday last October. An amateur magician, he delighted the crowd, above, by sawing his better half in half. To top it all off, he got to warble with idol Jimmy Buffett.

HEADLINE: HEALTH CARE'S GIANT -- When Hospitals Play Hardball;
A Hospital Chain's Brass Knuckles, and the Backlash

BYLINE: By MARTIN GOTTLIEB and KURT EICHENWALD

 BODY:
MOTORISTS in West Palm Beach, Fla., were recently confronted by a billboard 100 yards from the Wellington Regional Medical Center. "Why Stop Here?" it asked.
The sign advertised a nearby rival, the Columbia Palms West Hospital, owned by the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation. The billboard was a literal sign of the times from Columbia, the world's largest health care company. 
 No other operator of hospitals has become so successful or so big so fast in the increasingly cost-conscious system of American medicine. At the heart of that achievement is an aggressively competitive vision of medical care, one that applies the practices of corporate America to an industry still dominated by not-for-profit institutions.
These practices include not only in-your-face marketing, but hospital takeovers, cost-cutting and layoffs, volume purchasing, complex pricing strategies and large monetary incentives for managers who meet financial targets.
The formula has helped the company grow in a decade from nothing to $20 billion in revenues, with roughly 350 hospitals, 550 home-health-care offices and scores of other medical businesses in 38 states. Columbia says it is a model for efficient, high-quality health care. And indeed, the company is widely admired for driving a long-wasteful industry to change, and its strategies are often copied.
But now some of the very things that propelled Columbia are troubling people inside and outside the company, in some cases producing a backlash:
* The company intensely pressures managers to raise profits by cutting costs and increasing patient revenues. Administrators have been able to almost double their salaries through bonuses based almost entirely on meeting financial targets. By contrast, about half of the industry does not offer bonuses, and hospitals that do usually tie them more closely to standards like mortality rates and programs that benefit the community. Some doctors, nurses and administrators, angered by rapid staff cuts that raise profits, are questioning whether care is being compromised -- an accusation that the company sharply disputes.
* Columbia markets itself with assertions that its prices are lower and its quality higher than its competitors'. Yet a computer analysis for The New York Times shows that the median price paid for patients in Columbia hospitals is 8 percent higher than the norm. And there is no conclusive evidence that Columbia's care is better than that provided elsewhere.
* Columbia has used bare-knuckled competitive tactics once rarely seen in the hospital industry. Critics say the company can be unnecessarily ruthless and even petty when it does not get its way, from suing communities that reject its efforts to acquire hospitals to maintaining a skeletal hospital with only two inpatient beds, in order to avoid surrendering a valued operating license. From San Diego to Providence, communities wary of Columbia's hardball tactics have recently resisted its attempts to buy local hospitals.
On top of this, the company is the subject of several Federal inquiries. Criminal investigators raided its operations in El Paso two months ago and scores of Federal agents have been interviewing doctors and others familiar with the company's practices around the country.
The Federal agency that runs Medicare is also investigating whether certain Columbia hospitals have systematically overbilled the Government by overstating the severity of the illnesses they treat. It is also studying whether doctors who invest in Columbia hospitals and regional health systems violate the law by referring patients to outpatient services, like home care, in which they have investments.
Columbia executives dismiss criticism as anecdotal misinformation from disgruntled employees or others who do not understand the company. They say that while Columbia is aggressive, it plays fair.
Richard L. Scott, chief executive of Columbia, said his company was only responding to demands to curb runaway medical costs. "There's no way, as taxpayers, as employers, as employees, as individuals, people are going to pay what they paid in the past for health care," he said. "So if you say, 'O.K., that's true,' then we've got to change."
A result, the company proclaims in advertisements, is health care that "has never worked like this before."
 
The Beginnings
The Entrepreneur As a Maverick
 Mr. Scott, 44, is lean and driven, almost a personal model for his company. He typically begins his days with 5 A.M. workouts. He neither smokes nor drinks.
"I've never heard him use a four-letter word," said David Colby, a former chief financial officer with the company.
Mr. Scott grew up in Kansas City, Mo., where his father was a truck driver and his mother worked, among other jobs, as a clerk at J. C. Penney. While in college, he made his first foray into business with his mother and brother, buying and reviving two Kansas City doughnut shops.
After graduating from Southern Methodist University Law School, he did legal work for hospital companies. But he had other goals. In 1987, he created the Columbia Hospital Corporation with Richard E. Rainwater, a Texas financier. Each invested $125,000 and sought money on Wall Street. Mr. Scott was the operations man, although he had never run a hospital.
In 1988, the company spent $48 million, most of it borrowed, on its first purchase, two down-at-the-mouth hospitals in El Paso. Over the next few years, Columbia scooped up hospitals one by one, mainly in Texas and Florida. But its big steps came in 1993 and 1994, when it absorbed the more than 160 hospitals of the industry's earlier leaders, the Humana Corporation and the Hospital Corporation of America, known as HCA, both of which were faltering. Humana and HCA had prospered since the 1960's, but stalled in the 80's when Medicare and private insurers began limiting reimbursements. Struggling, Humana had spun off its 75 hospitals into a new company, Galen Health Care, which Columbia later purchased.
That Columbia, with 25 hospitals, could swallow Galen and HCA was a testament to the attractiveness of its stock. In each case, the company offered some of its rapidly appreciating shares in exchange for the lackluster stock of its target.
The company renamed itself Columbia/ HCA. In 1995, Columbia absorbed another large chain, Healthtrust, which had 117 hospitals, also by offering Columbia shares.
Today, Columbia is the largest health care provider in dozens of American towns and cities, including Atlanta, Denver, Houston, Miami and Nashville, where it is based. Since going public in 1990 Columbia's shares have more than quadrupled in value, to a high this year of $44.875. In just the last five years, the company's market capitalization has ballooned from a low in 1992 of about $2 billion to more than $25 billion today. The company's shares closed Friday at $36.625.
This notwithstanding, Mr. Scott portrays Columbia as a maverick challenging the medical establishment. Columbia may run roughly half of America's 700 for-profit hospitals, he notes, but most of the nation's 5,200 hospitals are not-for-profit institutions.
However wary they may be of Columbia, rivals from this sphere often acknowledge Mr. Scott's business acumen. "Here's a fellow with a law degree who has not spent one day in the traditional administration of a hospital who has outsmarted people with years more experience," said Peter Young, a consultant for nonprofit hospitals.

Formula for Success
Record of Reviving Troubled Hospitals
Cedars Medical Center in Miami was struggling when Columbia assumed control in 1993. Today the company holds Cedars up as an example of how to turn a hospital around.
Columbia poured money into the emergency room and the radiology suites and purchased a battery of high-technology medical machinery. Doctors were offered investments in the hospital, allowing them to share in its profits.
Columbia sliced costs by closing a nearby hospital and cutting Cedars's staff. Today the 1,600 Cedars employees care for roughly the same number of patients as 2,300 workers once did at both hospitals. Cedars also benefits from Columbia's size, which allows it to demand discounts on everything from soft drinks to surgical supplies.
Cedars became part of a Columbia regional network that includes not only hospitals but outpatient surgery centers, home care agencies and other facilities. Such services attract insurers because they cost less than hospitalization. Columbia also benefits because Medicare payments for such services can be far more lucrative than those for hospital care. Columbia also began to bill Medicare far more aggressively for inpatient care at Cedars.
Today, admissions at Cedars are booming. Outpatient procedures have doubled. Profits have ballooned more than 15-fold, to $30 million last year. "Columbia saved this institution," Dr. Arthur Katzman, a vascular surgeon, said.
"Has Columbia built a better mousetrap in the competitive world of health care?" said Joe Swedish, a Columbia executive who spent more than 20 years working for not-for-profit hospitals. "I believe it has."
That belief is hardly universal.

Pressure for Profits
Managers Answer To Wall St. Investors
Mark E. Singer will attest to the pressure Columbia managers feel to meet profit goals.
Last August, executives from Columbia's Midwest division ordered Mr. Singer and 14 other department heads at Michael Reese Hospital and Medical Center in Chicago into the hospital board room to lambaste them, one by one, for failing to cut costs aggressively enough, recalled Mr. Singer, administrative director for medicine at the time. (His job has since been eliminated.)
Mr. Singer was stunned by his treatment. "My father owned and operated a millinery factory in the garment district, and I never witnessed such an extent of demeaning, debasing and devaluing behavior in the tough street environment as I personally experienced on 29 August," he wrote to the hospital's chief operating officer.
In his case, Mr. Singer recalled, the team's ire focused first on the admission of three patients with no insurance to a special heart unit. In an interview, he said he had previously been instructed by the chief operating officer of the hospital not to admit "self pays" to the unit, and indeed the medical director of the unit, Dr. Earl Silber, confirmed that Mr. Singer had informed him of this policy in 1995. Columbia denies having such a policy and Dr. Silber said the unit always found a way to accept such patients regardless of the instructions he received from Mr. Singer.
Columbia administrators who meet their profit goals win big bonuses. Those who don't, forgo their bonuses -- and sometimes lose their jobs.
In 1995, 25 percent of Columbia's administrators won bonuses of at least 80 percent of their salaries, according to the Advisory Board, a consulting company. Thirty percent received none.
Company records show that at least 90 percent of the 1995 bonuses were based on financial performance. Where hospitals operate in regional networks, for example, 40 percent of their bonuses was based on reaching a pretax profit target at the hospital and 50 percent on profits in the network or division.
Ten percent of the bonus was discretionary. But the company suggested that this be based on revenue-producing yardsticks like "growth in admissions and surgery cases."
A company spokeswoman said that beginning next year bonuses would be paid based partly on the results of patient satisfaction surveys at hospitals, but she declined to say how much those results would affect bonuses. She said the company had also suggested that managers could use doctor and employee satisfaction surveys in determining bonuses.
Other hospital operators use annual bonuses, but Columbia is among the most aggressive. Every Columbia hospital has such programs, compared with about 57 percent for the industry as a whole, according to the Hay Group, a consulting firm. Among government-operated and not-for-profit hospitals, 47 percent use financial incentives.
And the average amount paid in bonuses at not-for-profit hospitals is far lower than that paid at for-profits. According to Hay, not-for-profits pay an average of 19.7 percent of salary to top administrators as an incentive bonus; for-profit hospitals pay an average of 41.5 percent.
Moreover, while executives in the not-for-profit sector are rewarded for financial performance, monetary incentives are heavily weighted toward other achievements like low death rates and programs to benefit local communities, said Dr. William Liccione, a senior consultant at Hay.
Then there is the threat of losing one's job. In 1995, 100 of about 350 Columbia hospital administrators were replaced, according to the Advisory Board, and while many were promoted or left voluntarily, the consulting company found, large numbers were "moved out" of the organization.
The company makes no apologies for setting hard goals. "Do I believe that people feel like there's high expectations?" Mr. Scott said in an interview. "Sure. But I'm not uncomfortable with that."
Pressure to meet profit targets, the head of one Columbia hospital explained, comes from Wall Street, especially because the company has paid for acquisitions with stock. Mr. Colby, the former chief financial officer, described how Wall Street's expectations make their way to the local hospital. Columbia sets targets for yearly profit growth -- typically about 15 percent. Each of the company's regional managers must deliver his or her prescribed portion. Regional executives, in turn, give hospital administrators targets to meet.
When a hospital lags behind, administrators can be called to task, more than a dozen past and present company executives said. "The message was very clear that either you would achieve these goals or they would find someone who would achieve those goals," one former hospital administrator said.
Samuel Greco, a vice president for operations, said he was disturbed by accounts of harsh treatment, which he said were remnants from companies Columbia absorbed. "Treating people with anything less than dignity and professionalism is absolutely unacceptable in any way," he said.
Few of the administrators critical of the company were willing to speak for attribution for fear of reprisal. One, John Leifer, a former senior vice president, said such fear was understandable. Last month, he wrote in an industry publication that he had resigned in part because of conflicts with company policies. He said that he had since been contacted by a senior Columbia executive who indicated "that I would be hearing from their legal department in short order."
Mr. Leifer added: "When I signed up for the organization, I believed in the gospel of Rick Scott. Suffice it to say, I've lost my faith."

Treatment Concerns
Of Financial Health And Patient Care
 The pressure to meet financial targets concerns some nurses, doctors and other professionals at Columbia.
"You have a highly decentralized system that grants a lot of autonomy to local and regional officers, and those officers have very significant monetary incentives tied to the net profitability of their markets," Mr. Leifer said. "I feel that this could be a prescription for disaster, because it can create tremendous temptation to make budget at times by inappropriate action."
There is no definitive evidence that the care at Columbia is better or worse than that provided elsewhere. Company executives said they monitored how patients fared to insure a high level of medical care. And some doctors and nurses said that care at hospitals acquired by Columbia had remained the same or improved even after personnel were cut. At Columbia Medical City Hospital in Dallas, for example, Dr. Winfred Parnell, the former chief of staff, said that standards had not slipped since the hospital was owned by Humana. "The quality of care had always been very high and we have not noticed any change," he said.
But others around the country expressed concern about their hospitals. In 1995, Columbia Women's Hospital in Indianapolis shrank its nursing staff and cut some nurses' pay. The result was an acute nursing shortage, with more responsibilities turned over to lesser-trained technicians.
Problems quickly arose. In July 1995, Dr. Bonnie Miller found herself caring for a newborn with breathing problems without the help of a qualified nurse. The baby pulled through, but Dr. Miller was disturbed.
In a letter to the hospital administrator, she wrote, "I hope that our quality of care at the Women's Hospital of Indianapolis would not be jeopardized by your endeavor to save money."
Despite the complaint, no changes were made. In January 1996, Kathryn Calahan, a nursing technician, who is qualified to handle certain nursing duties, arrived for work in the neonatal intensive-care unit. She was paired with a nurse who also had little training in the critical care of infants.
Ms. Calahan expressed her concerns to her superiors. The response was quick, according to state records and interviews. Ms. Calahan was told that if she was unwilling to accept the assignment, she could find employment elsewhere, according to nurses and state records. Columbia said it does not comment on personnel matters.
Nurses and doctors had begun contacting the state health department. And a state inspection soon found widespread problems.
Nursing levels were short around the hospital, according to the inspection report. The neonatal intensive-care unit was in particular disarray. Investigators found technicians -- without appropriate supervision from registered nurses -- handling complex tasks like inserting feeding tubes in premature newborns. Babies were attended as infrequently as every three hours. Once, the only nurse caring for seven ill infants was so busy she failed to hear an alarm when a baby stopped breathing. A parent dashed to the baby and stimulated breathing, the state report said.
The findings led to a $25,000 fine. Columbia settled the Indianapolis case without admitting wrongdoing, paying $12,500. A Columbia spokeswoman said the company worked closely with the state, adding that the state had since found the hospital in compliance.
But concerns about the adequacy of nursing care and the competence of support staff emerged in interviews with doctors, nurses, patients and volunteers at Columbia hospitals.
At Columbia Orange Park Medical Center outside Jacksonville, Fla., Cheryl Lorenzo, a nurse for 13 years who was highly regarded by the hospital, was part of an exodus last year after a reorganization. "With the current patient load of a minimum of 15 patients, you are sacrificing safety and care," Ms. Lorenzo wrote in her resignation letter last April. "I lie awake at night going over and over in my mind the events of the day. Did I do what needed to be done?"
Doctors express similar concerns. "Somebody's going to get hurt; we've come close to that," said Dr. Jamal Modir, a general surgeon at Good Samaritan Hospital in San Jose, Calif., who last year, a few months after Columbia took over, bemoaned nursing cuts and shake-ups that led to the replacement of many of the hospital's experienced nurses. He said he was striving to work with the hospital's chief executive to correct many of the problems. "Many times we don't know the nurses," he said. "When I get a call at night, should I depend on what she says? I don't know."
At Columbia Audubon Hospital in Louisville, Ky., Dr. Alan Lansing, a leading heart surgeon, recalled his distress last year when his cadre of nurses began to disperse through a staff reorganization. Many were transferred to other units; other nurses quit. He complained to administrators, who assured him that quality had not been compromised.
"I think the people who decided it didn't know much about how hospitals run or how staffs function," Dr. Lansing said. "These people don't understand about quality of care. And they don't want to listen to those of us who do."
Columbia executives dispute that there are any quality shortfalls at their hospitals, and say that much of the concern stems from doctors and nurses facing a world of medicine that is being forced to change for economic reasons.
Moreover, they said that the company was working to make patients fare even better. At Audubon, for example, Dr. Stephen Newman, president of Columbia's Louisville operations, said that the hospital closely examined such patient data to insure that it maintained the highest quality.
He also acknowledged that communications between administrators and doctors had been "suboptimal" in the past, but said that the company had begun efforts to improve that through regular meetings with doctors, task forces and other initiatives.
Reorganizations have created upheaval at for-profit and not-for-profit hospitals alike, and Columbia is by no means alone in generating criticism. Beyond savings, the theory behind the practice is that even with fewer workers, patients will receive better care because duties will be better organized.
But advocates of this practice say that to minimize disruption, administrators must extensively consult employees while introducing the procedures over as long as a year.
Columbia's time frame is much shorter, several former administrators say.
One former administrator who works for a not-for-profit hospital said a training process that is taking six months at his current employer had to be done in as little as two weeks at Columbia.
Columbia executives acknowledged pushing to conclude the training quickly, but said this could be positive. "The speed at which we ask folks to evaluate and implement re-engineering I'm sure is much quicker than what the industry has been used to," Mr. Greco, the senior vice president for operations, said. "If you study good companies and great companies over time, it would seem that when they've made changes, they've made changes swiftly."

Raising Revenues
When Costs Are Cut But Prices Are Not
"We can provide a better product at a better price," Mr. Scott proclaimed in an interview in 1994. And over the years, in its advertising and presentations in communities, Columbia has repeated that.
Columbia would have trouble convincing Nancy Brown.
In September 1995, Ms. Brown, an aerobics instructor, wrenched her knee. Four months later, she underwent surgery at Columbia Palms West Hospital in West Palm Beach. As she recalls, the surgery lasted about 20 minutes, her stay about four hours.
There were no complications -- until the bill arrived. Columbia charged Ms. Brown $32 for an ice pack, $34.50 for a sterile Ace bandage and $12.50 for a pair of surgical gloves. Two milligrams of Versed, a sedative that sells for roughly $4 wholesale, was billed at $29.03. A solution of the sedative Diprivan, about $12 wholesale, was billed at $102.18.
The total bill: $5,921.
"I was in shock," said Ms. Brown, whose insurance covered less than half the cost. "This digs into college funds."
While Columbia lowers prices for health maintenance organizations and employers that can provide many patients, many others are not so lucky. Ms. Brown lost out because she and her husband are self-employed and buy their insurance individually rather than as part of a large group, said her lawyer, Scott R. Shepherd, who has filed a class action that accuses Columbia of systematic overbilling.
Of course, many hospital bills include high charges for seemingly small items. But for many customers, Columbia bills higher and collects more than competitors. An analysis performed for The New York Times using the most recent data available, from 1995, shows that the median charge for a hospital stay at Columbia, before any discounts, was $2,300, or 35 percent higher per patient than the industry norm, when differences in regional wages for employees and the mix of cases are considered.
These days, most insurers negotiate discounts, and full prices are rarely paid. Yet the analysis shows that even when discounts and managed-care contracts are considered, Columbia's prices for in-the-hospital services are higher than average. In 1995, the last year for which complete data are available, the amount paid for the median-priced stay in a Columbia hospital was $4,370 -- 8 percent higher than that at other hospitals after accounting for differences in regional wages and the mix of cases.
The data also showed that Columbia's median cost for providing care to a patient was 1.5 percent less than other hospitals'. In other words, while cost-cutting saved the company money, many patients did not see the savings.
The study was performed by the Center for Health Care Industry Performance Studies at Ohio State University, which publishes an authoritative annual compendium of hospital data.
"Columbia has much higher prices and slightly lower costs," said William O. Cleverly, a professor of finance who runs the center. "The reason they make more money, the majority of it, is related to prices, not cost."
Professor Cleverly said one reason Columbia could charge more is that many of its hospitals are in affluent areas where most residents are well-insured. He said Columbia also benefited from its high prices because many insurance plans negotiate to pay a percentage of the full price; if the full price is higher, they pay more.
David Manning, a Columbia vice president, disputed the findings and said the company's success proved that its prices were competitive: "In today's competitive health-care system, it is inconceivable that hospitals can be successful if their pricing is out of line with the market."
Mr. Manning took issue with the way the Ohio State research group analyzed Columbia's price data. "Of the available measures, you have selected the one that puts Columbia in the least favorable light," he said. Columbia itself has bought raw data from the Ohio State unit, but chose not to analyze it in the manner used by those researchers and by many consulting organizations. Instead, the company used three other methods based on averages instead of medians. Using two of those, Columbia found its prices to be roughly 5 percent higher than the norm. Only one method showed Columbia with better prices, at 7 percent below the average for all other hospitals. But that method did not exclude hospitals with the most extreme high and low prices, as is generally done to avoid skewing the outcomes.
Beyond its charges to patients, Columbia has come under Government scrutiny for its bills to Medicare. The agency that runs the program is investigating whether, to reap higher reimbursements, certain Columbia hospitals overstated the seriousness of illnesses they treated.
In a statement, Columbia said it expected employees to follow the law and that if mistakes were made it would correct them.

The Rating Game
Varied Definitions Of Hospital Quality
 As evidence of the quality of care at their hospitals, Columbia executives cite accolades from the chief hospital accreditation group and an industry consultant's study, and say that their hospitals receive high marks on patient-satisfaction surveys the company commissions. But measuring quality is an imprecise science. And awards for quality often reflect factors that do not directly affect care, like financial performance and hiring procedures.
For example, Columbia advertises that 17 of its hospitals were named to a list assembled by Mercer Health Care Provider Consulting of the nation's top 100 hospitals. Last year, one of them was the Florida hospital with the billboard, Palms West, and in fact the billboard advertised "Top 100 in the U.S.A." While some of the study's standards deal with patient care, the majority measure financial performance. Moreover, the list is based on how hospitals compared with others of similar size and nature. The result is that a small hospital like Columbia's Horizon Medical Center in Dickson, Tenn., can make the list, while nationally acclaimed centers like the Mayo Clinic and Massachusetts General do not.
Another achievement cited by Columbia comes from the Joint Commission on Accreditation of Healthcare Organizations, the main hospital accreditation group. Nearly 30 percent of the company's hospitals have been awarded the commission's highest honors, compared with about 4 percent of all hospitals.
Commission officials say their survey measures the quality of care, but many experts question whether it adequately measures what is happening at the bedside. For example, the commission studies how hospitals monitor whether nurses are licensed. But it does not look at the ratio of nurses to patients or the appropriateness of many treatments they deliver.
The result, these critics say, is that a hospital with its paperwork in order can pass the commission's reviews with flying colors, even as the hospital's medical staff is decrying poor- care.
"We spend a lot of time doing paper trails for the J.C.A.H.O.," said one doctor on the quality-assurance committee at Columbia's Orange Park Medical Center, who insisted on anonymity. "There is very little time spent any more on actual quality."

Hanging Tough
A Company's Wrath When It Is Scorned
 For all its size, Columbia portrays itself as a collection of locally run hospitals that provide free community and charitable services. "Our facilities are locally managed by hometown people who share the values and interests of their communities," the company says on its Internet site.
But in many communities, the company has earned a reputation as an outsider willing to throw its weight around to get what it wants..
Federal investigators have interviewed at least five hospital executives in Florida who said the company offered jobs and perquisites to them or to their associates while negotiating with them about taking over their hospitals. Federal bribery laws prohibit such enticements, but the investigators recommended against prosecution in these cases because of the small value of the enticements and because the evidence involved conversations difficult to corroborate.
A few other pages from the Columbia scrapbook:
* When Lawrence Hospital, a community-owned facility in Lawrence, Kan., refused three buyout offers from Columbia, the company took an option on property nearby and sought to build a competing hospital. "We like to say here that they approached us in a very aggressive manner to marry them," said Ray Davis, chairman of the hospital board. "And when we said no, they decided they were going to kill us."
Earlier this year, at a meeting where hundreds of local residents showed up to oppose Columbia's efforts, the city commission unanimously voted to block construction. Columbia is suing the city.
* In 1994, Columbia announced its desire to close a money-losing 52-bed hospital in Destin, Fla., but it did not want to relinquish what was perhaps the hospital's most valuable asset -- its hard-to-come-by state operating license. So Columbia continued to run the facility as America's tiniest hospital, with two inpatient beds, the smallest number permissible. State inspectors later found that the company was not even maintaining those beds properly.
* As nurses at Audubon Medical Center in Louisville were preparing to vote on whether to join a union, David Vandewater, Columbia's chief operating officer, warned them that if the vote to approve the union succeeded, the company would refuse to negotiate, according to a legal complaint brought by the National Labor Relations Board. Last month, an administrative law judge ruled that the hospital had violated Federal labor laws through a series of actions and ordered it to negotiate with the nurses immediately.
"I do think there's a pattern here, and it's really tragic," said John Cusack, a lawyer who has locked horns with Columbia on behalf of several not-for-profit hospitals.
Many of these stories have another side, Columbia officials said. In Lawrence, Jamie Hopping, president of Columbia's western operations, said that the company was proceeding with its efforts to build a hospital despite the opposition because it believed the facility was needed and because it had the support of numerous community leaders.
In Destin, company officials said the hospital simply wasn't financially viable, but that they had worked hard to come up with other medical uses for it.
Mr. Vandewater said that at Audubon he was misunderstood about the company's willingness to negotiate with a union, and had only intended to tell nurses that he personally would not be among the negotiators. As for the administrative law judge's finding, the company said it planned to appeal.

Recent Setbacks
Some New Projects Stall at Roadblocks
Columbia last year set its sights west and north, from California to Rhode Island. Suddenly it began to taste defeat with unaccustomed regularity.
Its experience in Rhode Island was typical. Columbia struck a deal to buy the Roger Williams Medical Center in Providence. The state had no for-profit hospitals, and Representative Patrick J. Kennedy, a Democrat, said he began to look into Columbia. "It didn't take me long to know what common sense already told me: that this wasn't the kind of hospital I wanted for my community," he said.
Soon, Mr. Kennedy arranged forums that became rallying points for opponents Columbia had collected as it rose to prominence. Nurses who had battled Columbia's staff cuts testified; state attorneys general who had fought the company sent in statements.
Finally, last month the state Health Commissioner put the deal on hold while she undertook an extensive review.
Columbia's failure to move forward in Rhode Island was not isolated. The attorneys general of Michigan and California rejected major Columbia hospital deals in Lansing and San Diego. The Ohio Insurance Department rejected the company's agreement to take over the assets of Ohio Blue Cross. In many communities, groups have rallied against hospital takeovers by Columbia, sometimes under the slogan of "ABC," or "anyone but Columbia."
The aggressive business tactics that worked so well for the fledgling company have not played as well now. Most frequently cited are concerns that Columbia is buying hospitals on the cheap without enough assurances that it will continue to offer the same level of charity care or clinical services.
The resistance comes as Columbia counts on expanding comprehensive networks of hospitals and other medical services. And with its stock price down almost 20 percent in recent months during the Government investigations and collapsed deals, Columbia stock has not been as attractive to the shareholders of target companies.
The company is trying several new tactics to keep growing. For one, it is giving fresh attention to overseas acquisitions. And it is building 12 hospitals around the United States.
As for criticism, Mr. Scott has always expected it in his effort to transform the hospital industry. That was his message in a letter sent to tens of thousands of Columbia doctors in December 1994.
"I am reminded of an old passage about change that was recently sent to me," he wrote. " 'There is nothing more difficult to carry out, nor more doubtful of success, nor more dangerous to handle, than to initiate a new order of things. For the reformer has enemies in all who profit by the old order, and only lukewarm defenders in all those who profit by the new order.' "
Perhaps most telling was the passage's unidentified source. As he reflected on an industry in which thousands of institutions are named for saints and samaritans, Mr. Scott was quoting Machiavelli, the master analyst of political cunning.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: ROOSEVELT ISLAND;
Residents Want Answers on State Money

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
Ever since Gov. George E. Pataki eliminated millions of dollars in state subsidies for Roosevelt Island last year, the Governor's administrator for the island, Jerome H. Blue, has found himself the lightning rod for residents angry over the cuts.
Now, however, the level of hostility has escalated, with residents and elected officials accusing Mr. Blue of failing to provide information on how he is spending the money allocated. The officials, led by Assemblyman Alexander B. Pete Grannis, threaten to subpoena Mr. Blue and hold him in contempt if he does not provide details by Friday. 
 The president of the island's tenants association, Patrick Stewart, said that Mr. Blue had given only partial answers to budget questions and that the group had had to resort to nearly a dozen requests under the Federal Freedom of Information Act. "These are obstructionist tactics," he said, "and a lot of people over here are just mad as hell."
"I need information," Mr. Grannis said. "If he doesn't ask for the money, I can't fight for it. If he says we're O.K., we won't spend the money, I'm stymied." If Mr. Blue does not comply, Mr. Grannis said he will convene a public forum and subpoena Mr. Blue. A recent letter sent by Mr. Grannis and others to Mr. Blue said his earlier response to inquiries was "not acceptable."
The letter was signed by three Democrats: Mr. Grannis; Councilman A. Gifford Miller, and Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, as well as a Republican, State Senator Olga A. Mendez.
Mr. Pataki has criticized Roosevelt Island for "over-reliance upon state funds." For two decades, the state has subsidized the operating budget for the difference between what it costs to manage the island and what the island collects in rent and other revenue, which last year totaled $8.8 million. The state provides all the money for its long-term capital construction budget.
In the 1997 fiscal year, the State Legislature provided $600,000 for day-to-day operations and nothing for capital expenses; in 1996, it provided $1 million for daily costs and $5.2 million for capital costs. The officials want to know how Mr. Blue will finance what they contend is $7 million worth of continuing construction projects, including nearly $3 million in seawall construction.
In a statement, Mr. Blue said: "If Grannis and company were truly interested, why didn't they stand up when millions of dollars were being wasted? Where were they when the mess at this agency was created, when there was poor management and poor foresight?" ANTHONY RAMIREZ

GRAPHIC: Photo: Rikers, at right, a reprint of an article outlining plan to redevelop Welfare Island.
 
Chart: "Timeline: On the Other End of the Tram"
Key dates in the history of Roosevelt Island.

1860 -- The city builds a prison, an almshouse, a workhouse and three hospitals on Blackwell's Island in the East River
 
1935 -- After renaming the island Welfare Island in 1921, the city moves the prison to Rikers Island

1971 -- New York State announces plans for a residential community of 20,000 to be known as Roosevelt Island

Mid-1970's -- Inflation and the fiscal collapse of the Urban Development Corporation, the state agency developing Roosevelt Island, leads to sharply reduced plans

1989 -- Subway station is opened on Roosevelt Island; population has reached only 8,000

1996 -- State legislature halves island operating budget to $600,000 and eliminates capital budget, which totaled $5.2 million in 1995
