HEADLINE: Harsh Medicine

BYLINE: By Robert Pear; Robert Pear is a Washington correspondent for The New York Times.

 BODY:

MORTAL PERIL
 Our Inalienable Right
 to Health Care?
 By Richard A. Epstein.
 503 pp. Reading, Mass.:
 Addison-Wesley Publishing Company. $27.50. 
 Richard A. Epstein, a law professor at the University of Chicago, is one of the stars in the firmament of conservative intellectuals. He knows more about economics than most lawyers, doctors and health policy analysts. And health policy desperately needs the insights to be gleaned through economists' and lawyers' intellectual discipline. Mr. Epstein would seem ideally suited to the task of analyzing the nation's health care system -- and in some ways he is. But "Mortal Peril" is a curiously uneven book, combining flashes of brilliant insight with commentary that may strike many readers as morally obtuse.
He is best as a critic. His critique of President Clinton's ill-fated plan for universal health insurance, which embodied, he writes, an "egalitarian impulse," is skillful: "Congress was told all or nothing, and nothing was the response." But like many conservatives, Mr. Epstein has a hard time constructing a coherent set of health care proposals to replace the conventional wisdom in this field.
His thesis, in short, centers on "the mortal peril of beneficent regulation," the "unintended consequences" of high-minded schemes to guarantee access to health care. "Taken together," he says, "the full range of reforms poses a mortal peril to the very ends they are supposed to advance: the health and prosperity of society." The effort to transform charitable impulses and "moral intuition" into legal rights, like a right to health care, is, for Mr. Epstein, futile. He is a purist, and he does not want the Government to dabble in health care because, he says, "noble intentions quickly lead to an endless tangle of hidden subsidies, perverse incentives and administrative nightmares."
Thus, Mr. Epstein is skeptical of Medicare for the same reason he scorned Mr. Clinton's health plan. Medicare, the health program for the elderly and disabled, establishes, he says, "a single-payer monopoly for large parts of the health care market -- a perfect microcosm of a command and control economy." He recalls that his father, a radiologist, railed against Medicare with the admonition that "he who pays the piper calls the tune."
Mr. Epstein's aversion to Government intervention is so strong that he disapproves of a 1986 Federal law requiring hospitals to examine and stabilize patients with "emergency medical conditions." The law was prompted by reports of patients who died or were sent to public hospitals after being denied care at private hospitals. Mr. Epstein describes the law as "an institutional mistake," whose "hidden costs" have forced some trauma centers to shut down because they are not assured of payment for the care they must provide. "As far as government is concerned, any hospital should be able to 'just say no' to any patient," he writes. He would let hospitals deny care to people who persist in abusing drugs or alcohol.
Mr. Epstein's analysis is more subtle and useful when he explores the frontiers of medicine, ethics and the law, grappling with issues like organ transplants and physician-assisted suicide. But it seems odd that after arguing that people have no right to health care, he insists that the terminally ill should be able to hasten death with a doctor's help. "Why balk at active euthanasia if it is honestly invoked to avoid the pain and suffering that would otherwise follow?" he asks. Nor is "public support for children in a permanent vegetative state" high on his list of priorities. "We should suck in our gut and say no when asked to provide life support devices for those without hope of recovery," he writes.
The system of individual rights and duties enshrined in English common law "does a far better job of providing health care than the endless set of legislative and judicial innovations of our day," Mr. Epstein says. But it is a bit late in the day to sweep away those innovations and erect a new health care system on the old foundations. A more pressing task is to repair the internal defects and contradictions that Mr. Epstein cogently catalogues.

HEADLINE: Borderline Cases

BYLINE: By Thomas McNamee; Thomas McNamee is the author of "The Return of the Wolf to Yellowstone."

 BODY:

NORTH COUNTRY
 A Personal Journey
 Through the Borderland.
 By Howard Frank Mosher.
 259 pp. Boston:
 Houghton Mifflin Company. $23. 
 The borderlands between the United States and Canada harbor lost souls galore -- exiles, burnouts, neo-Nazis, poachers with machine guns -- embedded like raisins, or flies, in a great white pudding of unaccountable good cheer. Seeking joy in such a recipe is the chosen work of the unfashionably cheerful novelist Howard Frank Mosher.
To celebrate his 50th birthday, Mr. Mosher spent six weeks weaving back and forth across the border from the Atlantic to the Pacific in search of "exuberance and affirmation." Much of what he found would seem to most of us poor makings for joy -- "gutted schoolhouses and overgrown farms and collapsing railway stations and empty ore docks" -- but even in the grimmest settings Mr. Mosher will discern something worth a smile, however rueful.
He charges into town after weather-beaten town in sunny delight and soon has ferreted out of its shadows some garrulous eccentric with a strange tale to tell. From a customs agent he learns about the evil genius with a secret compound in the backwoods of Vermont who shipped howitzers via Antigua to South Africa, served six months in prison, then sold his 100-foot germ-warhead-hurling supercannon to Saddam Hussein. A Sioux "mini-Las Vegas in Michigan's remote Upper Peninsula" turns out to have been the tribe's salvation -- 1,200 people off welfare, a neon sign shop, a brewery, a finance company, a surgical instrument factory. A crafty farmer tricks the Federal Bureau of Investigation "into moving her 20-year-old manure pile" on the assumption that $40,000 from a bank heist "was buried at its bottom." In a cheap motel in Montana, Mr. Mosher lies awake as the newlyweds next door rage and reconcile all night, and freight cars clang together. And, at an inn elsewhere in Montana: "A hard-looking young woman in brief red shorts and a halter top, sitting at a nearby table with two guys who look more like carnival roustabouts than cowboys, starts shouting. 'Look, I told you worthless sons of bitches I'd buy you a meal if you gave me a ride. So here's your goddamn meal. Anything on the menu. Order it and eat it and then get the hell out of here.' "
The North Country, it seems, is a haven for the hard-bitten; the soft folks do not last. "The overwhelming majority of homesteaders, ranchers, trappers, outlaws, farmers, teachers, doctors, ministers and entrepreneurs who came to this harsh country along the Montana-Canada border within the last century sooner or later departed." Those who stayed disdain the easy life.
From coast to coast, the people depicted in "North Country" share a certain bleak outlook, squinting at the complexities of government, trade and culture through a lens of nonprescription, one-size-fits-all distrust. "Inherent in their endless battles with the weather, the sea, the rivers, the forests and outside regulations and markets and bureaucratic decisions is an ongoing dramatic conflict that seems to have characterized life in the North Country for the past two centuries," Mr. Mosher writes. "What's more, it seems to me that most of the North Country natives I've met enjoy, even relish, this conflict."
At times Mr. Mosher's infelicity with language is painful: "A sojourner in a strange land must go with the flow." Occasionally it leads the reader to doubt the accuracy of a quotation. I suppose a Quebecois bush pilot could have said, "So, now that we have such great cultural and linguistic and yes, political, autonomy, it may not be wise to cut our last economic ties with the rest of Canada," and "Our farms are alive and healthy, our social programs among the best in the world," but to me those phrases savor more of plastic keyboard than of silver tongue.
Never mind. When Mr. Mosher's interlocutors tell their stories -- often of loss, of the past or of something that happened to somebody else -- the faraway otherness of North Country life snaps into vivid, up-close focus. John Little Raven, a Chippewa who harvests wild rice from a homemade canoe in the marshes of northern Wisconsin, could be making real money in a steel mill in Milwaukee, but, he says, "I'm where my heart is."
So is Howard Frank Mosher when he returns to his own home in the North Country. "On the day of my 50th birthday, I thought that for me this life in the Kingdom had been the right life, that its simple, continuous satisfactions -- walking the mountain each day of the year, visiting with friends, fishing for brook trout, watching a pickup baseball game on the village green, sitting quietly in the evening with the person I've loved for 30 years and more, reading a good old or new book, writing a new story -- were enough."
"North Country" shows how a little can be enough. Lost souls, lonely places and small pleasures alike have their particular dignity when Mr. Mosher shines the light of his sympathy on them.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 1; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 2301 words

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
A Palace for a New Magic Kingdom, 42d St.

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP 

 BODY:
THE AGE OF DISCOVERY may be past, but the Age of Rediscovery is still young. One of the most important treasures unearthed by today's intrepid explorers is the Great American Street. The opening next Sunday of the New Amsterdam Theater, the magnificently restored 1903 show palace on West 42d Street, is above all an occasion to celebrate one of the most spectacular of these treasures.
Renovated with breathtaking skill by Hugh Hardy of the New York firm Hardy Holzman Pfeiffer, the New Amsterdam instantly becomes the keystone of a street that is also a major feat of urban reclamation. Forty-second Street itself has become a piece of theater, a metropolitan melodrama one might call the Boulevard of Broken Nightmares. After decades of futile cleanup campaigns, the place is no longer gripped by crime, vice and decay. Instead, there are shops, theme restaurants, two restored theaters, mammoth flashing signs, amusement arcades. Above all, there are people, milling around, gazing in amazement at other people milling around, as if it were the first warm day of spring. 
 And there is much more to come. A multiplex movie house holding as many as 25 auditoriums. The Roundabout Theater, which is scheduled to relocate to the Selwyn Theater. The Ford Center for the Performing Arts rising on the site of the Lyric and the Apollo theaters. A new 10-story building that will house rehearsal studios for theater and dance companies. And that's not even to mention the four office towers that will eventually rise on all four corners of this legendary Crossroads of the World.
But what will it all add up to? That is the question to ask, now that this renewal project has reached a state of critical mass. How will the plot turn out?
This street has the potential to become one of the most culturally important in urban America. It could do much more than revitalize one street. It could also redefine the relationship between the center city and American popular culture. Or it could simply be a bright but chuckleheaded exercise in consumerism.
The New Amsterdam's opening adds to the suspense. A triumph of the art and ideology of preservation, the renovation shows how far urbanism has progressed since the days of postwar urban renewal, when few planners would think twice about consigning architectural gems to the junk heap. The project is also a measure of what can be accomplished by partnerships between the public and private sectors -- in this case, between the Walt Disney Company and the city and state agencies that sponsored the renovation.
At the same time, the project raises questions about the impact of these partnerships on the cultural vitality of New York. The New Amsterdam is a glorious container, but as yet no more than that. It is the most recent chapter in the phenomenon the French theorist Guy Debord once termed "the society of the spectacle," a society eager to drug itself with endless images of desire.
It is hard to imagine that hard-bitten, gold-digging Ziegfeld girls and oily Adolphe Menjou types ever felt at home at the New Amsterdam Theater, for the place is an architectural version of an American Eden, the unsullied natural paradise in which European explorers cast the New World.
Laurel leaves, branches, vines, wreaths, bouquets, roses, heliotrope, grapes, apples, figs, berries, nuts, parrots, peacocks, mice, squirrels: there is scarcely an inch in the theater's interior not encrusted by some plaster specimen of flora or fauna, tumbling out in profusion. In this Arcadian setting, you would expect to see Isadora Duncan in a Greek tunic rather than a chorus girl in ostrich plumes.
Henry Beaumont Herts and Hugh Tallant, the architects, also designed the Opera House at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, and the New Amsterdam's auditorium is quite similar to it in its curved, egg-shaped interior, with a domed ceiling and oval boxes. But the New Amsterdam goes well beyond the Opera House in terms of ornament. A late-blooming American version of Art Nouveau, somewhere between Louis Sullivan and Victor Horta, the design tames the style's sinuous, hothouse eroticism but magnifies its opulence.
Instead of the red and gold theme of the European opera house, the colors here are green, rose and sand. The proscenium arcs overhead like a spreading crown of trees. The boxes and balconies ascend toward the ceiling like the slope of a hill. At the top of the dome, four classically draped women hang rigidly from the treetops: angels on swings.
Too much is not enough here. In the basement's New Amsterdam Room, formerly the men's smoking lounge, wings sprout from an angel's torso as well as his shoulders. Clouds, stars, electric bulbs and a golden halo wreathe his head. In short, this is a theater where people are not likely to start stamping their feet over a late curtain.
Rather than recreate the New Amsterdam as it appeared when new, the architects have attempted what they call an "interpretive restoration," retaining later additions like the Art Deco marquee. They have reconstructed the boxes, which were torn from the walls when the theater was converted to a movie house in 1947, and have virtually recreated from scratch the interior architectural ornament, which was almost obliterated by water damage in the 1980's.
It is hard to imagine a better patron than the Walt Disney Company for this Cinderella transformation. But Disney's arrival in New York has evoked powerfully ambivalent responses. As the brand name of family entertainment, Disney offers assurance not only to parents but to others who grasp that New York's future depends in no small measure on its capacity to accommodate the middle class. At the same time, those mouse ears terrify some people who see the aspirations of the urban middle class swiftly sinking beneath the values that govern suburban malls.
In the last four years, as the project has taken shape, Times Square has been the focus of complaints about the replacement of raunchy authenticity by a synthetic theme park atmosphere. Some critics believe that in the name of saving the city, the government agencies sponsoring this venture may actually be killing it. They envision the emergence of a city where the only culture is corporate culture, where entertainment has stifled art and demands for security have muffled the claims of difference and dissent.
As Michael Sorkin put it in his 1992 book, "Variations on a Theme Park," "The struggle to reclaim the city is the struggle for democracy itself."
I count myself a watchful supporter of the redevelopment of Times Square. The expulsion of porn doesn't strike me as a major threat to free speech. Maybe I'm a 1950's person. I smoke, eat steak, drink martinis, and if people want to look at dirty pictures, I think they ought to go to Paris, ooh-la-la.
Besides that, as someone who has been following this story for more than 30 years, I regard in wonder that things have turned out so well. It may be natural to view this state- and city-sponsored project as the work of some monolithic political-commercial complex. This opinion could not be farther from the truth. Forty-second Street now reflects the determination of some energetic and enlightened public servants who fought hard to prevent the street from turning into a granite corporate canyon.
If this street had stars in the sidewalk, some of them should be inscribed with the names of Rebecca Robertson, Cora Cahan, Gretchen Dykstra, Robert A. M. Stern, Tibor Kalman and Hugh Hardy -- the group of public officials and design professionals responsible for guiding the street's redevelopment. The public response to their efforts has insured that at the very least, the development of this street will be incremental. It will evolve over time.
Already, the street has become the infrastructure for the nation's media central, a public space that brings together the producers and consumers of popular culture. The Conde Nast building, now going up on 42d Street and Broadway, will reinforce a concentration already represented by the Bertelsmann Building at 45th Street, site of the Virgin Megastore, and the 43d Street headquarters of this newspaper. One block east along 42d Street is HBO headquarters and, across the street in Bryant Park, the seasonal tents for the "Seventh on Sixth" fashion shows.
BUT SOMETHING IS MISSING FROM THIS picture, an ingredient that could lift the whole enterprise into the cultural stratosphere: art. What is needed here, specifically, in this project sponsored by the public, is a forum for artists whose work is animated by the tensions between high culture and popular entertainment.
Those tensions have been driving the culture throughout the last half century, sparking an entire literature and inspiring several generations of artists. Writers like John Kouwenhoven, Marshall McLuhan, Guy Debord, Susan Sontag, Umberto Eco, Jean Beaudrillard and George W. S. Trow. Artists like Andy Warhol, Twyla Tharp, Barbara Kruger, Laurie Anderson, Cindy Sherman. What is glaringly absent from the new Times Square is the awareness and creativity that these artists represent.
It is not a minor omission. Mass media, popular entertainment -- these phenomena represent the most powerful economic forces at work in the modern world. The 42d Street project is the most important opportunity we now have to connect these forces to the contemporary urban condition. Artists are the most qualified people to make that connection.
Twyla Tharp is entirely correct when she insists that her dances deal with "major community problems" -- questions of leadership, hierarchy, cooperation, estrangement and courage. Laurie Anderson's multimedia performances explore the coercive influence of the homogenized global monoculture and the capacity of Americans to resist or even transform its overpowering advance.
These artists, and many others, have chosen to work in established forms of popular entertainment: pop music, movies, television, Broadway musicals. They have used these media to reflect critically on the media themselves, exploiting their power not simply to seduce and entertain but to enlighten and inspire.
Pop culture is alienating as well as binding. We all love Lucy. But it's not just gangsta rap and daytime talk shows that are socially corrosive. Popular culture is inherently a major force for estrangement. Think about Joe Camel. Cigarettes, once representative of urban sophistication, now have people in a most unsophisticated uproar.
Think about cars: how this national emblem of personal autonomy later became a cage on wheels, a rolling threat not only to the environment it sought to conquer but to the conquerers, the drivers who became the driven, charioteers in a race against the obsolescence of the industrial age.
The whole point of a city is to work these things out in public. That's the meaning of Sorkin's observation. Strike, scream at people, light up in public, make a fool of yourself, fall in the gutter, pick yourself up, move on.
I doubt that anyone seriously denies the importance of family entertainment in the contemporary city. On the contrary, those who care about the city's future should applaud efforts to accommodate the urban middle class. What raises skepticism is the use of culture to mask a latent hostility toward culture in all its messy, anxious vitality.
The point is this: the street is itself a form of popular culture, a medium as powerful as television, newsprint or the World Wide Web. No form of "interactivity" yet devised is more potently democratic. The American street is sacred space, for all its saturation in secular, materialistic values. Any great street turns each step into a stride toward freedom.
IN 1903, THE NEW AMSTERDAM WAS shamelessly escapist: in the industrial city, a theater might well want to resemble a park; it performed a similar function. The context of the New Amsterdam has changed. New York is no longer an industrial city. It is an informational city, driven largely by images. It is folly to think that the meaning of the restoration is the same as the meaning of the original design. The New Amsterdam was, essentially, an escape from business. The restored New Amsterdam is business itself, a building integral to the economy of tourism and mass media on which New York's economy now largely depends.
Some of us can remember seeing movies in the New Amsterdam as recently as the early 1970's. Cheap double bills. The lights were so dark that we didn't notice that the boxes had been torn from the walls. We were movie-generation people who could take in four films in one evening and didn't care if the surroundings were grungy. If anything, the battered surrounding added to the experience. Rundown places ripen the imagination. That is a basic New York story.
Decay, estrangement: these are not concepts with which civic boosters are ordinarily comfortable. Yet they are major aspects of urban beauty. Edward Hopper captured this beauty. So have James Baldwin, Joan Didion, George Tooker, Paul Cadmus, Jerome Robbins, Savion Glover, David Byrne. There are artists waiting now in the wings to interpret not only the community of the street but also the solitude of the street. Their vision is imperative to New York's enduring capacity to strengthen modernity's connective tissue.
The Glorification of the American Girl: Wasn't that a Ziegfeld slogan, when the New Amsterdam was young? How about the Glorification of the American Misfit? That's one of the things a great city strives for. It offers an Arcadia of opportunity where misfits get to make something creative from the experience of not fitting in. It sometimes happens that the weird niches misfits carve out for themselves turn out to be shape of things to come.

HEADLINE: FILM;
Face in the Crowd From Ireland, Via Outer Space

BYLINE: By MARGY ROCHLIN

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES

 BODY:
IN THE MID-1980'S, THE IRISH character actor Colm Meaney bought a shiny gray Hugo Boss suit that he couldn't afford. "Casting directors can smell fear and desperation," said Mr. Meaney, who strolled into every audition wearing the flashy garment and exuding confidence. "My suit put me in the position of saying, 'We're not starving here.' "
On this spring afternoon, Mr. Meaney's not starving at all. He was sitting in blue shorts and a white T-shirt near his swimming pool in the backyard of his San Fernando Valley home, chain-smoking Camel Light cigarettes and describing how he came to appear in two movies that will be opening shortly: the small British film "The Van" and the big American one called "Con Air." 
 The 43-year-old Mr. Meaney no longer needs to wear his designer good luck charm. For the last four years, for instance, he has appeared as Chief Engineer Miles O'Brien on television in "Star Trek: Deep Space Nine." Outside the Alpha Quadrant, Mr. Meaney is best known for the pink-cheeked working-class fathers he has portrayed in the movies based on Roddy Doyle's prize-winning Barrytown trilogy: "The Commitments" and "The Snapper."
On Friday, the final Barrytown episode will unfold in "The Van," directed by Stephen Frears. In it, Mr. Meaney plays Larry, an unemployed father of two who joins with his best pal, Bimbo (Donal O'Kelly), to sell fish and chips from a fast-food wagon. Though money pours in, the two men discover that working elbow to elbow alongside your matey in a narrow, greasy kitchen is certain to put a strain on any friendship.
In the Barrytown series, Mr. Meaney brings to life members of the blue-collar world often ignored by the American cinema; his lower-income patriarchs would never seek family counseling and solve perhaps too many problems with a couple of pints at the local pub, but are always searching for new ways to understand the wife and children.
"Colm can really play working-class figures and transcend class in a very good way," said Mr. Frears, who outlined Mr. Meaney's theatrical credits before devoting the rest of a telephone conversation to getting laughs at his good friend's expense.
"He looks like he's been in jail half his life, doesn't he?" he said in a confidential whisper. "And he's lazy too. I mean, given half a chance, he'll be off for a drink, gossiping or talking to his agent. He's very, very reluctant to come to work."
In truth, Mr. Meaney has been gainfully employed since adolescence. He did a brief stint as an apprentice fisherman on the Irish Sea, but mostly his jobs have involved reciting dialogue. The third of four sons, Mr. Meaney was 17 when he was accepted at the prestigious Abbey Theater in his hometown, Dublin. For two years, his mother, a housewife, worried that he would end up penniless. ("Her line was, 'You'll be going without a sole on your boot,' " he said.) Upon graduation, Mr. Meaney proved her wrong by becoming one of two students to be given a contract by the Irish National Theater.
For 15 years, he spent most of his time on stage, making his Broadway debut in 1981 in "Nicholas Nickleby." In 1986, hoping to try his hand at film and television, he moved to Los Angeles with his wife, Bairbre Dowling, and their infant daughter, Brenda. (Mr. Meaney and Ms. Dowling separated in 1994 after 12 years of marriage.) As it turns out, Hollywood was indeed interested in the formally trained emigre with a lilting Celtic accent and easy comic timing.
Over the years, Mr. Meaney has built a reputation for being believable in roles of varying size, though in small parts he is likely to vanish midway and in "Dick Tracy" his character didn't even have a name. Often, Mr. Meaney will do a bit as a cop, a priest or a doctor without sharing a frame with the project's star. "I've been in films with an awful lot of people I've never met," he said.
In fact, show business is a profession that supports not just top-billed headliners but also skilled ensemble players like Mr. Meaney, who has become so in demand that he, too, can make film makers scrape and bow. What Simon West, who directed "Con Air," knew about Mr. Meaney was that he could pull off playing a Corvette-driving American Drug Enforcement Agency agent whom a Federal marshal (John Cusack) must talk out of blowing up an airplane filled with criminals. (The $75 million movie opens next month.)
What he didn't know was whether he could work around Mr. Meaney's complicated schedule. "But Colm's such a versatile, technical actor that he makes your life much easier," Mr. West said.
Recently, Mr. Meaney, who is still a cast member in "Deep Space Nine," returned from New York, where he did a turn as a menacing pimp in a psychological thriller being directed by Lodge Kerrigan. In the next couple of weeks, he will be flying to the Isle of Man where he'll appear as a sweet-natured landlord in "Owd Bob." After that, he'll jet to Boston, where he'll show up as a street thug in "Noose," written by and also starring Denis Leary.
Much like anyone who logs so much time at 30,000 feet, Mr. Meaney has developed his own in-flight ritual. First, he kicks off his shoes. Then he consumes a large bottle of spring water to ward off dehydration. After that, he closes his twinkly blue eyes and slips on the courtesy sleep mask provided to first-class passengers.
"I used to always laugh at them," admits Mr. Meaney. "But now I'm like Zsa Zsa Gabor -- if I got my eye patch on and my hot curlers plugged in beside me, then I'm set."

HEADLINE: ARTS/ARTIFACTS;
Unlikely Tales Told by the Homely Woven Basket

BYLINE: By MITCHELL OWENS

 BODY:
BASKETS TODAY ARE A largely rustic conceit: quaint receptacles for magazines or bathroom bouquets of dried statice and cornflowers. Not so long ago, however, a hand-woven basket was one of life's necessities, a tool, not a trifle.
Farmers used them to store bushels of apples, housewives piled them high with sun-dried laundry, and at the Fulton Fish Market in Manhattan, merchants once displayed their briny wares in woven wood baskets with carved hickory handles. 
 Many of the baskets used at the Fulton Fish Market -- as well as by the textile mills of Norwalk, the cobblers of New Canaan and the commercial fisheries along Long Island Sound -- were manufactured in and around Pound Ridge, N.Y., a bucolic town in northern Westchester County.
Though today it is known for attracting celebrity householders like Christopher Reeve, Eartha Kitt and Susan Sarandon and Tim Robbins, from its founding in the 18th century until the early 1920's, Pound Ridge was pure Tobacco Road. Located far from economic stimulants like railroads, Pound Ridge was rough, rugged and isolated, a confederation of impoverished hamlets populated by farmers scratching an uncertain living from the half-rocky, half-boggy soil.
A certain amount of financial stability, however, could be found in a career in basketry. Between April 1864 and March 1865, for instance, Dann & Curtis, a local basket factory, sold an astonishing 22,848 baskets. More than 4,000 of these were one-bushel oyster baskets, a Pound Ridge specialty that is among the dozen or so styles represented in "Baskets: Woven in History," a pocket-size exhibition at the Pound Ridge Museum that runs through Aug. 3.
Given its literally lightweight subject matter -- and the limited size of the museum, which is a one-room former meeting house -- the exhibition is suitably modest. C. Jennifer Lawton, the curator, has assembled a total of 19 Pound Ridge baskets, most dating from 1880 to 1910 and all woven of hand-split strips of oak, ash or hickory that had been softened by soaking in ponds or troughs of water. Wicker was rare.
She has also clarified the method of construction by setting them alongside construction diagrams and contemporary photographs of local basket makers in action.
One-quarter of the exhibition space is devoted to the furnishings shown in several 1920's photographs of Sivori Selleck, a local basket maker, in his studio. Selleck descendants donated two ladder-back chairs, their ancestor's saw and razor-edge shaving knives, as well as his shaving horse, a teeter-totter-like contraption that was a combination chair and work surface.
The basket maker's spiffy sartorial ensemble -- the aged Selleck, grizzled and mustachioed, wears a band-collar striped shirt, pressed black trousers and polished leather boots -- is not part of the display, however. And it would not have been included anyway, had it managed to survive the intervening years.
"He looks like he's going to church," Ms. Lawton said, looking at a photograph of Selleck deftly weaving an oyster basket. "I'm sure he dressed like that just for the camera. For one, there isn't any wood chips or sawdust on him, which is a little suspicious."
Thanks to a boom in oyster consumption at the end of the 19th century that was fueled by the discovery that oyster beds could be replenished and expanded by stocking them with imported baby oysters, Pound Ridge baskets became a standard item between the 1860's and 1900. One community created baskets so fine that they were nicknamed Dantown crockery, while another Pound Ridge hamlet, Scotts Corners, produced enough to be informally called Baskettown.
Unfortunately, that 30-year-period was the extent of the basketry heyday. A typhoid outbreak in 1902 traced to infected oysters caused oystering and oyster baskets to take a beating. Finally, health regulations demanding improved methods of harvesting rendered the porous, hard-to-clean oyster basket passe.
"They are rugged, not beautiful by any means," Ms. Lawton said, pointing at a pair of oyster baskets that she recently discovered in nearby Rowayton, Conn. "But the way they were designed, for a particular purpose, is a kind of beauty."
The weave of oyster and clam baskets, Ms. Lawton explained, was "loose and open," distinguished by coin-size holes that were large enough to allow water to drain away but small enough to keep the shellfish securely packed.
Breadbaskets, on the other hand, were tightly woven to keep insects at bay and spare the bread from drying breezes. Shape was important, too. One of the baskets on display is a trug: its flat platterlike form allowed fresh-cut flowers to be gathered gently, resting at full length, before being transferred to vases.
Rounding out the exhibition are examples of American Indian basketry from the northeastern United States, dating primarily from the 1960's to the 1990's. Unfortunately, they fit awkwardly into the Pound Ridge Museum show, and their souvenir-stand decorative fillips are vacuous, even somewhat tacky. However, they do, unexpectedly to be sure, provide a poignant counterpoint: they underscore the sad devolution of a once noble craft.

HEADLINE: Long Island Q&A: Dr. Richard Horn;
Easing the Flow of People and Products

BYLINE: By LINDA TAGLIAFERRO 

 BODY:
LAST September, Dr. Richard Horn was apppointed executive director of the Nafta Intermodal Transportation Institute, a component of the National Aviation and Transportation Center at Dowling College.
The federally financed institute, at Brookhaven Calabro Airport, was established to address issues of trade flow among the United States, Canada and Mexico and to facilitate the movement of people and products throughout North America It also .strives to improve the productivity and competition of economies. 
 Dr. Horn was born in Wisconsin. He received a B.B.A. and M.B.A. from the University of Wisconsin and a Ph.D. in economics from Iowa State University.
For 17 years, he served as chief of the Motor Vehicle Project Office at the Volpe National Transportation Systems Center in Cambridge, Mass.
Dr. Horn lives with his wife in Oakdale.
Q. What is the significance of Nafta to Long Island businesses?
A. We have in New York a major presence both in Canada and Mexico. Our border crossings handle about 30 percent of all the trade traffic going to Canada. Nobody comes close to that except for Michigan.
Much of the activity is in some basic commodities, and we have a great deal of raw materials that come into New York from Canada, such as wood pulp and paper products. We have some commodities that are produced here that could have a market in Canada.
Long Island is a little different than other portions of the state. We have a high-tech industry and manufacturing here. The firms on Long Island have a tendency to be small to medium-sized, and one of the reasons why the NAT Center is interested in approaching this is that we believe these are the firms that need support in entering into the Nafta markets.
If you're a small to mid-sized firm, you know your market quite well, and if you're comfortable in that market, there's a tendency to view international trade as something that may be far more difficult to get into.
Under Nafta, it's far easier to find partners outside the country who can supply you with components for a product which you could then sell domestically or even internationally.
Q. How is the institute assessing the transportation needs of companies on Long Island?
A. We have been working with organizations such as the Hauppauge Industrial Association, the Long Island Association, the Long Island Import Export Association and others to help us assess the needs of Long Island businesses. We are using their expertise and connections in the community to give us a better understanding of what needs are strongest in Long Island.
Q. Do you think Long Island businesses could best import or export with the Nafta countries?
A. Actually, we're talking both imports and exports. If we can address the transportation costs effectively, then the additional distance between, say, Mexico and Long Island is not that much more of a barrier. We should be looking at both of those countries as trade partners.
Q. Commuters on the Long Island Expressway have a hard enough time getting home during rush hour. How can Long Island companies expect to import and export to Canada and Mexico with such traffic constraints?
A. There are discussions under way to provide additional access to the Island and I believe these have been going on for many years. Ferry service or a bridge link to Connecticut are all basically infrastructure approaches to some of the issues, but those are typically very expensive.
This question goes to the heart of I.T.S., or Intelligent Transportation Systems, which is basically finding ways to use the infrastructure that you have more effectively. Can you do it by better planning? Can you understand the routes and what you're shipping and when you are shipping so that you can take advantage of periods of time in which there is less congestion? Can you use this information to speed up some of the interchanges that will take place? Can you develop intermodal facilities that can consolidate some of the shipments and manage those more effectively?
Q. What are Intelligent Transportation Systems?
A. Intelligent Transportation Systems is the program within the Federal Department of Transportation and the various State Departments of Transportation that attempt to introduce technology into transportation activities using transponders, information systems, electronic communications and the like to expedite the transportation process.
Q. How does this improve the flow of commerce?
A. One of the things that we can provide through the effective use of I.T.S. systems and the exchange of information associated with the movement of commodities is the ability to know when something is going to arrive.
This is very important for North American trade because if you're concerned about the reliability of movement, then any time you have bottlenecks in the system, it's throwing a monkey wrench into your schedule.
In North America, those bottlenecks are often at the borders, and what we're going to try to do is to address some of those issues with better information and the use of I.T.S. as we approach and go through the border crossings.
Q. Are there any significant innovations in border-crossing technologies?
A. Right now, in the Buffalo area, there is a Federal Highway Administration field operation test to begin deploying some new I.T.S. equipment at the border.
In this case, the equipment is predominantly readers installed in Buffalo which will identify a truck as it comes up to the crossing. It's actually a small machine. It requires that the truck has a tag, a transponder, which is something like an electric license plate, and it's not unlike the E-Z Pass system that we have throughout much of the area.
Q. Once a truck has a transponder, how and what information is passed to the electronic reader at the border?
A. Once the truck has a transponder, without that truck having to stop, the officials at the border will know who the truck is. That's half of the process. The other half is officials will also want to know what's on the truck. This requires that information about the commodities being carried be sent to the border officials ahead of time electronically so that it will be in their systems as the truck approaches the border. Then officials would know if the truck had all of its appropriate credentials and permits for operating in Canada and in the United States.
Q. Would the cost of such equipment be prohibitive for small to mid-sized companies on Long Island?
A. The equipment itself is not terribly expensive for the transponders. In fact, the opportunity for carriers to manage their fleets more effectively has led many of the major trucking firms to equip their trucks with this already.
The cost actually depends upon the level of sophistication that they would need in the transponder. There are those that have relatively low information. They're basically an electronic license plate.
Then there is another level of equipment which allows you to use this tag, to plug it into an onboard computer, so that you can actually communicate with the driver to advise about road conditions and other information.
Q. There is a Continuous Flow Intersection at the entrance to the NAT Center. How does this expedite traffic flow?
A. It's a way of permitting traffic to turn earlier than at the actual intersection. As the traffic approaches an intersection where it would be turning left, it turns left before that actual intersection to go into a queuing lane that is left of the oncoming traffic.
The concept is very flexible because this system was originally designed with built-in sensors which would adjust the signal timing in real time. If the queues are very long, it would then permit left-hand turns more frequently.
Q. What are some of your future plans for the institute?
A.We plan to develop courses and seminars that we can take into the Long Island community and New York in general. These would teach firms how to get the kinds of information that they need, how to make good decisions about transportation and to understand a full range of issues that fall under the term "logistics."
We want to demonstrate to the small and mid-sized firms on Long Island and the State of New York in general that it isn't much more difficult to enter into the Canadian market. This may lead them to think that if Canada isn't so hard, then maybe Mexico is a possibility, too.
Although our focus is on the Nafta countries as trading partners, we truly believe that once a firm sees the advantages of participating in international trade in North America, they will generalize and also see Europe, Latin America, Asia and other countries as possibilities.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Richard Horn of the Nafta Intermodal Transportation Institute, at Dowling College. (Michael Shavel for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 1460 words

HEADLINE: O'Rourke Reflects on a 15-Year Adventure

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
WHAT he always pined for was not the County Executive's post, which he has held for 15 years. Nor was it a judgeship, as has often been rumored of late. What Andrew P. O'Rourke truly wanted, he revealed recently, was to be the Green Hornet.
With the characteristic blend of easygoing wit and geniality that has marked his career -- a style that only thinly veils his more serious side -- the 63-year-old Mr. O'Rourke reflected recently on his years as one of the county's most powerful elected officials. 
 And like many of the politician's other quips, the Green Hornet metaphor bore a message.
"He was an adventurous person who carried a gas gun and could knock you out," the County Executive said of the former Saturday night radio hero, "but the Green Hornet's job was to do good."
Mr. O'Rourke, who prides himself on doing good in government -- he is an admitted "sucker for a sad story" who has often championed the needs of women, children, the poor and the afflicted -- announced on Feb. 4 that he would not seek re-election. Leaving fellow Republicans scurrying to find a replacement for the county's top job, he ended months of speculation about his decision and said he would leave his $119,085-a-year position on Jan. 1.
"So today is bittersweet, as I bring this chapter of public service to a close," he told a crowded news conference that winter day.
Three months later, on a bright spring morning, the bittersweet tone was still present as he discussed his years in office.
"It was like a great ocean voyage, and I was the captain," he said. "If I pride myself on anything, it is that I took a great ship and steered it for 15 years and never hit rocks. It's still on course."
He talked about his journey to the County Executive's office and the problems he encountered once there -- like Westchester's economic depressions and recessions, the growing threat of AIDS and other diseases, commissioners who came and went, allegations of favoritism in office and his battles with the 17-member County Board of Legislators.
As an occasional child actor on stage and in television, Mr. O'Rourke grew up with four older sisters during the 1940's and 50's in the Hell's Kitchen area of Manhattan near Ninth Avenue, in a heavily Jewish, German and Irish neighborhood. His father, a doctor, died of tuberculosis when his son was less than 2; his mother, an active New York City Democrat, went blind eight years later and became a welfare recipient.
Mr. O'Rourke made his way up through the ranks of Westchester Republican politics, beginning in 1963 when he concluded a stint as a captain in the Air Force, moved to Yonkers and enrolled in law school at New York University at night.
Although he voted for John Fitzgerald Kennedy that year, he said he "never discovered where the Democrats in the city met" and so turned to the other camp.
Three years later as a Republican, he won a seat on the Yonkers City Council, where many Westchester politicians have cut their political teeth.
"If you can survive in Yonkers, you can survive anywhere," Mr. O'Rourke said. "It's a fairly Byzantine city. There used to be a story that after a political battle, the victors went out and found the wounded and killed them. I think it's still the same there."
It was during that early period that he first struck up his friendship with Alfred B. Del Bello, a Democrat who later became the Mayor of Yonkers, Westchester County Executive and Lieutenant Governor. Mr. Del Bello said recently that although he and Mr. O'Rourke were always on opposite sides of the aisles, they often voted together on social-programming issues.
When Mr. Del Bello was Mayor of Yonkers, Mr. O'Rourke was the majority leader of the City Council. When the Democrat ascended to the County Executive post, Mr. O'Rourke became a County Legislator and then Chairman of the Board of Legislators.
"Sometimes there was a lot of blunderbuss and conservative posturing, but when push came to shove, and money was needed for people programs, he would support it," Mr. Del Bello said.
He described his colleague as soft-hearted at the core.
And while Mr. O'Rourke does not deny that, he prefers to describe himself as a realist. For example, while he has supported a wide array of social programs, his Administration has also been notable for its efforts to reduce welfare rolls.
Fiscally, too, he has taken a tough stance, protecting Westchester's AAA bond rating, fighting to keep taxes down and tax revenues stable and privatizing some county jobs to cut costs -- even though that decision, he said, was painful.
He counts among his successes construction of a new terminal at the County Airport, a new jail and a recycling plant.
But he and his political allies have also been dogged by allegations of patronage. In 1989 an investigation by the State Government Integrity Commission criticized the influence of Anthony J. Colavita, who was then the county's Republican boss, describing an overly close relationship between political parties and government, and focusing on the awarding of franchises at the county-owned Playland Amusement Park.
In 1993, Mr. O'Rourke faced charges of reportedly using his position to help family members and friends. He acknowledged that a daughter worked for a law firm receiving county contracts, that he recommended his female companion for a job with a company that was seeking a county contract, that the county awarded a contract to a company employing his companion's son and that he asked New York Medical College, which is under contract with the county, to admit a daughter as a student and, at a later date, to hire a son-in-law.
An investigation by the District Attorney's office found that Mr. O'Rourke had not violated any laws.
"I've been investigated more than anyone else and never been convicted," he said last week. "I feel safe in saying that everything I've done has been on the right side of the law."
But he said that the real thorn in his side during his time as County Executive has been the sometimes stormy relationship with the legislative branch of county government.
"I feel that they have tried to encroach on the powers of this office," Mr. O'Rourke said. "It has been a problem of who's in charge of what."
His relationship with the current Chairman of the Board of Legislators, George Oros, has been cordial only of late.
"We didn't get off to the best start," said Mr. Oros, a Republican who won the post through a coalition of Democrats and Republicans and was not the Republican Party's choice.
"Despite our differences, the County Executive has always put Westchester first, and that deep-seated love comes through," Mr. Oros said.
Mr. O'Rourke's relationship with the previous chairman of the Board of Legislators, Stephen P. Tenore, was less friendly.
"It was difficult for him to deal with the Board's growing sense of independence at that time," Mr. Tenore observed recently.
The question on many observers' minds has been: Why, with a career that has been basically so successful, is the County Executive now stepping down, especially when informal polls taken by Westchester's Republican party showed he could win again?
Mr. O'Rourke said that, for a variety of reasons, it was time to move on.
One reason is that he is tired of running for re-election, even though he campaigned unsuccessfully only once, in a 1986 run against Mario M. Cuomo for Governor.
"I hate feeling like a nun in front of the subway station asking for money," he said, explaining that his efforts to reform campaign financing have borne little fruit.
Mostly, he said, he is stepping down because he has longed to be a judge, and there are reports that the State Legislature may create a new Supreme Court judgeship for him. He admitted last week that he "wouldn't mind that."
In 1991 Mr. O'Rourke was nominated by President Bush for a seat in Federal District Court in Manhattan, but the nomination stalled in the United States Senate as Democrats sensed a Presidential victory by Bill Clinton. In 1993 the County Executive wistfully turned down the offer once again even though the nomination for judgeship was revived by Senators Alfonse M. D'Amato and Daniel Patrick Moynihan. He said he would run once again for County Executive.
If for some reason, however, the Supreme Court judgeship does not materialize now, Mr. O'Rourke said, he might take up his part-time literary career full time. He is the author of two published adventure novels.
Or he could teach history on the college level -- "if they still teach history," he said.
He could also return to being a lawyer.
"It will all take some getting used to," Mr. O'Rourke conceded. "I'm an old warhorse. Politics is deeply in my blood."

HEADLINE: Potential Power Woes Now a Regional Worry

BYLINE: By MAURA CASEY 

 BODY:
MAYBE it is true that misery loves company. Consider: The potential power shortage Connecticut faced last summer will be shared this year by all of New England. Last year three out of four Connecticut plants were shut down, but at least the Connecticut Yankee nuclear power plant at Haddam Neck operated through July. Then last fall, its operator, Northeast Utilities, closed the Connecticut Yankee permanently after officials determined it made no economic sense to continue running the unit. Now, with all four of the state's nuclear plans shut down, the region as well as the state faces possible power shortages.
The three Millstone nuclear units have been shut down since March of 1996, two months after they were placed on the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's watch list of unsafe nuclear plants. Northeast Utilities is working hard to reopen one of its Millstone units, but does not expect to do so until the end of the year at the earliest. 
 Elsewhere in New England, the Maine Yankee nuclear power plant, which was placed on the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's watch list six months ago, is shut down. "Five of the New England states' eight nuclear power plants are now out of operation," said William P. Sheperdson, spokesman for the New England Power Pool, which regulates the region's distribution of power.
The five closed nuclear plants were capable of providing about 4,000 megawatts of electricity, said Myra Humphries, spokeswoman for Northeast Utilities, about enough to supply 1.2 million homes.
The nuclear-powered wattage now on hold is just shy of one-fifth of the expected peak demand of 21,400 megawatts that the power pool expects the New England states to need this summer, and more than two-thirds of Connecticut's expected peak demand of 5,800 megawatts, according to Ms. Humphries.
The power pool has become so concerned about potential power shortages that it requested that Northeast Utilities schedule maintenance weeks early for its nuclear plant at Seabrook, N.H. -- in May instead of July, Mr. Sheperdson said.
The plant, shut down yesterday, will be closed for five weeks. If all goes as scheduled, it will be producing power again in mid-June, Ms. Humphries said.
"The first time people get really hot weather in May or June, it's a relief, especially after the kind of cool spring we've had," Mr. Sheperdson said. "They go out to buy air conditioners, or put them in," but tend not to turn them on, he said. It's the second and third occasions when temperatures soar -- especially if they do so for long periods -- that people begin running the cooling apparatus at high. That is why the power pool sought an earlier maintenance plan for Seabrook, to get things in place before summer heat really sets in.
If Connecticut gets through this summer without power shortages, one major reason could be equipment that Northeast Utilities personnel spent much of the winter scrambling to install on major transmission lines that cross the state lines from New York, Massachusetts and Rhode Island.
Capacitors, electrical equipment attached to major utility poles, will significantly increase the voltage of electricity the state will be able to import, increasing voltage capacity from 2,100 megawatts of power last summer to 2,520 megawatts this year, according to Ms. Humphries.
Northeast Utilities is also keeping nonnuclear plants in reserve, plants that it reactivated last year. These include Middletown 1, Norwalk Harbor 10 and four gas turbine jet engines in Milford that themselves are capable of producing 160 megawatts of power. The United Illuminating Company, which provides electricity to 17 cities and towns including Bridgeport and New Haven, last year also reactivated its Bridgeport Harbor Unit 1, said Fran Mayko, a spokeswoman. "We're running the plant at minimum power in case it is needed," she explained.
Even the Navy submarine base in Groton was ready last year in case its help was necessary and the base intends to stand by again this year, said Chief Petty Officer William Polson, a base spokesman.
Last year, the Navy Construction Battalion Center in Port Hueneme, Calif., flew in 21 generators capable of producing 24 megawatts of electricity. "Not only would it have made us self-sufficient in case of a problem, it would have helped the community, too," Chief Polson said. The generators were never needed, but this year, the base has retained eight generators capable of producing 13.5 megawatts of power.
Ms. Mayko said that United Illuminating gave 350 commercial and industrial customers pagers last year in order to notify them in the event that a voltage reduction was about to occur. The company never had to call.
Utilities have also identified customers whose power is not to be interrupted -- hospitals, sewage treatment plants and downtown urban areas among them.
Both United and Northeast have granted rate reductions to customers who are willing to have their power interrupted in case a heat wave forces cutbacks, the companies said. In a worst-case scenario, the utilities would resort to rolling blackouts, cutting electricity to neighborhoods during the day on a rotating basis for one or two hours at a time.
But the utilities hope such steps will not be necessary. "We're cautiously optimistic that, if everything works well, we'll be in reasonably good shape during a heat wave," Ms. Humphries said.
Because potential power problems face the entire region, the New England Power Pool has put in place a series of warnings to alert the public that conservation is needed, especially if the weather is warm. It also has arranged with other regional power pools, in New York State and Canada, to purchase more electricity if it is needed.
Potential power shortages aren't unheard-of in New England, said Mr. Sheperdson. He pointed to the experience in 1984, when the New England economy was beginning to boom and several of the region's power plants -- including Seabrook and Millstone 3 -- were not yet completed. "New England managed then, and it might well make it through the summer without much of a problem," Mr. Sheperdson said.
Still, the best ally the region could have is another cool summer, like last year's.
"My gut feeling? It isn't likely that we'll get two such cool summers in a row," said Ms. Mayko, a sentiment that was echoed by other utility employees.

HEADLINE: Creating a Bond Beyond U.S. Borders

BYLINE: By NANCY POLK 

 BODY:
TEACHERS and carpenters, students and union members, artists and medical professionals from Connecticut have been going to Nicaragua since 1984 as part of the New Haven/Leon Sister City Project. The project is an unconventional program run from a small office on Whitney Avenue in New Haven.
Lee Cruz, director of the program, now considers Nicaragua his home and offers one answer for the continuing interest of Connecticut residents in the fate of Nicaragua: "Hope, the hope that always comes after the overthrow of a dictator." 
 Patty L. Nuelsen who runs the New Haven office (newhavenleon@igc.apc.org), adds: "I think people are frustrated by what's going on in the world. I think they see injustice. When opportunity for concrete action that will impact real peoples' lives, they become very motivated."
At first the New Haven Sister Cites Inc. organization resisted the Nicaraguan group's desire to join. "I think they perceived us to be political rather than economic and cultural," Ms. Nuelsen explained. "People's attitudes have changed and now we are full partners." Other Sister Cities in the umbrella organization include Avignon, France; Amalfi, Italy; Freetown, Sierra Leone; Hue, Vietnam, and Afula-Gilboa, Israel.
Local volunteers first went to help and see for themselves what was happening after the fall of the dictator Anastasio Somoza at the hands of the Sandinistas in 1979. Many built personal relationships and have returned often. "They see an opportunity to make a difference," Ms. Nuelson said. Furthermore, she added, "It is not uncommon for people to go down and say 'I leaned much more than I brought down there.' "
The Rev. Alice Perry, a pastoral counselor from New Haven, has visited the Leon area six times, pursuing an interest in liberation theology, picking cotton, delivering medical and school supplies and clothing as well as living with Nicaraguan families. Her visits led to a sister church arrangement between an evangelical church in an impoverished part of Leon and the United Church on the Green in New Haven where she was then employed.
"For me the most powerful experience was to appreciate the post-revolution developments in health care and literacy," she said. "In terms of the liberation theology perspective, it was the notion of a preferential option for the poor."
Ms. Perry, very disturbed by the land mine death of a Swiss agronomist at the hands of the Contras, learned that the mine involved was made in America. Upon her return she went to Washington to lobby against funding the Contras. "We urged legislators not to fuel and fund a war," she explained.
By the time of her most recent visit, in 1993, her Spanish was strong enough to take to the pulpit of the sister church and preach. She also helped revive a weaving cooperative that began with the support of the United Nations High Commission on Refugees. Sister Cities offered technical, financial and marketing advice. Now colored yarn is shipped to Nicaragua from New Haven, woven and shipped back for sale. American weavers are sent from Connecticut to work with the cooperative.
"It is very humbling to be in Nicaragua, seeing the effects of U.S. policy," Ms. Perry said. "I have learned that one of the freedoms in the United States is the freedom to exploit." She opposes such practices as using cultivatable land to raise exportable items like cotton when the people need the land to feed themselves.
Dr. Jose R. Santana, who grew up in the Bronx and Puerto Rico, has been to Nicaragua four times. As chief medical resident at the Hospital of St. Rafael in New Haven, he specializes in infectious diseases and tropical medicine.
He first went to Leon in 1995 when the area was hit with a mysterious epidemic. "It was leptospirosis, a rodent-borne bacteria that is common in the tropics," explained Dr. Santana. Eventually more than 5,000 people contracted the disease and an unknown number died of massive pulmonary hemorrhaging.
He spent his days helping the Centers for Disease Control collect mosquito eggs and blood samples from cattle. At night he cared for patients at a teaching hospital in Leon. His next visit was devoted to research. He characterized his visits as "very much a two-way exchange."
"I have tons to learn about the kinds of care they provide without relying heavily on extensive tests that we do over here," he said. In return, he has provided information about Yale's medical curriculum, to help revise their medical education program.
Susan A. Bramhall, a computer software engineer, decided to go to Nicaragua because "My political instincts had been buried. I was disappointed things weren't changing in the United States and had become cynical about people and their ability to want to do something good," she recalled.
Ms. Bramhall, who has made five visits since 1990, is now president of the Sister Cities Board.
The organization operates on a budget ranging from $100,000 to $150,000 annually. For Leon, that represents an enormous resource. "I was very emotionally connected from the beginning, very invested in making this organization robust and stable enough to handle the natural and political crises that regularly afflict Nicaragua," Ms. Bramhall said.
One of the most visible ways of helping is to deliver material aid. Vast amounts of donated summer-weight clothing, school and medical supplies, tools, sewing machines and bicycles are stuffed into a large container by volunteers. The 36th such container will be packed in New Haven on June 7.
The clothing is not distributed free. Mr. Cruz explained, "We donate the clothing to one of five communities," he explained. "They in turn sell the clothing and through the sale we help develop leadership. We help them learn business skills and accounting. They may raise $300 or 400."
The money is put toward construction projects. A volunteer American architect, a Nicaraguan contractor and community volunteers are slowly building a health center, a school and a pre-school. In a country where teachers earn $65 a month, small amounts of money can be stretched quite far. As Mr. Cruz explains it, the project's real importance is "not the building, it is what people learn in the process."
There is also a modest two-way exchange between New Haven and Nicaraguan artists and musicians. At Casa Otonal, a housing complex for elderly Spanish-speaking tenants, Daniel Pulido, a Leon muralist, painted a history of Latino culture.
In June a display of paintings from Solentiname, Nicaragua, will be on display at Casa Cultural Julia Burgos, the Puerto Rican Community Center at Yale.
