HEADLINE: LEFT BEHIND -- A special report;
As U.S. Economy Races Along, Upstate New York Is Sputtering

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON

DATELINE: SYRACUSE

 BODY:
Sunshine, a scarce commodity through the long upstate winter, has returned, bearing hope. Nature bursts with promise.
Mike McConnell is unmoved. 
 "It's spring and you're dead broke again," said Mr. McConnell, who works for his father's small 30-year-old concrete contracting company here. "After a while, you just say enough is enough."
That is what McConnell & Sons Contracting did in April. The firm placed its first bid for construction work out of state, a job in Raleigh, N.C. If the bid is accepted, the 35-year-old Mr. McConnell said, he and his wife and four children -- along with three employees and their families -- will head south, perhaps for good.
From the perspective of upstate New York residents like the McConnells, the nation's economic expansion in the mid-1990's has been a fiction -- a tale of other places and other people's lives. The state's broad top has become an island of glacial growth, sandwiched between generally thriving New England and booming Midwestern states.
In the four years since the recession of the late 1980's and early 1990's ended in the Northeast, New York City and its suburbs have made substantial gains, but much of the upstate economy barely budged. The growing national economy has lured away skilled, ambitious residents and young people.
More alarming still, the region's already tepid expansion in employment stalled completely in 1996, even as the pace accelerated in New York City and elsewhere.
The region's plight has been made all the more glaring by a reversal of fortunes within the state. New York City, long derided by upstaters as a sinkhole of waste and economic decline, has become the state's economic leader, fired by Wall Street, tourism and international finance -- all sectors of the economy that are smaller or absent upstate.
Of the 41,000 net new jobs created in the state in 1996, 31,000 were in New York City, according to the State Labor Department, and 9,000 more were in the city's suburbs on Long Island and in Westchester and Rockland Counties. Although there were areas of modest strength upstate, notably in Rochester, job losses elsewhere canceled them, leaving the region with zero net job growth -- its worst year since 1992.
The job numbers improved somewhat in the first three months of this year, but the basic pattern persisted: very slow growth, with pockets of outright contraction. Syracuse, for example, has lost 700 more jobs just since February, according to the State Labor Department.
Paradoxically, economists say that the upstate region's weakness grew in part from its past strength. Although major employers like Kodak shed thousands of jobs in the 1980's and 1990's, the region's industrial base, heavily reliant on manufacturing durable goods like air-conditioners and medical equipment, remained for the most part intact. It did not collapse entirely, as the military-based economy did on Long Island, for example. As a result of its relative stability, the area was not forced to modernize or seek out the sort of new industries that are now fueling growth elsewhere.
Although some of the troubled areas upstate are rural, like Hamilton County south of the Adirondacks, where the unemployment rate was 15.8 percent in March, economists say that the larger structural weaknesses upstate are urban -- concentrated in the string of metropolitan areas that stretches from Lake Erie to the Massachusetts and Vermont borders.
"Upstate New York right now has one of the weakest, if not the weakest, economies of any significant region of the country," said Mark M. Zandi, the chief economist at Regional Financial Associates, an economic consulting firm in West Chester, Pa.
Mr. Zandi said that except for small communities like some mining towns in the West that are in economic distress, he puts upstate New York alongside Hawaii, which has been battered by a drop in investment from Japan, and Washington, D.C., which has been hurt by Federal Government spending cuts, in a bleak triumvirate that are not sharing the nation's economic success.
Some politicians, especially opponents of Gov. George E. Pataki, say that if low numbers persist into 1998, the economy of the heavily Republican upstate areas on which the Governor depended for his election in 1994 could complicate his hopes for re-election.
Pataki aides point out that the total number of jobs in the region has increased slightly since 1992, and contend that there are signs of better things to come. Employers announced plans in 1996 to create more than 28,000 jobs upstate, according to the Empire State Development Corporation, the state's economic development arm.
But the shoots of growth that are here now, like Barilla, an Italian company that brought 70 jobs to the Syracuse area in 1996 to package bulk imported pasta, are mostly small and can be easily overwhelmed by new cutbacks. In late April, Bausch & Lomb, Rochester's third-largest employer after Eastman Kodak and Xerox, said it would eliminate 1,900 jobs, or about 14 percent of its workforce, on top of the 950 jobs cut since early in 1996.
Smaller firms like Mr. McConnell's, or the Wheatstone Corporation in nearby Cicero, which will take 80 electronics manufacturing jobs to North Carolina this fall, are leaving more quietly. Wheatstone has offered financial assistance to any worker who wants to move with the company.
Mr. McConnell said he knew 30 small contractors from the tightly knit construction community in the Syracuse area who have made the leap south already, searching for work. The local building industry, he said, has all but collapsed.
The prospects for the region's economy are made even more perilous by the fact that the rest of the nation is so far ahead in the business cycle, having expanded continuously now for six years. A slowing of the broader economy, which some economists expect later this year, would make a local recovery much harder. And an accelerating national economy could be just as bad, if concerns over inflation prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates further.
Upstate New York is not one monolithic place, of course, and each city and town has its own distinctive tale. Albany has suffered from the downsizing of state government. Buffalo has been hurt by the weak dollar in Canada, to which the city economy is closely tied. Rochester, though somewhat better off, has been hit by repeated job cuts at Kodak, and now again by the layoffs announced at Bausch & Lomb. Syracuse, where hospitals are the biggest employer after government, has been especially hurt by cutbacks in the health care industry.
The stagnant economy is causing young people to leave in search of opportunity. Since 1995, departures have exceeded arrivals in upstate New York by nearly 169,000 people, according to the United States Census Bureau. The metropolitan Syracuse area, with a population of 660,000, has had a net loss of about 17,000. When births and deaths are added in, upstate's population declined by about one-half of 1 percent.
Gregory Hotaling, 21, an engineering major at Syracuse University whose family has lived in the Syracuse area since Dutch colonial days, counts on his fingers the places he thinks he may find a job. His hometown is not among them. "Yes to Atlanta, yes to San Diego, yes to Houston," he said.
Mr. Hotaling said that of the 40 engineering majors who have passed through his fraternity house since 1993, only 3 are still in the area. The others regularly send back newspapers full of job tips for posting on the fraternity house bulletin board.

The Region
Losing Pace With Its Neighbors
Upstate New York used to look much like the rest of America in its economic performance, its mix of jobs and its income levels. But the appearances were misleading. Economists say that the region has been a different, distinct island of the economy for many years, moving on its own track.
For a long period, through the 1970's and much of the 1980's, that was good. The region specialized in a kind of durable manufacturing that seemed able to ride out bad times. Chilly Syracuse, for example, specialized in building air-conditioners for the growth of the Sunbelt. Kodak seemed to have a lock on a major part of the photography industry.
The industrial base upstate did not collapse in the early 1980's like the steel and automobile empires of the Midwest. And the region was spared the worst of the late 1980's and early 1990's recession, which was concentrated in financial services in New York City and in military manufacturing in places like Long Island and New England.
But now that appears to have been something of a curse. The pain and dislocation of the earlier downturns eventually led to the emergence of new, highly productive computer-driven manufacturing in the Midwest, and to a high-tech resurgence in places like Massachusetts and New Hampshire. The upstate economy did not crumble; it eroded. And it has absorbed more blows in the mid-1990's even as its neighbors moved on.
"Our problem is that a lot of our changes and restructurings have been going on more recently," said Paul Blackley, a professor of economics at LeMoyne College in Syracuse.
General Motors gradually closed its Syracuse parts manufacturing plant beginning in 1993, eliminating 1,200 jobs. Miller Brewing, about 25 miles north in the town of Volney, closed in late 1994, eliminating 1,000 more jobs. Kodak is racing to keep ahead of the technologies of electronic photography. Insurance, another major upstate industry, has also cut jobs in the last few years. Since 1994, employment among private businesses has risen only 1.19 percent upstate -- about a fourth of the 4 percent to 5 percent growth rates in the Midwest and most of New England, and about half the 2.19 percent growth rate in New York City, state figures show.
There are reasons to believe that the hard times may work to the advantage of the region, however. Since labor shortages loom in Sunbelt and Midwest markets, some economists think that upstate New York could start to seem attractive as an alternative.
The region's costs of doing business are competitive nationally, with Syracuse, Rochester, Buffalo and Albany all below the national average, according to an analysis by Regional Financial Associates. And falling house prices, while painful for longtime residents, have made the region affordable.
Transportation is also an advantage in central New York. Syracuse, for example, is at the intersection of Interstate 90, an east-west artery, and Interstate 81, a north-south artery. Barilla pasta chose to put its distribution site in the region partly because of that road network, city officials said (and because the company's research showed that upstate New York has the highest per capita consumption of pasta in the country).

Syracuse
A Distress That Mirrors a Region
Economic statistics do not reveal the struggles of people like Susan DeGraeve-Dupra. She and her husband, Kevin, who live in Syracuse with their two children, both have jobs. She has two of them, in fact. She installs and hangs drapes, and works in a crafts store. He is a mechanic. The problem is not unemployment, she said, but a lack of jobs that pay the bills. "We work like dogs and we can't get ahead or even get even," Ms. DeGraeve-Dupra said. "We constantly have to say, 'Who are we going to pay this month, and who are we going to blow off?' -- it just seems to get tighter."
In Syracuse, some problems are obvious, like the empty stretch of commercial office buildings on James Street, a major thoroughfare leading to the city's downtown. Others are hidden and private and, to some degree, obscured by the statistics, local officials say.
Connie Maute, the research director for the Syracuse Chamber of Commerce, said that the local unemployment rate of 4.9 percent in March, for example -- the same as the national rate, which was at a 23-year low -- is misleading, and the message it sends out, she said, has hurt the local economy.
When potential employers call, she said, they "look at the low unemployment rate and say, well, then you don't have the people to fill the jobs." Her job, she said, is to explain that things are in fact worse than they look because of underemployment, population losses, and uncounted residents who have stopped looking, or have stopped receiving unemployment benefits.
There are other subtle factors that have added to the economic distress. Not too many years ago, for example, Syracuse, a city of 160,000 -- which economists say is representative of many upstate communities in its mix of jobs and the kinds of problems it has faced -- had some big corporations that called it home and cared deeply about its fate. Carrier Corporation, the air-conditioner company, was generous and civic-minded. Lesser-known manufacturers like Crouse-Hinds, a maker of electronics, had major downtown presences.
Now, because of mergers and acquisitions and departures, there is only one corporate headquarters left, the Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation. Carrier was purchased by United Technologies Corporation, based in Hartford. Crouse-Hinds was bought by a Texas company, Cooper Industries.
City officials say those changes have had an unmeasurable but profound effect on Syracuse's fortunes, and are making its comeback harder. Syracuse's director of development, Vito Sciscioli, said that although other mid-size cities, like Cleveland, could call on cadres of corporate chief executives to attract civic projects like the Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame, "We're now down to dealing with wealthy individuals."
For many residents, Syracuse has become a place of waiting -- waiting for a house to sell, waiting for a job, waiting for things to get better.
George Camardella Jr. said part of his weekly routine was making sure he gets to Durston's Cigar Store by Thursday night to pick up The Arizona Republic and The Palm Beach Post for the help-wanted sections, because by Friday, all the copies are gone, even though they are almost a week old.
Mr. Camardella, 42, whose job selling ads for a local shopping guide is largely seasonal and barely makes ends meet, is waiting to sell his family home in East Syracuse. When it finally moves, he and his wife will, too -- maybe Florida, maybe Arizona. He has no job in either place, but he is confident he will. Selling the house is another matter. He has dropped the price twice since Thanksgiving, from $74,000 to $64,900 by late April. He held an open house for brokers, he said, and not a single broker showed up to look at the house he grew up in.
There have been major blows to community pride as well. Until 1994, for example, Syracuse was the state headquarters for Nationwide Insurance Enterprise's entire automobile insurance business in New York. That year, the company consolidated its claims-processing operations into two national centers, and several hundred jobs were pulled out of Syracuse. At the same time, it added an almost equal number elsewhere in New York, resulting in little or no change statewide but another tip of the scale within it: Almost all the new jobs were in New York City and its suburbs.

The Politics
An Important Shift Toward Downstate
Hating New York City is a popular pastime upstate. Residents and politicians have said for years that New York City officials venture north to Albany only to beg for more tax money to help pay for profligate programs and wasteful ways.
That is not happening now. These days, many of the arguments and equations about which part of New York needs or does not need the other have been turned on their heads. New York City's budget is flush. And while its economy is not booming, since late 1995 it has nonetheless been the state's main job-creation engine. Its crime rate is dropping. And the bull market on Wall Street has created a flood of tax revenues for the state.
It is too soon to tell whether the economic problems of upstate New York will be a major issue in the 1998 governor's race. But there have been noises to suggest that they might be. The Assembly majority leader, Michael J. Bragman, a Democrat from Onondaga County, and the State Comptroller, H. Carl McCall -- both seen as possible Democratic challengers to Mr. Pataki -- have become frequent critics of the Governor's policies upstate.
Mr. McCall argues that Mr. Pataki has neglected New York's smaller cities and aggravated their problems. Mr. Bragman said that high energy costs upstate, which he calls a major stumbling block to growth, have not been adequately addressed by the administration.
Upstaters, Mr. Bragman said, "are apprehensive because there's no job growth and they continue to see job losses." He said that although Mr. Pataki's popularity is high now, "over the next six to nine months, that could very well change -- jobs and economic growth are the key."
Mr. Pataki's chief spokeswoman, Zenia Mucha, called such criticism "ridiculous," saying both Mr. McCall and Mr. Bragman were part of the problem that the Governor was trying to fix.
"Both these politicians are responsible for leaving New York State in the dire straits it was before the Governor took office," she said. "They voted for and supported the policies that drove over half a million jobs out of state." She also pointed to announcements of major upstate investment by companies like Kodak and I.B.M. that she said would create jobs in years to come.
But upstate residents like Mr. Camardella say they are tired of waiting. "At this point I'm not sure I care if it gets better or not -- I'm just tired of it," he said. "I've been sitting here drinking beer too long."

"Five Cities That Have Faltered"
 Upstate New York has missed the steady economic expansion that most of the rest of the country has enjoyed in the last few years. In the five cities that are the spine of the region, job growth is flat, housing construction is down and personal bankruptcies are rising.
 
BUFFALO
 The city's anchor, General Motors, is building its new light-weight car engine here. But other manufactur-ing continues to recede and the weak Canadian dollar has hurt tourism.
 
ROCHESTER
 The story here has been one step forward, one step back. After years of cutbacks, Eastman Kodak, the city's largest employer, is expanding, but Bausch & Lomb will cut 1,900 jobs this year.
 
SYRACUSE
 Restaurants and shops downtown have added 2,000 service jobs in the last few years. But many established employers, like insurance companies, have contracted or left.
 
UTICA
 Population declines and job losses, including layoffs at nearby Griffiss Air Force Base, have battered the city, giving it the country's lowest bond rating from Standard & Poor's.
 
ALBANY
 A shrinking state payroll hit hard in the mid-1990's. In the last year alone, 3,200 state jobs were eliminated, the effects of which have rippled through the retailing and housing markets.

HEADLINE: Honey, I'm Not Home

BYLINE: By Nicholas Lemann; Nicholas Lemann is the national correspondent for The Atlantic Monthly.

 BODY:

The Time Bind
 When Work Becomes Home
 and Home Becomes Work.
 By Arlie Russell Hochschild.
 Illustrated. 316 pp. New York:
 Metropolitan Books/
 Henry Holt & Company. $22.50. 
 The photograph accompanying the 1953 Fortune article that William H. Whyte expanded into "The Organization Man" showed a tide of humanity (to the extent that guys in fedoras qualify as a tide of humanity) flowing across a train platform in Park Forest, Ill., over this caption: "5:57, back from the Loop."
The unmistakable message was that ominous big corporations were turning us into a race of work-automatons. Today, however, looking at the picture, you can't help thinking that they would have had to leave the office not much past 5 to make that train, and that their wives had probably been home all day attending to home, community and children. What a leisurely life!
Arlie Russell Hochschild's book "The Time Bind" is based on the same kind of intensive firsthand research into Midwestern corporate life that Whyte did, except that she is a sociologist rather than a journalist, and so doesn't tell us the real name of the town or the company. She spent three summers at the headquarters of "Amerco," an enlightened multinational in the low-key town of "Spotted Deer," and found that in most families both spouses put in much longer hours than just the husbands had back in the 1950's. Ten- to eleven-hour workdays are common (that's 8 A.M. to 6 or 7 P.M.), and family life is brutally squeezed.
Ms. Hochschild writes in a calm, understanding tone that tends to disguise how truly subversive and depressing her message is. Subversive, because although we've already heard, in Juliet Schor's book "The Overworked American" and elsewhere, that our hours are too long, the blame is usually laid at the feet of a demanding new economy. It isn't our fault. Ms. Hochschild says we work too much because we want to -- because we like it better at work than at home. Depressing, because in her account home has changed from a refuge into an arena of stress, and children are the victims.
At Amerco an elaborate series of family-friendly personnel schemes with hilariously earnest names (like the Work-Life Balance program) go mostly unused. Only 53 of 21,000 employees, none of them men, have chosen to work part time in response to the arrival of a new baby. Fewer than 1 percent share a job. And 1 percent of Amerco employees work from home, though the company permits it. Most employees don't even use all their vacation days.
A minor reason for all this office time is that Amerco is "a pretty workaholic place" where employees are judged more on input (that is, hours worked) than on output. "What matters is how much time you put into the job, the volume of work," one of Ms. Hochschild's interviewees is told by her boss. The major reason is volition. No dark satanic mills in Spotted Deer! Over and over Ms. Hochschild conveys Amerco's employees' attitude toward their work by using such sun-dappled terms as "sweet joy," "fun," "carefree," "emotionally supportive" and "more interesting than life at home." One interviewee tells her, "I come to work to relax." Ms. Hochschild has exposed something that feels like an unacknowledged home truth, America's clean little secret: work, not even the substance of it but the buzzy surface feeling of office life, is for many of us a source of intense pleasure.
Amerco has become somewhat homelike -- even, Ms. Hochschild insists, for the hourly workers in its "well-lit, fairly quiet, relatively pleasant" factories. At work people have buddies, they carry on flirtations, their birthdays are celebrated, they even have staged "commitment ceremonies" (to the company, that is). Home, on the other hand, has become "another workplace." The increased presence of women has led to a mild feminization of work, with more emphasis placed on cooperation and support, but also to a pronounced masculinization of home, where efficiency is now the overriding concern.
Parenthood, too, is judged by outputs, not inputs: one mother measures her performance "by how well her children were doing, not how much time she spent with them." Children are subjected to factory-style "speedups," hurried from one place to another all day and made to squeeze all their emotional needs into the hour or less that their parents have to spare in the evening. Home has developed its version of corporate "outsourcing" and "downsizing," with many traditional maternal functions off-loaded to baby sitters and therapists. In one of Ms. Hochschild's most horrifying anecdotes, two parents dash off to give presentations at work on a day when they know their son has to be taken to the hospital because of a medical emergency. Ms. Hochschild notes that Hallmark has introduced a new line of cards "for parents who are too busy to see their children," which say things like "Sorry I can't be there to tuck you in."
A cycle develops. Home, because it is continually shorted, keeps getting messier. Sullen children, resentful spouses, inconvenient stepchildren, elderly parents and manipulative exes lurk there. Relationships at work, which get the nourishment of time, become deeper and richer. One executive, typically of Ms. Hochschild's subjects, finds dealings with his "office children" -- subordinates, that is -- more rewarding than those with his flesh-and-blood children. The reversing of home and work has got to the point that Amerco employees who can't handle their family lives can now turn to the company to teach them how, through free workshops on such subjects as "Dealing With Anger."
Ms. Hochschild's previous book, "The Second Shift," found that in two-career couples, women still do the lion's share of the child care and housework. In "The Time Bind" she identifies a "third shift," consisting of emotional work at home, which nobody does. Many of her subjects have invented a "potential self" who would do all the things they are not doing at home; their garages fill up with recreational equipment, bought for the potential self to use, ignored by the real one. Although Ms. Hochschild's ideal plainly is that men and women would work side by side on all three shifts, she is also unsparing in pointing out that it was women's changing their priorities that produced the net reduction in emotional effort at home. Everybody knows men have never carried their share of the load of family life, she writes: "This isn't news. The news of this book is that growing numbers of working women are leery of spending more time at home, as well."
Several years ago Daniel Yankelovich, the psychologist and management consultant, observed that one of the main changes in American culture since the Second World War has been the emergence of a tendency "to view work as a source of personal satisfaction." When mothers entered the work force en masse, it was partly out of economic necessity and partly a manifestation of this alteration of the culture of work. Reread "The Feminine Mystique" and you'll see that Betty Friedan made her case for women working with a rhetoric not of justice or power, but self-fulfillment. (Ms. Friedan had the temerity to attack Sigmund Freud back when that took real courage, but she was completely under the sway of Abraham Maslow and his glorification of people who can ascend to the satisfaction of "higher-order needs.") Men, less noticeably because they were already working, made roughly the same change at the same time -- that's why "The Organization Man," with its dutiful drones, has become a period piece.
Ms. Hochschild ends "The Time Bind" by calling for a "time movement" whose members would organize to reduce work hours. This used to be a sturdy liberal-labor cause, but it has fallen into disuse since the Depression. Recently writers like Juliet Schor and Jeremy Rifkin (in "The End of Work") have also suggested reviving it. The trouble, judging by Ms. Hochschild's evidence, is that nobody would want to join.

LENGTH: 1408 words

HEADLINE: Hello to All That

BYLINE: By Owen Gingerich; Owen Gingerich is a historian of astronomy at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics.

 BODY:

THE WHOLE SHEBANG
 A State-of-the-Universe(s) Report.
 By Timothy Ferris.
 393 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $25. 
 AT one time cosmologists, like ancient anchorites on their pillars, lived on the fringes of science, half admired for the exotic nature of their calling and half scorned for being so disconnected from the real world. Equipped with an esoteric theory (Einstein's general relativity) and a single observational datum (the universe seemed to be exploding), they sat on their towers and spun elaborate scenarios of times past and future: Would the universe go on forever, perhaps renewing itself with new hydrogen atoms created in the interstices of space as space itself expanded? Would it expand to nothingness? Or would it end in an infernal big crunch?
What a different level of credibility surrounds cosmologists now! Armed with new astronomical data and joined by the high priests of particle physics, their new descriptions of the large-scale structure of the universe command attention both from the scientific elite and from the public at large. "Like the universe, cosmology is expanding," Timothy Ferris writes near the start of his comprehensive report "The Whole Shebang." A skilled and experienced popular writer, Mr. Ferris serves as one of the best guides for the curious reader. But the initiation requires careful attention, and despite his felicitous style the trail occasionally rises steeply uphill.
The first dozen pages lead up to Big Bang cosmology, the theory of the birth of our universe; the next dozen introduce us to state-of-the-art concepts like gravitational lensing, the Tully-Fisher method and the Sunyaev-Zeldovich effect -- all connected with the cosmological distance ladder, the steps that lead to an ever-greater distance scale. All this is leavened with tales of amateurs helping discover supernovas in distant galaxies, implying that, despite the jargon, the quest to find the size of the universe is not all that incomprehensible. At the book's end we learn that Mr. Ferris, an emeritus professor of journalism at the University of California, Berkeley, spends moonless nights with his own telescope, searching for supernovas.
"How can anyone learn anything new who does not find it a shock?" The question, from the physicist John Wheeler, typifies the pithy and challenging slogans with which Mr. Ferris opens chapters, in this case one on the shape of space. The shock is not the mind-boggling fact that space is curved, or even that in the presence of sufficiently dense matter space can curl around itself so intensely that it becomes a cocoon cut off from the rest of the universe, a black hole. Is it shocking that there is a place from which light cannot escape? No, the trauma lies in Stephen Hawking's audacious conjecture that matter can, after all, leak out of a black hole. Why? Because of the quantum nature of the universe, in which the positions of particles are subject to enough uncertainty that sometimes they can turn up on the other side of the black-hole boundary. The shock is palpable as Mr. Ferris's arresting account picks up momentum.
Matter is energy, Einstein said, and William Blake had already opined that energy is intense delight. Mr. Ferris remarks, in Blake's words, that we really can see "a world in a grain of sand" -- after all, "sand is largely silicon," and silicon burning in giant stars is a prototype for the evolution of the elements. Well, not quite: sand is mostly oxygen, but why spoil a good poetic connection? That, however, is the end of silicon in this account. Oxygen gets a little more consideration, though not until there is mention of design in the cosmos -- in the last chapter, "Contrarian Theological Afterword," to which I shall return.
Mr. Ferris fares better in describing how matter can aptly be called frozen energy. As the unimaginably hot Big Bang cools down, hydrogen and helium freeze out of the photon broth within the first three minutes. Mr. Ferris populates his report on the origin of the elements with colorful characters like the physicist George Gamow, who remarked, "The elements were cooked in less time than it takes to cook a dish of duck and roast potatoes." That was too seductive to leave out, but it is dead wrong. As Mr. Ferris correctly writes a few pages earlier, Gamow's work on the early universe incorporated a big right idea and a big wrong one. The wrong idea was that all the elements were forged in that initial explosion. Mr. Ferris sketches out the correct scenario: the heavier elements are formed from the initial hydrogen and helium in a long, slow cooking process that begins deep within giant stars. He is an astonishingly knowledgeable journalist, and glitches are relatively rare -- like the inclusion of this quotation, or his assertion that Gustav Kirchhoff in the mid-19th century (rather than Noah; remember the origin of the rainbow?) was the first to obtain a solar spectrum.
The story moves swiftly on, through "The Dark Matter Rap" to the large-scale structure of the universe, and to the evolution of quasars, galaxies and stars. And then a brief chapter on the evolution of the cosmos, with two moving quotations from Charles Darwin.
Now, at a cadence, the book turns from astronomers to quantum physicists. "The Hunting of the Snark," by Lewis Carroll, introduces symmetry, broken symmetry, renormalization and string theory:
You boil it in sawdust: you salt it in glue:
You condense it with locusts and tape:
Still keeping one principal object in view --
To preserve its symmetrical shape.
The inflationary development of the universe follows, with a good dose of the beguiling theory of chaotic inflation proposed by the cosmologist Andrei Linde. In this model our universe is only one of many that bubbled up out of the original quantum vacuum. "The classical Big Bang theory is dead," Mr. Linde says. But because the other parts of this multiverse are forever inaccessible to us, their existence must be taken on faith, so his opinion is far from universally accepted. But Mr. Ferris is sufficiently intrigued by the notion to subtitle his book "A State-of-the-Universe(s) Report."
Cosmology is expanding not only because of exciting new ideas but because of a flow of new data, some of it from the Hubble Space Telescope. Curiously, Mr. Ferris has rather little to say about the grand question of how the universe will end or the fervid battle over its age. Depending on the way the distance scale is read, the universe has been expanding for 10 or 15 billion years (or values scattered around this range). But the younger figure falls short of the age of the globular star clusters, and no one wants a universe younger than its parts. As for possible endings, instead of addressing the cosmological Armageddon, our guide brings us to quantum weirdness and the bewildering question of how a measurement of a particle in one place can instantly affect the state of a particle on the opposite side of the galaxy; "It is as if the quantum world had never heard of space," he writes. That is hardly part of cosmology, but this is a breathtakingly wide canvas, and for a brief description of some of the major conundrums of the quantum universe, Mr. Ferris is admirably lucid.
Finally, because God can scarcely be left out of the whole shebang, he turns to his theological afterword. Why is it contrarian? Admirers of the very moving scene in the Beauvais Cathedral in his PBS television special "The Creation of the Universe" will here miss the theme that science owes a lot to religion, especially the idea that the universe really is a universe; the notion of a single system ruled by a single set of laws came to Western science from Judeo-Christian and Islamic traditions. "The deity has been implicated in cosmology since the dawn of human history," he writes. But what can science tell us about God? Nothing, is his contrarian conclusion: "In a creative universe God would betray no trace of his presence, since to do so would rob the creative forces of their independence. . . . All who genuinely seek to learn . . . are united in not having a faith but faith itself. . . . For God's hand may be a human hand, if you reach out in loving kindness, and God's voice your voice, if you but speak the truth." Prophets' voices echo in this provocative finale, and this, rather than science, may indeed be the way God speaks to humankind.

LENGTH: 1512 words

HEADLINE: Harbor to Be Dredged, but Much Tainted Mud Lacks Home

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN

 BODY:
Sometime this week, after years of delays, a floating dredge is scheduled to begin scooping thousands of tons of accumulated mud from one of the main channels plied by the container ships that carry televisions, orange juice, furniture and almost every other imported or exported product into and out of New York Harbor.
Within weeks other dredges will similarly attack mud that has clogged several other important channels and berths. 
 Last week, a variety of Federal officials and New Jersey politicians, including Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and Senator Robert G. Torricelli, made much of the impending dredging, proclaiming an end to a four-year environmental battle over how to clear slightly contaminated mud from the dominant seaport on the East Coast without threatening public health or marine life.
But the problem is far from solved, say representatives of the shipping industry and port officials at the United States Army Corps of Engineers and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
A century-old ocean dump site for dredged mud, six miles east of Sandy Hook, N.J., will be closed to any further polluted mud on Sept. 1. After that, more than 3 million annual tons of mud tainted with industrial pollutants will need to be placed on land or in waters close to shore, the officials say.
The new projects will clear less than half a single year's accumulation of tainted mud. They will primarily clear shoals of mud that have been shown to be free of significant contamination, according to the Corps of Engineers, which issues permits for dredging.
The pollutants flow into the harbor from old hazardous waste sites up the Passaic, Hackensack and Hudson Rivers and from sewage plants around the region. Some pollutants, like traces of mercury, are thought by environmental officials to sift directly out of the region's dirty air.
With the impending closing of the old dump off Sandy Hook, the two states that share the harbor and its economic benefits have come up with a few innovative ways to dispose of dredged mud over the next several years.
But largely because of persistent public fears that the material poses a health hazard, the states still have not devised a long-term plan that will accommodate all the tainted mud, which will continue to accumulate each year until upriver pollution is stanched and sewage more thoroughly treated.
Major representatives of port businesses joined Mrs. Whitman and a small army of elected officials on a wharf in Port Elizabeth, N.J., last week to celebrate the new permits and Mrs. Whitman's signing of legislation authorizing a New Jersey bond act that provides up to $200 million for dredging.
But with new generations of oceangoing ships growing larger and deeper, many port officials and businesses connected with the harbor have warned in recent days that even with the new moves, New York Harbor still stands to lose its century-old status as a world-class port.
Sensing indecision here, many shippers have continued to divert goods to deeper ports like Halifax, Nova Scotia, before sending their freighters to New York Harbor.
Chuck Raymond, the chief transportation officer of Sea-Land Corporation, the giant container-shipping company with a major terminal in Elizabeth, said a typical Sea-Land vessel these days unloads about 300 containers in Halifax to lighten the ships so they can slip over New York's mud banks.
"Until the governors get together and come up with a plan that is safe and cost-effective, we don't see this as anything but an interim solution," Mr. Raymond said.
He also said that whatever solution New York and New Jersey choose, it cannot be so expensive that harbor fees become prohibitive. "The real issue here at the end of the day is keeping the U.S. competitive," Mr. Raymond said.
The black mayonnaise-like mud, some of which contains minute traces of toxic metals or other pollutants, poses no threat to people if properly placed on land or in buried pits underwater, according to a variety of environmental experts.
For decades, the contaminated harbor mud had been routinely -- and cheaply -- dumped at sea, but four years ago, stricter Federal environmental standards prevented any ocean dumping of the most tainted material.
After a protracted effort by New Jersey environmental groups and politicians, including Mrs. Whitman, the Federal Government agreed last year to close the mud dump entirely by this September to all but the cleanest dredged material.
Many port officials and businesses are irked that even though lightly contaminated mud dug from the harbors of Seattle, San Francisco, Boston and other ports can still be dumped at sea, that will no longer be the case here.
That fact places New York and New Jersey at a disadvantage, said Brian Maher, the chairman of Maher Terminals, which handles half the containers that flow in and out of New York Harbor each year. But he said: "We've finished fighting over the ocean. Now the thrust has to be to get people on land used to the idea that this is useful material, not a hazard."
One of the first places where harbor mud has been put to use is beneath the foundation and parking lots of a shopping mall being built in Elizabeth by OENJ Corporation of Princeton, a real estate company owned by European investors. The company's chairman, Peter Aagaard, was at Mrs. Whitman's side last week, explaining how the dredged mud, once dried and mixed with other soil, became stable and safe.
With the mall well under way, Mr. Aagaard is now working on using the mixed mud to create a golf course on top of two old closed landfills in Bayonne, across Newark Bay from the docks of Port Elizabeth. The first phase of the project is close to gaining permits, according to New Jersey environmental officials. It could take more than 4 million tons of tainted harbor mud -- more than a year's worth of dredging.
Other sites are being lined up to accept the dredged mud, said Robert C. Shinn Jr., New Jersey's Environmental Protection Commissioner. He cited a project in Pennsylvania where 500,000 tons of dredged mud -- most likely from Delaware Bay, for the test -- would soon be used to seal barren, eroded scars left by strip mining.
"We've got a lot of little pieces out there to this puzzle," Mr. Shinn said. But he added that for the time being, all New Jersey's projects would take mud only from New Jersey's side of the harbor.
But there have been setbacks, as well. A year ago, harbor officials praised a plan to bury up to 14 million tons of the tainted mud in pits beneath Newark Bay, which is already relatively polluted. But recent tests of the bottom showed that existing pollution went so deep that less than a tenth of the original estimate -- perhaps 1.3 million tons of dredged mud -- would find a home there.
Most troubling to many harbor businesses and dredging officials is the continuing public fear that the material is dangerous out of the water. In almost every case, the harbor mud is clean enough to be used to cap landfills, seal old hazardous waste sites or use in construction, Federal environmental scientists say.
But in recent months, almost every disposal option proposed by the Army Corps of Engineers -- which is responsible for keeping major shipping channels open -- has been attacked by one community group or another, said Peter Shugert, a spokesman for the Corps.
When the Corps held a public meeting on Staten Island to explain a proposal to put mud in underwater pits in the lower harbor and then cap them with clean sand, the presenters were shouted down by local residents, Mr. Shugert said.
The Corps was met with similar protests at a meeting 100 miles up the Hudson River, in Kingston, N.Y., where an old quarry has been identified as a suitable disposal site.
Even more vitriolic, Mr. Shugert said, was the reception at a meeting last month in a high school cafeteria in Leonardo, N.J., in Monmouth County. There, the proposal being described was an artificial island in Raritan Bay, similar to an existing island of dredged mud outside Baltimore's harbor. The island in Baltimore now provides bird habitat and a popular bathing beach, Mr. Shugert said. He added that Maryland politicians, eager to deepen Baltimore's harbor for larger ships, strongly supported used tainted dredged mud to rebuild a second island, creating dozens of acres of wetlands for birds and fish. That project was announced last month.
For shipping companies making plans for the next century, Mr Shugert said, the progress in places like Baltimore is more attractive than the piecemeal plans here. "It's mind-boggling," he said. "Baltimore has the same problems as New York. But they view it in a totally different way."
Citing a two-inch-thick report on mud disposal options released by the Corps last year, Mr. Shugert said: "There are 53 choices in there, but there's a 54th. We can think of the Port of New York and New Jersey as something less than it has been. If we don't do anything, that's the choice we'll be left with."

HEADLINE: Battling Teen Pregnancy

 BODY:
According to recent Federal surveys, sexual activity among American teen-agers is down -- the first decline in nearly three decades -- and use of contraceptives is up. That is promising news as the nation with the highest teen pregnancy rate in the industrialized world tries for a 33 percent reduction in teen pregnancies by the year 2005. But no national effort can be successful without a focus on community-based solutions.
Federal efforts to promote abstinence programs would be fine if the Government support did not carry with it a prohibition on the discussion of contraceptives. Abstinence programs can reduce teen pregnancies, but other educational activities are necessary as well. 
 America's mixed messages about sex too often portray it as a desirable activity with few or no consequences. But nationwide, there are 112 pregnancies for every 1,000 young women aged 15 to 19, resulting in 61 births, 36 abortions and 15 miscarriages. The rate of births and abortions among teens has been declining, however, in the last few years. The latest survey by the Department of Health and Human Services suggests that the downward trend may continue. In 1995, 50 percent of young women 15 to 19 engaged in sexual activity, down from 55 percent in 1990. Among boys, the 1995 figure was 55 percent, down from 60 percent in 1988, the last year with a comparable survey.
The National Campaign to Prevent Teen Pregnancy, an independent nonprofit effort launched in 1996, aims to reduce the number of pregnancies per 1,000 young women to 75 by 2005. Operating largely with private funds, the campaign, headed by former Gov. Thomas Kean of New Jersey and the economist Isabel Sawhill, hopes to avoid debates over abortion and contraception that have hindered several government attempts to address the issue.
A provision of the welfare reform law offers $250 million to states, under a matching formula, for programs that teach only sexual abstinence. Many states are reluctant even to apply for the money, fearing that they would be unable to field questions on condoms or other contraceptives. In addition, a recent study of abstinence-only programs in public schools in California, the state with the highest teen pregnancy rate in the country, found many offered misleading and harmful information.
Preaching abstinence can work, particularly with younger teens, but a variety of approaches are needed to persuade young people to delay sexual activity and to avoid pregnancy. Communities need to try everything from school-based clinics and after-school programs to mentoring and peer counseling. The latest Health and Human Services survey suggests that the best national approach is to encourage as many community-based solutions as possible.

HEADLINE: Jobs, but Few New Skills, for Those on Welfare

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN

DATELINE: DAYTON, Ohio

 BODY:
Diana Goodrich, 33, has had a hard time finding a steady job since a decade ago, when the nursing home where she worked closed. She had been getting along on temporary jobs and food stamps until she came up against a provision in the new Federal welfare law restricting adults without children at home to just three months of food stamps every three years.
But the law also offers people like Ms. Goodrich a way out: She could keep the benefits if she did "community service." So she became a part-time sorter of second-hand clothes at a Salvation Army warehouse here. 
 "They told me that to get my food stamps, 'You've got to work free for the country,' " she said. Her stint as a sorter is leading to a regular job and a real paycheck at $5.15 an hour.
"She's been working out very well," said Maj. Larry See, administrator of the warehouse. "I think we will end up hiring her."
Federal officials have high hopes for using community service to steer welfare recipients with few skills and little work experience into jobs, the main objective of the welfare legislation that President Clinton signed into law in August. Advocates of this approach say that at the very least, community service imparts a sense of what it is like to hold a job.
At least 100,000 welfare recipients are already doing these jobs because some states, including Ohio, established community service programs well before the new welfare law was passed. As more recipients come up against the law's deadline to go to work, millions more could be taking community service jobs.
Under the new law, single people who are not rearing children, like Ms. Goodrich, lose their one welfare benefit, food stamps, if they are not working. And parents who are rearing children lose their principal benefit, their monthly check, if they are not working within two years.
Working or not, parents also face a five-year limit to their welfare checks, so by then they will need real jobs, for which community service will not qualify.
But the community service approach is controversial, and as states start experimenting with it they are looking to state and local governments with experience in such programs. Among them are Hawaii, Montana and Ohio, and in particular, Montgomery County, Ohio, of which Dayton is the hub.
Starting with a pilot program a decade ago, Montgomery County has moved thousands of welfare recipients into community service jobs; 1,150 of the county's 9,000 recipients now hold them. Views among officials and employers about these jobs without real paychecks are decidedly mixed.
It is not hard to find workers like Ms. Goodrich who profited from a community service assignment, or to find employers like the Salvation Army who consider it a useful way to try out a new worker before making a commitment. But critics say that making welfare recipients work without pay is counterproductive.
One sobering view is that of the man who has supervised the program here for six years. "I have no interest in it," said Stephen A. Rice, director of the Montgomery County Department of Human Services.
Mr. Rice maintains that community service rarely prepares welfare recipients for, or leads them to, the paying jobs they will have to get after five years. "Our goal is getting people into paid employment so they can get out of poverty," he said, adding that community service is useful only when the worker is given schooling and vocational training.
Many people who deal with labor force issues share the ambivalence found in Montgomery County. Gary Burtless, a labor economist at the Brookings Institution in Washington, said of people like Ms. Goodrich, "As a citizen, I agree with the general public that it is better that this woman be doing something."
But he added, "It's going to be labor of a very particular type -- the least capable and the least flexible -- because the most flexible will find jobs in the private sector."
In New York and some other major cities, union officials say the community service approach gives public employers, particularly, an incentive to replace union workers with people on welfare. But here in Dayton, there has been little resistance by unions because the community service jobs are generally new and part time, and have been performed in the past by volunteers.
In many cases, the number of hours that community service workers are expected to put in is determined by dividing the $4.75 hourly minimum wage into the amount of their monthly welfare check. So a mother who receives a monthly check of $300, for example, would work 63 hours a month -- far less than the $800 she would earn in a full-time paid job at the minimum wage.
Montgomery County has rock-bottom unemployment, a condition conducive for even the least-skilled workers to find real jobs. Major See of the Salvation Army said that he had four minimum-wage openings in clothes-sorting and thrift shop services, and that after three months the workers would receive health benefits and life insurance.
But in communities where real jobs are not so plentiful, or where many jobs could evaporate the next time the economy takes a downturn, public officials worry that community service workers who are the least qualified even in good times will come up against the five-year limit, lose their benefits and be ill-prepared to compete for real jobs with other unemployed workers.
Like Ms. Goodrich, Tawnya Lambert, a 28-year-old single mother of four, is using community service as a bridge to real work. She is a community college student and a community service cook at St. Paul United Methodist Church in Dayton, which employs about 15 such workers.
"I got pregnant with my first child when I was 18," Ms. Lambert said. "I worked at an ice cream cone factory until the month before I had him. I was going to a medical clinic where someone said, 'You should apply for welfare.' I got all the benefits because I had quit work. It was an easy way to have money -- you didn't have to do anything."
After she had her second child, Ms. Lambert said she started helping out at the church, which provides services that include day care and meals for children like hers. Four years ago, the welfare office told her she would have to work, she said, adding, "It made me think, 'I can get a job and make more money.' "
Joan Johnson, the church administrator, called Ms. Lambert "a very talented person," but added, "I'm scared for these people." Ms. Johnson said that with community service and so many young children, Ms. Lambert could not carry the full load in college that would lead to a degree and a well-paid job before she reached the five-year time limit.
The church has been able to hire a few former community service workers, like William Slade, 45, who became a full-time custodian at $5.25 an hour after his predecessor quit.
Still, Ms. Johnson said, many welfare recipients the county sends her never show up, cannot cope or may never be able to hold a regular job.
"Many cannot work," Ms. Johnson said. "We're a church -- we help people. But there are people with fried brains. I don't want them flipping my hamburgers."
Other charitable organizations here and in other states have refused to hire community service workers, saying they work at dead-end jobs.
For example, Catholic Charities USA in Alexandria, Va., which represents a network of 1,400 private social service agencies, has been reluctant to take in welfare recipients because it also wants Government aid to train them for real work.
"It's kind of a moral dilemma," said Sharon M. Daly, head of social policy for Catholic Charities. "People should be paid, and paid enough to meet their needs. But our attitude has changed because the law has changed, and our clients don't have any choices."

GRAPHIC: Photos: By working for charities, welfare recipients can preserve their aid. Diana Goodrich, 33, sorting clothes for the Salvation Army in Dayton, Ohio. Community service jobs are intended to lead to regular work. Tawnya Lambert, 28, cooks at a church kitchen and attends college on the side. (Photographs by Mark Lyons for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Growing Latin Market Creates New Battleground of Cable TV

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER

DATELINE: MIAMI, May 11

 BODY:
With more than 450 million potential viewers, Latin America offers a cable television market ripe for the plucking, and with that idea in mind, CNN began giving Latin Americans news around the clock in their own language in mid-March. But there is a complication: CBS already provides such a service, as do networks based in Mexico, Brazil and Spain.
Cable television may have arrived late and only patchily to the Spanish- and Portuguese-speaking world. But rising incomes, the introduction of satellite dishes and the proliferation of 24-hour-a-day news services have transformed Latin America into one of the world's most contested pay-television markets, pitting networks based in the United States against indigenous rivals. 
 At stake is dominance of an area that already has almost as many households with television, nearly 90 million, as the United States and is experiencing a dizzying expansion as a growing middle class embraces cable and satellites and the news and entertainment they offer.
With the Latin American pay-television market expected to generate at least $2.5 billion annually in advertising revenue and subscriber fees by the turn of the century, broadcasters say it is imperative to establish a presence now.
"We feel the marketplace has matured to the point that a 24-hour-a-day operation makes sense both journalistically and financially," said Eason Jordan, executive vice president of International CNN, a unit of Time Warner Inc. "Latin America is an awfully big place, where the cable and satellite marketplaces are growing extraordinarily rapidly, advances in technology and systems of distribution have created new opportunities, and most countries, with the notable exception of Brazil, speak the same language."
CNN en Espanol, which went on the air March 17, is the Atlanta-based network's first venture into round-the-clock news programming under its own name in a language other than English. But the field is crowded: CBS, for instance, has been in the market almost a year, having bought Telenoticias in mid-1996 from a consortium that included Reuters, Telemundo and the Antena 3 network of Spain. CBS is owned by the Westinghouse Electric Corporation.
But the American entrants face competitors who argue they have a longer track record or greater familiarity with the Spanish-language news market. These include Eco, a nine-year-old, all-news subsidiary of Mexico's powerful Televisa group, and TVE, a news, information and entertainment channel operated by the Spanish Government, as well as Canal Sur, which rebroadcasts news programs from every major Latin America country, and Univision, the Miami-based Spanish-language network whose news and magazine programs are widely seen.
In addition, several companies are about to start Portuguese-language services aimed at Brazil, the region's biggest country, with a population upward of 160 million and a cable market that is growing by 60,000 households a month. Both CBS Telenoticias and Eco expect to begin broadcasting sometime this year, which will put them in direct competition with a news channel offered by Rede Globo, Brazil's leading network and a partner with Time Warner in a new Portuguese-language educational network scheduled to go on the air this summer.
Thus far, none of the channels are making money, not even Eco, which has been on the air since September 1988 and says it does not expect to turn a profit until 2000. But in a part of the world where illiteracy is still high and new entrants into the middle class are eager to consume, broadcasters say television offers opportunities other media do not.
According to a study published last month by Audits and Surveys, a New York media research company, the number of households in Latin America with cable or satellite television jumped last year to 14.2 million from 10.9 million in 1995, a 30 percent increase; in Brazil, the increase was elevenfold. In addition, nearly 30 percent of all Latin American subscribers belong to what the study described as "the highest socio-economic level."
CNN executives noted that some of the largest American, Japanese and European advertisers, eager to reach the Latin American audience with a single buy instead of fragmenting their budgets among 20 different countries, have been quick to sign on to the concept. CBS Telenoticias, which says it reaches 10 million households in 18 countries, sees its future lying in the same direction.
"The pie is so huge that we are going to see new budgets created by the big advertisers," Francisco de la Torre, a former Pepsico Foods executive who is now president of CBS Telenoticias, predicted. "Either everyone is crazy or everyone sees a tremendous opportunity that has yet to be exploited."
For CBS in particular, the Latin American market offers a rare second chance to make up for missed opportunity, and at a relatively cheap price. In the United States, CBS moved early into cable, but was soon overtaken by its competitors.
"We recognized right away that with CNN and MSNBC out there, getting into the English-language news business was an invitation to disaster," said Lloyd Werner, executive vice president for sales and marketing for CBS Cable. Latin America, in contrast, he said, was "an untapped market."
By buying Telenoticias in a complicated deal that saw Telemundo buy out Reuters and Antena 3 before selling the network to CBS, "we avoided the start-up costs and stutters" associated with a new operation, Mr. Werner said. According to Securities and Exchange Commission filings, CBS acquired Telenoticias for $5 million in cash and a $1.25 million five-year note.
Even without showing a profit, however, the news channels have clearly already transformed the way news is covered and watched in Latin America. In the past, the first thing any would-be dictator did during a coup was to seize control of the local television and radio stations.
"Today, with the proliferation of new technologies and channels, that sort of blockage and censorship of the news is impossible," said Rosental Calmon Alves, a professor of journalism at the University of Texas College of Communications who specializes in Latin America. "In some cases, it is obvious that the coverage of these news channels is more efficient and independent than that of the local channels."
Already, though, the battle to deliver news to Latin America's middle class has claimed a big-name casualty. NBC's Canal de Noticias, based in Charlotte, N.C., ceased broadcasting April 1 after nearly four years of low ratings.
An NBC spokesman, George Jamison, said that while "obviously you always pay close attention to the actions of potential competitors," the decision to shut down Canal de Noticias was "not a direct result" of CNN's entry into the field. Rather, he said, after the opening of the MSNBC English-language news channel last year, "it didn't make any sense for us to operate a much smaller niche service."
But articles in magazines and newspapers throughout Latin America, as well as executives at rival networks, said Canal de Noticias was too American. "Canal de Noticias was nothing more than a translation service that piggybacked onto NBC News, using the same stories and the same set," said Felix Cortes Camarillo, president of Eco.
Mr. Cortes added that he doubted that all of the channels now competing in the Spanish-language news market could survive. But he expressed confidence that his network could hold its own against the two American giants.
"There's no more news than what happens, and we all have access to the same news," he said. "What's different is the angle of vision. We speak the language, and when I say that, I'm not talking about Spanish so much as a point of view."
But CBS Telenoticias, which is based here, bills itself as the one truly regional network, proudly noting that its 12 anchors hail from 8 countries and that it has reporters and producers representing every country in Latin America. "We are the only ones taking a pan-Latin American approach, and being based in the city that is the crossroads of Latin America, we have access to the best talent and all the important newsmakers," said Ricardo Brown, a Cuban-American who is the network's news director.
CNN en Espanol, in turn, appears to be emphasizing the value of its brand name and its franchise as the world's most widely seen provider of news via cable. "We adhere to CNN standards and quality, adding a Latin American focus," said Rolando Santos, a Mexican-American journalist who oversees the channel. "We don't translate. We are a wide-ranging, full-service network."
Its jabs at its American rivals notwithstanding, Eco carries baggage of its own. Televisa, its parent company, is widely regarded throughout Latin America as the television mouthpiece of the Institutional Revolutionary Party, Mexico's ruling party for nearly 70 years, and its newscasts have been criticized as lacking the impartiality that both the American networks are using as a selling point.
"It is true" that in the past there has been "some contamination" of official Mexican Government views, Mr. Cortes acknowledged. That has changed because "the Mexican political system has been altered" in recent years, he said.
The opportunity to reach the rapidly growing Hispanic market in the United States and also 40 million people in Spain only adds to the appeal for all the competitors. About 1 of every 10 Americans, or more than 27 million people, are estimated to be of Hispanic descent.
Already, though, the Hispanic market in the United States has more disposable income than any country in Latin America except Brazil and Mexico, which makes it especially attractive to broadcasters and advertisers alike. CBS Telenoticias began separate programming aimed at the United States on March 17, the same day that CNN en Espanol went on the air.
Although United States cable operators are reluctant to give up a slot to a channel that has no hope of appealing to a majority of viewers, with the prospect of more openings materalizing soon, CNN plans eventually to follow CBS's lead.

HEADLINE: Arizona Governor Facing Trial on Fraud and Extortion

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr.

DATELINE: PHOENIX, May 11

 BODY:
Barring a last-minute plea-bargaining agreement, Gov. Fife Symington will go on trial here on Tuesday on 22 charges of fraud, lying and extortion, the second of Arizona's chief executives to be accused of felonious wrongdoing in less than a decade.
Mr. Symington, once a fast-rising star in the Republican Party, as well as one of Arizona's highest-flying land developers, is accused of misleading and financially muscling lenders in a desperate effort to shore up a multimillion-dollar real estate empire that went bankrupt in the grinding recession of the late 1980's and early 1990's. 
 If convicted, he could be sent to prison for scores of years.
A blueblooded descendant of a long line of wealthy businessmen and public servants -- his great-grandfather, Henry Clay Frick, made a fabulous fortune in steel, and a cousin, Stuart Symington, was a power in the United States Senate and a Presidential candidate -- the Governor contends that he is the victim of an overzealous Federal investigation.
He insists he is innocent and could never have committed the wrongs of which he is accused, not even in the freewheeling, live-and-let-live world of sunny, booming Arizona.
"I intend to fight," has been his mantra ever since his indictment a year ago after a five-year investigation by Government agents.
On a shelf in his office he has prominently placed a bumper sticker that proclaims: "Never Give Up. Never. Never. Never. Never."
Government lawyers contend that Mr. Symington, in the years leading up to his run for Governor and then in the early years of his first term, lied repeatedly to lenders about his assets and liabilities to persuade them to give him money to keep a string of foundering shopping centers and office parks afloat.
At one point, the prosecutors say, he fraudulently claimed to be worth $12 million when, in fact, he was $24 million in debt. At another point, they say, he threatened to steer tenants, including state government agencies, away from an office development operated by one lender. His intent, as the prosecutors tell it, was to extort from the lender better terms for the repayment of a $10 million loan.
It is a crime under Federal law to make false or misleading statements about a financial deal that involves money passing through a federally insured financial institution. Some of the institutions Mr. Symington dealt with over the years were federally insured.
The Governor says not only that he expects to beat the Government's charges, but also that come 1998 he will run for a third term in the office he won in 1991 after Gov. Evan Mecham was impeached and driven from the job.
Mr. Mecham was accused of accepting an illegal campaign loan. He was eventually acquitted, though not until after he had been forced from office.
Mr. Symington, freed without bond immediately after his arrest, thus far has managed to fend off all impeachment and recall efforts and in the interim has been notably active in pushing through a moderate-to-conservative agenda of tax cuts, social programs and environmental measures. But his standing with voters has nevertheless fallen steadily, to the point that only 1 in 3 now gives him a "good" approval rating, and he still must face his greatest challenge in his 51 years: the jury trial that will begin in Federal District Court here at 9:30 A.M. on Tuesday.
Though both the Governor and prosecutors say they will be in court that morning, rumors of plea bargaining that could head off a trial have been swirling in Phoenix for weeks. Neither side will comment on whether a bargain has ever been broached for discussion.
If a bargain is struck, it presumably would spare scandal-weary Arizonans some of the embarrassment of having their top elected official in the dock. Still, such a bargain might very well include a requirement that Mr. Symington resign, a development that would cause huge political and administrative turmoil in a state that is ever trying to put on its best face to draw in new faces, new business and new money.
Mr. Symington's indictment has already stirred considerable political turmoil, with a fairly large crop of possible gubernatorial candidates gathering in the wings.
And once his trial begins, some administrative turmoil almost certainly will follow because the Governor will be required to spend most of his working days in court rather than in his office a few blocks away.
Prosecutors estimate it could take three months or more to hear the case, given all the paperwork they plan to introduce. They say they and their investigators looked over more than a million documents in preparing for the trial.
"The bottom line is, we're ready," one member of the Government team, David Schindler, declared the other day.

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Remains Hostile to Census Sampling

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11

 BODY:
Republican leaders in Congress have hardened in their opposition to the use of statistical sampling to arrive at final population figures in the next census, setting up a probable showdown with the White House on an issue of huge political and social importance.
A letter this week to Martha Farnsworth Riche, the census director, voiced opposition to "statistical schemes that compromise accuracy for the sake of economy" and questioned the constitutionality of sampling, which the bureau wants to use three years from now. 
 The letter was signed by Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, the assistant majority leader, Speaker Newt Gingrich of Georgia, and Representative Dick Armey of Texas, majority leader.
"We must physically count each and every American," the letter said, pledging enough money to do that, without specifying an amount.
Dr. Riche replied in writing on Thursday that "it is fruitless to continue trying to count every last person with traditional census methods of physical enumeration." The Census Bureau wants to count 90 percent of the households in a given area, then use that data to calculate what the remaining 10 percent would presumably be like.
The Republicans' hard-line stance against that technique, outlined even as a compromise on the issue was supposedly being reached in the Senate, and Dr. Riche's reply highlighted a fight over constitutional questions, billions of dollars and the political fortunes of parties and individuals.
Many political analysts say that sampling would help Democrats and hurt Republicans, because it would tally members of minority groups and poor people who might otherwise go uncounted.
If that happened, the reasoning goes, legislative districts would be reconfigured to account for the newly counted people, who would almost surely vote Democratic. So Republicans, who waited four decades to regain control of the House, might have practical as well as constitutional reservations about sampling.
Local officials, especially big-city mayors who depend on Federal and state aid based on their communities' populations, also tend to favor statistical sampling.
The census director took issue with the Republican letter writers' assertion that "despite criticism, the 1990 census was the most accurate in history." In fact, she said, the 1990 census was the first to miss more people than the previous census. "It failed to count millions of Americans in urban and rural communities across the country," she said.
Census officials have estimated that the 1990 census undercounted the population by 1.6 percent, versus a 1.2 percent undercount in 1980.
The White House has said that President Clinton would veto any measure that bars the Census Bureau from using sampling. A White House spokesman, Barry Toiv, said on Thursday that there was nothing new in the Administration's stance.
"The Census Bureau and Commerce Department are confident that there will be greater confidence as people gain a greater understanding," Mr. Toiv said. He said the Senate might have cleared the way for "a good public debate."
As the Senate completed work on Thursday on a $5.5 billion disaster-aid bill, meant in part to help victims of flooding in the Middle West, it approved an amendment blocking the Census Bureau from making any "irreversible plans" to use sampling in the year 2000. The House will also vote on the sampling issue.
Although the wording in the Senate amendment was softer than that in a previous measure (the Senate Appropriations Committee had urged that the Census Bureau be forbidden to spend any money even planning for sampling), the Republican leaders who wrote to Dr. Riche seemed more adamant than ever.
If sampling does not work well or is ruled invalid, the Republicans' letter asserted, "the result will be chaos in government, uncertainty for voters, lawsuits lasting for the better part of a decade."
The Constitution refers to an "actual enumeration" of the population, and the Supreme Court has not ruled on whether statistical sampling is constitutional. The Republicans' letter warned that, if the census for 2000 uses sampling and the High Court later declares it unconstitutional, several billion dollars and incalculable work would have gone to waste.
Dr. Riche said that several lower Federal courts had upheld sampling and that the Justice Department had issued three opinions affirming its constitutionality and legality. These were handed down under the Presidencies of Jimmy Carter, George Bush and Bill Clinton, she said.
Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, a New York City Democrat, reflected the stakes of her party and her city on Thursday when she called sampling "critically important to New York" and the basis of "a fair, accurate census."
But political considerations do not follow a script. Six years ago, a Southern Congressman wrote to Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher, arguing that the 1990 census figures for his state should be adjusted upward to make up for "the admitted undercount." The Congressman was Newt Gingrich, Republican of Georgia.
