HEADLINE: Reporter's Notebook;
The Clintons' Caribbean: TV, a Pool and Time Off

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET

DATELINE: BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, May 11

 BODY:
For Bill Clinton, one of his closest aides once explained, "words are actions."
That, as much as his crutches and a sore back, may explain why Mr. Clinton was so exhausted by his talk-filled Latin American tour, before he finally got a day off today with his wife, Hillary, on this prim little island. 
 All the extravagant toasts and polite speeches, all the summit palaver and the pauses for interpretation, and all the joint agreements frosted with sugary items about protecting tiny dolphins and providing advice on electric vehicles, had clearly worn down even this notoriously loquacious President. Twice in recent days he has felt uncharacteristically compelled to say, "Most of what needs to be said has been said" -- and then to say less himself than anyone expected.
Today, the public chatter stopped. The Clintons are staying until Monday in Heron Bay, the borrowed 25-acre estate of British aristocrats, where the trees are labeled ("Breadfruit," "Sago Palm Coconut," "Pride of India") and the pool is guarded by statues of cherubs. As the sunlight glittered on the sapphire sea, President Clinton elected to relax today by watching basketball on television.
 
A Journalism Cease-Fire
For the United States and the countries he has visited, the lingering question, of course, is whether the piles of words President Clinton and his counterparts deposited during his three-nation swing will simply blow away, leaving nothing behind.
As a result, President Clinton was bombarded with skepticism by the American and regional press corps all week.
At a news conference on Thursday in Costa Rica, a Central American journalist asked if Mr. Clinton's summit meetings, apart from discussion of trade issues, "should not be considered as social events with rhetorical results that have nothing to do with reality"
It may not be surprising that President Clinton said they should not. He pointed out that he had promised to help train Central American law enforcement officers, and to help improve education and preserve the environment. "In addition to that, as you know, we still have some modest aid programs," he said.
Then he moved on to the next questioner. The journalist, an American, quoted an unidentified State Department official as saying that when it came to immigration issues, Mr. Clinton was offering only "words and promises and hot air." He wondered if that was so.
Here, in paradise, the press scrutiny has subsided somewhat, though. Outside the camera frame, some network correspondents are wearing shorts with their shirts and ties; during a briefing by high-level Administration officials on Saturday evening, the television sets flanking the podium showed not CNN but "Xena: Warrior Princess."
 
B-Word Makes a Comeback
Some of Mr. Clinton's words have certainly proved enduring in this region, although their precise meaning remains elusive. During the trip, foreign leaders, eagerly seeking a connection with the American President, ventured a suspicious number of metaphors regarding a certain feature of infrastructure.
P. J. Patterson, the Prime Minister of Jamaica and chairman of Caricom, a regional economic association, informed Mr. Clinton on Saturday that "the people of the Caribbean wish to cross that bridge with you."
During a speech welcoming Mr. Clinton in San Jose, President Jose Maria Figueres Olsen of Costa Rica made an even more explicit homage to Mr. Clinton's relentlessly repeated campaign theme.
"We have decided to call this encounter, 'Bridge to the 21st Century,' " he said, as a some members of the White House press corps shuddered.
 
Cheat Sheets Save the Day
Speaking of speaking, listeners sometimes wonder how those American leaders breeze their way through tricky foreign names in their speeches
A clue to the technique was provided by the text prepared for a speech by Hillary Rodham Clinton in San Jose, Costa Rica. The text began by acknowledging the first lady of Costa Rica and others: "Mrs. Figueres [Fee-Gay-Raise], President Iglesias [Ee-glay-see-ahs], Mark Schnieder. . . ."
It may be because Mr. Clinton so rarely refers to his texts that his Spanish pronunciation remained rocky all last week, beginning with the Americanized "Saludos amigos," which brought scattered chuckles at an arrival ceremony in Mexico City on Tuesday.
But the President did not experience the kind of difficulty faced by the Mexican officer who presented troops for his review that day. After dashing across a field to bellow a request to start the parade, the officer got as far as "William J." before apparently forgetting the President's last name. He sputtered and gave up.
"Did you see how hard he had to run?" Mr. Clinton asked later. "I would have forgotten my own name."
 
The Original 'Tough Love'
Despite his exchange student's level of earnestness about the countries he has visited on this trip, Mr. Clinton has not been above poking fun at his own initiatives back home. Touring the anthropology museum in Mexico City on Monday, he considered the impact on childhood development, one of his pet issues, of flattening infants' skulls, a practice of one ancient culture there.
"It depends whether you read to them and sing to them while you're squeezing their heads," he mused.
The museum tour came long before Mr. Clinton was worn down by the week's worth of speechifying. He was still spry enough to concoct some hypothetical words for a mother to say: " 'I'm squeezing your head,' " he suggested. " 'I love you. I'm squeezing your head because I love you.' "

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
As tourism stagnates, Hawaii fights back with a campaign to invigorate its image.

BYLINE: By Daniel M. Gold

 BODY:
THERE is trouble in paradise, at least in getting people to visit.
As a state, Hawaii is not yet 38 years old, but as a tourist magnet it is into a "mature product phase." That dry-eyed assessment comes not from jealous travel officials of other Pacific Rim destinations, but from the research department of the state's very own Hawaii Visitors and Convention Bureau. 
 The phenomenal popularity Hawaii once took for granted -- until the 1980's, the number of tourist visits was doubling every five years -- has cooled, with growth much slower and, in some segments, stagnant.
According to the bureau, total annual tourist spending tumbled in the years following its peak of $10.63 billion in 1991, dipping as low as $8.67 billion in 1993 before slowly climbing back. Preliminary estimates for 1995, the last year for which data are available, is now $11 billion. But the tepid rise is bad news for an economy in which one in three jobs is directly tied to tourism.
Moreover, while slippage from one market in recent years had been offset by growth in others, last year was different. "A few months ago, we started noticing that either the increase in business was not as strong as it had been, or a decrease," said Roberta Rinker-Ludloff, the bureau's vice president for marketing. "It was a wake-up call."
So, Gov. Ben Cayetano sought and won $10 million from the state Legislature in emergency financing for marketing and advertising. The first results of that call to arms began running last month nationally on cable channels like CNN, Discovery, A & E and Lifetime and on spot broadcasts in such key cities as Chicago and New York. The spots end with a telephone number (1-800-GOHAWAII) and Internet address (http://www.gohawaii.com) where travel planners may be requested.
The campaign, which has also included eight-page inserts in newspapers in New York, San Francisco, Los Angeles, Dallas and Denver, "is a big step forward compared to what we have done in the last few years," Ms. Rinker-Ludloff said.
Until the 1990's, the islands enjoyed almost uninterrupted growth as a tourist destination, but have since stumbled. "We've been in a slump since the Persian Gulf war," said Chuck Y. Gee, the dean of the University of Hawaii's School of Travel Industry Management.
The peaks for Hawaii's tourist trade were mostly set earlier this decade, some as much as seven years ago. Indeed, 1990 holds the record for total arrivals: nearly 7 million, with 4.7 million of those "westbound" tourists -- that is, travelers coming from the United States or other points east. By 1995, the total had fallen to 6.6 million, of whom 3.9 million were westbound. Preliminary estimates for 1996 are slightly higher for total visits, but westbound remains flat.
As the westbound visits have fallen, the good news has come from eastbound tourists. Of 2.7 million eastbound arrivals in 1995, 2 million were from Japan.
Even there, the immediate future is not bright: the state had been projecting up to 6 percent growth in Japanese visits this year. But citing the soft Tokyo stock market and weakness in the yen and Japanese consumer confidence, it recently revised the projection to zero growth.
To reinvigorate the state's image, the "We are Hawaii" campaign, which is produced by the Hawaiian office of Ogilvy & Mather, a unit of the WPP Group, tries to cover a lot in 45-second and 60-second spots.
Over shots from all six of Hawaii's main islands -- Kauai, Oahu, Maui, Molokai, Lanai and the Big Island -- a female narrator invokes Hawaii's Polynesian culture, recounting the legend of the islands' creation. The spots also mix glimpses of activities like horseback riding and kayaking with more conventional images of Waikiki Beach and luaus. The campaign's tag line is "The Islands of Aloha."
To Dean Gee, the challenge is to keep Hawaii as a top possibility when tourists consider vacation sites. "It's not quite like selling a can of beans, which comes with a certain degree of predictability," he said.
For example, the commercials must appeal to at least two specific segments of visitors: those from the Midwest and East Coast who take longer trips -- an average of 10 days -- because of the length of time it takes to travel there; and those from the West Coast, especially Californians, who have used Hawaii as a getaway for shorter vacations.
The campaign is also trying to pitch to both the first-time visitor -- a segment the bureau found had seen a "dramatic decline" in the last 10 years -- and the repeat customer.
"We are trying to stimulate travel through and to all the islands," said Frank Haas, managing director of Ogilvy & Mather Hawaii. That, he said, was the thought behind the tag line: "The islands suggest the diversity of experiences to be had; aloha tries to convey the hospitality of the people."
"The competitive stakes have been raised," he said. "The people we're trying to reach might also be thinking of taking a cruise, or going to Mexico, the Caribbean or Europe.
"We have to encourage people to take longer trips, explain that they shortchange themselves when they only take five days. Diversity and aloha works for both of those markets: For the East Coast, the diversity and aloha justifies the trip, and for the West Coast consumer who thinks 'I've been there, done that,' we are saying, 'Wait, you haven't.' "
Actually, the North American campaign is just the first of two the bureau is undertaking this year, and the lesser of the two at that. A $6 million campaign for Japan, to be handled by Hakuhodo Inc. in Tokyo, will begin later this month.
That campaign gets more state financing, Ms. Rinker-Ludloff said, because "we need to catch up a bit in Japan."
Most Japanese tourists seldom leave Oahu in their Hawaiian trips, so that campaign will also push the idea of visiting more than one island. "The overall theme will still be on Hawaii," she said, "but we want to start educating them on the uniqueness of each island."
Finally, Ms. Rinker-Ludloff said, the presentations about the campaign served as an education for state legislators, some of whom either were not convinced that the state needed promotion or felt that the job was best left to the private sector. "Our message to the legislature in trying to obtain funding was that we need to look at funding as an investment, not an expense, and that there will be a return for this investment," she said.

SECTION: Section D;Page 1;Column 2;Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1429 words

HEADLINE: The Internet as Commerce: Who Pays, Under What Rules?

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
Names and handshakes, it would seem, are simple matters of identification and etiquette. But the digital equivalents of names and handshakes are now subjects of fierce debate, international negotiations and accusations of corporate skulduggery. The bedrock issue is who will determine the commercial rules of the road on the Internet, as the global web of computer networks increasingly becomes a mainstream medium of communication and commerce.
At stake, industry executives and Government officials say, is the future of the Internet, and what role large corporations, governments and international organizations will play. 
 The current arm-wrestling centers on two seemingly arcane subjects: assigning "domain names," or suffixes like ".com" in Internet addresses, and "peering," in which Internet service companies exchange electronic-mail messages with each other free. Proposed changes in both practices have caused an uproar on the Internet in the last few weeks.
Yet the particular disputes, Internet professionals agree, are the beginning of a host of thorny business and public policy issues that lie ahead, affecting not only companies but the price and availability of services in cyberspace.
"How these issues are resolved will determine how we do things and how we live with this new technology," said Don Heath, president of the Internet Society, a nonprofit organization in Reston, Va.
The evolutionary path of the Internet as a whole may be uncertain, but two trends appear inevitable.
First, the Federal Government will become increasingly involved in the affairs of the Internet, even if that role is more as a referee than as a regulator. Second, the business of supplying Internet access is headed for a shakeout, with big, well-financed corporations more and more supplying businesses and households with links to the Internet.
The dispute over "peering" -- the digital handshake and swapping of messages between Internet companies -- illustrates both trends. The issue emerged in the last two weeks after Uunet Technologies Inc., a unit of Worldcom Inc. and a leading supplier of Internet "backbone" connections, informed 13 smaller Internet service providers that it would no longer exchange messages with them free and would start charging them fees. The move by Uunet brought an outcry from the smaller companies, which are typically regional suppliers of cyberspace connections to households and small businesses, and from some analysts, who called the tactic anti-competitive and discriminatory.
One vocal critic, David Holub, lost his job as president of Whole Earth Networks in San Francisco in a disagreement with his company's owner over how to handle the Uunet move. In a posting on an on-line forum for Net professionals last week, Mr. Holub argued that because the Internet is a public network, the backbone carriers, like Uunet, should have the same obligations as telephone common carriers to freely exchange messages.
"I am a proponent of some regulation in the Internet as soon as possible," he wrote. "I think this minimal level of regulation is critical to the Internet's open and unrestricted development."
The Internet service companies are all trying to reach an accommodation with Uunet either by negotiating affordable fees or making the investments in network capacity and equipment so Uunet will treat them as peers, freely exchanging messages at points around the country.
The Internet has spawned a libertarian, free-market ethos. Still, the Uunet experience has some Internet executives talking about an appropriate role for the Government, perhaps having the Federal Communications Commission provide the forum for public hearings to establish industrywide ground rules as it does in telecommunications. "That same kind of thing needs to happen," said Sandy Fitchet, vice president of CAIS Internet of McLean, Va.
In nearby Fairfax, Va., John Sidgmore, president of Uunet, views the change in his company's peer policy as a practical step in response to the growth in the Internet business. The practice with companies of all sizes dates back to the early 1990's when, he said, the Internet was "a smaller, gentler place."
Driving companies out of business, Mr. Sidgmore insists, is not his motive. But it is absurd, he adds, to expect a handful of backbone Internet companies like Uunet, which must invest hundreds of millions of dollars a year to build networks, to carry traffic in general free of charge.
To be treated as a peer, Mr. Sidgmore said, an Internet service company needs to have a high-speed national network and pay for connections with Uunet in four regional locations. "Anybody who wants to spend the money to do that can be a peer," he said.
The other backbone suppliers, analysts say, are likely to follow Uunet's lead. Five companies -- MCI Communications; Sprint; Uunet; BBN, a unit of the GTE Corporation, and ANS, a unit of America Online Inc. -- handle 80 percent of the nation's Internet traffic, estimates Gordon Cook, publisher of the Cook Report, a monthly newsletter. "These players are in a position to declare themselves the Internet, and it could mean the costs of access are going to go up sharply," Mr. Cook said.
And as the costs rise for Internet service companies, their ranks are expected to be winnowed sharply, from an estimated 3,000 today to fewer than 100 within five years. "The question is how much competition will result and what that will mean for consumers," said Mark Anderson, president of Technology Alliance Partners, a consulting firm.
The answer to that question is not clear-cut by any means. But it is clearly the kind of issue that will be watched closely from Washington.
The F.C.C. has so far taken few stands on Internet policy other than espousing general goals like promoting competition and innovation. One exception to that pattern was setting up a Universal Service Fund last week as part of the commission's overhaul of phone rates, with some proceeds going to equip schools and libraries with Internet connections.
Yet the Government's hands-off stance becomes less tenable as the Internet becomes an everyday necessity, a communications utility, for more and more people. And the advance of digital technology into telecommunications -- as voice, data and images are increasingly transmitted in the computer language of bits -- means that Government regulators will probably soon be pulled into the Internet business.
"Our approach has basically been that the Internet should not be regulated," said a senior F.C.C. staff member, who insisted on anonymity. "But that approach increasingly doesn't work in a world of convergence of telecommunications and computer technology."
The current spat over Internet domain names, oddly, is a byproduct of the Government's walking away from involvement with the Internet. The National Science Foundation, which used to run the Internet backbone, awarded a five-year contract in 1993 to a small company, Network Solutions Inc., to administer domain names. The Government contract expires next March, and the foundation has said it is getting out of the Internet business.
Instead, the Government is letting the Internet community -- an increasingly large, diverse and unruly group -- decide who should assign domain names. So far, it has been a bumpy process. A week ago, 57 companies and organizations signed a proposal for a new system of assigning Internet addresses presented by a group called the Internet Ad Hoc Committee, headed by Mr. Heath of the Internet Society. Among other things, the proposal calls for the addition of seven new domain suffixes, like ".store" and ".firm."
The proposal has supporters, but it has not yet been approved by many major high-technology corporations, including I.B.M. and the AT&T Corporation. The United States Government and the European Community have expressed reservations. Critics say the process should be slowed down and opened up to greater public discussion instead of embracing the plan of a self-appointed group of Internet old-timers.
A more authoritative international organization, some observers say, might be needed to serve the role of honest broker -- perhaps a quorum of governments.
Peter Harter, the global public policy counsel for the Netscape Communications Corporation, notes that the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development has been studying the economic impact of domain names, and has been circulating a working document among its members. "The O.E.C.D. is a possible forum," Mr. Harter said.

HEADLINE: O'Connor, Seeing Housing as a Right, Calls for a Panel to Advise Lawmakers

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY

 BODY:
Calling "dignified affordable housing" a human right and a moral imperative, John Cardinal O'Connor urged state lawmakers yesterday to preserve the current rent regulation laws until a panel could examine changes that would not hurt the poor and middle class.
In a carefully worded sermon at St. Patrick's Cathedral, the Cardinal acknowledged that the current system of rent regulations might be less than perfect. But he questioned the wisdom of replacing them "with either no system or an untried system" when they expire next month, especially in the supercharged political climate that surrounds the issue. 
 And while he did not pretend to offer solutions of his own, he said a broadly representative commission -- of landlords, tenants, the poor and the middle class from various racial and ethnic backgrounds -- should be convened to make recommendations to the State Legislature.
"It seems to me that government has a grave moral responsibility to meet the human needs and to help make possible the living out of the human rights of all its people to the best of its ability," said the Cardinal, who has often criticized cuts to welfare benefits.
"Who knows better what their needs really are or how well their human rights are given appropriate support than the people themselves?"
The comments by the Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York come as the opposing sides in Albany appear no closer to meaningful discussion and as Gov. George E. Pataki begins to promote a compromise plan. Landlord groups and other opponents of rent regulations had feared that a strong statement by the Cardinal in favor of the current system could weaken Senate Republicans, who have vowed to phase out the laws.
Joseph Strasburg, the president of the Rent Stabilization Association, the largest landlord group, indicated through a spokesman that he was more exasperated than worried about the Cardinal's position.
"With all due respect to his eminence, the issue has been studied over and over, and every reputable study has concluded with the need to abolish rent regulations," said the spokesman, Stephen Mangione.
"There are responsible ways to phase out regulations, and that's what we should be doing now. Small-property owners especially, whose expenses already outpace their income, cannot wait for two more years of studies."
But Michael McKee of the New York State Tenants and Neighbors Coalition, who met with the Cardinal on Friday to make his case for keeping rent regulations, said he thought that the sermon was unequivocal enough that it would provide a boon for rent-regulation proponents.
"It's very clear that his position is that it would be immoral to allow these laws to expire," Mr. McKee said.
He added that tenant advocates would agree to take part in a process to examine the system and replace it as long as affordable housing was maintained.
"We believe rent regulation is the best and cheapest way to provide affordable housing," Mr. McKee said. "But we're very willing to sit down on a commission to look at other ways to do it."
The Cardinal used much of his time in his homily to explain why he had decided to weigh in on what has become the most politically charged debate in the state this year.
Reading from a prepared text of six printed pages, he used quotations from three popes, a Yale political scientist, a noted Catholic economist and the catechism to underscore his assertion that decent housing was a fundamental right. As such, he said, it would be morally wrong if governments did not work to insure it.
"Moral reasoning may not be helpfully separated from reality, particularly, in this case, economic and political reality," the Cardinal said. The question, then, from the church's perspective, was "startlingly simple," he said.
"Does the current system make it possible or impossible for everyone to live in dignified affordable housing?"
Cardinal O'Connor said that though he had pored over rent studies until late at night, he had come to no firm conclusions.
But in an indication that he tended to reject some of the arguments made by property owners, he criticized those who spoke of trade-offs, in which people should be willing to pay much more if they choose to live in certain parts of the city.
"That's morality and economics in a vacuum," he said. "What is to be traded off? Food, education, health care? These are human rights."
Throughout the sermon, he steered carefully away from commenting on the lawmakers involved in the issue, and did not even mention the State Legislature by name.
In the end, though, Cardinal O'Connor seemed acutely aware of the political strategies animating the debate. Calling for the current system to be extended, he added:
"Smarter people than I will know how such delay could be provided without forcing legislators to be seeming to abandon positions which they believe integrity requires them to have taken."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Dignified affordable housing" is a human right and a moral imperative, John Cardinal O'Connor said. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Machine Tool Orders Rose 9.3% in March

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11

 BODY:
Orders for American-made machine tools jumped 9.3 percent in March from February, according to an industry survey released this weekend.
Orders from American companies for domestic and foreign-produced machine tools rose to an estimated $721 million in March from a revised $659 million in February, said a joint report from the Association for Manufacturing Technology and the American Machine Tool Distributor's Association. The increase was the third rise in estimated orders in the last four months. 
 Estimated March orders were 4.1 percent higher than the $683 million reported in March 1996.
Orders for the first quarter of 1997 totaled an estimated $1.9 billion, the groups said, up 11.5 percent from the corresponding quarter last year.
Analysts regard orders for machine tools -- used to shape and assemble metal in products ranging from diesel engines to dishwashers -- as a gauge of industrial output, investment and consumer demand.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
A Great Wee Place

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: BELFAST, Northern Ireland

 BODY:
I just visited Northern Ireland and I have some bad news: The status quo there is too comfortable.
Yes, the cease-fire between the factions broke down in February 1996, after 17 months of peace. But the truth is, the breakdown of the cease-fire has not really affected Northern Ireland much, because the I.R.A. has confined its bombings to England. As for life here in Belfast, well, McDonald's and Kentucky Fried Chicken seem to be everywhere. While I was here, Prince Charles inaugurated the new $40 million Waterfront Hall opera house, where he and 2,500 guests paying $125 each were serenaded by Dame Kiri Te Kanawa. The Europa Hotel, Belfast's most oft-bombed building, recently signaled its optimism by removing from the lunch menu its famous "BLAST" sandwich (Bacon, Lettuce and Some Tomato)! And in recent years the authorities have replaced some of the ugly corrugated steel fences dividing Catholic and Protestant neighborhoods with what the locals call "designer walls" -- the sort of patterned brick wall you'd find around a gated community in Florida. 
 No Toto, this is not the Gaza Strip.
Or as one moderate Catholic professor here remarked to me: "Let's be honest, the middle classes here are doing very well." The dirty little secret of Ulster is that while it has become a metaphor for civil war, that war is actually confined to a few very small areas in Belfast and Derry, and the rest of Northern Ireland is downright beautiful. For those who know the secret, Ulster is now a metaphor for a "great wee place" to retire. Housing prices are cheap, golf is plentiful and public schools, social services, investment subsidies and roads are the best in Britain -- thanks to the money the British and the European Union pour in here. Unemployment is around 8 percent, far better than in France, Germany or Italy. And if per chance the I.R.A. does blow up your shop, the British will rebuild it free.
That's why I wonder whether Northern Ireland's cure and its disease aren't the same thing: the same economic development that produced the cease-fire (and still limits its breakdown) also cushions the factions and reduces the pressure on them to make the tough compromises needed to get beyond the cease-fire and secure a lasting peace. There is an all too tolerable balance here now between violence and affluence.
Lord knows I'm not rooting for Belfast to become Gaza or Soweto, but the fact is Rabin and Arafat, Mandela and de Klerk were produced in pressure cookers exerting great pain on their rank and file -- not by black-tie receptions and one-star Michelin restaurants (there are two in Belfast). In Belfast, political leaders can still afford to indulge their ideological fantasies. Gerry Adams, head of the I.R.A.'s Sinn Fein party, David Trimble, leader of the Protestant Ulster Unionist Party, and Tony Blair, Britain's Prime Minister, all did better than ever in the last elections -- without having to promise any courageous initiatives to get peace talks going.
Successful peace talks would require Mr. Adams to take the risk of getting the I.R.A. to declare an open-ended cease-fire, without any guarantees about the timing and outcome of those talks. They would require Mr. Trimble to risk sitting down with Sinn Fein and negotiating a power-sharing arrangement with the Catholics. And they would require Mr. Blair's fracturing the bipartisan British consensus on Northern Ireland and negotiating with the I.R.A. before it turned in every weapon or gave ironclad assurances that the cease-fire wouldn't be broken again. All three would have to take these risks while their opponents denounced them for "selling out."
Maybe they will show such courage. But it won't be easy. The public longing here for peace is very real, but passive. Life here is already 85 percent normal and the political price for getting the last 15 percent is very high. It would require bringing into the peace process the hardest-core elements on both sides, such as the thousands of working-class Catholics and Protestants who still live in the pockets of very high unemployment, and for whom the Irish wars still burn white hot. The brutal murders last week -- a Catholic stomped to death by a Protestant gang in Portadown and a Protestant gunned down by Catholic guerrillas in a Belfast bar -- remind us how the pockets of abnormality here could still blow apart the web of normalcy. And such an explosion would really set back the chances for peace . . . or would it?

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Poor Residents in Louisiana Fight Plan for Chemical Site

BYLINE: By The New York Times

DATELINE: CONVENT, La.

 BODY:
Emelda J. West said she believed that President Clinton was thinking of her when he signed an executive order on environmental justice in February 1994.
"I don't guess he knew I existed," Mrs. West said. "But he did have people like me in mind." 
 Now Mrs. West, who is 71, and other members of a local group, St. James Citizens for Jobs and the Environment, hope that the Clinton Administration will keep her in mind.
In March, the Tulane Environmental Law Clinic, on behalf of 19 environmental groups in Louisiana, asked the Environmental Protection Agency to use Mr. Clinton's order to reject a permit for a proposed chemical plant here, halfway between Baton Rouge and New Orleans. It was the first time that the environmental agency had been asked to reject a permit on grounds of environmental justice.
[The request by the citizens' group to the environmental agency was bolstered when the Nuclear Regulatory Commission announced on May 2 that it had denied a license to Louisiana Energy Services, which had sought to build an $855 million uranium-enrichment plant near Homer.
[The commission's action was the first time that a Federal agency had used Mr. Clinton's order on environmental justice to deny a license or permit. The commission also ordered its staff to investigate accusations that Louisiana Energy had purposely chosen to locate the plant in poor black neighborhoods.
["Certainly, the possibility that racial considerations played a part in the site selection cannot be passed off as mere coincidence," the Atomic Safety and Licensing Board said in a 91-page decision.]
The proposed $700 million chemical plant -- sought by Shintech, a subsidiary of the Shin-Etsu Chemical Company of Tokyo -- would produce polyvinyl chloride resin, which is used to make plastic products like pipes. The factory would be built on a 3,700-acre site that is now covered with foot-high rows of sugar cane.
In Houston, the controller of Shintech, Dick Mason, said Convent was the most remote of 30 sites that the company had considered. Mr. Mason said the company had chosen the site in St. James Parish because it is near the Mississippi River, rail lines and gas pipelines.
"We did not look at the racial or socioeconomic makeup of the area," he said.
The proposed project has divided this working-class parish of 21,000 residents. The parish is home to more than 12 plants that produce and ship fertilizers, petrochemicals, grains and metal products. The parish also has the third-highest level of industrial pollution in the state.
The parish president, Dale Hymel Jr., who favors the Shintech plant, said it would help alleviate poverty.
"We need to do something to deal with that," Mr. Hymel said. "And getting people a job is the best way I know."
Shintech, he said, would add 165 jobs in the parish.
An opponent of the plan, Pat Melancon, said the factories in the region had done little to help residents. Driving past dozens of ramshackle homes within miles of the Shintech site, she asked, "If these plants are so good for us, why don't we have more economic development here?"
In an area where per capita income is $7,259, Mrs. Melancon pointed to the 1990 Census, which showed that within five miles of the site, 80 percent of the residents are black and nearly 43 percent have incomes below the poverty level.
Mrs. Melancon said she believed that the E.P.A. would have to deal with the question of environmental justice. On April 3, the opponents received a favorable response from Samuel J. Coleman, a regional director in the compliance assurance division of the agency. In a letter to J. Dale Givens, the Secretary of the State Environmental Quality Department, Mr. Coleman said the issue of environmental justice should "merit your attention prior to permit issuance."
Although the state agency would have to issue the air-quality permit for the plant, the Federal agency can, under the Clean Air Act, overrule the state. But Federal officials conceded that they were unclear about what effect Mr. Clinton's order would have on the Shintech proposal.
"The E.P.A. has not defined what an environmental-justice community is," said a spokeswoman in the agency's Dallas office, Cheryl Hochstetler. "So we are waiting to see what is going to happen with this."
Ms. Hochstetler said the final decision on the Shintech permit, which is due by June 2, would be made by administrators in Washington.
The executive order says each Federal agency "shall make achieving environmental justice part of its mission." The order requires agencies to identify and address the health and environmental effects of their policies on "minority and low-income populations."
Paul H. Templet, a professor of environmental studies at Louisiana State University in Baton Rouge, said such vague wording, along with the support of Gov. Mike Foster, a Republican, put Federal officials in a difficult position.
"If they do overrule the state," Professor Templet said, "then they have the Congressmen to deal with, and that's a tough political call."
In any case, Mrs. West of the citizens' group said she believed that Federal officials would deny Shintech the permit it needed to build its plant a few miles north of the blue wooden house where she has lived for 50 years. "They will not locate here, darling," she said. "We have too many problems here already."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Victory, If No Ring, For Wells At Stadium

BYLINE: By JACK CURRY

 BODY:
Moments of perfection were scattered throughout Yankee Stadium yesterday, and they had little to do with the splendid sunshine, the blue skies or the hot pretzels, all pleasant touches. They had everything to do with David Wells, in a sharp 3-2 victory over the Royals, and with one more flashback to 1996, when the Yankees were more nearly perfect than any other major league team.
Wells enhanced the afternoon for the Yankees with a performance that was both economical and exemplary. He did not waste pitches while holding the Royals without a run until the eighth. And he did not let his empty ring finger or his empty heart deter him on a day when the Yankees were finally given their World Series championship rings and when Wells spent his first Mother's Day without his mom. 
 The zany left-handed pitcher made sure the focus immediately switched from the pre-game ring ceremony to his in-game pitching clinic. Deposit a quarter and watch Wells throw his fastball to get ahead in the count. Watch him stay ahead of the Royals and challenge them. Watch him retire hitters on feeble fly balls or strikeouts. Then watch Joe Torre reach for another roll of quarters.
"He doesn't complicate it for himself, which I think is a big problem with a lot of pitchers," said Torre, the Yankee manager. "They try to do too much. He's a throwback to: 'Here, hit it. I dare you.' It's a nice feeling. I'm very comfortable when I watch him pitch."
Torre was not alone in being comfortable as the Yankees marched to their 16th triumph in 21 games. Bernie Williams homered and slashed three hits, Derek Jeter drove in what amounted to the winning run off Jose Rosado with a double and Mariano Rivera nabbed his 13th save and his 10th in his last 10 chances.
Of course, Wells is always comfortable at the Stadium, where he won his third straight start to elevate his career record in the Bronx to 12-2, tying him with Bob Wickman (18-3) for the best winning percentage there (.857). Wells's pitching philosophy is simple: just throw strikes, which he has done with an astounding 227 strikes in 317 pitches in his winning streak.
"It's no fun pitching behind in the count," said Wells, who struck out six, walked one and allowed two runs in eight and one-third innings. "There's too many good hitters in this league to fall behind. You're going to get blasted out there. It just makes it a long day. The guys on the field are going to be like: 'Let's go. Let's get something going.' I think if you go strike one, strike two, it makes it that much easier."
It was a weird and emotional day for Wells. Weird, because he pitched for the Baltimore Orioles last season and therefore did not receive a World Series ring. Emotional, because it was Mother's Day and Eugenia Ann Wells died of a heart disease related to diabetes on Jan. 4 at the age of 58. Wells has a tattoo of his mother, a single parent who raised him to be independent and be an individual.
"She's in my heart every day," Wells said. "I always say a prayer to her every day when I go out to pitch. That feeling will never go away. My mom has always had faith in me and believed in me. That relaxes me."
Asked how tough yesterday was, Wells said: "Very tough. I got a job to do. You got to think about it. It's hard."
In typical Wells fashion, the pitcher bounced from serious to slapstick in seconds. When he was asked how it felt not to get a ring, he said: "I got a ball game to pitch, so I can't worry about that. When a guy turns his back, I'll steal his ring from him and have my own ring."
Three players who were instrumental in the Yankees' Series victory over the Atlanta Braves were instrumental yesterday. Jeter doubled home Tim Raines in the seventh inning to give Wells a 3-0 cushion, Williams bashed his second homer in two games with a 416-foot shot in the third and Cecil Fielder drove in the first run with a groundout in the first. Although three runs is not perfect, it seemed plenty for Wells.
Even after the Royals nicked Wells for three hits and two runs in the eighth and had the potential tying run on first with two out, he salvaged his masterpiece by striking out Jose Offerman with a sweet 1-2 fastball. After Wells notched the first out in the ninth, Rivera replaced him and allowed two base runners before securing the last two outs. Wells wanted perfection, as in a complete game, so he left grudgingly.
"I'm going to fight to stay in there," Wells said. "Joe was out there trying to pry the ball out of my hand. I wouldn't let it go."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: ENTERING DEBATE, GOVERNOR OFFERS RENT COMPROMISE

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 11

 BODY:
In his first attempt to broker a compromise on rent regulations, Gov. George E. Pataki today proposed lifting protections for a small number of wealthy tenants immediately and appeared to lay the groundwork for a broader plan to remove controls from apartments as they become vacant.
The proposals set a middle ground between Republicans in the State Senate who want to abolish the current rent regulations and Democrats in the Assembly who want to preserve them. 
 The Governor's decision to shift the debate toward the center by keeping some protections intact and to eliminate some that favor the wealthy offers legislators on each side a way to appease their constituents. The regulations expire at 12:01 A.M. June 16 unless they are extended.
Today's proposal is part of a more detailed Pataki plan that is expected to call for scaling back the regulations now restricting the rent on 1.1 million apartments, most of which are in New York City and its suburbs. Mr. Pataki said he would release the full plan on Monday, and his aides would not provide details beyond what was disclosed in his one-page statement released this afternoon.
In that statement, the Governor indicated that he supported continuing most rent protections. In the most telling sentence of his statement, the Governor broadly hinted at vacancy decontrol without using those words: "My plan to save rent control will ensure that every middle-class tenant has the right to remain in their apartment for the rest of their lives if they choose, protecting rent laws for about 99 percent of New York tenants."
A few hours before the Governor released his statement, John Cardinal O'Connor, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of New York, called for current laws to be extended until a new panel could recommend ways to maintain affordable housing in the city. [Page B6.]
In the Governor's sneak preview today, Mr. Pataki proposed expanding a policy known as luxury decontrol, which would lift protections for wealthy tenants. Currently, tenants who earn $250,000 or more for two consecutive years and live in apartments with monthly rates of $2,000 or more lose their protection. The Governor's plan would lower the income threshold to $175,000 a year, regardless of the rent.
He said his plan would protect nearly all the 2.7 million tenants living in rent-regulated apartments. "Only the top 1 percent of all tenants in rent-regulated apartments, those individuals making more than $175,000 annually who can afford to pay market rates, will be asked to do so," he said.
In outlining a framework under which the administration might embrace vacancy decontrol, a policy of lifting rent regulations on an apartment when a tenant leaves, the Governor also included penalties for landlords who try to harass tenants into leaving. In doing so, Mr. Pataki seemed to be acknowledging that allowing vacancy decontrol could result in many forced evictions, a fear often cited by tenant advocacy groups.
Mr. Pataki has supported vacancy decontrol in the past but has been silent on the issue in recent months.
Among the questions the Governor left unanswered is how vacancy decontrol might be phased in or whether he will maintain provisions like the so-called succession rule, which allows relatives of occupants to inherit rent-regulated apartments.
Governor Pataki's decision to step into the rent debate comes just two weeks after the state's Democratic Party began an advertisement campaign accusing both Mr. Pataki and his mentor, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, of avoiding the deregulation battle. In response, D'Amato, the state's Republican United States Senator, predicted that any resolution would maintain protections for middle-income and low-income residents.
 Mr. Pataki's plan was immediately criticized by tenant advocates and Democrats in the Assembly, who said that it would recklessly weaken protection for tenants. "The numbers released today in the Governor's nine-paragraph statement are simply unrealistic in today's economy," Sheldon Silver, the Speaker of the Assembly, said in a written statement. The Assembly Democrats, particularly those from New York City, have found themselves with little room to negotiate because so many of their constituents are affected by the rent regulations.
Billy Easton, the executive director of the New York State Tenants and Neighbors Coalition, attacked Mr. Pataki's call for expanding luxury decontrol, saying it was just another step toward the landlords' goal of deregulating all apartments. In noting that the Legislature had established the $250,000 income ceiling just four years ago, Mr. Easton expressed concern that this additional lowering would further weaken high-end protections.
Mr. Easton also said there was an obvious reason that the Governor mentioned penalizing landlords who try to harass tenants into leaving: He intends to support vacancy decontrol.
"The Governor has absolutely no reason to propose anti-harassment laws," Mr. Easton said, unless he also plans a proposal that would encourage harassment. "And that proposal would be some form of vacancy decontrol. I would love to be proven wrong on this tomorrow."
On the other side, landlords, who have the most to gain if the rent-regulation system is dismantled, said Mr. Pataki's plan did not go far enough. They pointed out that his statement suggested that most people living in rent-regulated apartments would continue to be protected so long as they remained there.
"I was a little disappointed that he seemed to be implying that there was no end in sight for rent regulations," said Dan Margulies, the executive director for the Community Housing Improvement Program, a landlord group. "According to that statement, he is looking for lifetime rent laws."
One of the key questions left unresolved today was whether Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader who has been the main proponent of abolishing the regulations, would move to a more moderate position now that the Governor has taken a more specific stand. Mr. Bruno has called for phasing out regulations during the next few years for all tenants except the elderly, the poor and the disabled.
The position Mr. Pataki takes could seriously undercut Mr. Bruno, though many Democrats believe that the Senator is merely the Governor's stalking horse and that by taking an extreme position, he enabled the Governor to play the moderate with a proposal to eliminate some rent protections and to take credit for saving all the rest.
Mr. Bruno also issued a statement late this afternoon, commending the Governor for proposing further luxury decontrol. But he did not back away from his demands for an eventual abolition of the current regulations.
"The time is now to make changes that have long been overdue," he said. "We must have a gradual and reasonable transition away from rent regulations to an open, competitive housing market in New York City."
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani praised the Governor's intervention, saying: "In the past he was trying to get the Assembly speaker and the majority leader to get this resolved. But by entering it he'll help put pressure on them."
One of the Democratic candidates trying to unseat Mr. Giuliani, Manhattan Borough President Ruth Messinger, urged today that the state give New York City residents a chance to vote on whether rent regulations should remain in force.

HEADLINE: Turning Intellect Into Influence;
Promoting Its Ideas, the Manhattan Institute Has Nudged New York Rightward

BYLINE: By JANNY SCOTT

 BODY:
Amid the powerful conformist currents of midtown Manhattan, there is something unexpected about Myron Magnet's sideburns -- bushy white whiskers that billow out from his bespectacled face like something out of Dickens.
They began as an accident, he insists. He was studying at Cambridge University, living in a Tudor cottage with an unlighted wash basin in his room. One day, he noticed the overgrowth on his jowls. He says he figured, "What the hell?" 
 But that was 30 years ago, a visitor points out, puzzled.
Mr. Magnet shifts in his high-backed leather chair. Then he answers, slowly: "I value the past very much. I think it has an awful lot to teach the present. So I suppose it is a homage to the past."
Mr. Magnet is a member of the heterogeneous group of conservatives who make up the Manhattan Institute, a think tank that has pulled off the improbable feat of helping change the course of the country's most liberal big city. The institute has done as much as any group in recent years to challenge the rules by which New York was governed, and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has done as much as any politician to move its ideas from the margin to the mainstream.
It was an early proponent of shrinking city government; it enabled Charles Murray to publish the 1984 book that many people believe begat welfare reform, and it promoted theories about crime and public disorder that later underlay the work of the former Police Commissioner, William J. Bratton.
It took up the question of the quality of life in New York City in 1990, well before Mr. Giuliani made that a cornerstone of his successful election campaign in 1993. The institute has savaged open admissions at the City University of New York, pushed hospital privatization and aggressively promoted school choice.
Now, its critique of rent control is helping to inform State Senator Joseph L. Bruno's move to phase out rent regulations, and its proposal for charter schools is circulating through legislative offices in Albany.
"It has been fabulously successful as a source of ideas and as a networking structure for conservatives and moderates in some cases," said Mitchell Moss, director of the Urban Research Center at New York University. "And it has had a terrific impact in putting some issues, which were long overdue, on the public agenda."
In a city in which most people strive to make their ideas matter (or, if not, to have their ideas appear as if they do), the 19-year-old public-policy organization has made itself a player in the public debate (and mastered the appearance of influence, too).
The phenomenon has few precedents in living New York memory: a group of eggheads and other lofty, think-tank denizens (of the conservative kind, no less) actually accumulating enough heft to enable politicians and much of the public to agree on a profound shift in direction.
A short-lived New York offshoot of the Rand Corporation worked closely with the administration of Mayor John V. Lindsay in the late 1960's and early 70's on issues from rent control to Fire Department efficiency. But the role being played by the Manhattan Institute is something else.
"In New York, it has created a respectable place for people who disagree with the liberal establishment," said William J. Stern, who headed the state's Urban Development Corporation under Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and is now a contributing editor of the institute's quarterly magazine, City Journal. "What that does is make it easier for politicians to advance those ideas. I think everybody in New York City politics now, in one way or another, has adopted some of the views of the Manhattan Institute."
Not unlike its ally, Mr. Giuliani, the institute is a conservative force come into some power in a liberal town, somewhat unorthodox, priding itself on pragmatism, fraternizing with the occasional Democrat and dismissing the labels invariably prefixed to its name.
It has become home to a range of species on the right-hand side of the political spectrum: market conservatives, social conservatives, old-style aristocratic conservatives, libertarians, as well as a few registered Democrats and a self-described liberal or two.
City Journal, edited by Mr. Magnet, who wrote a book on the legacy of the 1960's that Newt Gingrich professed to admire, was edited in the early 1990's by Fred Siegel, now a fellow of the Progressive Policy Institute in Washington, who was known to be supporting President Clinton at the time.
Many of the institute's board members, as well as its magazine, have backed the idea of school vouchers. But the institute's 8-year-old Center for Educational Innovation, which consumes one quarter of the $5 million institute budget, is officially opposed to vouchers.
"The institute is more ecumenical than it is often given credit for," said Walter Olson, an author and senior fellow. "There is a range of opinion, all of it dissenting in one way or another from what had been the New York establishment point of view."
The current list of 20 fellows includes Peter D. Salins, interim provost of the State University of New York; David Gelernter, the Yale computer scientist injured in a Unabom attack, and Richard J. Schwartz, a former senior adviser to Mr. Giuliani and the architect of the city's workfare program.
It also includes Diane Ravitch, a former United States Assistant Secretary of Education; Edward N. Costikyan, a former Manhattan Democratic leader who has advised Mr. Giuliani, and a handful of former public school administrators famous for having set up alternative schools in East Harlem in the 1980's. Another person who was affiliated with the institute was Elizabeth McCaughey, who was plucked from obscurity there by George E. Pataki in an ill-fated political alliance.
Currently housed in an unprepossessing warren on the second floor of a building near Grand Central Terminal, the institute was founded as a free-market education and research organization by William Casey, who then went off to head the Central Intelligence Agency in the Reagan Administration.
For 15 years, until 1995, it was run by William M. H. Hammett, widely characterized as a kind of "intellectual entrepreneur" -- brilliant but difficult, with what Mr. Siegel calls "a whim of iron" and a gift for placing smart bets on relatively obscure scholars with seemingly far-fetched ideas.
Its earliest preoccupation was supply-side economics. Then, in 1982, it offered $30,000 to Charles Murray, a little-known social scientist without a job, to write "Losing Ground," the book that contributed to welfare reform. It later sponsored two books, by Mr. Olson and Peter Huber, said by many to have stirred up the issue of liability reform.
The institute's mission is to develop ideas and get them into mainstream circulation -- with the help of "the media food chain," as the current president, Lawrence J. Mone, puts it. It does that by publishing and relentlessly promoting books and articles, and by inviting influential people to lunch.
It is adamant about working only with commercial publishers, instead of publishing its own books, as other policy groups do. The aim is to maximize the books' credibility, make sure they get reviewed and discipline institute-sponsored authors not to speak only to the converted. The institute also pours $700,000 a year into City Journal, filling it with long articles with titles like "Welfare's Next Vietnam" as well as photo essays and articles on culture intended, one former editor said, to make it appeal not just to businessmen but to businessmen's wives.
Ten thousand copies go out, free of charge, to mayors, journalists, academics, libraries and others, Mr. Magnet said. Another 3,000 are sold to subscribers or on newsstands. Not infrequently, articles end up condensed and reprinted in places like The Wall Street Journal.
"We let people have this stuff for free," Mr. Magnet said. "The only thing we want is credit."
Several times a month, the institute holds discreetly lavish public-policy lunches, often at the Harvard Club in midtown Manhattan, to which it invites hundreds of journalists, politicians, bureaucrats, business people and foundation staff members to hear a speaker on a subject the institute likes.
Susan V. Berresford, the president of the Ford Foundation, recently went. Tom Wolfe has been known to go. Late last month, about 150 people turned out beneath a chandelier the size of a small swimming pool in a ballroom of the Grand Hyatt Hotel in midtown to hear Mr. Giuliani speak.
There was Henry J. Stern, the City Parks Commissioner and an institute regular; Dan Biederman, president of the Grand Central Partnership, also a regular, and Joe Rose, chairman of the City Planning Commission.
"It became a problem on our editorial page," said David Frum, formerly of The Wall Street Journal and now an institute fellow who does commentary on National Public Radio. So many people were disappearing simultaneously for institute events that the op-ed page editor had to crack down.
Mr. Giuliani and his campaign staff began meeting with institute members in 1992, and since that time have absorbed many of its ideas, particularly on such issues as the city's tax structure, economic development, education policy, policing and quality of life.
In mid-1992, the magazine published an issue on the quality of life -- full of articles on such subjects as "reclaiming public spaces" -- and Mr. Giuliani could be found seated in the audience at an institute-sponsored conference pegged to the issue, scribbling notes.
In a brief interview recently, Mr. Giuliani said he had found City Journal, in particular, "enormously helpful. I've read it for years, since it first came out. It has sparked a lot of the reanalysis, reinvention, reinvigoration of government. It produces provocative and very good ideas."
Alan G. Hevesi, the City Comptroller and a Democrat who has often differed sharply with Mr. Giuliani, recently found himself the speaker at an institute lunch. A former Queens College professor, Mr. Hevesi said later: "I don't agree with a lot of what the Manhattan Institute is all about, but I respect them."
"I think they're serious, they're students of government, they're not knee-jerk ideologues," he said. "I think they're valuable to the debate on policy in New York. These folks are not the moral equivalent of the freshmen in the Gingrich class in Congress. But in New York, they're quite conservative."

 CORRECTION:
A chart on Monday with an article about the influence of the Manhattan Institute misstated the headline of an article published in the institute's magazine last year. It was "Why Catholic Schools Work," not "Why Public Schools Work." A separate chart misidentified the company headed by John M. Hennessy, a trustee of the institute. He is chief executive of CS First Boston, not CS First Bank of Boston.

HEADLINE: Observer;
Lean, Mean, Love Ya

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER 

 BODY:
Why is it that when gigantic corporations say they are in business to enrich our lives, 250 million Americans do not rise as one and cry out, "Oh, stuff it!"?
The question comes from a friend who owns some AT&T stock and forwards this copy of its annual report for 1996. The passage that galls him in this prose souffle has the top AT&T boss, speaking of the customers, promising that the company will "enrich their personal lives."
 
What insolence! How many people here want AT&T meddling in their personal lives? All I want from AT&T is a clear connection to the party on the other end of the line, or whatever it is that the party on the other end is on these days.
Even a clear connection is unlikely to enrich my personal life. It's likelier to impoverish it since incoming-callers who want to give me money are outnumbered 20 to 1 by those who want me to give them money.
What the telephone is in my personal life is an irritation, like a hangnail on your ear. There's the telemarketing call just as you're dipping into the mashed potatoes. There's the charity moocher calling for money to stamp out some pestilence. There's the answering machine that takes your long-distance call and charges you for saying there's nobody home.
Corporate guff like this about enriching your personal life is dumped on us incessantly while, at the same time, the air is filled with manly boasts about the ruthlessness of corporate America.
The corporate Caesar pounding his chest about his pitiless determination to increase profits, the journalistic explicator of why laissez-faire economics will be good for you one of these days no matter how much it hurts at the moment -- such writings are now commonplace in the media.
They preach the gospel of what used to be called "trickle-down" economics: Let unrestrained business practices produce vast profits for managers and stockholders, and some of the money will trickle down to the bottom of the economy.
The theory suffers ironically from the same weakness that afflicted Communism. Both apply an excessively simple idea to the exceedingly complex business of making vast national economies succeed. Panaceas often turn out to be poisons.
What is curious just now, however, is the contrast between the soft-soap pitch of corporate advertising and the smash-mouth talk from champions of anything-goes economics.
From the boardroom we hear that Coolidge was right all along. The business of America really is business.
It is not personal enrichment of its customers. It is financial enrichment of its stockholders and its executives.
If executives are often enriched far more grandly than the stockholders, it is because their business skills and their hard-nosed, even courageous readiness to make tough, lean, mean decisions produce ever rising profits for stockholders.
And who are those enriched stockholders? They could be you, friend. And you and you, depending on how you have arranged for your financial future, assuming that you have arranged for your financial future.
Ruthlessness is the executive's philosophical duty. His job is to crunch the numbers, increase productivity, reduce or abolish fringe benefits for undownsized employees, export jobs to faraway lands free of unions and child-labor laws and keep America Number One despite intense global competition.
Business spokesmen are commendably frank about this, saying, "It's a jungle out there, and the soft-hearted do not survive."
Their advertising, however, still concentrates on telling us what swell folks they are. AT&T is thinking of our personal lives. The airline industry, which has made flying an extremely disagreeable experience, talks of friendly skies and devoted mechanics making planes safer and safer.
In the new corporate style you might expect the airlines to boast of their overworked crews becoming ever more testy, ever more dictatorial, to brag of loyal mechanics making the seats ever smaller, ever closer together -- and all to enrich their stockholders and keep America Number One, hurrah!
They don't do that. Instead they keep spoofing us about how much they like us. And 250 million do not rise as one and say, "Oh, stuff it!" That's probably because 249 million have become too cynical from being deceived so long that they no longer care about being deceived.

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW;
A Man of Few Words Is Sent Up by a Man of Few Acts

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS 

 BODY:
With "Mere Mortals and Others," a collection of six fast and ferociously funny comedies, that professional tease of a playwright, David Ives, is back at the top of his game. He has fashioned a madcap evening of one-acts at Primary Stages on West 45th Street that reconfirms his status as a maestro of the short form. By evening's end, your mood may be so improved that you may want to hunt him down and pinch his cheek.
Whether his subject is a mating dance on a miniature golf course, the life cycle of the mayfly or the machismo of David Mamet, Mr. Ives has the gratifying ability to unharness the intoxicating power of language and, at the same time, entertain. In the latter, he is served wonderfully here by a standout creative team and superb cast, who match this playful playwright pound for witty pound. 
 Mr. Ives was bathed in praise for his previous evening of one-acts, "All in the Timing," which had its debut at Primary Stages in 1993 and graduated to a lengthy Off Broadway run. His subsequent full-length plays, including the flat and cryptic "Red Address" at Second Stage earlier this season, failed to show off his skills to best advantage. "Mere Mortals" demonstrates that Mr. Ives's gift may be for riffing rather than ruminating.
Four of the six playlets have been performed before, at benefits and one-act play marathons, but it's probably safe to say none have ever been given so smart and imaginative a presentation. Mr. Ives is a pitcher with a great many tricks up his sleeve. Sliders, breaking balls, fastballs, curves: he throws like an all-star in "Mere Mortals," mixing comedic moods and styles with a dizzying assortment of changeups.
The best of the six is "Speed-the-Play," a virtuosic parody of the work of a playwright known for big thoughts wrapped in short sentences. The playlet is set in the meeting hall of the Joliet, Ill., Men's Club, whose members gather to honor Mr. Mamet, the man's man of contemporary theater. With a portrait of the writer on the wall, the M.C., played by Nancy Opel with the swagger of a lumberjack overdosing on male hormones, attributes Mr. Mamet's audience appeal to the brevity of his plays. "David Mamet knows Americans don't like to pay for parking!" the host declares, to the cheers of the cigar-smoking men at her side.
With that, the cast of six plunges into a zany capsulization of the Mamet oeuvre: four Mamets in seven minutes. It's highbrow "Forbidden Broadway": "American Buffalo," "Oleanna," "Speed-the-Plow" and "Sexual Perversity in Chicago" whiz by in a blur of profane and sputtering arguments. (The funniest condensations are of the sexual harassment case dissection of "Oleanna" and a nearly "Who's on First?"-caliber reductio ad absurdum of "American Buffalo.") "Foreplay or: The Art of the Fugue" is set in the Lilliput Lane miniature golf course, amusingly suggested by a whimsical windmill designed by Russell Metheny. It choreographs American dating rituals to the cadences of suggestive banter. The effect is almost orchestral: starting with one couple on the course and building to three, Mr. Ives composes, in effect, a six-part symphony to spoon by. The climax -- an end-of-the-evening decision on who wins and loses the dating game -- finishes the piece off like a crash of cymbals.
Some of the works, like the title piece "Mere Mortals," exhibit Mr. Ives's impish side. A trio of hardhats, lunching on a girder high above New York City, play a kind of supernatural game of "Can You Top This?" with tales of their grandiose secret and previous lives. One claims to be the grown-up Lindbergh baby; another the surviving son of Czar Nicholas; the third, a reincarnation of Marie Antoinette.
Just when the play veers toward irrelevance, however, your imagination moves it in the other direction. Is "Mere Mortals" an elaborate riddle? Is it a stretch to suggest that the play, set on a skyscraper, is a play on the words: tall stories?
The giddy high of Mr. Ives's entertainments is that he frequently allows your brain a workout, no matter how far afield you wander. And he could not have asked for a more fortuitous crew of playmates. John Rando, who staged the delightful "When Ladies Battle" for the Pearl Theater last season, may have been separated from Mr. Ives at birth, so attuned is this talented director to the dramatist's puckish sense of humor. Mr. Metheny's sets, particularly a post-modern lily pond for "Time Flies" that could double as a downtown apartment, share a joie de vivre with Anita Yavich's ebullient costumes that infects the entire production.
It's a harmonious setting for the versatile cast members, each of whom gets a chance to shine. Danton Stone's sunny turn as an unemployed dreamer enriches "Degas, C'est Moi," the final playlet. Arnie Burton and Anne O'Sullivan are touching as a pair of mayflies burdened with the knowledge of their mortality in "Time Flies." Willis Sparks and Jessalyn Gilsig set the pace for the social combat of "Foreplay." And Ms. Opel is terrific in, well, everything. They have only themselves, and Mr. Ives, to thank.

Six short comedies by David Ives: "Foreplay or: The Art of the Fugue," "Mere Mortals," "Time Flies," "Speed-the-Play," "Dr. Fritz or: The Forces of Light" and "Degas, C'est Moi." HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls Further vs. Yen, But Strengthens Against Mark

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar slumped to its lowest level against the yen in almost four months yesterday after a senior Japanese Government official said that last week's substantial yen gains against the dollar were not excessive.
The remarks from Eisuke Sakakibara, the influential director of the Finance Ministry's international finance bureau, sent the dollar to a low of 117.50 yen, its weakest level since mid-January. 
 They also sent the yen sharply higher against a number of European currencies, including the German mark, which fell sharply against the dollar as a result.
"After a few days of selling the dollar across the board, the market has had a chance to rethink and has decided that the selling against the yen is considerably more warranted than the selling against the mark and other European currencies," said Ben Strauss, assistant vice president at Bank Julius Baer.
The dollar fell as low as 117.50 yen in trading in Asia, the lowest since Jan. 22. The dollar later recovered to settle in New York trading at 119.30 yen, down from 120.35 yen on Friday. The dollar settled at 1.7064 marks, up from 1.6869 marks. The pound fell to $1.6184 from $1.6205.
Last week, strong gains in Japanese stocks, talk of higher Japanese interest rates and warnings of intervention to curb yen weakness sent the dollar tumbling against the yen. Mr. Sakakibara's remarks, which came on Saturday, added more fuel to the fire.
Yesterday, Mr. Sakakibara sought to limit the impact of his remarks, saying that the dollar was "likely to settle down soon."
In addition, a member of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party made comments that cast doubt on prospects for an increase in Japanese interest rates.
As a result, traders began buying yen for marks instead of dollars, allowing the dollar to post gains against the mark and recover somewhat against the yen.
The mark also fell against the British pound, after the new Chancellor of the Exchequer, Gordon Brown, said he had no plans to take the pound back into Europe's exchange rate mechanism, the system designed to limit currency volatility in the approach to monetary union.
