HEADLINE: Study Finds Public Science Is Pillar Of Industry

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD 

 BODY:
A NEW study has found strong evidence that publicly financed scientific research plays a surprisingly important role in the breakthroughs of industrial innovation in the United States, suggesting that impending cuts in the Federal science budget might eventually hurt the economy.
The study, prepared for the National Science Foundation by a private research group, found that 73 percent of the main science papers cited by American industrial patents in two recent years were based on domestic and foreign research financed by government or nonprofit agencies. Private companies paid for the rest. 
 Such publicly financed science, the study concluded, has turned into a "fundamental pillar" of industrial advance.
Advocates of Federal spending on scientific research are seizing upon the study to bolster their position. The science foundation finances much basic research, and its officials acknowledged that they had questioned the wisdom of cuts in the science budget. But they said the patent study was part of continuing research on science trends that began long before the current push to trim the deficit.
Democrats and Republicans are generally united in earmarking Government financing for science for sizable cuts as part of a plan to reduce the Federal deficit and balance the budget by 2002. This year, the Federal research and development budget is about $65 billion. Budget analysts say the Clinton Administration wants to shrink it 14 percent in the next five years, and Republicans want to reduce it by about 20 percent.
The study, to be published in Research Policy, a bimonthly journal based at the University of Sussex in England, a leading forum for this kind of analysis, is starting to circulate in the United States in manuscript form. Science policy groups say no previous study has addressed the intellectual foundations of American industry in such depth and with such rigor.
"It's a watershed," said Dr. Martin A. Apple, executive director of the Council of Scientific Society Presidents, a policy group in Washington that represents 65 science organizations and lobbies for more money for science. "It's a wake-up call for Federal investment policies."
Charles F. Larson, executive director of the Industrial Research Institute, a nonprofit group in Washington that represents large companies,said the report would be widely influential. "It's going to make people realize something they should have known all along -- that public investment in academic science through Government-funded programs pays dividends to society," he said. "It pays off handsomely."
On the other hand, budget cutters seem unlikely to find the report so persuasive as to set aside the ax. They argue that much fat can be sliced from the Federal science budget without damaging high-quality work at universities.
Basic science, the kind that pursues fundamental knowledge for its own sake with no clear vision of how it might be practically applied, has long been considered a prime source of military and economic power. Yet the exact relationship between science and innovation has been murky since the start of the Industrial Revolution.
In recent years, as private industry in the United States has grown big and sophisticated enough to surpass the Government in overall spending on research, some conservatives have suggested that public support of basic research is passe. Publicly financed research gave birth to high-technology industry, they say, but it is no longer so important.
The new study sharply contradicts that view. It examined one of the most vivid expressions of industrial creativity: patents, the main way that companies and inventors reap commercial rewards from their bright ideas. Once granted, patents give the holder a monopoly to produce, sell or profit from an invention for a period of years.
Patentable ideas include new kinds of machines, methods, processes and material compositions, including drugs and computer chips. The Supreme Court ruled in 1980 that patents could also be granted for genetically engineered forms of life.
The new study, the most thorough examination to date of the scientific foundation of American patents, strongly suggests that public science lies at the heart of most commercial innovation. The study is the culmination of 17 years of patent investigations by CHI Research Inc., a consulting firm in Haddon Heights, N.J., that analyzes contemporary science for industrial and government clients around the world.
Its customer for the most recent round of patent work is the National Science Foundation, a Federal agency. The foundation's budget is up about 1.5 percent this year, to $3.27 billion from $3.22 billion, an increase that almost matches inflation.
CHI Research, starting in 1980, while working for the National Science Foundation and other clients, began examining the role played by research in American patents. The main clues came from the scientific reports that patents cite on their front pages as evidence of their intellectual foundations.
For instance, patent No. 4,565,785, assigned to Harvard University in 1986, lists 52 scientific reports in journals that include Science and Nature. The patent shows how bacteria can be turned into tiny factories for the production of insulin, human growth hormone, interferon and other pharmacologically active agents.
An early CHI Research study examined patents issued from 1975 to 1986 and found that patented inventions were increasingly drawing on pure science, as measured by the growing number of citations of articles in scientific journals.
The new study, by Dr. Francis Narin, Kimberly S. Hamilton and Dominic Olivastro, sharpened this analytic tool by investigating the sources of the scientific reports. It tracked down and analyzed the institutional ties of the authors, which patent citations ignore.
The CHI Research team examined the science references on the front pages of American patents in two recent periods -- 1987 and 1988, as well as 1993 and 1994 -- looking at all the 397,660 patents issued.
It found 242,000 identifiable science references and zeroed in on those published in the preceding 11 years, which turned out to be 80 percent of them. Searches of computer databases allowed the linking of 109,000 of these references to known journals and authors' addresses. After eliminating redundant citations to the same paper, as well as articles with no known American author, the study had a core collection of 45,000 papers. Armies of aides then fanned out to libraries to look up the papers and examine their closing lines, which often say who financed the research. That detective work revealed an extensive reliance on publicly financed science. For instance, biomedical papers cited the National Cancer Institute for financial support 7,970 times, the American Cancer Society 2,131 times and the March of Dimes 293 times. Physics papers cited the National Science Foundation 1,072 times, the Navy 708 times, the National Aeronautics and Space Administration 255 times and the Sloan Foundation 22 times. Some research projects were financed by multiple public agencies.
The overall role of public support was impossible to tally because some papers made no mention of their source of funds. That was especially true for reports from industrial laboratories, where the source of funds was often implied but not stated.
Further narrowing its focus, the study set aside patents given to schools and governments and zeroed in on those awarded to industry. For 2,841 patents issued in 1993 and 1994, it examined the peak year of literature references, 1988, and found 5,217 citations to science papers.
Of these, it found that 73.3 percent had been written at public institutions -- universities, government labs and other public agencies, both in the United States and abroad. American institutions represented 43.9 percent of that figure and foreign ones accounted for 29.4 percent.
Over all, only 20.4 percent of the science citations in American industrial patents referred to papers from American industry, and 6.3 percent referred to reports from foreign industry. Even International Business Machines -- famous for its research prowess and numerous patents -- was found to cite its own work only 21 percent of the time.
"Regardless of how the data are arranged," the study said, "it is quite clear that public science plays an overwhelming role in the science base of U.S. industry."
The study found that industry's dependence on all science was soaring. It compared the number of science citations, both public and private, in the two study periods and found that they had almost tripled.
The rise, the study concluded, is "truly remarkable, and indicative of a rapidly increasing dependence of patented technology upon contemporary science."
Expert reaction to the study so far is favorable. David C. Mowery, a business professor at the University of California at Berkeley who studies technology policy, said the CHI Research team "has gone further than anybody else" in probing the inspiration behind patents.
Wesley M. Cohen, an economist at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh who studies American industry, said some experts might question whether the rise in citations was simply based on changing habits of source documentation, for instance, as the advent of electronic databases eased the tracking of journal articles, or actually indicated an increasing reliance.
But, he added, his own research, involving nearly 1,500 interviews with industrial lab managers, suggested the rise was real. "The effects of academic research may be much more pervasive across industries than previously thought," he said.
Mr. Larson of the Industrial Research Institute said, "Industry depends considerably on academic science for new knowledge."
Dr. Narin, the lead author of the patent study, said he hoped his work would help dull the budget ax. "Look at the things that are coming out of the research pipeline," he said. "We'd be fools to close it down."

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Chance for Americans

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Beginning May 20, Americans will get a specific opportunity to decide whether they want the U.S. to use at least some part of its political and economic influence to help Christians persecuted for being Christian.
On that day Congressional legislation will be introduced that would put an economic price on the persecution of Christians who try to worship openly and freely. The price tag would certainly get the attention of the persecuting nations, dictatorships all. It might even persuade some of them to give ease to their victims. 
 Six months or more will be needed for the legislation to get through Congressional machinery -- or die in it. If they start early enough Americans will have the time, and responsibility, to declare themselves -- individually or with other members of their religious, political and economic groups.
If Americans in sufficient numbers make it clear to their representatives that they want action for the persecuted, the measure will pass. If not, not.
The legislation will be introduced by Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania and Representative Frank Wolf of Virginia, Republicans, and has co-sponsors from both parties. It designates two other desperate religious groups as coming within its definition of persecution -- the Buddhists of Tibet and the Bahais of Iran.
The bill is the legislative expression of slowly increasing American awareness that in China and other Communist countries and in at least eight Muslim countries Christians are arrested, beaten, tortured or killed for their Christianity.
But generally, among American Christians and Jews the awareness has not overcome decades of silence and abdication or been translated into much action. Still, it does grow.
In New York, the City Council is expected to adopt a resolution tomorrow asking Congress and the President to make ending Christian persecution a diplomatic and economic priority. Then, without waiting for that to happen, Council Speaker Peter Vallone will introduce a measure prohibiting city contracts with companies of the persecuting nations, ending city deposits in their banks and selling off their stocks.
In Congress, Specter-Wolf would create a White House office to monitor religious persecution. Its director would determine where religious persecution was widespread and ongoing -- torture, imprisonment, murder, as of Christians in China, or enslavement, as of Christians in the Sudan, or mass resettlement, as of Tibetan Buddhists by China.
The bill would stop U.S. loans to such countries and mandate Washington's opposition to international loans. It would prohibit export to persecuting nations of products that could be used as instruments of oppression -- like software for tracking dissidents using the Internet or E-mail.
A list of government units assigned to persecution would be created and all exports barred to them. Visas would be denied to officials of the persecution. Logically that should mean no visas for officials of the Chinese puppet churches.
The Sudan would be put in a pariah class of its own. The same tough sanctions would be applied as to South Africa during apartheid.
Deliberately, the bill avoids the question of tariff penalties for China. The Congressional vote on that promise, made and broken by President Clinton, will come first. The legislation against religious persecution would apply, however the tariff vote went.
I would have preferred legislation more muscular -- including prohibition of trade with companies owned by the military. That would have cut nicely into China's military treasury.
But the bill is not just one more resolution for virtue over evil. It has real sanctions aimed at real persecuting nations.
Therefore it will be opposed by U.S. politicians, bureaucrats and businessmen who want the U.S. to do only two things about the victims of religious persecution: look away, walk away.
Americans who want their country to stand up against religious persecution should start supporting the bill now and continue on for as much time as it takes. And they will have to remember that the opponents of help to the persecuted will have just as much time and a lot more money, and fight hard.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Flat Ahead Of New Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities ended little changed yesterday in thin trading. Bonds were supported by expectations that today's retail sales report would be weak, providing new signs of a slowing economy.
The expectations prompted short- covering by speculators who were betting that the market would go the other way and provided some support for bonds. 
 Short-covering occurs when investors sell borrowed securities, hoping to buy them back at lower prices, thereby pocketing the difference. But if prices rise, investors have to cover short positions by buying back the securities to limit losses.
A late recovery in the dollar on the currency market also bolstered bond prices. A stronger dollar makes dollar-denominated investments like Treasury securities more attractive to foreign investors.
The 30-year bond finished at a price of 96 23/32, to yield 6.89 percent, unchanged from Friday. The seven-year note rose 2/32, to 103 19/32, to yield 6.60 percent, down from 6.61 percent. Bond prices and yields move in opposite directions.
At the Treasury's regular weekly sale of three- and six-month bills yesterday, rates were mostly in line with expectations, with bidding not nearly as impressive as is was last week. The average rate at auction for the three-month issue was 5.08 percent, down from 5.14 percent last week, while the six-month bill's average rate at auction was 5.30 percent, down from 5.37 percent.
Jack Regan, chief derivatives strategist at Josephthal, Lyon & Ross, said yesterday's slow trading was not surprising given the economic data to be released this week. In addition to today's retail sales data for April, the Government reports on producer prices tomorrow and consumer prices on Thursday. The Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia issues its survey of regional business conditions on Friday.
Analysts and traders are expecting the retail sales report to show a decline between three-tenths and four-tenths of 1 percent.
Some market participants say that if there are enough data this week to indicate an economic slowdown, the Federal Reserve may be less likely to raise interest rates when Fed policy makers meet next Tuesday.
Kathleen Camilli, director of economic research for Tucker Anthony Inc., said she expected the bond and stock markets to trade sideways before the Fed's meeting. "There is still downside risk in the front end of the Treasury curve," she said, "but the market is poised for softer economic data. And once that is confirmed, cash should continue to come off the sidelines, propelling both markets even higher."
Market participants continue to be divided on whether the Fed will raise short-term interest rates by a quarter-point next week.
Kenneth J. McCarthy, founder of the Economic Intelligence Company, a research analysis firm, said that although the Fed chairman in the last two years has begun to acknowledge that the economy may be capable of growing faster than the widely accepted 2.5 percent rate, "he continues to behave as though there is a speed limit on growth."
"Yet if we look at the performance of productivity in the current business cycle," Mr. McCarthy added, "it is unlike anything we have experienced in the past 50 years. The enormous increase in the power of the microprocessor and the huge growth in investment in this technology is taking the economy to new heights of productivity and enabling us to grow faster for a sustained period than we have this century."

HEADLINE: Study Questions Cost of Shift To Harsh Cocaine Sentences

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

 BODY:
Meting out harsher prison terms to drug dealers provides fewer benefits per taxpayer dollar than old-fashioned law enforcement or simply treating addicted offenders, according to a new study released today.
The detailed analysis published by the Drug Policy Research Center of the Rand Corporation, a policy analysis institution that has made its reputation doing government studies, seems bound to supply fresh fuel for the contentious national debate over Federal and state laws that require judges to impose automatic minimum sentences for dealing in some illegal drugs. 
 Supporters say mandatory sentencing send a tough message and take criminals out of circulation. Critics contend that the laws impose a draconian punishment out of proportion to the offense, take discretion away from judges, and in the process, lock up many more black and Hispanic offenders for low-level trafficking than white offenders for high-level trafficking.
The 183-page Rand study appears to be the first to examine the cost-effectiveness of mandatory minimum sentences. Addressing cocaine as the nation's "most problematic" drug, the researchers crunched hundreds of numbers, from cocaine's average street price to the cost of a prison cell. They determined that spending an additional $1 million on longer sentences for convicted dealers would reduce the nation's total consumption of cocaine -- estimated to be from 276 to 321 tons a year -- by less than 29 pounds a year.
The same $1 million spent on arresting, prosecuting and sentencing more dealers to discretionary prison terms, as well as seizing their assets, would trim annual cocaine consumption by nearly 60 pounds, or twice as much, the study reported.
But spending $1 million more on treating heavy cocaine users would cut consumption by as much as 220 pounds, it said.
"Mandatory minimum sentences are not justifiable on the basis of cost-effectiveness at reducing cocaine consumption or drug-related crime," the researchers concluded, assuming that lower consumption of cocaine leads to fewer drug-related crimes. They attributed this mainly to the high cost of incarceration. Locking up a convicted felon costs $20,000 to $30,000 a year. By comparison, the researchers calculated, a mix of residential and outpatient treatment would cost the government as little as $1,740 a year for a heavy cocaine user. Residential treatment can, however, run from $8,000 to $16,000 a year.
"We don't say mandatory minimums have no effect," Jonathan Caulkins, the principal researcher in the Rand study, explained in an interview. "They do have some effect, but they turn out to be not very cost-effective."
But the researchers, who included C. Peter Rydell, William L. Schwabe and James Chiesa, emphasized that their findings did not support shifting all anti-drug resources to treatment from enforcement.
The issue was raised anew two weeks ago when the United States Sentencing Commission, an advisory body on prison sentences, recommended that Congress reduce, but not eliminate, the 100-to-1 disparity in sentences involving crack, compared with sentences involving powder cocaine. Federal law sets a five-year minimum sentence for possession with the intent to distribute less than one-fifth of an ounce of crack cocaine, compared with eight ounces of powder cocaine .
Crack is made by heating cocaine powder with baking soda and water. It is more addictive than the powder form and has been more often associated with violence.
Two years ago, the Clinton Administration joined Congress in rejecting a recommendation by the Sentencing Commission that the disparity in sentencing between crimes involving powder and crack cocaine be eliminated. Congress has shown no inclination to change the laws.
Many states have their own mandatory minimum sentences. In 1973, New York, under Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller, passed legislation dictating a sentence of 15 years to life for anyone convicted of selling four ounces of cocaine or possessing four ounces of cocaine. By the end of 1996, 8,760 drug offenders were locked up under the Rockefeller laws at a cost of $260 million a year, according to the Correctional Association of New York, which monitors prison conditions.
"Long sentences for serious crimes have intuitive appeal," the Rand study said. "They respond to deeply held beliefs about punishment for evil actions, and in many cases they insure that, by removing a criminal from the streets, further crimes that would have been committed will not be."
But, it continued, "long sentences are expensive and cocaine-control resources are limited. As we show, if reducing consumption or violence is the goal, more can be achieved by spending additional money arresting, prosecuting and sentencing dealers to standard prison terms than by spending it sentencing (fewer) dealers to longer mandatory terms."

HEADLINE: Dow and S.& P. Index Hit Highs As the Rally in Stocks Surges On

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
The Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks both jumped more than 1.5 percent and set closing highs yesterday, continuing the rally that has seen these indexes climb about 14 percent since the spring selloff that ended on April 11.
Other major indexes, including the Nasdaq composite and the Russell index of 2,000 smaller stocks, also rose, but not nearly as much, reflecting the fact that the recoveries in stocks of small companies and technology concerns featured in those indexes remain far behind. 
 The Dow climbed 123.22 points, or 1.72 percent, to 7,292.75, yesterday, while the S.& P. 500 rose 12.88 points, or 1.56 percent, to 837.66. The Nasdaq rose 9.14 points, or 0.68 percent, to 1,344.19, and the Russell index finished at 363.76, up 2.34 points, or 0.64 percent.
Even some fervent stock bulls were surprised at the market's performance. The rally, they said, came just ahead of the release of several important economic reports this week and next week's meeting of the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee. At that meeting, the central bank could decide to raise its short-term interest rate target again. Investors seem to be betting the data will show economic growth slowing enough to convince the Fed to leave its target for the Federal funds rate -- a key short-term rate -- at 5.50 percent.
"Investors are seeing the glass half-full, not half-empty," said Alfred Goldman, the director of market analysis at A. G. Edwards in St. Louis.
"Even I as a bull am amazed that we added 120 points today onto what we have done," Mr. Goldman added, noting that the Dow has risen more than 900 points since mid-April.
One contributing factor to the stock market's rise, analysts said, is the recent sharp decline of the dollar, which means that American exports could become more competitive abroad. In the currency markets yesterday, the dollar fell again against the Japanese yen but rebounded somewhat against the German mark and other European currencies.
Against the yen, the dollar is now down 5.8 percent since May 2. Against the mark, even after yesterday's rebound, the dollar is still off 1.3 percent.
Hedge-fund operators, who have been major players in the yen market by borrowing at low interest rates in Japan to buy United States Treasuries that offer much higher interest rates, said they had not yet seen funds with big positions bailing out, a move that would push the dollar even lower.
But they agreed that it was still unclear whether the dollar's longer-term rally against the yen, from lows set several years ago, had ended or whether the dollar might resume its recent gains. They noted that the differential between interest rates in the United States and Japan still favored the dollar by giving dollar-denominated securities higher yields.
The Dow was led higher by General Electric, which rose 1 5/8 a share, to 59 7/8; I.B.M., up 6, to 173 1/2, and Hewlett-Packard, up 2 3/4, to 56 7/8. Indeed, just one Dow component stock closed the session lower: Caterpillar, which fell 3/8, to 96 1/4, after a downgrade by an analyst.
Among the monthly economic data due this week are retail sales, which will be reviewed for indications of how much consumers are still spending; the Producer Price Index; the Consumer Price Index; industrial production, and housing starts.
Based on these data, analysts will place bets on what the Fed's Open Market Committee will do when it meets next Tuesday. It now appears that a growing number of forecasters feel that the Fed will not raise interest rates.
Thus, if the Fed does move, it could lead to a market selloff while at the same time giving a lift to the dollar.
But given the current optimism, investors might also decide to put a positive spin on any Fed rate increase, choosing to regard it as possibly the last of this economic cycle -- assuming that the economy continues to slow, as some indicators suggest it already is. Such a positive conclusion could just send stocks higher.

HEADLINE: Guinness and Grand Met in $22 Billion Deal

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM 

DATELINE: LONDON, May 12

 BODY:
Faced with a steady decline in liquor consumption in their traditional markets, the world's two biggest distillers, Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. and Guinness P.L.C., agreed today to a merger valued at about $22.27 billion, the fifth-biggest deal in history.
Together, the companies own some of the best-known brands of Scotch, vodka and gin, along with the famed Guinness stout, and their top executives said today that they were confident that the efficiencies resulting from a combination, including eliminating 2,000 jobs, would lift sales and profits. But at least one big competitor, the Seagram Company, bitterly objected to the market dominance that the deal would create in Scotch, the liquor category with the highest profits. 
 The driving force behind the surprise announcement today is the generational divide that has plagued the liquor business for years. Basically, distilled spirits are popular with people 60 and older, while younger drinkers tend to prefer wine, wine coolers, beer or nonalcoholic drinks -- a trend that does not bode well for future growth.
In mature markets like the United States and Europe, the liquor industry faces the need to cut costs of advertising, sales and production to build back profits, while in developing markets, the challenge is to try to make inroads quickly and profitably, though some companies have found that difficult.
If approved by shareholders and regulators on both sides of the Atlantic, the merger will create a new company, GMG Brands, that will reign over some 150 internationally known labels including Johnnie Walker and J & B Scotches; Gordon's and Tanqueray gins; Smirnoff, the world's best-selling vodka, and its rival Stolichnaya; Jose Cuervo tequila, and Baileys Original Irish cream.
GMG would also absorb Grand Met's huge food operations including more than 9,000 Burger King restaurants, Green Giant vegetables, Haagen-Dazs ice cream and Pillsbury.
"This is not just a United Kingdom deal, it's a global deal that will create the seventh-largest food and drink group in the world," said John Carnegie, an analyst at BZW, the London merchant bank. "They will have a market share twice as big as the next competitor. It is right up there with McDonald's and bigger than Campbell."
Shares of Guinness and Grand Met soared here this morning. Guinness shares surged 86 pence to close at 602.5 pence ($9.78) while shares of Grand Met jumped 76.5 pence, to 591.5 ($9.60).
"Both sets of shareholders will benefit equally, and both companies are properly rated by the market," said Tony Greener, Guinness's chairman.
He and George Bull, the chairman of Grand Met, said they agreed to explore a merger over dinner in London a month ago. The two men, who said they had known each other for 17 years, will be joint chairmen of GMG Brands until Mr. Bull retires in July 1988. Mr. Greener will then be chairman and chief executive.
"It is a marriage made in heaven," said Dermott Carr, an analyst at Nikko Europe. "They will have a global reach in different parts of the world with a wide range of products and the critical mass to drive the sales in a very competitive market."
Guinness gets 44 percent of its revenues from emerging markets, and GMG Brands would be well placed to take advantage of rising demand in the increasingly affluent economies of Latin America, while Grand Met is poised to expand in Eastern Europe.
Even so, GMG Brands would have only 10 percent of the world liquor market -- far from a dominant position, but certainly a leading one.
Under the terms of the proposal, Grand Met shareholders would wind up with a controlling 52.7 percent of the shares in the new company. Analysts valued the deal at 13.72 billion ($22.27 billion), based on today's closing stock market prices.
Officials said they were confident the merger would pass regulatory scrutiny in Britain as well as in the United States and Europe. Except for Scotch, there is little overlap of products between the two companies. In Scotch, Guinness has Johnnie Walker, the No. 1 brand, and Dewar's and Bell; Grand Met has J & B.
That situation was cited by Robert W. Matschullat, vice chairman and chief financial officer of Seagram, in strongly objecting to the deal. "This proposition assumes the regulators are dozing," he said in a telephone interview from New York. "There are serious antitrust problems because this merger will create one company with well over half of the global Scotch market, which is the most profitable category."
In London, the two companies and several analysts insisted that there was little overlap. "We are entirely confident we will be able to satisfy regulatory requirements," Mr. Bull of Grand Met said. "Our brands fit like hand in glove. There are very few brand markets of real conflict."
The announcement of the deal also affected the big French luxury goods company, LVMH-Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton, which owns 14.2 percent of Guinness. Its shares rose 4.9 percent on the Paris bourse, in part because of the higher value attached to its Guinness holding. Analysts were also speculating that the proposed merger might open up wider distribution channels for the Cognacs, Champagnes and other drinks produced by LVMH.
The enthusiasm for the deal apparently was not shared by the chief executive of LVMH, Bernard Arnault, who is a nonexecutive member of the Guinness board. He voted against the merger proposal on Friday, after questioning the rationale of the move. He is understood to have proposed a three-way merger of the liquor businesses of LVMH, Guinness and Grand Met.
"Discussions will continue," Mr. Greener said today of the relations with LVMH; Mr. Arnault was not available for comment.
Besides its hard liquor lines, Guinness owns the Irish black stout with the famous creamy head, Guinness Stout Ale, which sells some 10 million glasses a day produced in a string of breweries stretching from Dublin to Britain to Nigeria, Malaysia, Cameroon and Ghana. The brew, which is synonymous with Ireland's name, has been immortalized in verse and prose for 200 years.
After the merger, the new company will have four divisions: UDV, thespirits unit; Pillsbury; Burger King, and Guinness Brewing Worldwide. Mr. Greener said there were no plans to sell any of the four businesses.
The chiefs of the companies said at the news conference that some 2,000 jobs might be eliminated out of a combined 85,000 jobs worldwide. The companies said they expected substantial savings through integrating sales forces and office functions as well as improved purchasing.
A spokesman for the general labor union at Grand Metropolitan said, "We are seeking urgent talks to establish the reality of the 2,000 job losses."

HEADLINE: Steepest Hikes Are Expected Chiefly in Parts of Manhattan

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
Under one scenario, the character of dozens of neighborhoods in New York City would be radically altered within a decade, as gentrification swept the poor and middle-class out of areas with the best schools, the best views and the least crime.
Under another scenario, the fabric of most neighborhoods would remain as stable as it ever has in such a crowded, protean city. Any big changes would take more than a generation, and developers would have more of an incentive to create new housing. 
 As Gov. George E. Pataki presented his plan yesterday to phase out rent regulations by removing price limits when apartments become vacant, such were the extreme visions offered of the city's future under so-called vacancy decontrol.
But economists and urban planners suggested that the effects of Mr. Pataki's plan would probably be much more complex, with rents increasing substantially in only about a dozen neighborhoods around the city -- mainly in Manhattan -- as tenants in rent-regulated apartments move out.
That, however, could have an unpredictable ripple effect on rents in the rest of the city, recent studies indicate, as middle-class and poorer residents eventually get priced out of those neighborhoods and look elsewhere for lower unregulated rents, driving up demand in other neighborhoods. And at some point, the demand and the city's limited stock of affordable housing could collide.
"One thing that vacancy decontrol would most likely do over the long haul, as people move out, is lead to a decrease in housing opportunities for low- and moderate-income households," said Michael Schill, a professor of law and urban planning at New York University, who will release a study on Wednesday that shows which neighborhoods could be most affected by vacancy decontrol.
The study, written with Benjamin P. Scafidi Jr., a research associate at the Center for Real Estate and Urban Policy at New York University School of Law, identified neighborhoods where rents of regulated apartments were substantially lower than the market rate.
When regulated tenants move out, rents will likely rise in Riverdale, Soundview and Parkchester in the Bronx; Chelsea, Clinton, Greenwich Village and the financial district, Midtown, Stuyvesant Town, Turtle Bay, the Upper East and West Sides, Morningside and Hamilton Heights in Manhattan; and Bayside, Little Neck, Bellerose and Rosedale in Queens.
"You're probably going to have instances where people living in, say, Chelsea, have a family and decide they need to move out," Mr. Schill said. "And they're going to move to other neighborhoods, because they are not going to be able to attain housing at the old rent levels."
But landlords and owners have long contended that opponents of rent deregulation are overlooking an important factor when they present such theories. Phasing out the cumbersome regulations, they say, will spur construction of housing in a city where too few new apartments arebeing built or rehabilitated.
But Michael McKee of the New York State Tenants and Neighbors Coalition, the largest tenant group, predicted yesterday that vacancy decontrol would force the middle class out of Manhattan and destroy the city's unique character.
"If you want New York City to be a vibrant, diverse community, with artists and writers and creative people, then rent regulation is a very important part of that mix," Mr. McKee said. "Without rent regulation, creative people will be gone."
Ronald Shiffman, director of the Pratt Center for Community and Environmental Development, said, "I think it will hurt New York City in ways that one can't even imagine right now. It's going to have a dramatic affect on the social and economic integration of many of our neighborhoods."
Tenant advocates, relying on statistics from the last time New York City tried vacancy decontrol, believe that changes could occur rapidly, with most apartments reverting to the market within a decade. From 1971 to 1974, about 400,000 apartments became deregulated as tenants moved out. There are about 1.1 million regulated apartments in the city.
But many economists think it would take much longer for apartments to turn over. "The notion that there are millionaires lurking out in the weeds waiting to take our apartment is a little far-fetched," said Frank Braconi, the executive director of the Citizens Housing and Planning Council. "Rents will look much like they do now in many parts of the city for a long time."

HEADLINE: Pataki Urges End of Rent Cap When Apartment Is Vacated

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday proposed eliminating rent protections on apartments once they become vacant, but the Democratic Speaker of the Assembly vowed to fight the plan.
The Governor's proposal, which would eventually end the five-decade old system that limits rent increases on 1.1 million apartments, came a day after he disclosed that his full proposal would call for lifting controls immediately for a small number of wealthy tenants. 
 Taken as a whole, Mr. Pataki's proposal begins a new phase in the debate over the state's rent laws, which are set to expire on June 16. It appeared to establish the Governor as the main bargainer in negotiations with the Assembly Speaker, Sheldon Silver, who has called for continuing the laws unchanged, while shifting the spotlight away from the Republican Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, the leading proponent of abolishing the laws altogether.
It was far from clear whether the Governor's plan would move either side toward a quick compromise. Tenant advocates, including many Democrats in Albany, reiterated their strong opposition to any plan that would lift rent limits when current tenants leave, a process known as vacancy decontrol. And landlords, who have fought for a quick end to controls, assailed Mr. Pataki's plan as too weak and expressed fear that he might be prepared to soften it even further in talks with Mr. Silver.
The plan Mr. Pataki released yesterday would allow landlords to raise rents to market rates as soon as tenants move or die. Over time, vacancy decontrol would bring an end to the entire rent regulation system as more and more units became vacant. But just how long that process would take has been debated, with tenants' groups saying it could happen in a handful of years and landlords maintaining it would take decades.
To temper his proposal, Mr. Pataki also called for continuing laws that allow blood relatives, in-laws and even domestic partners to inherit rent-protected apartments when tenants die or move away. Landlords contend that such succession rules have allowed families to keep rent-regulated units off the open market for generations and are sure to slow down deregulation significantly.
By releasing his plan over two days, Mr. Pataki seemed intent on focusing public attention on its least controversial element -- ending protections for wealthy tenants -- while playing down yesterday's more contentious, and far more sweeping, proposal for vacancy decontrol.
Repeatedly using the words "fair" and "balanced" to describe his plan, Mr. Pataki proudly suggested at a news conference yesterday in Manhattan that he had found a way to split the difference between Republicans and Democrats.
"We must insure that every tenant who needs rent protections has those protections for as long as they live," the Governor said. "This proposal will insure a smooth transition over the course of the next few decades to a market system."
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who has supported extending the rent laws, welcomed Mr. Pataki's entry into the debate, even though he disagrees with major portions of the Governor's plan. The Mayor also called on Mr. Silver, his ally on this issue, to begin negotiating with the Governor, suggesting that Mr. Giuliani is prepared to accept a compromise that would end some rent protections.
"I've talked to the Governor about it and he indicated to me that he's willing to be flexible," Mr. Giuliani said. "So, he's willing to move if other people will sit down with him and start negotiating with him."
But Mr. Silver and tenants' groups accused the Governor of being a front man for landlords, who they say secretly consider vacancy decontrol their ultimate goal.
"This is not a compromise by any stretch of the imagination, but rather the Governor has chosen to take the side of vacancy decontrol and the side of the landlords and abandon the middle class of this state," said Mr. Silver, a Manhattan Democrat.
Billy Easton, executive director of New York State Tenants and Neighbors Coalition, the state's largest tenants' advocacy group, said Mr. Pataki's political handlers had "artfully packaged an assault on tenants' rights to look as if they were providing new tenant protections." Vacancy decontrol, he added, "is the major prize landlords have wanted all along."
But groups representing landlords expressed disappointment with the Governor's plan, contending that it would prolong for decades a system they consider rife with abuses.
"We're extremely disappointed that the Governor wants to maintain rent regulations after 50 years of failure and economic devastation," said Jack Freund, executive vice president for the Rent Stabilization Association, a group representing 25,000 landlords. "We believe there needs to be a date certain to end rent regulations in New York, as Senator Bruno has suggested."
Mr. Bruno, who has called for ending most rent protections in two to four years, praised Mr. Pataki for trying to broker a compromise. But he called the current succession laws "ludicrous" and said he would continue to push Mr. Pataki to agree to a specific deadline for the rent laws.
"Frankly, I just don't agree with his position that in decades you'll be out of rent control and rent regulations," said Mr. Bruno, of Rensselaer County. "If it's wrong, it's wrong. If you're going to correct it, you should do it in a timely way."
It is not clear, however, what Mr. Bruno can do to move Mr. Pataki off his position. Several of his fellow Republicans in the Senate oppose his plan for ending rent regulations, giving him the barest of majorities to pass a bill.
The Governor's plan "takes the ball away from Senator Bruno, who had a more extreme position," said Senator Roy Goodman, a Manhattan Republican who supports continuing the rent laws. "It's now up to Mr. Silver to come to the table and do some serious negotiating."
On Sunday, the Governor called for immediately lifting rent protections for tenants who earn more than $175,000 for two consecutive years, a policy known as luxury decontrol. Disabled tenants and people older than 62 would be exempt. The proposed change would extend luxury decontrol to about 10,000 additional households, Mr. Pataki's aides said.
Under current law, tenants who earn more than $250,000 a year for two consecutive years and who pay rent of $2,000 a month or more lose their rent protections. The Governor's threshhold of $175,000 would apply, regardless of the rent.
Mr. Pataki also called on Sunday for tougher civil and criminal penalties for landlords who harass tenants to make them vacate apartments. Tenants' groups say such harassment is sure to increase if vacancy decontrol is enacted.
And yesterday, Mr. Pataki said he supported continuing the law requiring landlords to offer lease renewals automatically. He also endorsed legislation that would require tenants to deposit rent in an escrow account during disputes with landlords, a policy long sought by apartment owners.

HEADLINE: Another Ancient Innovation: City Planning

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD 

 BODY:
A CITY that throbbed with vitality in the third millennium B.C. lies buried, forlorn and silent, beneath the wind-blown soil of the Upper Euphrates River Valley in southeastern Turkey. Gone are the din of commerce, the clatter on cobblestones and the cries and murmurs of family life behind mud brick walls. But the ruins speak to archeologists of a time when a revolutionary idea may have shaped the newest cities in antiquity.
Mapping the site of the city, known today as Titris Hoyuk, archeologists are delineating the usual urban remains. At the center once stood a palace and other public buildings on high ground. Out from there, streets ran through residential neighborhoods. Beyond city walls lay a cemetery and scattered suburbs. 
 On closer examination, however, archeologists have found surprises. The streets and terrace walls appear to have been laid out and built before the houses. And the houses seem to follow a master plan, some larger than others but all of the same design.
Archeologists are thus drawn to the conclusion that Titris Hoyuk, population 10,000 in its heyday, represents a striking example of urban planning in antiquity. Built in about 2500 B.C., this was a kind of Levittown-on-the-Euphrates.
"There was a centralized vision of what a city should look like that appears remarkably similar to a typical master-planned community in the United States today," said Dr. Guillermo Algaze of the University of California at San Diego, who is directing the excavations.
Dr. Gil Stein, an archeologist at Northwestern University who has excavated in the same region, called the explorations at Titris "very, very important research, which gives us a whole new look on what urbanism was like in the ancient Middle East."
Scholars had long ago established that the first cities anywhere arose about 5,000 years ago in the lower valley of the Tigris and Euphrates Rivers, an area known as Mesopotamia that is part of present day Iraq. Cities were presumably an outgrowth of an increasingly productive agriculture. Crop surpluses supported expanding long-distance trade and freed people to specialize in such crafts as textiles and ceramics. As the number of merchants and artisans grew, farm villages evolved into cities.
By the middle of the third millennium B.C., it now appears, the first experiments in city living were such resounding successes that people were flocking to new cities over the entire region, in what is now Syria, northern Iraq and Turkey. This excavation, and similar clues at other sites in northern Mesopotamia, suggest that only well-planned construction projects could satisfy their needs fast enough. Further work at Titris and other sites is expected to reveal some of the changing social and political forces behind this rapid expansion of urban civilization and the innovation of planned cities.
"What we're discovering is that in the third millennium a lot of very exciting and creative things are happening in all areas of the Middle East, not just the southern Mesopotamian heartland," said Dr. Charles L. Redman, an authority on early urban civilization at Arizona State University in Tempe.
Excavations at Titris, begun in 1991, are expected to be especially revealing of the form, structure and organization of these earliest cities. For one thing, Dr. Algaze and his team are concentrating research on the neighborhoods and households where ordinary people lived, not on the palaces and temples most archeologists have focused on.
The vagaries of history also appear to have simplified the task. Titris was ultimately a failure as a city, rising and falling over a 300-year period, never again to be reoccupied. So, in contrast to most ancient cities, the ruins of Titris are not obscured by layer upon layer of debris and they lie less than three feet beneath the surface.
"I'm jealous," Dr. Stein said. "Archeology shouldn't be that easy."
Even so, archeologists working with Dr. Algaze have so far excavated only small sections of two neighborhoods. But they have used hand-held magnetometers to map the buried foundations of more than half of the 125-acre site. Outlines of the city's architecture are readily mapped because the nonmagnetic limestone foundations stand out clearly from the surrounding iron-rich soils.
By analyzing the magnetometry maps in the light of actual excavations of representative areas, the archeologists detected patterns suggesting a planned community that, as Dr. Algaze said, "was built in one go." A study of pottery styles seem to confirm that the houses were built and occupied within the same century.
In a new report on the research, Dr. Algaze and Dr. Timothy Matney of Whitman College in Walla Walla, Wash., described excavations at the eastern end of the city that exposed at least four large multiroom houses aligned along a central street. The foundations, they said, "showed extensive evidence for urban planning in its regularity, plan and constructional details."
Excavations at another part of the city exposed remains of terraces built behind retaining walls that in turn, serve as major load-bearing walls for the houses. This also suggested planning.
So did street construction. Streets examined by the archeologists were carefully prepared, cut into virgin soil and then paved with cobbles and crushed pot shards. It was clear, the archeologists concluded, that the streets were "laid before the houses at either side because, in places, the foundation trenches for the house walls had cut into the street."
At both excavation sites, archeologists uncovered limestone and fieldstone foundations of several houses that were more or less identical in design. Walls rising from the foundations were made of mud brick, which have now disintegrated. The roofs were of thatch.
One well-defined dwelling consisted of 15 rooms arranged around a central rectangular courtyard. The courtyard seemed to be subdivided with low partition walls defining what appeared to be four separate working areas. People typically entered the houses through a door off the street that led to an antechamber and then to a second small room that opened on the main house.
Such a house plan, the archeologists said, appeared to be characteristic for domestic dwellings of ordinary people, not the elite, though some were smaller variations on the same design. The houses were probably occupied by extended families, for each one contained several cooking areas.
The houses were places of work as well as residence. In the ruins, archeologists found several raised oval basins lined with plaster. High concentrations of tartaric acid in the plaster indicated that the basins were used in wine production, though some of the basins may have served several purposes.
Since some basins drained into the street, Dr. Virginia Badler, an archeologist at the University of Toronto, said they would not have been used for wine but perhaps in washing and processing wool or fleece. Among the artifacts in several houses were stone loom weights, no doubt associated with weaving.
One aspect of Titris was unlike anything associated with a Levittown or other modern tract housing communities. Each house excavated so far had a family crypt, usually in the central courtyard. Though partly subterranean, the tops of the crypts were visible above the floor foundations.
Each of the tombs contain skeletons of seven to nine people, as well as the remains of food, weapons and other artifacts for use in the after life. One of the most poignant finds in the tomb was a perfectly preserved thistle-type flower in a vase.
The grave goods, Dr. Algaze said, promised to help establish the affluence and social status of these families in the community. Burying the dead inside private residences was not thought to be common, he said, and was not well documented in the Middle East Bronze Age until now.
Working with Dr. Algaze and Dr. Matney at Titris have been archeologists from Britain, Italy, Turkey and the Universities of Chicago and Michigan. Dr. Lewis Somers of Geoscan Surveys Inc. conducted the magnetic mapping.
Dr. Harvey Weiss, an archeologist at Yale University, said that similar evidence of planned cities had been showing up at other sites in northern Syria and Iraq. "We don't understand why," he said, "but this sudden urbanization and now this feature of it, urban planning, are becoming a very remarkable story of how civilization spread."
Dr. Stein said the spread of urbanization and city planning probably reflected a high degree of social organization and complexity and more powerful rulers who wanted to expand and strengthen their political bases and had the means to do it. At the time of Titris, the landscape of both southern and northern Mesopotamia was covered with competing city-states, many of which would eventually be consolidated in a single Akkadian empire under Sargon the Great, around 2300 B.C.
The rise of cities, scholars have noted, coincided with such transforming innovations as writing, use of animals for traction, wheeled carts, metallurgy, irrigation and agriculture surpluses and craft specialization.
Dr. Redman suggested a more elemental, less materialistic reason for people's being encouraged to congregate in cities in ancient Mesopotamia and ever since. "We are a gregarious species," he said. "We like to live and work in groups."
In one sense, Dr. Redman noted, the phenomenon of the third millennium B.C. has been repeated in the last half of the 20th century, perhaps for some of the same reasons. "We are in a period of hyper-urbanization, with the Tokyos and Mexico Cities and Lagoses overflowing with humanity," he said, "because cities are the centers of learning and excitement, places for doing things and making your mark."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Drops for a Sixth Day; Off 6% in Week Against Yen

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The dollar declined against the yen yesterday for a sixth consecutive day even as Japan's top finance official suggested it had fallen enough.
The dollar was also weaker against the mark and other European currencies, dragged down by its slump versus the yen. 
 In the last week, the dollar has fallen more than 6 percent against the yen, after reaching its highest level in four and a half years earlier this month. Traders sold dollars after weeks of warnings from Japan's central bankers, who said they were prepared to sell the dollar to curb its two-year rally.
The slide slowed yesterday after Finance Minister Hiroshi Mitsuzuka of Japan told a parliamentary committee that the dollar was stabilizing at an appropriate level.
"It looks like mission accomplished," said Kevin Lawrie, manager of foreign exchange at Mellon Bank in Boston. Japanese officials "jawboned it down, and now they're saying they're happy with it where it is."
In trading in New York, the dollar closed at 118.50 yen, down from 119.30 yen Monday, and at 1.6959 German marks, down from 1.7064 marks. The British pound rose to $1.6329 from $1.6184.
While Mr. Mitsuzuka's comments did not stop the slide, they slowed it, and many traders say they are confident that the worst is over.
"The dollar had risen too far, too fast, so they were trying to temper it," said Mary Ann Bartels, a portfolio manager at Avatar Associates, a money management firm that oversees $4 billion. "They've back-tailed on those comments and they're now comfortable where it is."
The dollar's decline against the yen contributed to the dollar's slide in Europe.
"If the yen strengthens against the dollar, the dollar sometimes weakens against the mark," said Varick Martin, manager of foreign exchange at Manufacturers and Traders Trust Company.
The dollar fell further against the mark after a report of weak United States retail sales reduced expectations that the Federal Reserve would soon raise interest rates.
Higher interest rates often help the dollar by making dollar-denominated bank deposits and bonds more attractive to global investors.

HEADLINE: Clinton Wreaks Havoc on Research and Policy

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Maureen Dowd (column, May 7) characterizes the Clinton Presidency as having become "so becalmed, so shrunken" that it is paralyzed. Would that it were true. Two recent examples illustrate that ill-conceived policies continue to emerge. 
 A final Environmental Protection Agency regulation under the Toxic Substances Control Act was published in April that virtually eliminates several industrial sectors of biotechnology research, the most important of which is bioremediation, the use of microorganisms to clean up toxic waste. By capturing for review virtually all field trials of microorganisms crafted with modern biotechnology techniques, the agency insures that researchers will continue to face regulatory roadblocks.
Also in April, the State Department published a policy statement, the theme of which is that environmental issues are of such importance that they are now co-equal with national security and economic issues. Should foreign policy decisions turn on whether France harvests an old-growth forest in Provence or Mexico City decides to build highways instead of a subway system?
Big government is still with us and working overtime against the public interest.
 
HENRY I. MILLER, M.D.
Stanford, Calif., May 8, 1997
 
The writer is a senior research fellow at the Hoover Institution.

HEADLINE: Winning Friends for Foreign Policy: Albright's First 100 Days

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 13

 BODY:
When Madeleine K. Albright appears in public or walks along the street, ordinary people rush up to her, as if they know her, and often call her by her first name. She is astonished and pleased, still on a high after 100 days as the first woman to be Secretary of State, and even her security detail is getting used to the attention.
"They don't say Madam Secretary, they call me Madeleine," she said in an interview. "I'm loving it." She has a quick explanation: "People feel that a woman Secretary of State -- this woman -- is approachable, and they are transferring it somehow to demystifying foreign policy. They even say they're reading about it more." 
 But she admits that foreign policy can be a hard sell in a post-Soviet age when the public wants the benefits of peace, not the burdens of global responsibility.
All the adulation does not necessarily mean any important shift or improvement in foreign policy. And Ms. Albright's concentration on public relations has at times meant an oversensitivity among her staff to criticism, some of them admit, especially when it was disclosed that her grandparents had died in the Holocaust and her aides scrambled to find the right balance between openness and privacy.
There is a tendency to react too quickly to problems that get air time, like Ms. Albright's first impulse to propose sending American troops to Albania or the State Department's sudden decision last month to back a particular politician in Zaire, Prime Minister Kengo wa Dondo, a few days before Parliament ousted him. Her staff blamed another official for the decision. Either way, they acknowledge, the incident was telling.
When Zaire started to collapse, Ms. Albright supported sending her successor at the United Nations, Bill Richardson, to try to persuade President Mobutu Sese Seko to resign in time to forestall a military takeover of the capital and preserve the possibility of elections. But the American effort appeared to be weeks too late.
 
A Tart Tongue Sometimes Cutting
Ms. Albright's first real test will be how she shapes the new atmosphere, in which security seems less urgent, Congress and the President are at odds and her boss, President Clinton, ran most of his first term on the premise that he could afford to be a domestic-policy President because George Bush had been a foreign-policy one.
Having discovered that foreign policy is not just about trade and jobs, Mr. Clinton has found in Ms. Albright not only an adroit politician, but also an articulate defender of the very notion of foreign policy.
So this is not quite Secretary of State as favorite aunt, for Ms. Albright is a workaholic, demands much from her small staff and has a witty, tart and sometimes lashing tongue. But she is still a far cry from the traditionally forbidding image of a distant, stiff man in a dark suit -- Dean Acheson, say -- surrounded by aides.
She revels in her new popularity and sees its political importance. "I'm using that, frankly," she said, to try to restore "a compact between Congress and the American people about doing foreign policy."
But all this attention to public relations and image -- especially while so few senior positions have been filled in the State Department because of more rigorous vetting -- has meant that many areas have been neglected, some senior career officials say.
From Zaire and Albania to China and the Middle East, important aspects of policy have drifted while Ms. Albright has focused on early goals.
At the same time, her popularity and visibility give her more influence in internal Administration battles, particularly with a President made even less bold than usual on foreign policy by the continuing fund-raising scandal. It has helped her with another early goal, to seize back from other Cabinet members pre-eminence for the Secretary of State as the chief voice on foreign policy.
The caressing of the public has been skillful and relentless. After diligent practice, she threw out the first ball at the Baltimore Orioles' opening day. She has appeared on television, worn a variety of hats and been mentioned, to her glee, on National Public Radio's "Car Talk."
 
Hand in Hand With Jesse Helms
Other than a world tour to introduce herself, a quick trip to Moscow and her tag-along with President Clinton to Latin America, she has spent more of her time traveling in the United States than abroad. On several domestic trips, including one to Denver today, in journeys to Capitol Hill and in phone calls to legislators, she has courted public opinion, Congress and Republican leaders.
Ms. Albright says she is trying to establish a popular, bipartisan base for foreign policy -- and its costs -- in a divided Government where the chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee is the conservative Senator from North Carolina, Jesse Helms, with whom she was photographed walking hand in hand.
After teaching and thinking for years about executive-legislative relations and policy-making, she said, "what I'm trying to do is to connect with the American people in order to get support for foreign policy so we can get money for foreign policy so we can do foreign policy."
Will it work? "Well, we'll have to see," she said, shrugging.
To get the Senate to approve the Chemical Weapons Convention, Ms. Albright urged the White House to give Mr. Helms important concessions, including a State Department reorganization.
But it was also Ms. Albright who went to Michigan to honor former President Gerald R. Ford, and who broke her speech to stare down at Republican critics like Henry A. Kissinger and Dick Cheney, and to say pointedly: "As I look down at my predecessors, I would like to ask you, at a meeting, would you like to sit on the same side as Iraq and Libya, or would you like to sit with all the other countries in the world? I am asking that you do not put the United States and the President and the Secretary of State in that position."
Success brought more relief than rejoicing. But failure to ratify the convention would have been an enormous blow to Mr. Clinton's credibility and endangered more difficult and important tests to come, like NATO expansion, China policy and paying America's bills at the United Nations.
Ms. Albright's essential problem, said Fareed Zakaria, managing editor of the journal Foreign Affairs, is to get Mr. Clinton to be bold. "You take a President ordinarily uninterested in foreign policy and add to it all these scandals, especially the connection between foreign policy and the campaign, and he gets even more gun-shy." On China, for instance, he said, "it's amazing how unable we are to coordinate our policies with the Europeans when our interests are essentially the same."
 
Inner Circle Is a Bit Small
While concentrating on her early priorities, Ms. Albright has been hobbled by the White House's caution in approving the key senior officials she has chosen, recognized heavyweights like Thomas R. Pickering and Stuart E. Eizenstat.
Samuel R. Berger, the national security adviser, has joked: "Madeleine has the strongest team in Government, but unfortunately they're all off the field."
In the meantime, she is making decisions with a small group of close aides who worked with her at the United Nations. They include her chief of staff, Elaine Shocas, and her adviser and future spokesman, James P. Rubin. While extremely bright and protective of their boss, they are more steeped in politics than in global strategy. Wendy Sherman, a friend of Ms. Albright who ran Congressional liaison for Warren Christopher, is to return as "counselor."
Deputy Secretary Strobe Talbott has provided much of the coordination, what one official called "less big thinking than how to connect the dots." But his main experience is in Russian affairs and NATO, where Ms. Albright is also strong.
Even on NATO expansion, there is skepticism about the coherence of America's goals. The Romanian Foreign Minister, Adrian Severin, said after meeting State Department officials, "I'm sure the NATO strategy is strong and exists, but we were not able to identify it."
One senior official said: "She needs a couple of people who can say: 'Our overriding strategic objectives need to be here. Let X handle that and you handle this and get the Pentagon to do that. Where do we need to be 12 months from now?' It's too early to say she won't have that, but it's not there now."
Robert B. Zoellick, who played that role for Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d in the Bush Administration, is impressed with her fast start. "But everyone knows that will end and people will start to probe into what they're accomplishing," he said, just as bipartisanship will get a harder as mid-term elections approach.
"There's a difference between public relations and a serious public-education strategy," he said. "P.R. is how you get through the day or the meeting and come up with the right quip, and they're very good at that. But how do you use the combination of substance and goals to explain your aims to the Congress and the journalists who cover you regularly?"
 
The Strategy Is Her Game, Too
Asked who will be doing strategy, Ms. Albright said: "With all due respect, I think I'm going to do some of that myself. That's what I do for a living."
When it was suggested that she is too busy to do it, she said, "With this strong team coming on, I will not have to be involved in some of the day-to-day stuff."
Asia policy in particular has drifted, Mr. Zoellick and others say, just when China has become a central issue. One State Department official pointed to Vice President Al Gore's awkward visit to Beijing and his decision to avoid Hong Kong and said, "That trip is a window into the Administration's soul."
The Administration has also decided to play down the Middle East, given the difficulty of dealing with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel. In an important speech describing Mr. Clinton's "Foreign Policy Agenda for the Second Term," Mr. Berger did not even mention the Middle East until the middle of page 5 of 7 pages, and only in passing. Privately, she is said to be concerned not to push a policy Mr. Clinton will quickly disavow, and he is reluctant to press Mr. Netanyahu now.
Bosnia, too, seems stalemated. Ms. Albright plans a speech about what can be done before July 1998, when American troops are scheduled to leave. She was also prominent in the imposition of economic sanctions on Myanmar, the former Burma, for rights abuses.
Ms. Albright has reached out for advice. She has talked with Zbigniew Brzezinski; the departing president of the Carnegie Endowment, Morton Abramowitz; the philanthropist George Soros; and Leslie Gelb, president of the Council on Foreign Relations.
Working long hours, Ms. Albright says she loves it all. But she has had to order her staff to schedule her day more efficiently, including time for reflection.
She calls her job "a great privilege" and with the remaking of her native central Europe in mind after the cold war, she has put up a portrait of George C. Marshall in her office. She is to give a commencement speech next month at Harvard, where 50 years ago he proposed what became the Marshall Plan.
"We are in one of those phases of history where we are the creators," she said. "So getting it right is really important."

HEADLINE: Switzerland's Debts

 BODY:
Recent disclosures about Switzerland's duplicitous role in World War II and its hoarding of Nazi assets have been wrenching for the Swiss people, many of whom long believed the myth that their country was truly neutral. But the reckoning is not yet over. Switzerland has amends to make, and they must be commensurate with the Nazi wealth Switzerland failed to surrender after the war.
Apportioning responsibility today for misconduct half a century ago is not easy. The United States, which led the Allied battle against Germany, made its own mistakes, including decisions not to accept more Jewish refugees and not to bomb the rail lines leading to Nazi concentration camps. 
 In 1946, in the interests of rebuilding Europe and keeping the Soviet Union at bay, a divided Truman Administration unwisely agreed to let Switzerland return just $58 million of some $400 million in gold the Nazis had looted from conquered governments and transferred to the Swiss National Bank. By today's valuation, the $400 million in gold would be worth roughly $4 billion.
Under the same accord, Switzerland promised to liquidate non-gold German assets worth between $250 million and $750 million ($2.1 billion to $6.1 billion today), and turn over half to the Allies for European reconstruction and assistance to war victims. Switzerland never made good on the commitment, even after the amount it owed was reduced in 1952.
That Switzerland was not alone in its misjudgments does not excuse it from making appropriate restitution today. Switzerland's collaboration with the Nazis was extensive and its moral obtuseness after the war quite remarkable.
Switzerland has no legal obligation to reopen the 1946 agreement, which was a valid though flawed international accord. But moral considerations weigh heavily here. The Nazi gold was stolen by Germany. In some cases, the gold bars were smelted from the jewelry and even dental fillings of slaughtered Jews. Surely full recompense is due now that the history of this gold is clear and the economic and political pressures of the postwar period are just a memory. Swiss responsibility for repaying the non-gold assets seems equally clear.
So far Switzerland has established a $175 million fund for Holocaust victims and proposes to create a $4.7 billion foundation to help people in need around the world, provided Swiss voters approve the project next year. That is far from certain. The Government has also formed an independent commission to review Swiss conduct during the war, and Swiss bankers have belatedly agreed to make a full search for dormant bank accounts left by Jews who were killed in the Holocaust.
None of these steps represent full restitution of Switzerland's unpaid obligations. Should the foundation vote fail, the postwar balance sheet will be largely unchanged. That would be unforgivable.
If Switzerland falls short, the Clinton Administration can freeze an appropriate portion of the $86 billion in public and private funds that Switzerland invests in the United States. It should not come to that. Switzerland has ample resources. The question is whether it has the conviction to act.

HEADLINE: Mr. Ferrer Drops Out

 BODY:
Fernando Ferrer may be the first mayoral candidate whose hopes were undone by an empty room. All those televised pictures of vacant tables at Mr. Ferrer's fund-raiser last week, symbolizing his difficulty raising money and winning popular support, could qualify for a list of the top ten signs that your candidacy is in trouble. If Mr. Ferrer did the sensible thing in withdrawing, however, it should also be said that in four months of campaigning he showed an impressive command of city government, a feel for its issues and a personable style. As a strong favorite for re-election as Bronx Borough President, Mr. Ferrer still has an excellent future in city politics.
His decision immediately transforms Ruth Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, into the front-runner in the Democratic primary in September. She is way ahead of the other two Democratic challengers, Councilman Sal F. Albanese and the Rev. Al Sharpton, both of whom have had trouble broadening their base of support. Both men see themselves as tribunes for disaffected New Yorkers who have not shared in the economic upturn and have suffered from the cutbacks in city services that were part of Mayor Rudolph Giuliani's efforts to balance his budget. 
 The thinking among political professionals is that Ms. Messinger must meet the arguments of her Democratic rivals head on even as she moves to the center. Her challenge will be to move beyond her background in Manhattan politics and embrace issues of concern to the middle class in the other four boroughs if she is to have a chance against Mr. Giuliani's re-election bid. Ms. Messinger hopes that her emphasis on preserving families, neighborhoods and schools will do the job.
These are good themes, and New Yorkers deserve a lively debate on all of them. Mr. Giuliani may be tough to beat. Any mayor running for re-election at a time of economic growth and declines in crime, welfare and some taxes would be a formidable opponent. But the city needs a race that focuses on its lingering problems, from collapsing schools to child welfare to economic development strategies. It is not too soon for that debate to begin in earnest.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities' Prices Fall

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
The prices of Treasury securities fell yesterday as economic signals were mixed. An initial gain in bond prices caused by a report of slow retail sales quickly gave way to cautious trading as investors waited for more economic data as they try to anticipate whether the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates next week.
The 30-year bond slid 13/32, to a price of 96 10/32, and the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.92 percent, from 6.89 percent on Monday. 
 Total sales of United States retailers in April fell three-tenths of 1 percent. Even with volatile auto sales excluded, sales were down one-tenth of 1 percent. While the overall decrease was smaller than expected, any decline in sales is generally positive for the bond market, because it indicates that inflation -- which erodes the value of bonds -- is less likely to be a threat. Investors have been concerned that the Fed may raise interest rates again at a policy meeting next week in an effort to slow the economy and head off price increases before they start.
But any positive effect of the retail sales report was quickly snuffed out by a report from the Fed bank of Atlanta indicating surprisingly strong business for manufacturers.
Anthony Chan, vice president and chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisors in Columbus, Ohio, said: "Clearly, any excitement that was generated by the softer core retail sales figures was quickly extinguished by the explosive outcome of the Atlanta Fed survey.
"With manufacturing continuing to expand at a rapid clip, it is difficult to believe that pockets of softness seen in other sectors of the economy are really going to have an opportunity to slow growth sufficiently."
The only reason that there was not a bigger selloff, he said, is that the market generally follows the retail sales report more closely than the Atlanta Fed survey.
For many investors, yesterday's data did little to alter expectations of another rate increase by the Fed. And while the Producer Price Index, due for release today, and the Consumer Price Index, to be released tomorrow, are expected to be market friendly, traders said they expected only limited gains in bond prices, because favorable reports have already been factored into the current prices.
While the Fed's intentions regarding rates are still the main question for traders, action by the central bank helped buoy prices yesterday. The Fed went into the market to buy $1.485 billion in securities for its own account, in a move known as a coupon pass, which adds cash to the banking system. The Fed bought securities that are maturing between Nov. 15, 1997, and April 30, 1999.
Countering the positive effect of the coupon pass was the continuing weakness in the dollar in currency trading. A strong dollar makes dollar-denominated investments like Treasury securities more attractive to foreign investors, not only for the high rate of return but also because of the potential for gains in currency translation.
Elsewhere, a deluge of new corporate debt may make it difficult for Government securities to make headway. Among the corporate paper that is expected to come to market this week is the Norfolk Southern Corporation's $3.5 billion debt offering, whose higher yields are likely to detract from demand for Treasury securities. In addition, the firms managing sales of corporate debt often hedge against possible losses by selling Government securities before the corporate bonds come to market.
