HEADLINE: Retail Sales Down 0.3% Last Month

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 13

 BODY:
The nation's consumers, after spending at a surprisingly strong pace during the first months of the year, have sharply cut back on shopping, with April posting the first monthly decline in retail sales since the start of the Christmas holiday season.
The Commerce Department estimated today that shoppers spent three-tenths of 1 percent less last month than in March as automotive sales and nearly all other major categories weakened. Moreover, a small March rise vanished through revision. 
 The latest sales figures, which were expected to provide a clue to whether the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates again next Tuesday, were widely seen as confirming that the economy had begun to decelerate from first-quarter growth that was the fastest so far of the 1990's -- a 5.6 percent annual pace.
But in light of several distorting factors this year -- unusual winter weather, income tax season, an early Easter and New York's moratorium on sales taxes -- analysts said they could not clearly distinguish between a new, sustainable trend in retail sales and what might turn out to be simply a breather followed by renewed strong growth. And that left many of them saying that the Fed was still likely to raise interest rates, probably next week but certainly within the next few months, unless clearer signs of a slowdown emerge.
"You can't tell how much is seasonal impact and how much is a genuinely slower pace of demand," said Kathleen Camilli, chief economist at Tucker Anthony in New York.
Howard Keen Jr., an economist for Conrail, was similarly skeptical. "It's quite premature to be calling this any kind of a significant downshifting," he said.
Although various other data, including two gauges of inflation, are to be published before the Fed's policy meeting on Tuesday, today's tally of retail sales is probably the last critical figure the Fed will have before the meeting. Retail sales not only account for one-third of economic activity but are one of the most up-to-date indicators available to monetary officials.
Today's soft sales results were in line with expectations and prompted no clear reaction on Wall Street. Interest rates initially edged lower, helping power the Dow Jones industrial average above 7,300 for the first time, but after a report from the Atlanta Federal Reserve Bank indicated that manufacturing activity in the South had picked up speed, both markets reversed course and ended with losses.
While analysts generally regarded the sales report as one straw in the wind against Fed action, the dominant view seemed to be that the Fed would probably still raise rates, given an unemployment rate below 5 percent and industry running at a robust pace that is using more than 84 percent of capacity.
"It gives them a little more opportunity not to tighten next week but it would take a lot more weakness than we've seen so far to forestall it," said Chris Varvares, president of Macroeconomic Advisers in St. Louis.
Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, warned last week of a need for higher rates unless the economy slowed, but it was unclear whether he was expecting immediate confirmation of a slowdown or was prepared to wait for more solid evidence of the longer-term trend.
William C. Dudley, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs, dismissed the notion that today's figures represented a significant slowdown in consumer spending. Rather, he contended that the weak sales were merely the "flip side" of early-year strength that owed much to such temporary factors as mild shopping weather and income tax refunds that were bigger than in the past and were received earlier than usual.
Still, Mr. Dudley added, "this does give Chairman Greenspan one more arrow in his quiver to argue for waiting" when the Fed deliberates next week.
James McCormick, an economist at Morgan Guaranty Trust, expressed a common view when he said the Fed faced "a close call" but one that "slightly favors" a quarter-point rate increase.
"Supports for consumer spending are still in place," he noted, "including a strong labor market, rising real incomes and increased wealth from financial markets."
The decline in April retail sales, which was the first since November and the biggest since June, included a drop of five-tenths of 1 percent for durable goods. That mainly resulted from automotive sales, which fell nine-tenths of 1 percent. Merchants selling furniture and other home equipment reported receipts were three-tenths of 1 percent below the previous month, while sales were unchanged for those selling building materials, hardware, garden supplies and mobile homes.
Among nondurables, the biggest drop was a fall of nine-tenths of 1 percent at department stores and other general merchandisers. Other declines were six-tenths of 1 percent in apparel; five-tenths of 1 percent in food, and one-tenth of 1 percent for gasoline stations (where prices fell) and for drugstores.
The only sales increase -- five-tenths of 1 percent -- was at restaurants and bars.
In all, retail sales -- unadjusted for inflation -- were 4.9 percent higher than in April 1996, reaching an estimated $212.2 billion.

HEADLINE: Stocks Move a Bit Lower As the Rally Takes a Pause

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stocks edged lower yesterday, hurt by concerns that the Federal Reserve might raise interest rates next week.
The Dow Jones industrial average bobbed above 7,300 for the first time, but ended the day at 7,274.21, down 18.54 points from Monday's record finish. 
 Most broad market measures also retreated after struggling to extend Monday's rally. The Dow rose 123 points Monday, bringing its bounce from April's lows to 900 points.
"You cannot have the market continue to move up at the rate it's been moving," said Robert Freedman, chief investment officer for the John Hancock Funds in Boston. "The market is a little overdone on the upside and needs to rest and consolidate."
The Nasdaq market suffered the heaviest damage yesterday as Intel slid sharply on news that it had been sued by Digital Equipment, which accused Intel of patent infringement.
The bond market briefly provided some support for stocks after a report that retail sales fell three-tenths of 1 percent in April, slightly more than expected and the biggest decline in 10 months.
The decline in retail activity bolstered the recent optimism that the economy's vigorous pace is easing enough to keep inflationary pressures under control without another move by the Federal Reserve to raise short-term interest rates.
But analysts said the retail sales report, as well as reports today on producer prices and tomorrow on consumer prices could have little impact on next Tuesday's meeting of Fed policy makers.
"Even with good numbers showing no inflation, it doesn't mean the Fed won't raise rates," Mr. Freedman said. "They've said all along that they're trying to stay ahead of the inflation curve."
Stocks gave back their early gains as bonds retreated, increasing long-term interest rates, and the slide steepened after a Federal Reserve official asserted that consumer activity remained strong.
Al Broaddus, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, said yesterday that "the time to resist inflation is precisely when there is no inflation."
 Declining issues outnumbered those advancing by about a 13-to-12 margin on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 4.53 points, to 833.13, and the New York Stock Exchange composite index fell 1.60 points, to 433.97. Both measures had closed at record highs in Monday's advance.
The Nasdaq composite index fell 10.60 points, to 1,333.59, as Intel tumbled 6 3/4, to 152 3/8, on news of the lawsuit by Digital, which rose 2 1/4, to 35 3/8, on the Big Board.
Among other issues, Wal-Mart Stores rose 1/4, to 30. The company, the nation's largest retailer, reported after the market closed on Monday that its first-quarter earnings had risen 14 percent.
Shares of Owens-Illinois rose 3/8, to 28 7/8. The company sold 14.75 million shares yesterday at an offering price of 28 1/2, raising $420.3 million.
Inbrand surged 10 7/8, to 26 7/8, on news that Tyco International had agreed to acquire the company for stock valued at $320 million, or $27.20 a share. Inbrand makes disposable adult incontinence products.
Boston Chicken shares fell 3/4, to 22 1/16, after the restaurant chain was cut to "market outperform" from "trading buy" by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
10 Years Later, I.B.M. Sets a New High in a Changed Market

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
This is a tale of how the dominant can fade, and how technology, unlike most other industries, can see huge companies shrink and smaller ones become behemoths.
On a summer day nearly a decade ago, the shares of the International Business Machines Corporation, then the dominant maker of computers and by far the largest company in the country, hit a record high of $175.875. It was the only company in the land with a market value of more than $100 billion. 
 Yesterday, for the first time since that day -- Aug. 21, 1987 -- I.B.M., no longer dominant but once again in favor on Wall Street, rose above its old high, peaking at $177.125 a share in New York Stock Exchange trading, before closing at $173.625.
Yet I.B.M. is now only No. 9 among all American companies, and just No. 3 among technology companies, in market value. It is far behind Intel and Microsoft, companies that at the end of August 1987 were together worth less than a tenth of what I.B.M. was worth.
The No. 1 company now is the General Electric Company, which makes everything from jet engines to refrigerators, but which has seen its biggest growth in financial services. Yesterday, it became the first corporation to be valued at more than $200 billion, compared with just $57 billion in that summer of 1987, when it was the third-largest company.
The fall and recovery of I.B.M. -- which bottomed on Aug. 16, 1993, at $40.625 a share, or 77 percent below its peak -- has come amid one of the great bull markets and amid a changing of the guard atop corporate America. Now there are seven companies worth more than $100 billion, and I.B.M. is worth only $86 billion.
How, one might ask, can the company be worth about 15 percent less than it was in 1987, when the stock price is roughly equal? The answer lies with financial engineering, at which I.B.M. has excelled in recent years even as its share of the computer market has slipped.
From the end of 1994 through March 31, I.B.M. has spent $13.2 billion on share repurchases, as noted in the current issue of Grant's Interest Rate Observer. During the same period, it has spent $9.9 billion on research and development. With fewer shares outstanding, the overall market value is lower, even though the per-share figure is higher.
Comparing the lists of America's highest-valued companies in 1987 and now shows how things have changed. There were then two computer-related companies among the top 10. Now there are three.
But while I.B.M. has fallen from first to ninth, the Digital Equipment Corporation was then the second-largest computer maker and No. 10 over all. As of Monday, it ranked 324th, according to Bloomberg Financial Markets.
The two new computer-related companies are Microsoft and Intel, now ranked fourth and fifth. Both owe their high position in part to opportunities opened up by I.B.M., which used Microsoft's operating system and Intel's semiconductors when it invaded and greatly expanded the personal computer market. One can only imagine how different the world would be had I.B.M. managed to maintain control, or at least a sizable stake, in those two markets as the PC market grew.
Over all, five of the top 10 a decade ago are still on the list. The Exxon Corporation has fallen from second to third, the Philip Morris Companies has climbed from eighth to seventh and Merck & Company has moved from ninth to sixth.
The other corporations that have fallen from the top 10 -- AT&T, General Motors, Du Pont and Ford Motor -- all remain in the top 40 and are leaders in their industries. AT&T would still be among the top 10 had it not spun off Lucent Technologies and NCR last year. The other three newcomers to the top 10 -- Coca-Cola, Procter & Gamble and Johnson & Johnson -- were in the top 25 in 1987.
Only in technology can companies come from nowhere to reach the top in a decade -- or vice versa. In August 1987, Intel was valued at about $6 billion by the stock market, and Microsoft at about $3 billion. Now the figures are $125 billion and $142 billion, respectively.
Of the top 10 in 1987, the computer companies are the only ones with lower market capitalizations now than then. Digital has gone from $25 billion to about $5 billion. An aside on Digital: It was an early adherent to the theory, which it did well in selling to Wall Street, that dividends do not matter because it is better for a company to plow its profits back into the business. As a result, owners of that stock in the last decade have not only lost money -- Digital's price is down 81 percent from August 1987 -- they have not gotten any dividends that would cushion the blow.
I.B.M. has always paid a dividend, which it has just raised to 40 cents a quarter, up from 35 cents but well below the $1.10 quarterly it was paying when the stock last was hitting new highs. Since August 1987, a holder who stuck with I.B.M. has collected $31.08 in dividends for each share.
The new technology leaders are closer to Digital, at least in dividend philosophy. Microsoft has never paid a dividend; while Intel has been making payouts since 1992, they are not exactly generous. It now pays 5 cents a quarter, or 20 cents a year -- a dividend yield on the current stock price of $152.375 of one-tenth of 1 percent a year.
On that summer day in 1987 when I.B.M. last set a high, the Dow Jones industrial average did the same, closing at a record 2,709.20. The Dow would reach one more high that year, on the following Tuesday, and then plunge in the October market crash. It would be another two years, in August 1989, before the Dow again set a new high. The Dow is now up 167 percent from its 1987 peak.
I.B.M. is the last of the 30 stocks now in the Dow to rise above its 1987 peak. Two stocks then in the Dow -- but removed this year as Dow Jones pruned losers -- remain below their 1987 peaks. They are Bethlehem Steel and Woolworth.
And, of course, I.B.M.'s stock price still has not kept up with inflation. Adjusting for the rise of the Consumer Price Index, I.B.M. is still 28 percent below its 1987 peak.

HEADLINE: Rent Debate: Drama Is Familiar

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 13

 BODY:
The day after Gov. George E. Pataki announced his plan to broker a compromise that would gradually end rent regulations, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver was still saying that he wanted the laws extended, untouched. The Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, arguing that the Governor's plan did not go far enough, was still saying he wanted the laws abolished in a handful of years. Compromise seemed as distant as ever.
Far from softening their stances, the legislative leaders seemed prepared today to battle over the laws until the hour they are scheduled to expire, at midnight on June 15. They accused each other of intransigence, marshaled support for their positions and issued dire warnings about each other's plans. 
 In what seemed like a coordinated campaign, Mr. Pataki and Mr. Bruno, both Republicans, accused Mr. Silver, a Democrat of Manhattan, of trying to frighten tenants for political gain. Mr. Bruno defiantly reiterated his threat to allow the laws to expire unless Mr. Silver agreed to a plan to bring about their end.
"If the Speaker stays where he is, he's going to have the full responsibility for this law expiring, and every tenant will suffer and be hurt," said Mr. Bruno, of Rensselaer County, across the Hudson from Albany.
Mr. Silver returned the Republicans' accusations. "I would think the Governor should look at the record as to who has been frightening tenants," he said. "He and his colleague, the majority leader, came out in December telling tenants he was going to end the rent laws."
So where does this leave the 2.5 million people in regulated apartments who are subjected almost daily to the anxiety-raising news flashes about the future of the rules? Are things as hopeless as they seem?
Like almost everything the Legislature touches, the answer is not clear. Though some people might think there is not much time left before the expiration of the laws, 33 days is an eternity in Albany, where politicians habitually wait until moments before a deadline to work out compromises on thorny issues. That means there will be a lot more saber rattling on the rent laws before anyone will publicly admit a willingness to budge.
That is partly because both Mr. Bruno and Mr. Silver want to look as if they are fighting until the last minute for their constituencies: for Mr. Silver, urban tenants; for Mr. Bruno, landlords and business interests.
May 20 looms as important in this political dance, because on that day thousands of tenants, probably accompanied by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and his Democratic challengers, will trek to Albany for demonstrations in support of extending the laws. For symbolic as well as negotiating purposes, neither side, particularly not Mr. Silver, wants to display any signs of weakness before then.
But major philosophical and policy differences also separate the Governor and the two leaders that will be extraordinarily difficult to bridge. How do you find a middle ground when one side insists that the system has been a disaster and must be dismantled, and the other contends it has provided immeasurable benefits and must be defended at all costs?
"It is an issue that won't submit to compromise," said John Zogby, a pollster from the Syracuse area. "You've got to take one side or the other: preserve it or get rid of it. Any effort to walk the middle ground becomes obviously just that: a dodge."
Of the three leaders, Mr. Pataki has the most difficult balancing act. He does not want to alienate city voters or his fellow Republican, Mr. Giuliani, by endorsing Mr. Bruno's call to end rent protections immediately. But as a proponent of free markets and smaller government, he also does not want to continue a system forever that many economists say has deprived landlords of a fair return on their investments and discouraged new housing.
What the Governor proposed earlier this week attempts to walk both paths. He called for expanding a policy known as luxury decontrol, under which rent protections would be immediately abolished for people earning more than $175,000 a year for two consecutive years, except for tenants who are over 62 or disabled. He also proposed allowing landlords to charge market rates on apartments once they are vacated, a policy known as vacancy decontrol, which would eventually eliminate the limits on all 1.1 million regulated apartments.
Still, neither Mr. Silver nor Mr. Bruno was willing publicly to embrace the Governor's proposal today, even though it contains elements both sides like. Mr. Bruno, who is the Governor's main ally in the Legislature, said today that he considered Mr. Pataki's plan "closer to mine" than to Mr. Silver's, but still raised objections to it.
In particular, Mr. Bruno says he wants a definite date for ending most rent laws, something Mr. Pataki says he opposes. While vacancy decontrol would eventually accomplish that goal, it could take many years.
"When should it end?" he asked. "The Governor says maybe 30 years, maybe two centuries. That's unacceptable. I'm saying some reasonable, realistic length of time. I said two years, maybe it's four, maybe it's five. It sure isn't 20 or 30."
Besides setting a definite date for ending rent regulations altogether, Mr. Bruno said he would insist on decontrol for all apartments that become vacant before that date. That way, landlords could get immediate relief on vacated apartments while they were waiting for the rules to expire.
Many politicians in Albany have privately suggested that one avenue for compromise might be some form of limited vacancy decontrol, under which rent protections are lifted only on costly apartments as they become vacant. That policy already exists for units renting for $2,000 or more a month, and could be expanded by including less expensive apartments.
But Mr. Bruno seemed to close the door to that idea today, saying he would not allow any bill to pass in the Senate unless it included vacancy decontrol for all regulated apartments, regardless of their rent. "It absolutely will not get through the Senate," he said, referring to any form of limited vacancy decontrol.
That leaves Mr. Silver. Today, after Mr. Bruno, Mr. Pataki, former Mayor Edward I. Koch and the editorial boards of several major newspapers all called on him to be more flexible about scaling back the laws, he still was not budging.
Republicans say they think that Mr. Silver is playing a waiting game because he thinks voters will blame Mr. Pataki if the rent laws lapse, forcing him to accept a Democratic plan. But today, aides to Mr. Silver denied that.
"There is no such cockiness on this side," said a Silver aide, speaking on condition of anonymity. "People just need to wait until we get closer to the 15th."

HEADLINE: For a Flood-Stricken Town, Hope Is a Next-Door Neighbor to Despair

BYLINE: By DON TERRY 

DATELINE: FALMOUTH, Ky., May 11

 BODY:
Rigg Street will never be the same. The Licking River made sure of that when it tore through the block and the rest of this small town like a tornado two months ago, ripping houses off their foundations and floating away cars, trucks, mobile homes, people and dreams in its angry, fast-moving flood waters.
Bob Wellman and his wife are the only people living on the street these days. Mr. Wellman recently spent an afternoon trying to hook up a makeshift sewer line to a used camping trailer parked on a muddy lot where his home once stood. He and his wife live in the trailer and pray they can get enough Federal disaster relief to build a new home outside of town, far from the Licking River. 
 "The river is going to go crazy again," Mr. Wellman said as he sawed a piece of plastic pipe. "But I'm not going to be here to see it. Whatever the Government offers me for my property, it's theirs."
Before the flood there were 25 families living on Rigg Street in tiny houses that meant the world to them. They are people like Ricky Cookendorfer and his mother, Dorothy, who has lived most of her 79 years on the street.
"It used to be nothing but families looking out for each other around here," Mr. Cookendorfer said. "That's all gone now."
But Mrs. Cookendorfer, now living with her daughter outside of town, is determined to return to Rigg, one of the hardest hit stretches of Falmouth, even if she is the only living soul left on a block of ghosts.
"This is home," she said. "I'm not going to let the river run me off."
Throughout the Midwest, cities and towns from Grand Forks, N.D., on the Red River to hamlets along the Ohio and Mississippi Rivers were devastated this spring by some of the most widely scattered flooding across the nation in years.
So far this year, 516 counties in 16 states have been declared major disaster areas in separate occurrences. Though complete damage assessments will not be clear for some time yet, the cost to recover from the flooding in the upper Midwest alone is expected to run into the billions.
While hardly the biggest town in the area to be submerged by the flooding, Falmouth, population 2,400 and about an hour's drive south of Cincinnati, was among the hardest hit. Five people here were killed -- more deaths by floods than any one town suffered. And in Falmouth, which sits at a bend in the Licking, more than 400 homes were damaged or destroyed when the swollen river, instead of following the bend, went straight across town.
The story of Rigg Street and Falmouth is partly one of surrender and sorrow, but mostly it is a story of a determined struggle to rebuild homes, businesses and hope. It is also a look into the future for other towns and cities, like the much bigger Grand Forks, which are in the earlier stages of putting back together lives and livelihoods torn apart by rivers gone crazy.
It is an uncertain future, as anyone in Falmouth could testify.
Falmouth is the seat of Pendleton County, where unemployment before the flood was 5 percent, about equal to the national level. Now the jobless rate is 15 percent, because many businesses have not reopened.
On some streets, like Rigg, there are almost as many vacant lots as buildings. Bulldozers knocked down dozens of homes too badly damaged by the flood to be repaired.
But there are also signs of hope springing up. McDonald's restaurant, the Dairy Queen and Wyatt's, the only grocery store in town, have reopened.
"It's still going to take years for us to come back to where we were," said a Falmouth City Council member, Jeff Carson. "For lack of a better term, we're making our way through uncharted waters."
More than two months have passed since the Licking stormed its banks and flooded at least 60 percent of the town in early March. But hundreds of Falmouth residents are still unsure when or if they will be able to return to their homes. So as they wait and worry, they sleep on sofas and spare beds in the homes of family and friends, or move into "New Hope," a village of mobile homes supplied by the Federal Government, two miles south of town.
"People are scattered in all directions," said Jack Wright, executive director of the Pendleton County Economic Development Authority.
Finding flood refugees a roof is Bill Hopper's job. Before the flood he was a geologist who inspected coal mines for the Kentucky Department of Surface Planning. Since the flood he has been on loan to the Federal Emergency Management Agency, helping locate housing. In the last 60 days he has put 7,000 miles on his blue, mud-splattered state truck.
"It's the best job I ever had," Mr. Hopper said as he stood on a porch of a flood-damaged house here on South Liberty Street. "I've got good news for people for a change. I got a place for them to live."
Lately, Mr. Hopper has been arranging for travel trailers to be set up next to homes now undergoing repairs so the owners do not have as far to go to work on their homes. He said he and other F.E.M.A. workers were surprised that they had not been busier. He said the demand for housing assistance is not as great as relief agencies had expected.
"There are ghost towns out there, and we don't know where the people are," he said. "They're not coming to F.E.M.A. Here in Kentucky, you got four or five generations of a clan living next to each other, and they're taking each other in."
Federal officials say 85 mobile homes have been set up at New Hope, and 37 are occupied. The site has a capacity of 162. Mr. Hopper and F.E.M.A. officials have set up 21 travel trailers in Falmouth, including the one next door to 410 Liberty, the home of Tony and Beth Spence and their two small children.
Until a week ago, the Spences had been living with her family near Cincinnati, which made her husband arrive late for work almost every morning since the flood.
"We're so lucky to have this trailer," Mrs. Spence said. "I never thought I'd miss Falmouth so much."
The couple hope to be back in their home, a one-and-a-half-story house, in a couple of weeks. They thought hard about not returning. The flood took so much: toys, appliances, a grandmother's dining room set.
"But there's something about a small town that makes you want to hold on," Mrs. Spence said. "In a small town, people know your name at the grocery store, at the bank. We're just going to pray that it doesn't happen again. I can't go through this again."
A lot of her neighbors have decided not to rebuild, at least not anywhere near the river. Federal officials say 212 applications have been filed in Falmouth for a buyout program.
Using a combination of Federal, state and local money, the authorities hope to buy as many of the most seriously flood-damaged properties in town as they can, so the homeowners can salvage as much of their lives as possible and either move out of town or rebuild on higher ground.
Statewide, the program has a budget of about $16 million. But Falmouth was only one of dozens of Kentucky towns hit by flooding this spring. Falmouth officials say they need at least $8 million for the buyout program, and they have no idea how much money they will receive from the Government. They also have no idea what the cash-strapped town will do with the lots if it buys them.
"It's going to be a nightmare," said Terry England, the Falmouth treasurer. "How do we maintain the lots? We don't have any money."
Unlike in Grand Forks, where city officials knew for weeks that melting snow would make the Red River dangerously high, and where the land is so flat that flood waters spread relatively slowly, the Licking turned deadly almost overnight after a day of heavy rain on Feb. 28.
People here talk in terms of hours, not days, when they recall how fast the water took over their town. One longtime resident, Bob Pettit, said that the water was ankle deep one minute, and 15 minutes later was up to his thigh and moving so fast that a strong man could barely walk through it.
"It was a humbling experience," he said. "But I'm through with crying. We're going to get back to normal. We're stubborn."
And in Falmouth, normal means going to buy groceries at Wyatt's, which has been part of the town in one form or another for 52 years, ever since Abe and Ruby Wyatt started selling eggs and milk from the back of an old truck. Soon they built a store, and in 1990 the family opened a sparkling supermarket on the edge of town and the river.
The flood sent nearly six and a half feet of water into the store. Mrs. Wyatt, an 81-year-old widow, had to lay off all 50 employees, and the business lost about $1 million.
Until the store reopened last Wednesday, the people of Falmouth had to drive 20 miles or more to buy groceries. "But when you're knocked down," Mrs. Wyatt said, "the only thing to do is get up."
A few blocks from Wyatt's, Mrs. Cookendofer sat in a swing on her porch at 416 Rigg Street. The swing was one of the few items the river did not steal from her. Inside, her family was painting and cleaning. A new stove sat in the middle of the living room, waiting to be installed when the kitchen is finished. She hopes to move back home in a week or so.
Across the street, on a crooked porch covered in mud and debris left from the flood, was a rust-colored dog, a chow, apparently abandoned by the people who lived in the house before the river chased them out. Any time someone approaches the dog it runs away, only to return to his lonely vigil when the person leaves.
"We bring him food and water," Mrs. Cookendofer said. "He's the only neighbor we've got right now, and on Rigg Street we take care of our neighbors."

HEADLINE: In Her Own Words

 BODY:

RUTH W. MESSINGER
In prepared remarks outside Public School 234 in lower Manhattan, she outlined her differences with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani on a number of issues:
"Rudy Giuliani doesn't see the devastating effects of the budget cuts he has loosed upon the city's public school children. 
 He doesn't see the neighborhoods where the number of cops on the beat is going down.
He doesn't see the need to fight to make sure 2.6 million New Yorkers continue to have rent protection.
He doesn't see the one out of every 10 New Yorkers without jobs -- he says that a rising unemployment rate is really a good sign for New York.
If Rudy doesn't see the problems New Yorkers face, he can't fix them. And if he can't fix them, he should no longer be the Mayor.
I see the problems. And, as Mayor, I will fix them.
I've seen the problems in our schools. And, as Mayor, I will fix them. I will undo the damage the Mayor has done and restore our schools to excellence.
I will work with, not against, the Chancellor to cut class sizes. I will raise standards and lift scores, restock school libraries and make sure our kids don't have to attend class in converted closets or restrooms.
And, as Mayor, I will not balance the city's budget on the backs of our public schools."

HEADLINE: Rent Decontrol Study: From No Impact to 30% Increases

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
A study commissioned by New York City has found that allowing rent increases once an apartment falls vacant, a policy recommended by Gov. George E. Pataki, would have a limited impact on the rent of most apartments during the next two years. But a few areas, including the Upper West Side, would see rent increases as high as 30 percent, the study found.
The study, co-sponsored by the city's Rent Guidelines Board and by the Center for Real Estate and Urban Policy at the New York University School of Law, addresses the potential effect of vacancy decontrol, as the policy is known, over two years, and does not consider a longer term. The results are based on data from the city's official 1996 Housing and Vacancy Survey. 
 As expected, the study suggests that vacancy decontrol would have the greatest effect on rents in Manhattan, where market rates are highest. It predicted significant increases above 96th Street in Manhattan, averaging 24 percent, since market rents are much higher than regulated rents in those neighborhoods. It also found that rents in newly vacated apartments in Stuyvesant Town and Turtle Bay would rise an average of 14 percent. In Chelsea, Clinton and Midtown, rents would rise an average of 23 percent upon becoming vacant.
The study predicts the tenants who would most likely leave their apartments in the next two years: those who are younger, single, or couples without children who live in apartments where the difference between the regulated and market-rate rents is smallest.
Over the longer term, rents on newly deregulated apartments would likely rise by even higher levels, the study's authors say. That is because apartments that become vacant in the first two years after decontrol would generally have regulated rents that are close to market levels.
"Over the long run, as people who currently enjoy the biggest rent discounts move out of their apartments, we can expect substantially larger increases," said Michael Schill, director of the N.Y.U. law school's real estate institute.
On Monday, Governor Pataki proposed eliminating rent protections on apartments as they become vacant, a plan that would eventually end a half-century-old system that limits increases on 1.1 million apartments in the state, most of them in New York City.
Tenant advocates, including Democrats in Albany, oppose any plan that would lift rent regulations, arguing that vacancy decontrol would encourage landlords to harass tenants to make them move out. Landlords, backed by Republicans who have supported efforts to eliminate regulation quickly, criticized Mr. Pataki's proposal as too weak. Without some form of agreement, rent regulation is scheduled to expire on June 16.
The study was conducted by Dr. Edgar O. Olsen, a professor of economics at the University of Virginia. It compared the rents of regulated apartments with the rents on similar market-rate units in the same neighborhoods.
"We commissioned this study in January, anticipating that the debate might come down to vacancy decontrol," said Douglas P. Hillstrom, executive director of the Rent Guidelines Board, the city agency that sets annual increases for rent-stabilized apartments. "We didn't have any idea that the report would be as timely as it's proven to be." It was completed on Monday.
Across the city, the study said, the median increase on vacant apartments would be $32 a month, or an average of 4 percent. The change would vary; many neighborhoods would see small increases or none at all, and some neighborhoods would see sizable increases in rents, the study said.
The study breaks down its figures by sections of boroughs taken from the Housing and Vacancy Survey. In Manhattan, the calculations show, rents would rise in Greenwich Village and the financial district by a monthly average of $131, or 12 percent, but would not change on the Lower East Side and in Chinatown. On the Upper West Side, the increases would average $293, or 30 percent, and on the Upper East Side, $108, or 11 percent. Perhaps surprisingly, the increase in Manhattan above 96th Street would average $147, or 24 percent, a month.
Asked why the northern part of Manhattan would experience relatively high increases, Dr. Olsen said that in general the estimates for the smaller areas "are less reliable than for the city as a whole."
He added: "And this problem was especially severe in a few cases, such as Manhattan above 96th Street, because of the small number of unregulated units available to estimate market rents. In central Harlem, for example, there were only four unregulated buildings that were surveyed."
In greatly simplified terms, the study used data from previous Housing and Vacancy Surveys to predict which types of tenants would most likely vacate their apartments in the next two years. Data from the 1996 survey were then used to estimate what the market rate rent for those newly vacated apartments would become if they were decontrolled.
In Brooklyn, the projected increases per month ranged from $59, or 10 percent, in southern Crown Heights, and $38, or 7 percent, in Sheepshead Bay, Gravesend, Flatlands and Canarsie, to no increase for sections like East New York, Brownsville, Williamsburg and Greenpoint. Flatbush would experience an average increase of $13, or 2 percent, the study said, while, surprisingly, apartments in Brooklyn Heights, Fort Greene, Park Slope, and Carroll Gardens would see no increases on average.
Asked to explain that finding, Professor Schill said Brooklyn has a large number of areas in which the average stabilized rent is close to market rates.
"The average stabilized rent in Brooklyn Heights is 90 percent of the unregulated market rent, which is fairly close," he said. "And in Park Slope, it's even closer, 96 percent of the unregulated rent."
As expected, landlord and tenant advocates took widely divergent views on the study.
"The independent study by the Rent Guidelines Board and N.Y.U. answers the first big lie that has always been trotted out by tenant leaders, that rents will skyrocket in every part of the city," said Joseph Strasburg, president of the Rent Stabilization Association, the city's largest landlord organization. "What this study confirms is that most of the benefits of rent regulation are primarily in Manhattan."
Michael McKee, the rent law campaign manager for the New York State Tenants and Neighbors Coalition, referred to the only previous period of vacancy decontrol in New York, from 1971 to 1974, and said: "It was really devastating. There was an enormous amount of evictions and eviction attempts."
"This study is predicated on the assumption that no one will move, except voluntarily," Mr. McKee continued. "There will be a replay of history and landlords will go wild."

HEADLINE: WITH FERRER OUT, MESSINGER FOCUSES ON FACING GIULIANI

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
With her main Democratic adversary stepping aside, Ruth W. Messinger yesterday sought to transform the mayoral race into a two-person contest with Rudolph W. Giuliani, ignoring her remaining Democratic rivals as she demanded a one-on-one debate with the Mayor.
Mr. Giuliani laughed off Ms. Messinger's demand for an early debate, which she said should be devoted to the candidates' differences on New York's endangered rent control system. But he heartily concurred with Ms. Messinger's assertion that this has become a two-person race, and in a hint of the general election ahead, painted the Manhattan Borough President as ideologically out of step with a changing city and a Manhattan partisan unable to relate to the four other boroughs. 
 The give and take between two politicians who now seemed poised to dominate New York's political life for the next six months occurred after Fernando Ferrer announced yesterday that he was quitting the mayoral race, choosing instead to run for a third term as Bronx borough president. Mr. Ferrer said he was halting his troubled campaign and endorsing Ms. Messinger to avoid a divisive primary that would insure Mr. Giuliani's re-election.
Mr. Ferrer's abrupt exit put Ms. Messinger in the spotlight. She quickly sought to take advantage of the unusual, if welcome, sight of microphone-wielding reporters and camera operators trailing her through the streets of lower Manhattan to a news conference. With the trim and gleaming backdrop of Public School 234 behind her -- and clearly enjoying what one adviser described as the biggest soapbox of her life -- Ms. Messinger engaged in the time-honored political tactic of challenging an incumbent to a debate, while laying out some of the themes that she will bring to the contest.
"My mom and dad used to tell me that you can't solve a problem you don't see," Ms. Messinger said, as an aide cleared out people behind her to insure cameras a clear shot of the school. Listing difficulties with public schools, rent protection and street police patrols, she concluded: "If Rudy doesn't see the problems New Yorkers face, he can't fix them. And if he can't fix them, he should no longer be the Mayor."
Notwithstanding Ms. Messinger's sudden dominance in the Democratic primary, her two remaining opponents, Councilman Sal F. Albanese and the Rev. Al Sharpton, both signaled that they were not prepared to give up. Mr. Albanese and Mr. Sharpton trail Ms. Messinger in endorsements, money and early opinion polls. But they have reputations as articulate and innovative mavericks, willing to take risks to advance their candidacies.
"There's no way in the world we're going to have a campaign coronation for Ruth Messinger," Mr. Albanese said. "I'm a much stronger candidate." He described her as the Mayor's "dream candidate," and predicted she would be demolished by Mr. Giuliani because she was too liberal on too many issues.
Mr. Sharpton disputed the idea of a two-person race. "The pundits say what they want," Mr. Sharpton said. "We have grown even in their polls. We have grown in fund-raising. We believe that we can be successful. The people that I speak for must be heard. The people that I've tried to represent must be at the table."
Mr. Sharpton also said that, the way the race was shaping up, every major party candidate for citywide office -- mayor, public advocate and comptroller -- was white. "We cannot end this century with an all-white Republican slate facing an all-white Democratic slate in a city that's majority people of color," he said.
Indeed, there were signs yesterday that if Ms. Messinger was now being seen as the inevitable Democratic nominee, which she was, it was creating as much of a sense of resignation as of celebration. Many New York professional political leaders had endorsed Mr. Ferrer precisely because they were wary that Ms. Messinger, with her Manhattan base and longtime affiliation with liberal causes, would present the Mayor with an easy political target.
And the Mayor and his political aides happily fed those anxieties yesterday. Fran Reiter, the Mayor's campaign manager, did not even wait for Mr. Ferrer to finish his withdrawal news conference before launching the artillery at Ms. Messinger.
As Mr. Ferrer spoke at the bottom of the steps of City Hall, Ms. Reiter assembled a news contingent at the top, where she called Ms. Messinger a renegade from 1960's.
Even Mr. Ferrer, in endorsing Ms. Messinger, could not bring himself to rebut the notion that she was too liberal to win a race against Mr. Giuliani. "That's a knock that I have never made," said Mr. Ferrer, who would like to run again for Mayor in 2001. "Apparently some others have, and they'll have to answer for it."
Mr. Ferrer's remarks, as well as his withdrawal, reflected a widespread sentiment among Democrats that Mr. Giuliani would be exceedingly difficult to defeat, given the city's ascending economy and descending crime rate.
Ms. Messinger shrugged off such questions as she made the best of her sudden political celebrity. Her decision to challenge Mr. Giuliani to a debate on the rent regulations was a last-minute addition to her speech, reflecting what asides said would be a new aggressiveness to a campaign that many Democrats believe has been, until now, listless.
Messinger campaign aides said they did not expect Mr. Giuliani to ever agree to a debate so early. But her aides calculated that such a gambit would bring attention both to her and her proposal that city residents in a referendum, rather than the State Legislature in a public vote, be allowed to decide the future the rent regulation system.
"I've made it clear where I stand," Ms. Messinger said. "I'm for a referendum in New York City by New Yorkers on the issue of rent regulation. It's time for Rudy to come out and tell New Yorkers where he stands on this issue. I challenge him to a debate immediately on rent regulation and rent protection for New Yorkers."
Mr. Giuliani supports the continuation of rent regulations and has called in the past for control of the system to be given to New York City. Ms. Messinger has refused to say what changes she wants in the system, other than having it extended for two years and studied further.
At the same time, Ms. Messinger, in her position as Manhattan Borough President, began airing radio advertising yesterday promoting the rent regulation proposal. Her aides said she would broadcast 54 such as advertisements, at a cost of $10,560, paid for out of her Manhattan Borough President budget.
Beyond that, Ms. Messinger offered other themes that she planned to develop during the campaign. She charged that Mr. Giuliani had imposed 'devastating" budget cuts on city schools. She also said that the number of police officers on the beat was declining.
By any measure, this was the most significant day in Ms. Messinger's political life, though there was not much public indication of that. After her news conference, Ms. Messinger walked back to her office. In one indication of the political hurdles Ms. Messinger faces in the months ahead, she was barely recognized as she made her way up the street through the lunch-time crowd.
She spent most of her day calling fund-raisers and political leaders, trying to nail down support. She ended her day in what was for her a routine stop at a dedication of an exhibit at Temple Emanu-el on Fifth Avenue. And her advisers argued that Mr. Ferrer's exit would ultimately prove liberating to Ms. Messinger, who has seemed stifled on the campaign trail so far.
"Ruth will have a bigger soapbox to say a lot of things we held in abeyance," an adviser said. "This race is now between Ruth and Rudy. That is just a fact. That's just the way it is."

HEADLINE: CONSUMER'S WORLD: THE ENERGY-EFFICIENT HOME LAUNDRY;
Washday's Frontier: The Front-Loaders

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr.

 BODY:
SO you need to do the laundry, and while you're at it you wouldn't mind cleaning up the planet, too. Would it be worth spending close to $1,000 on an energy-efficient washing machine to help do your part of the global chore?
Many people, without a second thought, would reckon not. But environmental experts say that such washers are a sound investment, both on ecological grounds and in terms of household economics. 
 For years, the Federal Government has been requiring manufacturers to produce more efficient appliances. In April, for example, it required that all refrigerators made after 2001 use 30 percent less energy.
But sometimes, the appliance makers move faster than the regulators. Such is the case with washing machines: more efficient models are entering the market before the Government imposes new standards.
The new machines are radically different from what American consumers are used to. Like big machines in laundries -- and like models popular in Europe -- they load from the front and tumble clothes in a horizontal drum. In top-loaders, all the clothes sit in a large tub of water and are swirled around by an agitator. In front-loaders, also known in the trade as horizontal-axis washers, the tumbling provides the agitation.
Doing away with the back-and-forth agitation saves wear and tear on clothes. Because not all of the clothes need to be in the water at the same time, front-loaders use a third less water, saving a third of any energy needed to heat the water. In the spin cycle, the extra force of gravity helps the clothes to dry more quickly, saving still more energy if a clothes dryer is then used. And front loaders also take a lot less soap, for financial and environmental savings.
This summer, Maytag plans to introduce a front-loading model, the Neptune, retailing for $999. Last year, Frigidaire started marketing the Gallery, which sells for $799. And several models from Europe, like the Asko 20605, have been sold in the United States for years. All of them cost considerably more than the typical top-loading machines, although the prices of the domestic models are likely to go down as more are sold.
But whether or not consumers are willing to crunch the numbers, the fact is that machines like these pay for themselves over time. It has been proved since efficiency standards were set for air conditioners, refrigerators, freezers and other appliances.
According to tests conducted by the Association of Home Appliance Manufacturers, a trade group, a front-loading washing machine cuts energy and water bills by an average of $100 a year (depending on how much laundry is done and on the costs of local water, sewage and gas or electricity services).
"If you are in a place where water or energy is very expensive, with high electric costs, then obviously the economics are going to come out even more favorably," said Jim McMahon, an energy conservation analyst at the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in Berkeley, Calif., operated by the United States Energy Department.
But will consumers be willing to spend more now to save more in the long run?
"A typical rule of thumb is that things that offer a three-year payback get accepted, and things that do not are rejected," Mr. McMahon said.
That suggests that people might balk at the new machines. A top-of-the-line conventional washer costs roughly $600. So, with a machine costing about $1,000, a typical household would need four years to save the additional $400.
Although the savings involved for any single household might not be much, the savings on a national scale would be enormous.
It is estimated that Federal energy-efficiency standards for appliances, including air conditioners and dishwashers, will save consumers upward of $200 billion over the next three or four decades. The adoption of these technologies has already reduced the nation's demand for electricity by a few percentage points. And the energy savings available from new, efficient appliances will cut 400 million tons of greenhouse gas emissions, equal to the pollution from 16 million cars, according to the Livermore lab.
It vexes policy makers that Americans generally disdain capital investments that offer what economists consider a very attractive rate of return. Spending $1,000 for a washing machine that spins off savings of $100 a year is almost like buying a long-term bond that pays 10 percent, tax free and practically risk free. (There are some obvious differences: the machine eventually wears out, and the bond is easier to sell.)
But whatever the economics, few people replace major household appliances until they break, and even then most consumers opt for lower-price machines over those that cost the least to operate. So, advocates of efficiency are always looking for ways to entice consumers.
Many electric companies are willing to subsidize efficient appliances, since they postpone the need to build ever more costly generating plants.
The Consortium for Energy Efficiency, a Boston-based coalition of conservation groups, government agencies and electric utility companies across the nation, is promoting high-efficiency washers by enlisting utility companies in a program to encourage consumers to buy them. So far, utilities serving one-sixth of the households in the country are participating or have promised to do so, often offering cash subsidies for the purchases.
No such programs are in place in the New York metropolitan area. But in California, Pacific Gas and Electric and some water utilities are offering rebates of as much as $250 to customers who buy efficient washers before Oct. 31.
Appliance makers are counting on such deals to give their new products a foothold. But manufacturers also say they are not counting on environmentalism or frugality alone as their marketing pitch.
"If I am after the mass market, and I am, I'm not looking for a niche product that only people who are concerned about the environment will buy," said William L. Beer, the vice president for strategic marketing at Maytag. "Just based on energy savings alone, this product will pay for itself. But that may not be compelling enough. It has to be more than just saving money."
So, while Maytag set about to build a front-loading washer mainly as a way of anticipating Federal conservation requirements, the company gave its new machine the largest capacity of any household washer on the market, top- or front-loading. Because the machine is not yet in stores, independent tests by consumer groups have not been conducted.
When the suds clear, will a greener, cleaner nation emerge?
That may depend on whether consumers think of appliances as capital investments intended not only to perform chores, but also to generate financial and environmental returns. It also may depend on customers' being convinced that front-loading machines do a better job -- and on manufacturers' bringing the prices down.

LENGTH: 1241 words

HEADLINE: Pied Piper of the Second-Floor World

BYLINE: By BARBARA FLANAGAN

DATELINE: EASTON, Pa.

 BODY:
MATTHEW HOEY is lugging his furniture down his apartment stairs, across the sidewalk, into his truck and heading east, 80 miles, to New York City.
Neighbors guess that the rising young furniture designer is finally moving out, up to the Big Town, to make his mark, chase his dream, swim in the big pond and melt his little-town blues. 
 Isn't it time? Against the backdrop of Easton's neglected grandeur and endearingly quaint proportions, a 6-foot-6 architect with Fabio hair and dark suits (both rumpled) might feel a bit confined.
But this dramatic exit is not what it seems. Mr. Hoey, 34, is simply driving his design collection -- the C.L.C., the M.P.C. and the A.A.S. -- to the I.C.F.F.
That is, he's exhibiting the Corian Lounge Chair, the Molded Plywood Chair and the Aluminum Adjustable Stool at the International Contemporary Furniture Fair at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center from May 17 through May 20. After the fair, Mr. Hoey says he will come back to live in Easton forevermore.
Every town needs a Matthew Hoey. A modern furniture designer who likes to explore new processes, he has not only designed a way to live without Manhattan, but also figured out new ways to help in historic Easton's renaissance and to share it with the cooped-up Manhattan editors and manufacturers who travel west to meet with him.
"He's really a pioneer of design development who's also an urban pioneer," said Susan Szenasy, editor of Metropolis magazine.
While producing furniture for limited-edition runs and large-scale manufacturing, Mr. Hoey also sells his design services to large companies and teaches industrial design to Lehigh University students who help him develop his work. It's a role, or a number of roles, that designers seldom craft for themselves.
He has transformed the ramshackle second floor of an elegant 1850's town house near Centre Square into his one-man headquarters, a sleek private apartment linked to a workshop and showroom.
"This is where I want to be," said Mr. Hoey, who was born in Camden, N.J., raised in Medford, N.J., and trained in Philadelphia before apprenticing with an Easton architect.
He is credited with being among the first to reclaim what he calls "this whole second-floor world." Where families once lived above their stores, there is a vast amount of empty space sitting right above the street-level shops of many American towns. In Easton, a city sapped by regional malls and then slighted by absentee landlords, the vacancies have looked especially forlorn.
The second-floor world Mr. Hoey extolls is not just square footage. The low cost of his space (less than $1,000 a month for 1,600 square feet) freed him to work more experimentally. As a part of a growing artists' community within a reawakening city (population 26,275) set at the confluence of two rolling rivers -- the Delaware and the Lehigh -- Mr. Hoey seems to feel a responsibility to keep up the momentum.
"I really feel like I'm setting an example by doing what I'm doing here," he said.
One client, Tom Samples, a market development manager at Dupont in Wilmington, Del., was impressed. "For Matthew, I think Easton is sort of a project in and of itself," he said. "He likes to do things that haven't been done before, and I think Easton is inspirational for him."
Initially, Mr. Hoey approached Dupont wanting to make curvaceous furniture out of Corian, its famously flat countertop material that is a nougat of minerals and acrylic. "We never dreamed you could make a chair from this material," Mr. Samples admitted.
Working with Dupont's technology center, Mr. Hoey had Corian mixed in candy colors and baked into shapes that seem to melt over the loopy frame of his surprisingly comfortable, all-weather, slightly bouncy Corian Lounge Chair. The charismatic piece was published in "The Sourcebook for Modern Furniture" (W. W. Norton, 1997), a reference full of 20th-century classics.
Many designers would stop there and wait for some big furniture corporation -- a Knoll or a Herman Miller -- to buy their intellectual property with a big lump sum or with royalty payments. Mr. Hoey is fixing to manufacture his own patented designs himself to retain as much quality control as possible, from the frame bending to the shipping.
Others might envy his economy of means. Rather than start a big company staffed with employees, Mr. Hoey creates a "virtual organization" to produce each design, employing independent subcontractors in Pennsylvania.
Collaborating with professors and undergraduates in the Integrated Product Development program at Lehigh, where industrial designs for the likes of Exxon and Chrysler are developed and tested, Mr. Hoey won a $70,000 state grant to figure out how to manufacture the Corian Lounge Chair. This summer, Mr. Hoey will produce a limited-edition series (at $1,360 a piece) while he talks to companies about ways of commercializing that design, and others, for a wider audience.
In the Tomato Project, Mr. Hoey and Lehigh students will explore his patented idea of using breast implant technology to make a line of what he calls "liquid furniture" by ganging together "little fluid pods."
"The idea is to find new uses for a material on which billions of dollars have already been spent," he explained, gently lifting a scale model of a chaise lounge. "And give it a more honorable function."
His workshop, according to the city's Mayor, Thomas Goldsmith, has done a "magnificent job" of spurring others to turn some of the town's abandoned assets -- its stately buildings -- into "relatively cheap live-work space." Mr. Hoey's landlord, who commissioned the renovation of the second floor ("as an original Hoey"), has a craft store on the ground floor. Around the corner, two architects, Oliver Andes and Jeffrey Gilbert, Manhattan transplants, opened the Archive Shop, a design store, in another landmark building. The ground-floor store sells Mr. Hoey's furniture.
In early May, Ms. Szenasy day-tripped out of New York with the furniture fair's organizers to see the very modern chairs he had just invented. The chairs were posed against the backdrop of the old architecture that's newly revamped, which is, in turn, surrounded by the old town that's being discovered.
Typically, Mr. Hoey leads his visitors on a working walking tour that starts in his studio, moves down the main street to one of Easton's vintage coffee shops and skirts the new Crayola Factory visitors' center. Occasionally, the group detours through a downtown artist's loft -- there's a new one every week or two -- so that Mr. Hoey can show the synchronism of his neighborhood.
"He's found a more humane way of conducting faraway relationships, and that allows him to reach out to his own community in a more relaxed way," Ms. Szenasy said. "He's showing how this new life style can actually work."
Perhaps there's a whole new design frontier out there in the small places lost between the big cities, where a new generation of entrepreneurial loners can repopulate the second-floor world that Mr. Hoey inhabits so gracefully.
Thinking about that new frontier and all its potential, Mr. Hoey shook his head and said, "It's untapped."
Matthew Hoey is to speak to the design trade on May 19 at 11 A.M. at the International Contemporary Furniture Fair at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. The public can see his work on May 20. Admission, $20; (212) 879-5776.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Again Falls vs. Yen, Losing 8.1% in Two Weeks

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar slid to another four-month low against the yen yesterday and fell against most other leading currencies after inflation data raised doubts that the Federal Reserve would lift interest rates next week.
The dollar's decline against the yen accelerated yesterday after a report showing an unexpected drop in United States producer prices. The report diminished hopes among some traders that the Fed would again raise interest rates next week. 
 "A lot of people don't think the Fed is going to tighten anymore," said Doug Horlick, a currency trader at ABN-Amro Bank in Chicago.
In New York, the dollar settled at 117.20 yen, down from 118.50 yen Tuesday and the lowest level since Jan. 17. The latest decline left the dollar barely 1 percent higher than its 1996 close of 115.93 yen. It was the eighth consecutive day that the dollar fell against the yen and left the dollar 8.1 percent below its four-and-a-half-year intraday high of 127.47 yen set only two weeks ago.
The dollar was quoted at 1.6944 marks in New York, down from 1.6959 marks on Tuesday and off 2.5 percent from its 38-month high of 1.7386 marks set May 5.
"With the dollar not doing well against the yen, that's certainly dragging it down against other currencies," said Lee Kassler of the Israel Discount Bank in New York. "The market's appetite for dollars has waned."
The British pound rallied to $1.6466, from $1.6329, partly on expectations that interest rates in Britain would rise further. The newly independent Bank of England, which raised rates last week, warned on Tuesday in its quarterly inflation report that rates would need to increase again in coming months to suppress inflationary pressure.
The mark strengthened against the dollar after Klaus-Dieter Kuhbacher, a member of the Bundesbank's policy-making council, said the German Government would likely confront a 20-billion-mark shortfall in 1997 tax revenue. His comments, coming one day before the German Government reports its 1997 tax revenue estimates, suggested that Germany would face new difficulties keeping its 1997 budget deficit below the 3 percent of gross domestic product required for participation in the single-currency plan.

HEADLINE: Better Act Now to Prevent Another Balkan War

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Notes From the Underground on Another Balkan Rift" (news article, May 11) rightly signals the danger of another war in the Balkans. A year ago, a delegation of the Council on Foreign Relations' Center for Preventive Action found that Albanians in Kosovo were losing patience with nonviolent resistance to Serbian rule. 
 With Albania on the verge of disintegration and Macedonia still vulnerable to economic crisis and ethnic Albanian unrest, peace and security in the South Balkans remains at risk. United Nations-mandated European troops led by Italy in Albania, along with United States and United Nations peacekeepers in Macedonia, are helping to stabilize the region. But these deployments are not backed up with the high-level political initiative needed to settle regional problems.
While Serbs and Albanians are not ready to agree on the final status of Kosovo, there are signs of willingness to talk. The United States and Europe must insist that the Belgrade Government end repression and enter unconditional negotiations with the nonviolent Albanian leadership. We must also persuade the people of Kosovo that they cannot press nationalist demands without considering the consequences for their neighbors.
Kosovo has not received the high-level attention it requires. It is time for both Europe and the United States to show they are serious by convening a high-level conference on the danger of war in the South Balkans.
 
BARNETT R. RUBIN
New York, May 14, 1997
 
The writer is director of the Center for Preventive Action, Council on Foreign Relations.

HEADLINE: Crossroads For France

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

DATELINE: PARIS, May 14

 BODY:
When the Gaullist president of the National Assembly, a man previously known for his caustic views on American capitalism, enters the electoral fray by praising the way a free-market economy "rewards those who dare, those who take risks," it seems safe to say that something is stirring in France.
When the president of the French Senate, and a man with the ear of President Jacques Chirac, suggests that it is time to abolish the minimum wage and move faster on market reforms to "insert France in a world on the move," it even appears that real change may be at hand. 
 At the very least, these recent statements by Philippe Seguin and Rene Monory suggest that the central issue in a lackluster campaign for French parliamentary elections is now being set out more clearly: How much of the market-driven American and British models of economic growth does a depressed France want to adopt?
The right, long torn between economic liberty and Gaullist fraternity, has finally opted for the former, praising -- with a growing if still prudent openness -- the merits of privatizations, reduced taxation, a shareholding culture and deregulation. These changes would probably ease France's planned adoption of a single European currency. But because such ideas smack of what the French pejoratively call "Anglo-Saxon" economic models, their overt adoption has been a painful and wrenching process.
On the other side, Lionel Jospin's Socialist Party, unready for a Blair-like embrace of the market, has opted for a defense of the state's central role in the economy and attacks on those favoring "the path of harsh capitalism."
Such a debate may seem outdated. But in many ways France is.
It has not been through the Reaganite or Thatcherite reforms that, in the wake of economic change, moved President Clinton's Democrats and Tony Blair's Labor Party toward the center. Nor, like the Netherlands and even Italy, has it put pragmatic reform of the welfare state before paralyzing ideological clashes. Its economy has sagged and unemployment risen steadily to 12.8 percent of the population.
"The French people see increasingly that they are faced by choice between a right-wing government they do not like, and a Socialist opposition whose program they simply do not believe in," said Alain Touraine, a political scientist. "How can the Socialists support a free-market Europe and defend a bloated state at home? It is this that explains that a government whose popularity rating has hovered around 30 percent seems set to win rather than suffer a landslide defeat to the Left."
The Socialist Party program calls for a reduction of the working week to 35 hours from 39 without any loss of salary, and the creation of 350,000 new jobs in the state sector. It equates the pressures of the global economy with a return to the cruelty of 19th-century capitalism. "When people are fired, the stock market rises: that is the logic of this capitalism," it says.
The position is clear enough. Yet, since President Chirac abruptly announced the dissolution of Parliament three weeks ago and set the two-round election for May 25 and June 2, the point of the vote has tended to remain obscure. Having spoken of critical choices to justify calling the election one year early, the President and his Prime Minister, Alain Juppe, veered toward language so guarded that the choices seemed deliberately obscured.
Mr. Chirac's references to private initiative were invariably balanced by calls for solidarity. Allusions to Europe and the planned introduction of a common currency, the euro, in 1999, were dropped, apparently out of concern that the euro had become synonymous with fiscal austerity and reform of the state.
Only this week has such guardedness started to fall away. Mr. Monory's statement was, in French terms, extraordinary. "I do not believe in the minimum wage in France," he said. "What is better? I am going to shock you, but is it better to have one million unemployed young people or pay someone 4,500 francs a month instead of 6,000 Francs?" The current gross minimum wage is 6,406 francs, or $1,133 a month.
Mr. Seguin, never previously known as a free marketeer, followed up by declaring that, "If we have chosen a free-market system, it is because we believe that it is the economic system that best guarantees innovation and creativity." In so doing, he used the word liberalisme, considered taboo by wide swaths of Mr. Chirac's Gaullist party.
The electoral debate remains curiously muted. Over half of French people say the election leaves them indifferent and their hesitations make the result unpredictable. But Mr. Chirac seems to be moving toward the conclusion that the right can say what it believes and still win.

HEADLINE: Producer Prices Fall A Sharp 0.6%

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
In an inflation report better than the most optimistic predictions, prices paid to American manufacturers and other producers fell six-tenths of l percent in April, the biggest monthly drop in nearly four years, Government figures showed today.
"It was, almost across the board, fabulous news," said Noralyn Marshall, an economist with Scotia Capital Markets in New York. "There is no serious visible inflation currently or in the pipeline." 
 The decline in the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods, which pulled inflation at the producer level down to less than 1 percent over the last year, touched off early rallies in the bond and stock markets. Analysts had been expecting no change in the index.
Investors were heartened by the report because it suggested that inflation continued to be contained and that as a result Federal Reserve policy makers would have little reason to raise short-term interest rates when they meet on Tuesday. But stock and bond prices later retreated to end little changed on the day.
While analysts said today that Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, would now have a harder time defending a rate increase, few said that either today's inflation numbers or those contained in Thursday's report on consumer prices would be decisive.
"We're in a different environment" with the unemployment rate below 5 percent and the economy apparently still running faster than its sustainable long-term trend, said Nicholas S. Perna, an economist with Fleet Financial Group in Hartford. He put the odds that the Fed would raise rates next week for the second time this year at still "close to even money."
Evelina M. Tainer, chief economist at Indosuez Carr Futures in Chicago, noted that that the lagging nature of inflation data made today's report a poor guide to policy moves by the Fed, which looks ahead for bottlenecks and other pressures that are inflation's source.
But she said Fed officials had "time on their side" to wait for the economy to cool and were somewhat more likely than not to avoid raising rates on Tuesday. The central bank in March pushed short-term rates up a quarter of a percentage point, the first increase in two years, as insurance against overrapid economic growth generating faster inflation.
A separate economic report today indicated that the economy had begun to slow from its strong pace earlier in the year, bolstering the case for the Fed to leave interest rates unchanged.
The Commerce Department reported that business sales slumped three-tenths of 1 percent in March, while inventories rose three-tenths of 1 percent. The drop in business sales, the first this year, could portend a significant slowdown in the economy if shelves begin to bulge and cause store managers to reduce orders for fresh production, analyst said.
The report on producer prices was impressive not just in the magnitude of the fourth consecutive decline in the price of finished goods -- those ready for sale to the final business or individual user -- but in the fact that goods at earlier stages of production eased in price as well.
Such intermediate items as bolts of cloth fell three-tenths of 1 percent while crude goods, like raw cotton, declined nine-tenths of 1 percent. Both measures of price pressure in the product pipeline have now fallen three consecutive months.
"There is no evidence of industrial sector price pressures," commented James F. O'Sullivan, economist at Morgan Guaranty Trust. "The main threat continues to be labor costs, especially with the unemployment rate now a half-point lower than the 1996 average."
On Thursday, analysts will be closely watching the Labor Department's report on weekly first-time claims for unemployment insurance as well as the Consumer Price Index, which, unlike the producer index, includes services.
Although skidding energy prices once again accounted for much of the drop in April's producer prices, the core rate, which excludes the volatile energy and food sectors, was also surprisingly well behaved. It eased one-tenth of 1 percent for the third time this year, the only increase being a temporarily unnerving four-tenths of 1 percent March spurt.
The core rate benefited particularly from lower prices for computers, aircraft, automobiles, women's apparel and prescription that more than offset increases for tobacco, periodicals and other items.
Food prices, which jumped nine-tenths of 1 percent at the finished level in March, dropped four-tenths of 1 percent, the Labor Department's report also showed. Fresh and dry vegetables dived 20.4 percent, following a 13.3 percent surge, while the price of pork jumped 5.6 percent to more than reverse a March decline.
In widely watched sectors or intermediate goods, prices of nondurables used in manufacturing, such as wood pulp, declined two-tenths of 1 percent, while durables such as copper and brass mill shapes edged down one-tenth of 1 percent.
Among crude goods, natural gas dropped an additional 13.3 percent in April to contribute heavily to a 5.2 percent overall decline for raw energy materials.

HEADLINE: Dow Rises by 11.95 as Early Gains Wane

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Stocks barreled toward new highs yesterday but ended only barely stronger as some pleasing inflation data failed to convince investors that the Federal Reserve would not raise interest rates next week.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose by as much as 77 points in the first hour of trading, but finished with a gain of just 11.95 at 7,286.16, about 7 points shy of Monday's record high. It was the second consecutive day that the Dow broke past 7,300 only to retreat below that mark by the close. 
 Broad market measures also faltered after an early jump with the bond market, although the New York Stock Exchange composite index managed to hold just enough of a gain to close at a new high.
With the Federal Reserve's next policy-making meeting less than a week away and the stock market suddenly trading near record levels again, it was not surprising to see the rally fade so easily, analysts said.
Much of the enthusiasm behind the market's speedy recovery has hinged on expectations the Fed would not increase short-term interest rates again in its crusade against inflation.
"It's kind of do or die now; we just made record highs, and there's no way of knowing exactly what's on the Fed's mind," said Rick Jandrain, chief investment officer for equity securities at Banc One Investment Advisors in Columbus, Ohio.
Bonds rallied yesterday morning after the Labor Department reported that wholesale prices paid to farms, factories and other producers fell a surprising six-tenths of 1 percent in April, the largest drop in nearly four years and the fourth consecutive decline.
The inflation data buoyed the recent optimism that inflation is not enough of a threat to merit another rate increase by Federal Reserve policy makers, who are scheduled to meet again on Tuesday. The Fed -- concerned that heavy market demand would aggravate inflationary pressures such as rising wages -- moved to slow things down in late March by raising a key short-term rate known as the Federal funds rate from 5.25 percent to 5.50 percent.
Until about a month ago, investors were fearful the Fed would muzzle consumer spending and company profits with a series of further Fed funds rate increases. Recent signs of moderation in the economy have eased those worries, spurring a sharp rebound in the markets.
Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by nearly a 3-to-2 margin on the Big Board, where volume totaled about 505 million shares, up from Tuesday's pace.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock list rose 2.92 to 836.05, about 1 1/2 points below Monday's record. The New York Stock Exchange composite rose 1.63, to 435.60, barely topping Monday's all-time high of 435.57.
The Nasdaq composite index rose 1.96, to 1,335.55, as technology issues struggled despite an encouraging earnings report from Applied Materials, the leading manufacturer of chip-making equipment. Applied Materials rose 3 27/64 to 63 55/64.
Intel, meanwhile, started the day with another steep slide amid news of another lawsuit charging patent infringement in the design of its Pentium microprocessors. But the stock, which in the morning nearly duplicated Tuesday's 6 3/4-point loss, rebounded in the afternoon, rising 1/2, to 152 7/8.
The American Stock Exchange composite index rose 2.37, to 581.97.
The Dow's biggest gainers were J. P. Morgan, up 2 1/2 to 104 1/2, and Du Pont, up 2 1/8 to 110 1/4. The weakest Dow issue was Procter & Gamble, down 2 1/8, to 130 3/8.
