HEADLINE: Demigods in Pinstripes

BYLINE: By James Grant; James Grant, editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer, is the author of "The Trouble With Prosperity: The Loss of Fear, the Rise of Speculation and the Risk to American Savings."

 BODY:
Next week, when a Federal Reserve Board committee meets behind closed doors to discuss interest rates, the press will be expectantly crouched by the keyhole. Is there another governmental planning body, in this country or the former Soviet Union or points in between, whose deliberations inspire even a small charge of electricity, let alone reverence?
The veneration of central banks is the idolatry of the 1990's. Enjoying ultra-low unemployment in the United States, Americans worship and fall down. Yet -- strange to tell -- Germans seem to think no less of their own central bank despite record-high unemployment in Germany. It strains belief that the Fed could, by imposing a single interest rate on an increasingly deregulated financial system, cause a $7.9 trillion economy to move obediently in the desired direction -- or keep an $8 trillion stock market from falling out of the sky. 
 The most trenchant technical criticism of central economic planning was that the planners couldn't know enough to see into the future. The same holds with equal force about central banking.
Yet in this heyday of free markets, central bankers and the currencies they manage have never been more trusted. The stupendous bull market, the apparently endless economic expansion and the historically moderate inflation rate are things of wonder. Well, somebody must have caused them. Somebody, certainly, would be blamed if they went up in smoke. These days, praise or blame seems to fall on one head more than any other, that of the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan.
And so it goes around the world. There is a global bull market in the institution of money management. An "independent" monetary authority has become the intercontinental ideal. Independence, in this context, means liberation not only from gold bullion, which used to anchor the dollar, but also from politics. Even the politicians are prepared to believe that central bankers know best (or, at the least, that it would be inexpedient to suggest that they don't). Certainly, there are enough central banks: 171 in all, not forgetting those of Tonga, Sao Tome and Principe and the Solomon Islands.
When, in its fourth day of existence, Britain's Labor Government conferred on the Bank of England a new measure of autonomy in setting British interest rates, it cast its lot with governments around the world. Central banks, the Laborites implied, should be above petty politics. Drinking in the news, the London financial markets surged.
Likewise, the Japanese Government is moving to confer a measure of independence on the Bank of Japan. And the nations of a possible European Monetary Union are said to envision a future European central bank along the lines of the fiercely independent German Bundesbank.
There is just one thing wrong with this monolithic consensus about the omniscience and omnipotence of central banks: It is almost certainly wrong.
The only certainty about 20th-century monetary arrangements is their changeableness. No monetary system has lasted much longer than a quarter century. The classical gold standard died in World War I. Its successor, the road-show gold standard (the so-called gold exchange standard), sputtered out during the Great Depression. A still more free-form gold standard, Bretton Woods, came a cropper in the inflation of the early 1970's. The current pure paper standard -- in the Fed's case, a system based on the manipulation of a single interest rate, the Federal funds rate -- can therefore be considered almost long in the tooth.
Yet it, too, seemed to have no future at all on Aug. 6, 1979, the day Paul Volcker took over the apparently thankless job of leading the Fed. Inflation was then shortening the shelf life of money the world over. By the fall of 1981, long-term United States bonds had to yield 15 percent to find any buyers.
Then, a miracle: the high interest rates set by the Fed brought inflation down. What is largely ignored, however, is that the high rates did not bring about an actual fall in prices. Historically, rising prices had generally been followed by falling ones. In the 1980's, there was no deflation, but rather "disinflation," merely a slower rate of price increases.
The Volcker Fed inherited an inflationary mess, but by 1987, when Mr. Greenspan took over, it bequeathed one of another sort: asset inflation, caused in part by a series of Fed-engineered interest rate deductions in 1986. Mr. Greenspan was faced with a case of overblown prices in the stock market (and in the real estate and art markets) rather than at the checkout counter.
The excesses, which cropped up globally, were most vividly on display in Japan. Falling interest rates and a depreciating dollar (the latter helpfully engineered by the Reagan Administration) contributed to one of the zaniest and ultimately most destructive speculative episodes in history. Japan, its banks devastated by bad loans, is still trying to recover.
So is the world. In the 1990's, a kind of deflationary undertow tugs at many countries' economies almost eight years after the Japanese crackup. Central banks, complicit in the asset inflation of the 1980's, are now the not wholly deserving beneficiaries of the disinflation of the 1990's.
To be sure, consumer price inflation is setting new low readings almost everywhere. Before giving unconditional thanks for this blessing, however, we might pause to reflect on its probable future costs. In central banking, as in so many other human endeavors, underdoing it leads to overdoing it, and vice versa. In Germany, Japan and Switzerland, central banks have pushed interest rates down to record, or near-record, postwar lows. It is telling that these heroic measures -- modeled in part on the Fed's efforts -- have so far failed to revive their moribund economies.
What central banks can do is to manipulate domestic interest rates. What they can't do is what American entrepreneurs have so often successfully done: create jobs, build software companies, rehabilitate office buildings that should never have been built in the first place.
The suppression of interest rates, of course, can be highly inflationary -- both for the prices of financial assets and the reputations of central bankers. "Remember the glut of Japanese bank money that swept the world in the 1980's and led to the staggering bad loan problem that now hobbles the nation's banks?" The Wall Street Journal asked the other day. "Well, the Japanese banks are at it again -- this time in Asia." Despite clear signs of a new lending riot, there is no shortage of economists who are prepared to reassure us that the business cycle is dead.
Anything is possible, of course. It seems to me, however, that the new idolatry has already changed the behavior of individuals and corporations in ways that will contribute to the next downturn.
Believing devoutly in central banks, investors have assumed more risk than they would have taken in a more suspicious frame of mind. Seizing on their ability to borrow at low rates, corporations have overspent on capital projects ranging from automobile plants to semiconductor factories. Trusting implicitly in paper money, bankers and bondholders have apparently failed to draw any alarming, or even cautionary, conclusions from the recent plunge in the dollar exchange rate.
Only a Puritan could quarrel with easy credit, sky-high stocks and vintage champagne. But there should be no mistaking these time-honored symptoms of lax monetary policy with the permanent genius of central bankers.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Such a Deal: A Security That Thrilled Short-Sellers

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
Why would a company issue a security that was virtually certain to drive down the price of its stock?
That is the question for Response USA, a small home security company based in Lawrenceville, N.J., and traded on the Nasdaq small-capitalization market. Last summer, the company issued a very unusual preferred security that seemed almost certain to push the price of the stock lower. And it did. 
 Needing capital to buy other home security businesses, Response USA found a bank willing to lend $15 million if Response could raise $7.5 million by selling equity securities.
The obvious way to do that would have been to sell common stock, or perhaps preferred stock that paid a fixed interest rate. But Response, advised by Zanett Capital, instead raised the $7.5 million by selling a very unusual type of convertible preferred stock.
The preferred securities were convertible into common stock within three months, at a price for each common share of $5 or less. The price was to be 80 percent of the market price of the common in the three days before the preferred shares were submitted for conversion. In other words, the lower the stock price, the more shares the preferred holder received. There was no floor to the conversion price.
At the time the issue was sold, on July 2, Response common was trading for about $9 a share. At a conversion rate of $5 a share, preferred buyers were getting a huge bargain. The obvious way to lock in those profits was to borrow Response common stock and sell it short, planning to repay the borrowed shares with stock the investor would get from the conversion.
At worst, the preferred owners would then lock in as profit the difference between the $5 conversion price and the price at which they sold the stock short. Assuming the short position could be put in at, say, $7 a share, that would reap a profit of $2 a share, or 40 percent, for a three-month investment.
At $5 a share, the conversion would require the company to issue 1.5 million new shares -- a lot for a company that only had 3.9 million shares outstanding at the time. And if the price of the common went down, that would mean more profits for the short-sellers, and more shares to be issued when the preferred shares were converted.
Predictably -- but evidently unpredicted by Response -- the short position in the stock soon soared. Some holders of the preferred found they could not sell it short, because no shares were available to be borrowed. The price fell to less than $5 within a few weeks. In late September, with the price a bit under $5, the company said it would not allow the shares to be converted, pending talks with the preferred holders about new terms. Those talks bore no agreement, and Response kept refusing to allow the conversion.
A preferred holder, Halifax Fund L.P., filed a lawsuit in Delaware, where Response is incorporated, seeking to force the company to convert the preferred stock. Responding to the suit, the company argued that its management and board had a "fiduciary duty to the corporation and all of its shareholders" to protect the company, and said that duty took precedence over its contract with the preferred shareholders. Response said that its stock price, already less than $2 a share, might fall to less than $1 if it lost, which would result in the loss of its Nasdaq listing.
On Tuesday, the Delaware judge, Vice Chancellor Jack B. Jacobs, ruled that the conversion must be allowed. "There is no fiduciary duty that excuses management causing the corporation to breach its fundamental contractural obligations to its investors," the judge said. "The defendants' argument that they acted under a good-faith belief that they were acting in the best interests of the corporation is not relevant."
David Parker, a partner in the New York law firm of Kleinberg, Kaplan, Wolff & Cohen, which represented Halifax, called the decision "a clear and swift vindication of the rights of convertible security holders."
That decision came Tuesday, but it was not reported by the company until late yesterday, when Response essentially gave up but declared victory while doing so. The company said in a statement that it had reached a settlement with Halifax Fund that will let the fund do what it wanted to do all along -- convert the preferred shares and sell the common it receives.
As for the other holders, Response said it believed that most of them were willing to accept a settlement that would allow the company to redeem the preferred at 135 percent of the purchase price, plus 12 percent interest beginning last Monday. Any shares it does not redeem by Nov. 30 can be converted on what amount to the original terms. The company did not say where it would get the money to redeem the shares, and a company official said it would not comment on that or anything else.
One might expect management to be apologetic for getting into this position, in which it was forced to pay a 35 percent interest rate for money used for less than a year. But that is not the case. "We believe that the sale by the company of the series A preferred stock was a positive and integral part of the continuing endeavor to effectively capitalize our growing business," the company quoted Richard Brooks, its president, as saying.
Response stock rose 25 cents yesterday, to $2.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene: Battered by Its Rivals;
Competition at Every Turn Has Post Office on the Run

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
What snow, rain, heat and gloom of night cannot stay, U.P.S., fax machines and the Internet just might. That is the view of the Postmaster General, Marvin Runyon, who predicted last month that his giant quasi-government enterprise would lose about $1.4 billion next year, setting the stage for an increase of 2 to 3 cents in first-class postage in 1998.
"The Postal Service," he warned Congress, "faces growing competition across all product lines" -- a reality forcing policy makers to take the first hard look at the post office in a quarter-century. 
 Mr. Runyon's answer to the financial pressures of delivering mail six days a week is to expand into ancillary businesses like packing services and electronic-mail "postmarks" that could absorb part of the Postal Service's awesome overhead. "Growth," he said, "is what sustains our network."
But critics of the Postal Service are unconvinced. For one thing, they note, Mr. Runyon's ambitious plans are opposed by private competitors and viewed warily by postal unions. Even if expansion proves politically feasible, the skeptics argue that it is a formula for distracting already hard-pressed managers.
Their proposed alternative: strip the system of the privileges and obligations of its legal monopoly and let it stand or fall as a competitive enterprise. "The U.S. Postal Service embraces almost all the aspects of socialism discredited in Eastern Europe," said George Priest, a professor at the Yale University School of Law.
This radical approach, long dismissed outside conservative ranks, is now taken seriously by the mainstream and even by some of the Postal Service's largest customers. "The current framework is an anachronism," said Gene Del Pollito, president of the Advertising Mail Marketing Association, the trade group representing third-class "junk" mailers.
When the Postal Service was created in 1971 from the husk of the old Post Office, Congress demanded that it act like a private business. But the new enterprise's mandate still gave it powers almost unimaginable in free markets. Those who poach on the Postal Service's monopoly on the delivery of nonurgent letters are subject to criminal sanctions. Private delivery services are even prohibited from using privately owned mail boxes -- a stricture that explains all those sacks of circulars hanging on front door knobs.
By the same token, the scale of postal operations puts the service out of the league of all but a handful of mega-corporations. Last year the Postal Service's 800,000 employees processed 182 billion pieces of mail using 36,000 buildings, 200,000 vehicles and contract space on 15,000 commercial air service flights a day. Revenues exceeded $56 billion, more than the combined gross of Intel, McDonald's and Kodak.
But from a business perspective, this 900-pound gorilla looks more like a beached whale. The huge work force of the Postal Service (average compensation in 1996: $44,613) absorbs four-fifths of its revenues, leaving little room for productivity increases without unpalatable job cuts. It operates thousands of inefficient branches in rural areas, some of which, according to Larry M. Speakes, the former Presidential spokesman who is now a Postal Service senior vice president, absorb $4 for every dollar they generate.
Equally ominous, the Postal Service has been unable to hold its own in markets legally open to competition. While the service pioneered overnight delivery in the 1970's, it has since ceded 96 percent of the market to competitors. And it has hardly done better in package delivery: United Parcel Service's employee-owners now carry 10 times the volume of parcel post.
Paradoxically, the visible problems of the Postal Service in competitive markets are probably less threatening to its long-term viability than the subtler problems of sustaining its absolute monopoly on nonurgent letters. Both first-class and ad mail are running at record volumes, with deliveries reaching 170 billion in 1996. But indirect competition is gnawing away at the foundations.
The volume of third-class mail is relatively sensitive to postal rates: "Advertisers have a growing list of alternative media," Mr. Del Pollito said -- options ranging from newspaper inserts to Web-site sponsorship to infomercials on specialized cable channels.
So while the Postal Service is legally bound to cover its costs on each class of mail, it bends the rules to keep down rates by allocating proportionally less overhead to junk mail. In 1996, third-class mail represented 40 percent of postal volume but carried just 18 percent of what the Government calls "institutional costs." As a result, much of the fixed costs of the system are borne by first-class mail.
That has not proved a problem to date: the decline of first-class mail, as long-distance phone calls (and recently, E-mail) supplanted written personal correspondence, has been offset by the rising volume of business mail. But business mail -- particularly bills and checks -- is suddenly vulnerable to electronic bypass.
Starting in 1999, notes Martin Mayer, the author of "The Bankers," who is now a visiting fellow at the Brookings Institution, the Treasury will be required to make all payments electronically, from Social Security checks to the bills for paper clips. Mr. Mayer predicts the switch will spur a lot of companies to use electronic services for all their bill issuing and payment collection; if so, he predicts that could gobble up one-third of the Postal Service's first-class mail business.
One company already draining such business from the Postal Service is the Checkfree Corporation, based in Norcross, Ga. Checkfree operates computerized bill-paying systems used by 1.5 million people, most of them customers of banks now aggressively promoting electronic transfers, and says that it issues payment on 41 percent of customer transactions by electronic funds transfer -- rather than by mailing a check -- at a cost of 1 to 4 cents a transaction.
Checkfree dropped the other shoe in March, offering a system that allows large billers -- among them, BellSouth, General Public Utilities and the Small Business Administration -- to present bills through Checkfree's Web site rather than by mail. "It's the electronic round trip" -- the capacity to present and pay bills at the Web site -- "that makes this service so valuable," Matthew Lewis, a company spokesman, said.
To extricate the Postal Service from its tightening financial noose, Mr. Runyon is asking Congress for greater pricing flexibility, notably the right to offer volume discounts on third-class mail. The Postal Service is also seeking to sell new products, including an electronic "postmark" to act as proof of delivery of E-mail. And it is expanding into such complementary businesses as packing services and delivery of unaddressed advertising. But this route, too, is circumscribed politically: Representative Duncan Hunter, a Republican from the San Diego area, and 15 colleagues have fired a warning shot, introducing legislation that would bar the Postal Service from competing with some 10,000 private stores (including San Diego-based Mail Boxes Etc.) that already offer ancillary postal services.
Expansion plans are also viewed with suspicion by organized labor, which acknowledges the long-term strains on the current system but fears the consequences of change on their members' bargaining power and job security. "We need to look at our core business and keep doing the very best we can," said Tom Fahey, a spokesman for the American Postal Workers Union, which represents the clerks and mail sorters.
Nor is it clear that plunging a quasi-government agency into the sink-or-swim environment of the free market would succeed. A much-publicized effort to become a force in E-mail never got off the ground in the mid-1980's, and there is little evidence that the organization has the skills to succeed in other new, fiercely contested markets. "The idea that the Postal Service is going to compete effectively with some of the most efficient and technologically sophisticated companies in the world is bizarre," scoffed Jim Rogers, a vice president at U.P.S.
Gregory Sidek, an economist and lawyer at the American Enterprise Institute and co-author of "Protecting Competition from the Postal Monopoly," would not even attempt to shore up the postal monopoly. He would abandon it, along with the system's obligation to provide six-day-a-week delivery to every mailbox at a common postal rate.
Mr. Sidek doubts that the loss of what is widely seen as an entitlement would alter the lives of many customers. The vast majority, he argues, would get equivalent or better service from private companies that would respond to market incentives, much like deregulated long-distance phone carriers. Besides, household-to-household communication -- the "Aunt Minnie mail" that Washington zealously defends -- now represents less than 4 percent of the mail stream.
And if Congress does want to guarantee daily deliveries to remote rural areas, Mr. Sidek says that it could appropriate money for the service, much the way it now subsidizes postage for the blind. Or it could mimic the regulation of phone service, using revenue from a fixed monthly charge on all mailboxes to underwrite uneconomical delivery. "If universal service generates social benefits, society as a whole should foot the bill," Mr. Sidek argued.
Eliminating the legal obligation to universal mail delivery -- what Mr. Speakes of the Postal Service labels "the sacred trust"-- is hardly on the radar screens of mainstream politicians. Indeed, the only changes under consideration would let the Postal Service give volume discounts on junk mail to big mailers in order to take the revenue-generating pressure off first-class mail. A bill to this end sponsored by Representative John M. McHugh, a Republican from Watertown, N.Y., who is chairman of the House postal subcommittee, is bitterly opposed by the postal unions.
Professor Priest of Yale doubts that radical postal changes will be taken seriously until the debate shifts from the question of abandoning an expensive public entitlement to the prospects for innovation. "Privatization is an opportunity," he argued, "not a punishment."
But Robert Poole, president of the libertarian Reason Foundation, said he expects attitudes to change as electronic bypass eat into the Postal Service's first-class mail dominance. "The death of the Postal Service's monopoly cash cows," he predicted, "will transform what now seems a radical idea into an economic necessity."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Growth is what sustains our network," says Postmaster General Marvin Runyon. (Associated Press)
 
Chart/Graph: "Beaten to the Punch"
Continued growth in the mail volume handled by the United States Postal Service belies the agency's deep-seated problems, postal executives and critics agree. Almost every time that the lumbering Postal Service develops an innovation in communications, aggressive private competitors quickly conquer the new business. Some experts warn that the Federal government's move to electronic bill payment in the next few years -- which may prompt the private sector, too, to abandon traditional billing practices -- could be the final comeuppance for the Postal Service as it is now organized.

SECTION: Section A; Page 28; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 375 words

HEADLINE: The Leverage of Federal Research

 BODY:
An exhaustive study for the National Science Foundation has discovered that the novel ideas conceived by American patent holders depend far more on research paid for by government than on research paid for by private industry. The finding belies the glib assertion, heard often in Congress last year, that as private industry expands its research budget, Washington can scale back its research activities. The implication is that proposed cutbacks in Federal research would damage the economy.
Ten years ago, private industry and the Federal Government spent about the same amount on research and development. Today the Government still spends about $60 billion -- much less if corrected for the cost of programs like weapons maintenance that do not add to scientific knowledge. Meanwhile, industry-funded research and development has soared to about $120 million. Yet the Government's relatively small research budget has produced big results. Research funded by government and nonprofit agencies accounts for over 70 percent of the scientific papers cited in the study's sample of recent patent holders. 
 One explanation for the disparity is that government, more often than business, pays for basic research -- benefits from which spread throughout the economy, raising productivity. Industry spends its money on more narrow pursuits, like development of a specific product. Also, government and nonprofit researchers publish their findings early. Some industry research is suppressed to preserve proprietary advantage.
Spending on research and development contributes perhaps half of the growth in American living standards. Each dollar spent on basic research permanently adds 50 cents or more each year to national output -- an impact that is many times larger than the permanent gains from increases in ordinary business investment. This latest study suggests that government and university-based research pack the biggest wallop. Even so, the Administration and Congress are working on budget plans that would cut Federal research by between 14 and 20 percent after accounting for inflation.
President Clinton ran for office in 1992 on an agenda of public investment. It was a good idea then. It is an even better idea now.

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Showdown in Milwaukee

BYLINE: By BRENT STAPLES

 BODY:
In the 1960's, the economist Milton Friedman provoked a furor when he argued that students should be permitted to transfer from failing public schools to successful private schools -- taking public dollars with them. Mr. Friedman predicted that free-market pressure would force the worst schools to close and mediocre ones to shape up. His critics countered that such a system would "skim off" the brightest students, promote white flight and leave inner-city schools black and poor. The proposal went nowhere.
Forty years later, inner-city schools have indeed become largely black and poor -- not through vouchers, but because dismal schools have frightened away both the black and white middle class. The voucher debate has re-emerged, but this time focused on means-tested strategies aimed at the poorest of the poor. Three-fifths of the states have choice programs that allow movement among public schools, with about 10 others considering means-tested plans that would afford poor families an escape hatch from miserable inner-city schools. As Joseph Viteritti wrote recently in The Brookings Review, the impulse has "erupted from a diverse coalition of activists that includes black, whites, and Hispanics; liberals, conservatives, and libertarians; Republicans and Democrats." 
 The battle lines have been drawn in Milwaukee, which has two voucher programs -- one financed primarily by foundations and one put into place by the Wisconsin legislature in 1990. Abysmal schools and an onerous busing program made the city an obvious candidate. With white flight nearly complete, the busing program had scattered inner-city children from one neighborhood to as many as 30 far-flung schools. The busing did little for integration, but afforded handsome subsidies for suburban schools that took children from the inner city. Meanwhile, many inner-city schools were either closed or turned into magnet campuses, with half the seats in some reserved for whites. The desire to educate children well in their home neighborhoods made African-American parents supporters of choice.
Independent calculations show that the average Milwaukee high school graduate leaves with a grade point average of D-plus. African-Americans and American Indians lag far behind whites in achievement. An analysis by Milwaukee's Policy Research Institute asserts that the citywide graduation rate has fallen from 80 percent two decades ago to about 45 percent today. In black central Milwaukee the number gets as low as 20 percent. By contrast, the parochial and private schools graduate more than 80 percent and send twice as many to college -- while spending about half as much per pupil.
The public choice plan was written by State Representative Polly Williams, who is from a poor district in central Milwaukee. An early study found that voucher students did no better academically than those who remained behind. But two better-designed studies -- one from Harvard University, the second from Princeton -- showed that the voucher students improved appreciably in math. The program functioned smoothly for its first seven years, when it included only 1.5 percent of the student body.
A law passed in 1995 expanding the program to 15 percent -- and including parochial schools -- was thrown out by a state court. Among other objections, the court cited the church-state connection. The teachers' union, the American Civil Liberties Union and the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People are all fighting the plan. Of the three, the N.A.A.C.P.'s reasoning is weakest. It defends failing schools on the grounds that vouchers might destroy them.
State legislators seem determined to expand the plan to parochial schools, even if it means appealing to the United States Supreme Court. Timing favors the legislators. The Court has signaled in several recent cases that it wants to weaken church-state barriers in education.
In Milwaukee, the threat of expanded competition has worked precisely as Milton Friedman predicted. A system that once treated parents with contempt has begun to answer their calls and embrace local experiments through a charter school and other partnerships with community groups. A city that once rebuffed requests for public Montessori schools now has them. Said John Gardner of the Milwaukee school board: "A system that has been arrogant and indifferent for 20 years has suddenly got religion."

Midwest Utility Merger Back to Drawing Board
A Federal regulatory agency told two utilities in the upper Midwest, Wisconsin Energy and Northern States Power, that it would withhold approval of their merger agreement as it is now structured, saying that it would give them too much dominance over the electricity market in their regions.
But the regulators said the utilities could draw up a plan to sell some of their generating plants and then resubmit the merger for consideration. [Page D2.] 

ING Ends Talks With Dillon, Read
ING, the Dutch bank, said it had withdrawn from talks to buy the investment bank Dillon, Read. Dillon Read has now begun talking with other parties, including Swiss Bank , people close to the firm said [D2.]
 
Dollar's Slide Against Yen Continues
The dollar slid to a four-month low against the Japanese yen and fell against other currencies, too. The decline accelerated after benign producer price data were released, raising doubts that the Fed would lift interest rates. [D19.]
 
The inflation report was received enthusiastically in the bond market, though price gains were checked somewhat as a big offering of corporate debt by Norfolk Southern siphoned off demand. The yield on the 30-year Treasury fell to 6.88 percent from 6.92. [D22.]
 
The stock market, however, was apparently not quite so sure that the producer price report would end the threat of a rate increase. The Dow, in record territory for much of the day, ended only 11.95 points higher. [D10.]
 
Billion-Dollar Wisconsin Bank Deal
In a combination that will create the third-largest bank in Wisconsin, Associated Banc-Corp agreed to buy First Financial of Stevens Point, Wis., in a $1.05 billion stock swap. [D2.]
 
Philip Morris Reveals Inquiry
Philip Morris said that the F.T.C. was investigating how the company distributes its cigarettes, focusing on whether it restricts the distribution of competing brands. [D5.]
 
Former Nomura Officials Arrested
Tokyo prosecutors arrested three former executives of Nomura Securities on charges of illegally paying money to gangsters. [D4.]
 
China Securities Regulator Ousted
China has replaced its top securities regulator, officials and traders said, prompting speculation that the Government might move further to try to contain the country's surging but volatile stock markets. [D5.]
 
Marvel Bondholders Gain in Court
Bondholders fighting Marvel Entertainment's plan to merge with Toy Biz and emerge from bankruptcy won a round in court. [D2.]
 
Shell Protesters' Effort Rejected
Filing past demonstrators, some wearing devil horns and face paint, shareholders of the British arm of Royal Dutch/Shell rejected a resolution calling for greater attention to environmental and human rights policies. Shell operations in places like Nigeria have been criticized on those grounds. [D4.]
 
Hong Kong and China Ratings Lifted
Standard & Poor's said that it had upgraded its credit ratings for Hong Kong and China, delivering a vote of confidence in the future of the colony as it prepares to be transferred to the Beijing Government's control. [D4.]

HEADLINE: Bill to Redesign Housing Policy Clears Hurdle

BYLINE: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
Challenging decades of housing policy that favored the neediest, the House voted today to change the face of public housing by providing shelter to more of the working poor.
The bill, which passed 293 to 132, would repeal a landmark 1937 Depression-era housing law that Republicans say has turned once livable housing projects into miserable ghettos for the unemployed. It would replace the old framework with a system that made way for higher-income tenants and created what the bill's supporters said would be more self-sufficient communities, requiring less Government aid. 
 The measure, which is opposed by the Clinton Administration as too harsh, could cut roughly in half the percentage of extremely poor tenants living in public housing, now roughly 75 percent, through attrition. It would also retool rent policies so that every tenant's monthly payments would not necessarily rise along with income, a practice criticized as discouraging public housing residents from getting off welfare.
The measure would also require many public housing tenants who are unemployed to perform eight hours of community service a month, or in most cases, risk eviction.
The legislation is another step in Republican efforts to compel more people to get off welfare and join the work force or at the very least, repay the community through volunteer neighborhood work.
"There will be no bill that is signed that will end poverty," said Representative Rick A. Lazio, the New York Republican who sponsored the measure. "The best that we can hope for is that we will begin to set a set of incentives for work, for family, for local control, for responsibility and for accountability."
Only a single Republican, Representative Ron Paul of Texas, opposed the measure, while 71 Democrats supported it.
The Senate is expected to take up its version of the bill later this spring. That legislation does not go as far as the House measure and is closer to a Clinton Administration proposal. Last year, similar bills were passed by both houses but died in a House-Senate conference.
The Housing Act of 1937 was designed to provide shelter on a temporary basis to working-class people who had lost their jobs during the Depression and were forced out of their homes. Sixty years later, housing projects are set aside almost entirely for extremely poor tenants, most of whom receive public assistance. Critics say many of the regulations passed during the last several decades have encouraged tenants to remain unemployed, turning public housing into violent ghettos.
Representative Jim Leach, the Iowa Republican who heads the Banking Committee, which developed the bill, said his party wants to 'break the dependency cycle."
The majority of Democrats who opposed the measure objected to the community service requirement, which Representative Jesse L. Jackson Jr. of Illinois called a form of slavery. But they were most disturbed by provisions that they said would abandon the nation's poorest people, denying them admission to public housing at a time when the housing stock is considerably diminished.
"So we turn our back on the very poor," said Representative Joseph P. Kennedy 2d, Democrat of Massachusetts, whose substitute bill was voted down today, 261 to 163.
"We can allow public housing to go to more working families, but we don't have to do it by abandoning the poor," Mr. Kennedy said in debate on the floor.
Convinced that the New Deal-era housing law had grown cumbersome and out of touch in the last two decades, House Republicans called for the new legislation to incorporate notions of responsibility and accountability. It was time, they argued, to grant local housing authorities the discretion to remedy deep-seated problems of violence and neglect in public housing.
Chief among their proposals in the bill is to allow local housing authorities, which depend primarily on Federal money, to reconfigure the mix of tenants in housing projects. The bill would free housing authorities from rules that give preference in subsidies and apartments almost exclusively to the country's poorest people.
Under the bill, the agencies will be allowed to set aside most units, as they open up, in public housing projects for the working poor -- tenants who hold jobs and earn as much as 80 percent of an area's median income. The bill would not allow them to evict very poor tenants -- who earn 30 percent or less of an area's median income -- to make room for higher-income tenants. The local housing authorities would also be permitted to give the working poor a greater number of subsidized housing vouchers, which give residents a choice of where they want to live.
More than 3,400 local housing authorities own and operate about 13,200 public housing developments, which shelter 1.4 million families. About 2.7 million households receive Federal rent assistance. The bill would cover all such housing.
Just as crucial, Republicans said, the new measure would not link rent levels to income, a rule that both Republicans and Democrats agree discourages tenants from working. Currently, tenants pay rent that is up to 30 percent of their income. The House bill gives residents a choice. They can pay 30 percent of their income or a flat rate set by their local housing authority.
And in keeping with the welfare system's new work policy, tenants who are able-bodied, unemployed and not students or enrolled in a public assistance work program would be required to perform at last eight hours a month of community service. That would affect 450,000 people who get Federal housing subsidies.
In addition, the bill would allow local governments to develop their own low-income housing programs and receive Federal housing money.
Representative James P. Moran, a Democrat from Virginia, said the new bill goes a long way toward revisiting the intent of Roosevelt's 1937 law. "Housing was never supposed to be a permanent entitlement," Mr. Moran said. "The purpose of assisted housing was to help families get on their feet, give them an opportunity to become self-sufficient and then enter the economic and social mainstream of society."

HEADLINE: THE NATO DECISION: THE POLICY;
Road to Approval Is Rocky, And the Gamble Is Perilous

SERIES: EXPANDING ALLIANCE -- The American Push

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
The decision to extend membership in NATO to former Soviet-bloc countries in Central Europe, which Russia explicitly if grudgingly accepted today, is almost certainly the most significant United States foreign policy initiative since the end of the cold war. It represents a redrawing of the world security map as basic as Washington's decision to recognize Communist China.
Yet it was made, early in 1995, in characteristic Clinton Administration style, without a formal policy review, without a structured evaluation of competing viewpoints, without political debate and over the initial objections of senior military officers. 
 With both President Clinton and his Republican rival, former Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, committed to NATO expansion, the subject figured very little in last year's electoral campaign.
And so the key question is only now being posed: will this momentous decision enhance and enlarge the democratic Europe that has been built in the half-century since World War II or will it draw a new scar-like line across the Continent, east of the old iron curtain, and hinder Russia's rapprochement with the West?
Today's agreement vindicates the insistence of the Administration that it could reach an accommodation of sorts with the Russians, which its critics had doubted was possible. But the jury may be out for years on what the accommodation will cost in obliging Moscow to accept an arrangement it clearly detests.
Although the decision to expand NATO was described at the time as a preliminary and tentative one, it has stood without substantial revision and is scheduled for final approval at the alliance's summit meeting in Madrid early in July.
Hungary, Poland and the Czech Republic, which have evolved most rapidly from totalitarianism toward democracy and market economies, are universally expected to be voted in this summer. Slovakia, Slovenia and Romania are still pressing for admission at the same time, but they are more likely to be told to wait.
Then, probably next year, the new arrangement will have to be ratified by the 16 existing members and the new candidates. Turkey has already suggested that it may refuse, but that is taken by the other allies as a bargaining position.

Ratification Is Called 'No Easy Sell' in Senate
Gaining the necessary two-thirds vote in the Senate may not be easy, given widespread skepticism about making new American commitments in an area where the national interest is not clear to many and where the payoff is not evident.
"This is no easy sell," said Senator Richard G. Lugar, the Indiana Republican on whom the Administration is counting to lead the fight for Senate approval.
The public, whose interest in foreign policy has waned since the crumbling of the Berlin wall and of Communist governments almost everywhere, has paid little attention -- even though the expansion of NATO will commit the United States to fight if need be for Prague and Budapest precisely as it is now committed to defending cities like Berlin and Paris.
That obligation is laid out in Article 5 of the North Atlantic Charter, signed in 1949. Early on, it gave pause to leaders in several Western capitals; several years ago, Douglas Hurd, then the British Foreign Secretary, told a group of Americans that he thought any American President or British Prime Minister would be "most reluctant to send their boys to die for Warsaw or Bratislava."
Within the foreign policy community, the debate has been intensifying in recent weeks, but the exchanges have been polite and curiously muted. They make it plain, nonetheless, that many experts consider this a perilous gamble. Even the advocates of expansion see it as a close call; a top Administration official termed it "a very difficult decision, for me and most other people."
Underlying the gamble is the conviction -- publicly voiced by Henry A. Kissinger, unspoken but deeply held by the main shapers of foreign policy here -- that Russia might someday threaten Central and Eastern Europe once again and that now is the moment, when Russia is weak, to extend Western protection to potential targets. Doing so, the Administration says, will have important side benefits as well, including the encouragement of reform in the Eastern European countries and the discouragement of regional disputes.
But many are not convinced.
"Something of the highest importance is at stake here," wrote George F. Kennan, the retired diplomat and Russian scholar, arguing that expansion "would be the most fateful error of American policy in the whole post-cold-war era."
Mr. Kennan asserted that NATO expansion would likely "inflame the nationalistic, anti-Western and militaristic tendencies in Russian opinion; to have an adverse effect on the development of Russian democracy, to restore the atmosphere of the cold war to East-West relations and to impel Russian foreign policy in directions decidedly not to our liking."
Another man who has spent his life studying and writing about Russia, Strobe Talbott, the Deputy Secretary of State, has been one of the main advocates of the new policy. He has argued that Russia has nothing to fear from a bigger NATO, although he readily acknowledges that many Russians have yet to be persuaded that this is the case.
"By expanding NATO but linking Russia to it," he said the other day in an interview, "we are trying to avoid the errors that were made at the end of World War I and the end of World War II: not punitive like Versailles, not permissive like Yalta."

'Catastrophic Effects' Of Closing the Door
Russia'a agreement today to a formal relationship with the new NATO-to-be, a White House official said, "is proof in itself, along with the renewed strength of the reformers in Moscow, that this isn't destabilizing Boris Yeltsin."
American policy makers argue that not expanding NATO would have had, as one senior State Department official put it, "catastrophic effects" in Central and Eastern Europe by implying that countries like Hungary and Poland were consigned permanently to be a buffer zone between Germany and Russia. That status cost them dearly during most of the 20th century.
The policy makers also insist that countries like Slovenia have been prompted by the possibility of NATO membership to accelerate their commitment to democracy (although Slovakia, just as eager for membership, has felt no such incentive). They also argue that countries like Hungary and Romania have begun to put aside their ancient animosity in the hope of winning NATO backing, just as Germany and France were able to abandon their hostility in NATO's early days.
"Just the prospect of NATO enlargement has given Central and Eastern Europe greater stability than it has seen in this century," Secretary of State Madeleine Albright, who is of Czech descent, said recently. "This is the productive paradox at NATO's heart: By extending solemn security guarantees, we actually reduce the chance that our troops will again be called to fight in Europe."
Maybe yes and maybe no, say the critics, including both Republicans and Democrats.
Some, like Mr. Kennan, worry about the Russians. Arms-control experts like Paul H. Nitze and Fred C. Ikle oppose expansion at least in part because they think it highly unlikely that the Russians, faced with a Western alliance even close to their borders, will ratify the Start 2 treaty or show any enthusiasm for further reductions in their still-formidable stockpiles of nuclear weapons.
Others, such as Michael Mandelbaum, an adviser to Mr. Clinton during the 1992 campaign and now a professor at the Johns Hopkins School of Advanced International Studies, see the agreement as a bad bargain from almost every point of view "because we're getting nothing and might lose a lot."
The three countries most likely to be admitted, Professor Mandelbaum argued, need no incentives to move toward democracy and are no threat to the stability of the region. Russia, he said, "is not now a threat, and if it became a threat, the countries that it would threaten are not these three but the Baltic states and Ukraine -- precisely those that NATO is least likely to admit."
Mr. Mandelbaum conceded that "the Russians are too weak to lash back now -- that's not the real problem." But he insisted that relations between Washington and Moscow had already deteriorated on such questions as arms control and the continued independence of former Soviet states with which Moscow is at odds.
Few current members of the Senate have objected publicly to NATO enlargement. But on April 23, Ms. Albright and Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen were subjected to an intense, prolonged barrage of senatorial skepticism from members of the Armed Services Committee.
Senator John Warner of Virginia, a Republican who usually takes a bipartisan approach to foreign policy, said of NATO, "I come from the school that if it's not broken, why try and fix it?" After hearing from him and others, Ms. Albright commented, "There is no question that we have a very difficult job ahead of us" on ratification.

The Accord's Shepherd Fears Overconfidence
Although a special office has been set up to handle the ratification effort, and Ronald Asmus, a Rand Corporation expert, has been recruited as a special adviser, Mr. Lugar said he was concerned that the Administration was overconfident. Winning ratification, he said, would require an effort every bit as intense as that which won ratification of the chemical-weapons treaty at the last moment this month.
No one doubts President Clinton's commitment to expansion, a subject that first moved into his policy plans early in 1993, when he was pressed on the subject by President Vaclav Havel of the Czech Republic and Lech Walesa, then the President of Poland, when they were in Washington for the dedication of the Holocaust Memorial.
That summer, a group of mid-level advisers in the White House and the State Department began pushing for early action on four countries: the three current leaders and Slovakia, which had not long before separated from the Czech Republic. Anthony Lake, then the President's national security adviser, signed on.
But the advocates were unable immediately to win the backing of Warren Christopher, then the Secretary of State, of Mr. Talbott or, crucially, of the top Pentagon brass. Gen. John Shalikashvili, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, became the intellectual godfather of the Partnership for Peace, a loose alliance that for a time constituted an alternative to NATO expansion.
Discarding NATO and setting up a new organization was briefly considered, because that might have seemed less a red flag to the Russians, for whom NATO is a prime symbol of cold war confrontation. That was discarded as too expensive and as a move that might suggest to the European allies that American commitment to Europe was somehow softening.
As is so often the case, Mr. Clinton's mind was concentrated by a forthcoming trip, and without a formal policy review, according to several senior officials, he decided to announce during a European visit in January 1994 that it was no longer a question of "if" but of "when" NATO would expand to the east. The destination of the train had been made clear, but it hadn't left the station yet, one official said later, and there were a lot of potential blockages on the track.
Getting rid of them fell to Richard Holbrooke, who in August 1994 became become Assistant Secretary of State for European affairs. Long talks with Mr. Talbott produced a consensus for action, the generals were brought on board and the work of calming Moscow began. The European allies had their doubts -- one foreign minister complained about "steamroller policy-making that leaves basic questions unanswered" -- but Mr. Holbrooke got them into line, too.

The Price for Europe Of U.S. Involvement
In the end, despite deep misgivings, the Europeans had no choice, a British diplomat said this week. Their highest priority is keeping the United States engaged in Europe, and if the expansion of NATO was the price for that, they had no choice but to pay. Furthermore, it would ease the pressure on them to integrate Eastern and Western Europe by taking the new democracies into the European Union, which would entail major economic sacrifice.
How much of a role domestic politics played is hotly disputed.
One of the main players said flatly, "Not one iota." But another said that in the days after the Republican triumph in the 1994 election, he reminded many in the Administration who were reluctant that NATO expansion was part of the Republicans' Contract with America. Senator Barbara Mikulski, a Polish-American Democrat from Baltimore, reportedly told a State Department official that her parents had turned Franklin D. Roosevelt's portrait to the wall after Yalta and said she did not want to have to do the same thing with Mr. Clinton's picture.
Mr. Clinton managed to travel often to Cleveland, the city with the largest population of Americans of Eastern and Central European origin. He and his aides passed the word before November 1996 that they would not be disappointed.
 
Expanding Alliance
 Later articles will examine other aspects of NATO's expansion in Europe.

HEADLINE: Ghosts of Earlier Day Still Haunt the Fed

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your May 10 Business Day article about the softened Grinch-like qualities of Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, is interesting but beside the point. The Fed chairman is not a Grinch, but the chief of a highly cautious and powerful institution whose actions affect the welfare of every American.
Lately the Fed has been in a quandary because the United States economy has performed in a manner that the Fed's economic data and historical experience say it shouldn't. Growth has been rapid but price inflation tame. Wages and employment have also grown briskly, but so have productivity and corporate profits. 
 The Fed agrees that direct evidence of price inflation is scant but is nonetheless uneasy. It is nagged by the fear that inflationary pressures will somehow build up and ignite sooner or later. The Fed's institutional instincts are pushing it toward a restriction of the economy's present growth rate, which by all indications is still quite healthy.
The Government's economic data are not picking up the effects of rapid technology growth, while the Fed has not recognized that the economy is not nearly as inflation-prone as it once was. The Fed needs to lead the country toward the realization of the nation's full growth potential and be less susceptible to the ghosts of an earlier day.
 
LEON KOROBOW
Great Neck, N.Y., May 11, 1997
 
The writer is a retired assistant vice president and economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

HEADLINE: City Budget Shuns Tricks and Election Ploys

 BODY:

To the Editor:
"Mr. Giuliani's Budget Challenge" (editorial, May 9), on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's 1998 budget submission, declares that it is "using more gimmicks than ever." Nothing could be less true.
The foundation of the budget is fiscally prudent and was developed without fiscal gimmickry. One-time revenue sources represent less than one-tenth of 1 percent of the budget, and not one cent can be found from refinancing of debt. The only asset sale is of a hotel, which a government in a free-market society should not have owned in the first place. 
 While the city's economic performance accelerated significantly in fiscal 1997, resulting in unusually high increases in tax receipts of $1 billion, the 1998 tax revenue forecast contains prudent assumptions based on historic trends. Unlike your editorial, a news article the next day highlighted this fact.
This budget is not, as you say, a typical "election-year budget." Active and disciplined management of the operating budget has allowed the city to finance new needs through reductions in agency spending. This has generated additional surplus revenues that will allow $856 million of fiscal 1998 expenditures to be prepaid this year. Previous mayors in re-election years have used surplus revenues to expand government.
Tax cuts in the budget are not just "crowd-pleasing," as you charge; they are necessary. The tax burden on our private sector is onerous.
Your editorial says the Mayor should look "ruthlessly" for savings in delivery of services. I applaud your Damascus-like conversion: over the last three years, you blasted this administration for "ruthlessly" cutting costs. As you now know, reductions were not "ruthless" but led to enhanced service delivery. Let's hope you do not abandon your new-found principles.
 
JOSEPH J. LHOTA
New York, May 11, 1997
 
Director
Office of Management and Budget

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Interest Rate Concerns Push Dollar Lower Against Yen

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against the Japanese yen yesterday to near the level at which it started the year amid diminished expectations that the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates next week. But it rose slightly against the German mark.
Higher rates would help the dollar by making bank deposits and bonds denominated in it more attractive. The dollar has fallen nearly 10 percent against the yen since reaching a four-and-a-half-year high May 1. 
 The plunge followed three months of warnings that Japanese officials opposed further gains by the dollar. And it came as analysts questioned whether the pace of economic growth in the United States will compel the Fed to increase rates at its policy meeting next Tuesday. The uncertainty has led Japanese investors to unload dollars, traders said.
"We've seen the Japanese selling dollars -- particularly in the options market -- to hedge their dollar investments," Chris Iggo, a currency strategist at Barclays Bank, said.
The dollar fell as low as 115.85 yen in intraday dealings before settling in New York at 116.10 yen, down from 117.20 Wednesday. It was the weakest since Jan. 10 and left the dollar barely above its 115.93-yen level at the end of 1996.
But the dollar cost 1.6988 marks in New York, up from 1.6944.
A German Government warning that tax revenue would fall short of projections lifted the dollar. A revenue shortfall would increase Germany's budget deficit, making the country less attractive to invest in.
Economic reports released yesterday in the United States carried mixed implications for the Fed's interest-rate policy and hence the dollar, traders said.
First, the Labor Department reported that consumer prices, excluding food and energy, rose three-tenths of 1 percent, compared with economists' average forecast of a two-tenths of 1 percent increase. While the gain barely exceeded expectations, and while the overall Consumer Price Index was up only one-tenth of 1 percent, the report buoyed the dollar because it seemed to increase the chances of a rate increase.
The rise was tempered by other, weaker economic figures released a while later, including data on industrial production.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Edge Up Amid Mixed Economic Data

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury prices ended slightly higher yesterday as investors remained divided over whether the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates next week.
Reports showing that consumer prices barely rose in April and that industrial production was flat raised hopes among investors that the economy was slowing enough to forestall a rate increase by the Fed. 
 But a sharp drop in initial weekly unemployment claims and a weak dollar discouraged bond buyers early in the session.
"Today's economic data releases provided support for both sides of the 'Will the Fed tighten on May 20 question?' " said Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 6/32, to 97. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.86 percent, from 6.88 percent on Wednesday.
Market participants were encouraged by a report from the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia showing a decline in manufacturing activity. The Philadelphia bank's index of business activity dropped to 1.6 in May from 5.7 in April.
A slowdown in manufacturing was also indicated by a Federal Reserve report showing that production at factories, mines and utilities was unchanged last month after rising a revised six-tenths of 1 percent in March.
While the bulk of economic evidence points to a slower pace of business activity, there is still much uncertainty about what this means for second-quarter growth in the gross domestic product, Mr. Fine at Chase Asset Management said.
Bond prices were also supported by a report on consumer prices, which like Wednesday's report on producer prices showed little inflationary pressure. The Labor Department's Consumer Price Index rose one-tenth of 1 percent in April, matching expectations.
But the bond market was somewhat unsettled by the core rate of the price index, which excludes food and energy costs. The core rate rose three-tenths of 1 percent -- the biggest gain since September.
Still, Mr. Fine noted, the monthly year-over-year increase in the index continued to decline and now stands at 2.5 percent. He called it "a truly remarkable performance."
One month of softer economic data by itself would not be enough to deter the Fed from throwing water on the fires of exuberance, irrational or otherwise, Mr. Fine said. When coupled with the recent agreement to balance the budget, however, what the Fed does next week will carry a political undertone and will thus be a significantly stronger signal to the market, he added.
"A Fed move to a less accommodative posture on May 20, therefore, is being approached by many market participants as a 50-50 proposition," Mr. Fine said. "However, another Fed tightening move at some point in the future, irrespective of whether or not it occurs next week, is highly probable."
"Another Fed tightening move of 25 basis points at Tuesday's Federal Open Market Committee meeting would not come as a surprise and would certainly be justified if the Fed wants to remain pre-emptive and guard against the preponderance of upside risks," he said.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
The Real Choice

BYLINE: By A.M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
And now NATO will expand its membership, to help protect democracy and Western civilization in Europe. But outside Europe, in Asia and the Middle East, its members and partners will continue doing everything they can get away with to strengthen dictatorships that are the enemies of democracy and Western civilization.
 Studiously and persistently, NATO members continue to ignore or pervert the most important international choice they face -- how to deal with those dictatorships. 
 For a decade, Western leaders have said the choice was between "isolating" the dictators, which they think dangerous, or "engaging" them in the hope that they can be talked into not being bloody-handed tyrannies, or maybe not quite so bloody.
 The real choice is far different -- collaboration with dictatorships, or democratic self-protection.
 Shall we continue to make dictators stronger politically, economically and militarily? Or shall we refuse to transfer to them the technological, military and money power created under Western democracy, and which they can one day use against us?
The talks on NATO expansion did not even deal with that. Now only the U.S. Senate can save us from NATO's deliberate failure.
 The choice has faced the West for generations. Three times it chose collaboration -- with Hitler, Japan, Iraq -- until they made mistakes that brought the West into war against them.
 But in those days at least we knew what was going on -- appeasement of the dictators, and betrayal of their victims. Churchill, Roosevelt, de Gaulle let the world know.
 Now Western political and business leaders, without public discussion or personal shame, choose their favorite dictatorships -- meaning with the most contracts.
 China is their first pick. In their insipid self-delusion, Western nations believe that there the cash register rings loudest. Chinese leaders are the smartest in the world. They have made America believe it is in its interests to suffer a $39.5 billion annual deficit in its China trade, damage its own manufactures and kiss hand for the privilege.
 The U.S. frowns on deals with Iran, Iraq and Cuba. Western Europe says who are you to lecture us when you too are deep in the China trough?
 Russia, our newly proclaimed partner, busily arranges military and nuclear deals with Iran. From all over Europe businessmen traipse to Baghdad. They line up contracts against the day their governments succeed in lifting the U.N. embargo.
 No leader speaks the full truth, not even the great dissident for democracy, President Vaclav Havel of the Czech Republic. He says NATO expansion is essential to Euro-American civilization -- but slides off on ending the empowerment of its enemies outside Europe.
 Western leaders know what to do. About China, end the huge Western financial contribution to its military potential by refusing trade with the hundreds of companies owned by China's army. Stop Western aviation and technology companies from helping Beijing duplicate their plants.
 Almost all Western leaders are Christians. Why do they not at least economically penalize all countries that persecute Christianity? The day is coming when President Clinton will be asked that in his own church.
 Does anybody believe that if the U.S., Britain, France and Germany took such steps the rest of NATO, or Russia or Japan, could hold out?
 The goal would not be to "isolate" all dictators but to force them to real "engagement" that might reduce their threat to Western society and loosen their oppression at home.
 The Clinton Administration has consulted every foreign country involved on expanding NATO -- but not the American people, who will have to take the risk of getting involved in still more of what Mr. Havel calls Europe's "tribal passions."
Mr. Clinton will not end collaboration for the U.S., let alone for NATO. Responsibility passes to the Senate.
The Senate has a chance that will not come again: to demand that NATO members not expand the power of hostile dictatorships, before it agrees to expand NATO.
 May American senators have the strength and wisdom to choose protection of democracy over collaboration with dictatorships that would destroy it.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Union Cites Productivity As an Issue In Police Pact

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
The Patrolmen's Benevolent Association is taking some jabs at Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani because the Mayor, who likes to boast that he has made city workers far more productive, does not want to negotiate with the police union about increased police productivity.
The union, representing 29,000 police officers, is demanding that the city negotiate over how savings from increased police productivity should go toward raises for the police. 
 But city officials say they have already made a generous offer to the union and do not have to bargain over productivity. The union, whose contract expired 26 months ago, has rejected the city's offer, which calls for a two-year pay freeze and then a raise of almost 16 percent over the next three years -- more than the 13 percent received by most municipal unions in the last three years of their contracts.
The skirmish has come in a flurry of legal papers filed with the city's Office of Collective Bargaining, which has taken preliminary steps to arbitrate the long-simmering contract dispute.
City Labor Commissioner James F. Hanley is arguing that the three-person arbitration panel should not be required to weigh the union's productivity claim when it determines what should be in a new contract.
But the union's top negotiator, Charles G. Moerdler, says the panel should take productivity into account, asserting that the police have been working harder and should be rewarded for saving the city money and helping reduce crime.
Raymond D. Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a business-backed watchdog group, said it was odd that Mr. Giuliani, who has often bragged about raising productivity, would want to take that subject off the bargaining table.
"There is some irony here," he said. "I'm a great believer in gain-sharing. You should have to negotiate over productivity, and the city should have the force of character to take the issue head-on and not hide behind it."
Efforts to resolve the contract dispute are proceeding on two tracks. In January, the city asked the Office of Collective Bargaining to set up an arbitration panel after the two sides hit an impasse. On the other track, the union, fearing that the panel would rule in the city's favor, persuaded the city to resume talks in February in the hope of reaching a settlement and avoiding a contract imposed through arbitration.
In its legal papers, the police union rejects the city's demand for a pay freeze for 1995 and 1996, insisting instead that the police should receive a retroactive "gain-sharing raise" for those two years and subsequent years based on increased productivity.
The union argues that the police have "generated savings in excess of 2 percent per annum," or more than $40 million a year, by working harder and merging the transit and the housing police into the Police Department. The union also is demanding larger seniority raises, more vacation days and holidays and higher city contributions for health insurance and annuities.
"What the P.B.A. seeks, as part of its overall wage increase, is a share of the economic savings it has helped generate," the union said.
But the city argued that any decision involving an increased workload and greater productivity should be made unilaterally by management and not through negotiations.
One senior city official said: "It doesn't make sense to give the police more money because crime is down. Does that mean you'd cut their pay if crime goes up or raise teachers' pay if test scores go up one year or pay firefighters more if there are more fires?"
Labor experts say the main reason the city does not want to give the police more money to reward them for greater productivity is that other unions, most notably the teachers and firefighters, would no doubt complain that their contracts did not similarly reward them for increased productivity. These experts say Mr. Giuliani does not anger those unions in an election year.
Nor does Mr. Giuliani want the police dispute to last through November. Several labor experts who have followed the dispute said the city might secretly ask the arbitration panel to award the police more than the city is offering at the bargaining table. Such an award might make the police happy, and could inoculate Mr. Giuliani against charges that he gave more to the police than to other unions.
City officials deny any such strategy.

HEADLINE: 3 Democratic Rivals Attack Giuliani, Not One Another

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
In their first appearance together since Fernando Ferrer dropped out of the mayoral race, the three Democratic candidates politely sidestepped invitations to criticize one another at a forum yesterday while they attacked the record of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
Speaking to some business people and political aides, Ruth W. Messinger, Sal F. Albanese and the Rev. Al Sharpton spent 90 minutes agreeing on several topics, from their support of rent regulations to their assessment that race relations had deteriorated in New York City since Mr. Giuliani moved into Gracie Mansion. 
 Since the withdrawal earlier this week of Mr. Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President, Ms. Messinger has been buoyed by the perception that she is now the front-runner in the Sept. 9 Democratic primary. But she has also been criticized by some Democratic officials that she is too liberal to win against the Republican Mayor.
Throughout the forum, Ms. Messinger never strayed far from discussing the need to improve the city's schools and her wish to stimulate economic development and create jobs, topics that seem to be developing as core themes that campaign aides said were intended as part of a moderate political platform and image for the Manhattan Borough President.
"I am focused particularly on education," she said. "On reducing class size, on setting standards and telling the school system: 'If you reach the standards we set for you, we will reward you. If you do not, we will have to take action against you.' The education of our children is that important."
She also touched on the city's high unemployment rate. "Wall Street is hitting record highs, but we've got bragging rights to the nation's highest unemployment," she said. "I cheer the successes, the places where our economic engine is running strong. But that engine isn't pulling enough trains. If we're going to create new economic opportunities for unemployed New Yorkers, we must reinvest."
While they gave similar views on current issues like rent regulation, the three candidates also discussed issues that they consider the themes of their campaigns. They often went to those themes, regardless of the questions they were asked.
Mr. Albanese, a City Councilman from Bay Ridge in Brooklyn, reiterated his call for campaign finance reform and for further restrictions on campaign donations.
"We have a campaign finance system in this city and in this country that's flawed," he said, responding to a question seeking how he defined himself politically. "Anything we talk about here in terms of jobs, education, is affected by the political system. The political system is so flooded by big money that everything that flows from there is polluted."
The breakfast forum, held in a dining room near the top of the World Trade Center, was sponsored by the New York City Partnership and Chamber of Commerce and the weekly business publication Crain's New York Business.
As in other candidate forums, Mr. Sharpton provided many of the most memorable lines, making humorous jabs at Mr. Giuliani's record as well as offering lively rejoinders.
When asked whether they considered themselves liberal, each candidate declined to answer directly.
Mr. Sharpton said jocularly that he is a conservative. "When one fights for the criminal justice system to uphold its principles and laws as we've done in various civil rights cases, we're conserving the law," said Mr. Sharpton, a Baptist minister who has played a role in cases involving allegations of racially motivated violence and police brutality.
"We are fighting for law and order," he said. "When we stand and say that we cannot have a city where cops or robbers engage in criminal activity, that's a very conservative notion." He said the Giuliani administration has been "very liberal in giving away money intended for children's education."
"We need conservatives like me," he said.
Mr. Albanese described himself as an "economic populist with a strong law enforcement record."
Ms. Messinger declined to discuss labels altogether. "We can spend this entire election season trying to figure out what label fits with what person and whether that label is a good or bad label," she said. "I think what voters want is someone who will identify problems New Yorkers are facing, and who will tell New Yorkers what she's going to do to solve their problems."
After the forum, the Giuliani campaign wasted no time placing a label on Ms. Messinger. No sooner had the forum ended than Fran Reiter, the Mayor's campaign chairwoman, spoke to reporters as Mr. Giuliani's Democratic rivals stood nearby.
"I think Ruth is running away from her past," Ms. Reiter said, asserting that Ms. Messinger's record was more liberal than those of many Democrats. "She's trying to create a centrist image for herself that belies a 20-year record in public life."
