HEADLINE: Price Waterhouse to Receive State Grants in Exchange for More Jobs

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
In exchange for a pledge to add more than 1,000 workers in its Manhattan offices over the next five years, the accounting firm of Price Waterhouse will receive $2 million in state grants, Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday.
Although the incentives, which also include tax breaks, are modest compared with those granted other companies, city and state officials praised the agreement as a reflection of the growing willingness of companies not only to remain in New York City, but also to expand here. 
 "It is a signal of our continued faith in the city as a great place from which to serve our premier clients," James J. Schiro, the accounting firm's chairman, said in a news release.
Under the agreement, Price Waterhouse is to add 1,090 workers in Manhattan by 2002, an increase of nearly 50 percent from its current New York City work force of 2,200. The firm said its expansion will take place mainly in its headquarters at 1177 Avenue of the Americas, at 44th Street, where almost all its workers are based, and in two floors of a building it has leased at 11 Madison Avenue, at 24th Street.
Price Waterhouse said it had been courted by developers and government officials elsewhere in the region. Mike Ascolese, a company spokesman, said it had considered sites in Westchester County, New Jersey and Connecticut.
"This is another fight we have won," Mr. Pataki said at a news conference.
Unlike other companies that have threatened to move everyone from executives to clerks out of New York City, Price Waterhouse, which has been Manhattan since 1890, said an exodus was not considered.
"The question was not whether we would remain, but how much of us would remain," Mr. Ascolese said.
Price Waterhouse ranks fourth in employment among New York City accounting firms, behind Arthur Andersen, Deloitte & Touche and Ernst & Young. It said the swift pace of employment growth that it pledged to city and state officials would result from an expansion of its management consulting business, which is centered in Manhattan, and a faster rate of hiring in Manhattan than at its offices elsewhere in the nation.
The agreement does not obligate Price Waterhouse to transfer any current employees to Manhattan, the firm said.
The state grants to Price Waterhouse amount to slightly more than $1,800 for each new Manhattan worker it has promised to hire. Past business retention agreements have been far more costly, reaching a record of $51,000 per employee that was granted to Chase Manhattan in 1988.
In addition to its $2 million in state grants, Price Waterhouse is to receive an exemption from city and state sales taxes on things like computer equipment and furniture for the offices it has leased on Madison Avenue.
State officials said the accounting firm had agreed to pay back some of its financial benefits if it does not meet its objective of 1,090 new jobs in five years, and retain a Manhattan work force at least that large for the following five years.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Flying Is a Pain That United Wants to Share

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT 

 BODY:
After more than three decades of peddling the "friendly skies," United Airlines is changing course for a bold but risky alternative: acknowledging just how problematic the skies, the gates, the planes and even its employees can be for travelers, particularly frequent fliers.
That high-stakes shift in marketing strategy, which tries in an empathetic way to feel passengers' pain, was inspired by a study of frequent travelers on all airlines. 
 The change is unusual for an industry that almost always uses the most positive imagery to portray its services. Carriers from Eastern in the 1960's ("The wings of man") to Delta today ("On top of the world") have confidently asserted that their skies are the bluest, their flight attendants the most courteous, their meals the tastiest. With rare exceptions, advertising campaigns have shied from suggesting, much less showing, that flights can land late, luggage can get lost or workers can turn surly.
But United, still remaking itself almost three years after employees took control of the company, is gambling on the unconventional approach -- to be introduced in television commercials and print advertisements that begin appearing next Thursday -- as a way to appeal to skeptical consumers and break through the increasing clutter of airline campaigns.
Only by addressing the myriad difficulties that frustrate fliers, executives of United and its two new advertising agencies declare, can their message be believed about the airline spending $400 million over the next 5 to 10 years on improvements aimed at customer satisfaction.
That surprising switch may help improve perceptions about United's performance, said Karen Goodwin, editor in chief of Frequent Flyer magazine in Oak Brook, Ill.
"For a while, our readership has either been picking on United or not that happy with United's programs," she said in a telephone interview yesterday. "A lot of the letters about United have been negative, feeling perhaps that they're not that customer-driven."
In a survey released on Wednesday by Frequent Flyer and the research firm J. D. Power & Associates, Ms. Goodwin said, United's service finished below average among airlines for flights of less than 500 miles, trailing America West, Continental, U S Airways, Delta and Southwest. On flights longer than 500 miles, United finished third, she added, behind Continental and Trans World Airlines.
According to the most recent Department of Transportation data for on-time performance, United finished fourth among 10 carriers.
The new campaign has been eagerly awaited by the airline and advertising industries because it is the first since United shocked both by dismissing the Leo Burnett Company, the large Chicago agency that won United's business in 1965 by creating the "friendly skies" theme.
The campaign makes its case for United in brash, slyly forthright ways. One print ad proclaims that United is "a better way for cynics to travel" and another asks cheekily, "Wouldn't it be great if we could all fly commercials?"
One of three United television spots even rewrites history, canceling the Wright Brothers' first flight by interpolating modern-day difficulties like unexplained delays and indifferent airline personnel. "If Orville and Wilbur had to go through what you do just to fly," says the announcer, the actor Mandy Patinkin, "they would've stayed in the bicycle business." The successor slogan to "friendly skies" is "United Airlines. Rising."
"We need to get at and disarm, as quickly as we can, a lot of angry people who are not paying attention to us," said Bill Westbrook, president and chief creative officer of Fallon McElligott, the upstart Minneapolis agency that in October was named, along with Young & Rubicam Advertising in New York, to replace Burnett on the $120 million worldwide United account. The Fallon McElligott work is for domestic markets; Y.& R.'s runs overseas.
"Most frequent fliers are angry because they feel they're not appreciated for the contribution they make to the airline industry's bottom line," he said, "and they are incredulous about airline promises, because they're almost always disenchanted."
Peter Murphy, executive vice president and senior creative director at Y.& R., said: "The customers are all we've got, and therefore they're everything to us. 'Rising' gives concrete reasons why we are rising to meet, and we hope rise above, their ever-changing expectations in an ever-changing world."
Mr. Westbrook said: " 'Friendly skies' was created at a time when a lot of people were afraid to fly and when friendliness was of higher value. It's a wonderful part of advertising history, but the market changed."
John D. Kiker, vice president of corporate communications for United, a unit of the UAL Corporation in Elk Grove Village, Ill., said that the nontraditional tone of the campaign was the result of interviews with consumers, adding, "They said, 'Don't lie to us anymore.' "
All the executives said they recognized the dangers involved in bringing up the problems associated with flying, from delays to unresponsive employees to bad food, before offering United as the answer for those weary of airline annoyances.
That kind of advertising, known as problem/solution, is a staple for products like detergents and drugs. But it is rarely done for airlines. Exceptions include a 1967 ad for Pacific Air Lines addressed to a passenger "with the sweat in your palms" and a 1974 commercial for Southern Airways comparing competitors' coach-class service to steerage on an immigrant ship.
By contrast, most airline ads are all solution and no problem, such as "On top of the world," created for Delta by the Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide unit of Cordiant P.L.C.
The reason for avoiding reminders that anguish seems to be issued with boarding passes is a fear that depicting those difficulties may only send worried customers to fill seats on rivals' aircraft -- or push them to driving or teleconferences.
But doing that is necessary, Mr. Westbrook said, because "only by showing we understand can we get through that wall built up, brick by brick, over the years."
The solutions detailed in the campaign include improving service at gates; for instance, unhappy fliers will be offered perks like upgrades. Also promised are better meals and more employee training.
That last point is important because United's adoption of its employee stock ownership plan in July 1994 has not eliminated a reputation for fractious labor-management relations. For example, United's flight attendants decided against becoming employee-owners.
"If you have happy employees," said Ms. Goodwin of Frequent Flyer magazine, "you probably have happy customers."
The part that employees will play in whether "Rising" rises or falls is underscored by a commercial devoted to them. That spot shows employees waiting, grumbling and fidgeting, for a 6 P.M. training session that starts at 6:26.
"Feeling a little frustrated?" the trainer asks when he finally arrives. "Well, hang on to that feeling the next time a frustrated customer comes to you with a problem."
"Act like you own the place," he adds, "because, you know, you do."

HEADLINE: Canada's Leader Finds Hometown Fretful

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: SHAWINIGAN, Quebec, May 14

 BODY:
Prime Minister Jean Chretien's Liberal Party holds a commanding lead as the June 2 national elections approach, but Mr. Chretien himself is in one of the toughest fights of his long political career.
As he campaigns for his own seat in Parliament representing this old French-speaking mill town northeast of Montreal, he faces a tough opponent and a grumpy electorate that is largely disappointed that Mr. Chretien has not been able to solve the problems in his own backyard. 
 For the 63-year-old Prime Minister, Shawinigan, with its railcars heaped with wood pulp and workers carrying metal lunch pails, is as much a part of his personal myth as Hope, Ark., is for President Clinton's.
Mr. Chretien was first elected to represent this area in Ottawa in 1963, and Shawinigan has returned him to the House of Commons eight times, the last as a hard-working Prime Minister who looked and sounded like an ordinary guy. He always campaigns with his crooked smile and fractured diction, in both English and French, as "the little guy from Shawinigan."
But the common-man guise may be wearing thin. "For 30 years he's been saying 'I'm the little guy from Shawinigan' and in my mind it's pejorative," said Yves Duhaime, 57, a local lawyer and Bloc Quebecois politician who polls say is running neck and neck with Mr. Chretien. "What people need now is a gentleman from Shawinigan."
The main issues here can be seen as a microcosm of the most important issues facing Canada in this election: the need to create jobs, protect the social network and keep the country together.
But while Mr. Chretien remains popular in English-speaking Canada, he has not made friends here with the way he has handled those issues since taking office as Canada's 20th Prime Minister a little over three and a half years ago.
"He's a real liability in Quebec," said Larry LeDuc, a professor of political science at the University of Toronto.
Many people here still see him as a traitor to the Quebec cause, Professor LeDuc said, and his inability or unwillingness to shower Shawinigan with governmental goodies has added to local disappointment over his leadership.
In some ways, it is the achievements that Mr. Chretien most proudly boasts of elsewhere in Canada that get him into the most trouble here.
He tells voters that his Government has created 793,000 jobs, and reduced the national unemployment rate to 9.6 percent, from just over 11 percent when he took office.
But in Shawinigan and surrounding areas in the district, unemployment is about 16 percent, and more than 10,000 of the district's 75,000 residents are on welfare.
To reduce the ballooning national deficit that he inherited in 1993, Mr. Chretien has had to cut deeply into Canada's most cherished social program -- universal health care -- and generally tighten the broad range of assistance programs. Here, some 450 poor families rely on a food bank run by Roman Catholic priests.
And wherever he campaigns, Mr. Chretien is reminded that although the "no" side won the October 1995 referendum in Quebec on splitting up Canada, he badly underestimated the separatist sentiment of his fellow Quebecers. In a personal rebuke for the Prime Minister, who led the campaign for unity, 54.6 percent of the people here voted for Quebec to pull out of Canada.
Few analysts actually expect Mr. Chretien to lose, although they say that if the Liberals do poorly, there will be pressure on him to resign. If the unexpected happened and he were to lose while his party retained control of the Government, space would be found for him in another district so he could remain Prime Minister.
For now, Mr. Chretien is taking no chances of suffering any such blow to his leadership. While he campaigns for his party across Canada, a number of his Cabinet ministers go on the stump for him in Shawinigan, repeating the rather modest message he gave in a nationally televised debate among party leaders on Monday.
"In some areas, I am sorry to say, we were not able to do all we wanted to do," Mr. Chretien said. "You do not expect your Government to perform miracles."
There has never been love lost between Mr. Chretien and Mr. Duhaime. Both are lawyers born in Shawinigan, but they have taken very different paths. Mr. Chretien staunchly supports keeping Quebec in Canada. He has always belonged to the Liberal Party, and he held nearly every major Cabinet position before becoming Prime Minister.
Mr. Duhaime has held office in the provincial government but in the mid-1980's he retired from politics. He came back to the political scene last fall, running unsuccessfully for the leadership of the Bloc Quebecois, the separatist party.
Mr. Duhaime and Mr. Chretien have been in some very public shouting matches, and the Prime Minister once threatened to punch Mr. Duhaime in the nose because he had blocked a favorite project. ("I'm not the chicken type at all, so try it," Mr. Duhaime responded.)
The mood of the people in Shawinigan is as acrid and unpleasant as the thin smoke coming out of the huge paper mill on the outskirts of town.
"They have reduced the deficit on the backs of poor people," said Claire Doucet, a manager of the Roland Bertrand Center, which runs a food bank here. "They should all stop talking about the deficit and start doing something about poverty."
Even those people who have jobs are worried about losing them. "For me now it's not too bad because I have work, but really we need many more jobs," said Roger Beaulieu, 38, production director at the Doral International boatyard in nearby Grand-Mere.
Mr. Duhaime's party, the Bloc Quebecois, has focused on Shawinigan and gladly helps in the attack on Mr. Chretien. The party's leader, Gilles Duceppe, called Mr. Chretien "the little guy from Ottawa who disguises himself as the little guy from Shawinigan every four years."
Mr. Chretien may have caught a break recently. The separatist movement was badly splintered when former Premier Jacques Parizeau hinted in a new book that he had arranged to have France recognize Quebec independence within days of a yes vote in the 1995 referendum. Previously he had pledged to first negotiate a new partnership arrangement with the rest of Canada.
Mr. Chretien pounced on Mr. Parizeau's statements as proof that the separatists had been deceiving the people of Quebec. That has put Mr. Duhaime, who had asked Mr. Parizeau to campaign on his behalf, on the defensive. "What we've been doing in the last few days is what everyone knows is damage control," Mr. Duhaime said.
Although Mr. Chretien has tried to keep national unity from dominating his campaign, it once again threatens to take control. Mr. Duhaime is relying on voters who approved separation in 1995 to withhold their support for Mr. Chretien, even if he is Prime Minister.
But for Mrs. Doucet at the Shawinigan food bank, unity is not the most important issue to be decided.
"Here, the first preoccupation is survival," she said. "If you have nothing to eat, it doesn't matter whether you are in a country called Canada or a country called Quebec."

HEADLINE: What Is NATO? Europe's Glue, Not Kremlin's Foe

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

 BODY:
Western Europeans who support NATO's expansion to take in the new democracies of Central Europe do not see the move, primarily, as insurance against the possibility that Russia might one day emerge again as a threat to their security.
From President Jacques Chirac of France to President Vaclav Havel of the Czech Republic, most of them instead see NATO expansion primarily as a way of guaranteeing the stability of an ethnically riven and historically volatile region that spawned two world wars. For this purpose, they have also viewed Russian assent as essential. 
 Though expanding the alliance would certainly move back the day when Russia might ever threaten Central Europe again, to Europeans that argument seems to be -- as detractors of expansion often portray it -- outdated thinking from the cold war. Convincing the Russians that expansion would be no threat to them was the aim of the Founding Act that President Boris N. Yeltsin and NATO leaders announced this week and will sign in Paris on May 27.
Most European leaders, east or west, would have no trouble agreeing with Mr. Yeltsin and Chancellor Helmut Kohl, who agreed yesterday that the deal was a "fundamental, far-reaching step toward insuring lasting stability and security in Europe."
NATO, which never fired a shot in anger during the cold war, is now seen as the best way of deterring another tragedy like the war in Bosnia, which neither the European Union nor the United Nations could stop. NATO, once it was led reluctantly and belatedly by the United States, could, and did halt the killing, with Russian troops as part of the NATO peacekeeping force.
Gradually, Western European and American leaders have come to understand that fear of this kind of disorder, more than anxiety about their larger eastern neighbor, is the most important reason Central European countries like the Czech Republic, Hungary, Poland, and now others, farther east, like Romania and Bulgaria want so badly to join the alliance.
There is an important symbolic value, as well.
"The new democracies want to join NATO for the same reason they want to get into the European Union -- because they see admission to both these institutions as proof that they have been fully accepted as Western democracies," one high-ranking NATO diplomat said.
People in these countries watched a security vacuum develop around Bosnia and Herzegovina in the early 1990's and drew a lesson from that disaster for themselves.
That lesson was that joining a collective alliance whose members pledged mutually to resolve ethnic, historical or territorial disputes peacefully was the best way to avoid another Bosnia-like war elsewhere.
Motivated by the desire to join the alliance, first Hungary and Slovakia and last year Hungary and Romania resolved historic impediments to cooperation between them that were long masked during the Communist period.
The Hungarian-Romanian accord removed tensions between the two countries over the treatment of the large ethnic Hungarian minority in Romania as a potential source of friction nearly as serious as the one in Bosnia.
More recently, Romania and Ukraine, which wants to associate itself with NATO but not to join it, have resolved border disputes by treaty, NATO diplomats point out.
Skeptics may say that Greece and Turkey, both longtime NATO members, have not resolved their disputes over territory in the Aegean Sea or over ethnically divided Cyprus, and both have nearly gone to war over those differences in the past.
But, as Mr. Havel said at a meeting with editors and writers at The New York Times this week, "I believe if it weren't for NATO, three wars might have been fought between Greece and Turkey in the last decade."
There are many in Western Europe who would agree with him -- even the French, who under Mr. Chirac are considering whether to put their military forces back into NATO structures that President Charles de Gaulle pulled them out of in 1966.
Adding Central European countries to the NATO mix will help give the alliance the more European cast that Mr. Chirac is insisting upon as a condition of reintegrating.
France would be happier about expansion if Romania and possibly other south-central European countries were included in the first wave. But Mr. Chirac, at least, has never been known to doubt the wisdom of expansion in principle, or to voice suspicions that the Clinton Administration foisted expansion on unwilling Western Europeans to insure continued American domination of European security structures, as some cynics surmise.
President Clinton and other NATO leaders plan to name the first new candidates for membership at a summit meeting in Madrid July 8 and 9.
Italy and Spain, concerned that the expected admission of Poland, the Czech Republic and Hungary could divert the alliance's attention from security problems in the Mediterranean region, agree with the French about Romania.
Italy is also backing Slovenia for early membership, and now that Bulgaria has voted out a neo-Communist Government, there is some support for encouraging it too.
On the success of expansion and gradually increasing cooperation with Russia, Ukraine and other countries on the eastern edges of the alliance hangs a great deal.
A transformed NATO, in the view of its supporters on the Continent, can provide the necessary security underpinning for a successful transition to democracy and a free market economy not only for Central Europe but also for the countries of the former Soviet Union.
That will enable the European Union to go ahead with its own expansion, bringing the new democracies into a political and economic institution that has done as much as NATO did over the last half century to make war unthinkable between old enemies, ethnic or otherwise.
And it will also preserve what many Europeans believe is the linchpin of the entire post-World War II structure.
NATO, which will celebrate its 50th anniversary in 1999, is the most tangible political and strategic link between the United States and Europe. Even France, which often views the United States as a rival, is eager to guarantee the continued commitment of the world's only superpower to Europe's continued security and prosperity.
NATO's expansion, by guaranteeing the alliance's continued relevance, also guarantees Europeans that continued and valued American commitment.

HEADLINE: Price Inflation Held to Scant Rise in April

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 15

 BODY:
As part of a last flurry of statistics before the Federal Reserve meets on interest rates, the Government reported today that declines for energy and food held consumer inflation to a scant one-tenth of 1 percent in April.
But the latest tabulation of consumer prices did not provide any insight into what the Federal Reserve would do when it meets Tuesday. 
 "The Fed has more reason to tighten than not -- but it's not a laydown," said Frederick Breimyer, chief economist at the State Street Bank in Boston, offering a typical comment.
With the economy clearly slowing in recent weeks, the main question seemed to be whether the central bank thought the deceleration would be enough to prevent an increase in inflation.
Unlike recent reports on employment costs and producer prices, which were widely regarded as reassuring on this score, today's Consumer Price Index was a bit unnerving in that its core rate climbed by three-tenths of 1 percent, the largest increase since September.
The core rate, which disregards energy and food because they swing widely from month to month, often because of weather, also crept up to 2.7 percent over the latest 12 months from 2.5 percent in March.
Analysts expressed some concern about this even though the April increase largely reflected the biggest jump in four years in the price of clothing, also a volatile item because of seasonal introductions and markdowns.
"These data are somewhat disconcerting in the face of the upcoming Federal Open Market Committee meeting" and could be used to justify a tightening of monetary policy, Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, the investment firm, told its clients today.
Securities markets largely took today's news in stride, apparently reflecting the status of the Consumer Price Index as an indicator of past developments and not of future risk.
William Cheney, chief economist at John Hancock in Boston, said he doubted the April consumer index would count for much in the Fed's deliberations. "Waiting to see inflation in the C.P.I. before hiking rates is like waiting to see flames in the windows before calling the fire department," he said. "At that point, you are too late."
Instead, the labor market poses a bigger threat to continued low inflation, Mr. Cheney and others contend. They point to an unemployment rate of 4.9 percent, a tightness that seemed to show no letup today with the Labor Department's report that the number of people making initial jobless claims, a forward-looking indicator, dropped sharply in the week ended last Saturday.
Claims tumbled 31,000 from the previous week, to 319,000, returning to low levels after two weeks when totals were swollen by automotive strikes and floods in the Midwest.
Still another report, this one compiled by the Fed, showed that output of factories, mines and utilities was unchanged in April after an increase of six-tenths of 1 percent in March.
Industrial production, an indicator of current conditions, would have advanced three-tenths of 1 percent had it not been dragged down by a drop in output of motor vehicles and parts, more than half of which was attributed to strikes. Utility production jumped 2 percent, reflecting cool temperatures, the Fed said.
The capacity use rate, which measures how near to production limits businesses are operating, fell to a somewhat slower 83.4 percent of capacity last month. The March rate was revised down to 83.7 from 84.1.
"Our economy is in for a smooth landing on a pathway of moderate growth and stable inflation," contended Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers. "After a massive rise in consumer demand and a buildup in inventories in the first quarter, production is slowing down until the surplus stocks are sold off."
The Consumer Price Index report was marked by a second consecutive large drop in the price of energy, 1.5 percent in April, and a two-tenths of 1 percent decline in food that owed much to fruits and vegetables but also included a 6.8 percent jump in the price of coffee.
Transportation costs fell for the third time in four months as gasoline fell 2.6 percent and used cars slumped 1.6 percent to more than offset higher automobile finance charges and a l.2 percent rise in airline fares. Plane tickets had jumped 4.5 percent in March on renewal of the 10 percent Federal tax.
The jump in the price of apparel was nine-tenths of 1 percent, the biggest since February 1993. This, along with another increase in tobacco prices, 2.4 percent, accounted for the core's acceleration to three-tenths of 1 percent after increases of two-tenths of 1 percent for five of the six preceding months.
Merrill Lynch summed up the price report as "mixed," but added, "On balance, we believe that inflation remains dormant."

HEADLINE: New Buyers Turn Art Sales Into Expensive Parties

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL 

 BODY:
The feel-good factor that economists and real estate brokers keep talking about has infected the market for Impressionist, modern and contemporary art at virtually every price level. For the last two weeks, bidders at the important spring sales at Sotheby's and Christie's in Manhattan spent staggering sums on everything from ultra-sweet Impressionist paintings to hard-edged modern ones. There were even takers for the tough subjects tackled by avant-garde contemporary artists in the late 1980's and early 90's.
One reason the atmosphere at the auctions was so buoyant was that many new collectors showed up at the Sotheby's and Christie's salesrooms. This new breed buys in new ways. Its members are not like the successful businessmen in the 1980's who made conspicuous consumption part of the fun by wanting to be seen. Nor are they like the buyers of the far quieter early 1990's, who simply stayed home and bid by telephone or through a dealer. 
 Today's buyers, still business tycoons for the most part, like to be seen, and they treat these sales as parties with a highly selective guest list. But they don't necessarily want to be known as big spenders. They come to the sales, cellular phones in hand, and sit in one part of the room instructing an agent in a different part of the room, also using a cellular phone, on how much to spend.
And spend they do. At all levels. Several years ago it was only the top-notch works that had a lot of competition, but the market has expanded. Even middle-range paintings, drawings and sculptures, in the $100,000 to $1 million range, often had several interested buyers.
Of the two auction houses, Christie's was the winner this spring. Its sales of contemporary art totaled just under $30 million and for Impressionist $234.5 million, the highest total since 1990. Sotheby's contemporary sales brought in $21.9 million and its Impressionist sales $100.5 million.
"There's a broadening of the market worldwide," said Christopher Burge, Christie's chairman in America and the company's star auctioneer. "The money's been stockpiled. All these people buy things like luxury cars, and now it's filtering down to us and they're buying art. We all feel it."
Diana D. Brooks, Sotheby's chief executive worldwide, called the current market healthy. "When you have as much material as we did selling so well, it's a good sign for days ahead," she said. "Still, it's a selective market."
Collectors today do their homework: they know when the condition of a work of art presents problems, if it has been around the market or simply isn't a good example of an artist's work. They are scared by what happened to the speculators of the 1980's, who paid too much in moments of passion and later were burned when they tried unsuccessfully to sell for the same high prices. Value and quality mean a lot today.
"Today's buyer keeps getting smarter and smarter," said Ernst Beyeler, a dealer based in Basel, Switzerland, who bought several important works this week for clients.
Mr. Beyeler was an important presence at what was the most anticipated sale of the last two weeks, the auction of 29 Impressionist and Post-Impressionist paintings, drawings and sculptures from the collection of John Langeloth Loeb and Frances Lehman Loeb. The 66-minute sale made $92.7 million, above Christie's $80 million estimate.
Mr. Loeb, a Wall Street investor, and his wife, a philanthropist, had been serious collectors since the late 1950's, often buying from well-known galleries like Knoedler & Company in Manhattan or at auctions in the United States and abroad. Mr. Beyeler bought the most expensive work of the spring sales, Cezanne's "Madame Cezanne Seated in a Yellow Chair" (1888-1890), a powerful portrait of the artist's wife in a red dress; it was a star of the Loebs' collection. Mr. Beyeler paid $23.1 million, less than Christie's estimate of $25 million.
Another big-ticket painting from the Loeb collection was "Manet With His Palette" (1878). Christie's had estimated the self-portrait would fetch $15 million, but it did better, selling to an unidentified telephone bidder for $18.7 million.
The prices of the Cezanne and the Manet were the second highest paid for works by these artists. But Toulouse-Lautrec's "Seated Dancer in Pink Stockings" (1890), which was bought by another unidentified telephone bidder for $14.5 million, set a record for his work. The price was well above Christie's $10 million high estimate. (Final prices include the auction house's commission, 15 percent of the first $50,000 and 10 percent of the rest. Estimates do not reflect commissions.)
The Loebs' art was the most important private collection to be sold at auction this spring, but it was not by any means the only one. Christie's also offered eight works that had belonged to Jacques Koerfer, a German businessman whose heirs have been selling his collection at Christie's for three years. These works got off to a tough start, with some not selling at all. Among them was Braque's "Bottle of Rum" (1912), an oval Cubist painting estimated at $3 million to $4 million, for which no one was willing to pay more than $2 million.
But Mondrian's "Composition No. 3 (Composition With Red, Blue, Yellow and Black)" (1929) brought $4.1 million, just above its $4 million estimate, from Thomas H. Lee, the leveraged-buyout specialist. A small painting (19 3/4 inches square) in pristine condition, with the artist's original frame, it drew bids from several New York dealers, including Larry Gagosian and Robert Mnuchin.
There was still more competition for "Gauguin at His Easel" (1884-1885), a self-portrait. Bids hopscotched from one end of the sales room to the other, finally landing at the telephone bank. An unidentified telephone bidder paid $3.8 million, more than twice the painting's high estimate of $1.5 million.
Sotheby's had its share of estate property, too. And because these works had not been on the market, they tended to fare the best. Its top seller, Klimt's "Tavern at Litzleberg" (1915-1916), sold for $17.4 million to an unidentified telephone bidder. It was from the estate of Serge Sabarsky, a New York dealer and a pioneer in supporting 20th-century German and Austrian art, who died in February 1996.
Another fresh work that brought Sotheby's a large price was a Degas pastel, "Dancers" (1899), which set an artist's record by fetching $11 million, above its estimate of $7 million. The unknown buyer bid through Alexander Apsis, head of Sotheby's department of Impressionist and modern art in New York. The work was sold by the heirs of the French dealer Paul Durand-Ruel.
Contemporary art generally does not have great estate property, but it does benefit from brand names. Take Christie's sale, where sculptures being sold by Douglas S. Cramer, a television producer best known for "Dynasty" and "The Love Boat," brought high prices. Among the most popular was Ellsworth Kelly's "Untitled," a stainless-steel wall sculpture from 1986 in the shape of a flying arch. Estimated at $200,000 to $300,000, it sold to a telephone bidder for $442,500.
Sotheby's was selling art from the CBS corporate collection, about 100 works, primarily paintings and prints, purchased since the 1960's. The collection's artists included Jean Dubuffet, Franz Kline, Jackson Pollock and Henry Moore. Among the best was Kline's "Crosstown" (1955), a black-and-white abstract work bought by William C. Paley, the founder of CBS, more than 30 years ago. It sold to an unidentified bidder for $2.2 million, above its $1.5 million estimate.
But by far the most exciting part of the sale was a group of 11 works sold by the Boston Children's Heart Foundation. The collection was assembled by Dr. Bernardo Nadal-Ginard, a Boston cardiologist now serving a one-year sentence for misappropriating money from the nonprofit research foundation. In his buying days, Dr. Nadal-Ginard was offered the best of the newest artists, and buyers at Sotheby's knew it.
Robert Gober's untitled wax leg of a girl, for example, was expected to sell for $50,000 to $70,000. It went for $96,000. While Mr. Gober's work has brought higher prices at auction, this was one of the most sought-after pieces. So was Kiki Smith's sculpture of a woman crouched on the floor, urinating. Several people tried to buy it, but it finally went to Anthony D'Offay, a London dealer, for $223,500, almost three times its high estimate of $80,000 and a record for the artist.
This is tough art that appeals to a small but passionate group of collectors. But it is what Tobias Meyer, director of Sotheby's contemporary art worldwide, called "the art of our day," the kind of work buyers in 10 years will wish they had had the nerve to buy.

HEADLINE: Late Rally Sends the Dow Above 7,300-Point Level

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks surged yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average closing at more than 7,300 points for the first time.
Stocks were bolstered by manufacturing data that pointed to a slowing economy, suggesting that Federal Reserve policy makers would not need to raise interest rates when they meet on Tuesday. 
 The Dow rose 47.39 points, to 7,333.55, with virtually all the gain coming in the final hour of trading.
The Nasdaq composite index, loaded with technology issues, rose 18.03 points, or 1.35 percent, to 1,353.58, its best gain in nine sessions. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 5.84 points, to 841.88.
Reports on factory utilization across the country and a review of Philadelphia-area manufacturing suggested that growth is slowing from its decade-best rate in the first quarter, diminishing the potential for inflation.
"The markets either don't expect a Fed rate increase, or they expect a benign one," said Laszlo Birinyi, who runs his own research firm in Greenwich, Conn.
Advancing issues outpaced those that declined by 1,302 to 1,188 on the New York Stock Exchange.
Shares of the Intel Corporation rose for a second day, extending its comeback after two rival makers of computer chips filed lawsuits contending that Intel's best-selling Pentium chip uses their patented technology. Intel climbed 5 1/4, to 158 1/8, after falling as much as 13 in the previous two sessions.
Shares of the Hewlett-Packard Company rose 2 1/4, to 58 7/8, on expectations that its second-quarter profit would exceed estimates on strong sales of servers and other computers. After the market closed, the company posted earnings of 75 cents a share, 6 cents less than estimates.
Shares of Amazon.com Inc., a money-losing Internet book retailer, soared on their first day of trading. Amazon jumped as much as 12, to 30, before closing at 23 1/2. Strong demand for shares bolstered the initial sale price to 18 each late on Wednesday, more than the original forecast of 12 to 14.
Gateway 2000 Inc., a direct-marketing retailer of personal computers, saw its shares surge 7 1/2, to a record 68 7/8, after the company said it would split its stock 2 for 1, buy back as many as 10 million shares and move to the New York Stock Exchange from the Nasdaq market.
Among retailers, Gap Inc. said its profit rose to 31 cents, from 28 cents in the quarter a year earlier, matching forecasts; its shares rose 5/8, to 32 3/4. The Kmart Corporation's stock fell 3/8 a share, to 14 1/8, after it reported profit of 3 cents a share, better than some analysts' forecasts. Investors apparently anticipated slower growth later this year.
The Capital One Financial Corporation's shares fell 3 1/2, to 36 3/8, after the company forecast lower-than-expected earnings for its second quarter.
Oil shares declined as the slowing economy and ample supplies pointed to a decline in petroleum prices. The Exxon Corporation lost 1, to 58 7/8; Texaco Inc. fell 7/8, to 110 1/8.
Banks gave up some of Wednesday's gains. Shares of the BankAmerica Corporation fell 1, to 119 7/8, after rising 4 on Wednesday.
Shares of Intuit Inc. climbed 3 3/16 , to 27 1/8, on speculation that the financial software company might be acquired as soon as Monday.

HEADLINE: One Thrives, The Other Doesn't;
After Latin Venture Fails, VW Succeeds And Ford Scrambles

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: PACHECO, Argentina

 BODY:
Supported by concrete posts and topped with five lines of barbed wire, the six-foot-high chain-link fence zigzags through the heart of what used to be a blossoming auto-making partnership here. On one side of the fence are the operations of the Ford Motor Company, on the other side those of Volkswagen A.G., now divided by a nasty corporate divorce -- a case study of the difficulties in breaking up a big-company joint venture.
The basic mistake of Ford, its officials now acknowledge, lay in assuming that a marriage made in the late 1980's would last indefinitely. The union looked good on paper: the companies would make cars together for Brazil and Argentina, sharing all the profits and producing no competing models. 
 The trouble was that Ford let VW make the subcompacts, a segment that has since come to account for half the region's auto sales, with Ford still struggling to catch up. Ford was also caught off guard by rapid economic changes that turned the once-stagnant countries into attractive markets.
As a result, Ford has endured heavy losses in a region that has become the most profitable in the world for rivals like the General Motors Corporation and Fiat S.p.A. "We've essentially started over; we're building a new company from the ground up in Argentina and Brazil," said Alex Trotman, Ford's chairman and chief executive.
Ford and Volkswagen combined their subsidiaries in Brazil and Argentina in 1987, when hyperinflation, weak growth and a ban on car imports had badly hurt sales in both countries. Their joint venture, known as Autolatina, became highly profitable even in this hostile environment by closing surplus Ford and Volkswagen assembly plants and offering aging models that were cheap to build. The plant here, on the northern outskirts of Buenos Aires, was originally a Ford factory, with Volkswagen moving in; it is now divided roughly in half by a fence even more sturdy than the one that wraps around the whole complex.
With Brazil and Argentina banning car imports for most of the 1980's, Autolatina sold some of the world's stalest models. Midsize Ford Falcons, nearly identical to the 1960 United States model, were made here from 1961 until 1991. So many of these automotive fossils are still on the road that a visitor almost expects to see Elvis Presley step out of one at any moment.
But after the debt crisis of the 1980's faded away, the Brazilian and Argentine economies sprang back to life in the early 1990's. Autolatina, and Ford in particular, was caught unprepared.
Inflation dropped, economic growth increased and car sales soared. The import ban was replaced with steep tariffs, prompting nearly a dozen auto makers to start exporting their latest models here and begin planning new factories. Suddenly faced with true competition -- and reluctant to share the technology needed to build their own latest models -- Ford and VW decided in early 1995 to break Autolatina apart.
That decision was a boon to Volkswagen, which has since produced steady earnings while holding onto a third of the regional auto market. But Ford's operations emerged from the venture in disarray, with much lower market shares -- mainly because of its lack of small cars. Because of the Autolatina breakup, Ford lost a staggering $645 million in its South American division last year.
The moral, as Ford officials see it now, is that companies combining operations should look hard at what might happen if the venture later comes undone.
"Emotionally, you know, the last thing you want to do is contemplate coming apart," said Jacques Nasser, president of Ford's worldwide automotive operations.
Still, he said, "At some stage up front, you kind of need to brainstorm the conditions under which the partnership stops providing the added value and synergies."
Roger D. Stark, a specialist in auto industry joint ventures at Coudert Brothers, the international law firm, boils down Autolatina's lesson for other multinationals more succinctly: "Be careful who you marry, and have a good prenuptial agreement."
The biggest problem for Ford has been that almost all the growth in both auto markets has come in subcompacts, particularly the smallest subcompacts, called "popular cars." But Ford specialized in midsize cars before Autolatina, while Volkswagen built mainly smaller cars.
During the joint venture, the two companies made all Autolatina's cars together and shared all the profits. The larger cars mostly bore Ford nameplates and went to family-owned Ford dealers, though, while the smaller cars tended to have Volkswagen nameplates and went to Volkswagen dealers.
Ford dealers begged for a small car as the Brazilian market in particular shifted strongly in the early 1990's. But Ford executives were reluctant to erode Autolatina's profits by developing a subcompact from scratch and then placing it in competition with Volkswagen's Gol, from which Ford was already taking half the profits.
At the same time, VW officials were reluctant to share their subcompact designs with Ford for fear that Ford would use them in other world markets.
Yet the result of Ford's decision to focus on Autolatina's profits rather than on Ford brand cars was that Ford emerged from the alliance with a reputation for making cars bigger than most consumers wanted.
"Obviously, we should have nurtured our brand better in those years," said Ivan Silva, the new president of Ford of Brazil. "It would be much less painful now."
For their part, Volkswagen officials are delighted with the breakup, having retained their dominant market position in Brazil and gained a larger share in Argentina. VW entered Autolatina in 1987 with just 10 percent of the Argentine car market, for instance, but was the market leader last year with 18.6 percent. "Things have turned out very well, even better than we hoped," said Norberto C. Dubar, president of Volkswagen Argentina.
Volkswagen officials even feel that they learned a lot from working with Ford in Autolatina, improving their abilities to track costs more closely and cut the number of management meetings. "VW learned how to be leaner," said Miguel Jorge, the acting president at Volkswagen of Brazil.
Ford's failure to develop a small car earlier is only one of several embarrassing mistakes. Overconfidence when the venture broke up, for example, resulted in extravagant spending by local managers. They started by opening a new headquarters in one of the most expensive skyscrapers in Sao Paulo, renting 10 floors at an annual cost of $1 million a floor. New executives sent down from Ford's headquarters in Dearborn, Mich., have now broken the lease, laying off hundreds of salaried workers and moving the rest into unused office space at a Ford assembly plant on the city's outskirts.
"Frankly, being part of an auto company is having the feel of it," said James J. Padilla, Ford's new corporate vice president for Brazil and Argentina, who has his offices at the Sao Paulo assembly plant.
Ford's South American operations hit bottom on Dec. 29, when a huge explosion destroyed one end of the assembly plant here in Pacheco, killing one worker and injuring four others while shattering cars, walls and the roof across an indoor area the size of a football field.
While large explosions sometimes happen in oil refineries and chemical factories, they are rare in auto assembly plants. Ford officials acknowledge some responsibility for the accident, which occurred when gasoline leaked over a weekend from fuel pumps at the end of the assembly line, forming a foot-deep pool that ignited when workers tried to clean it up.
"The maintenance procedures and operating procedures for the fuel pumps were not totally safe," said Jorge T. Mostany, president of Ford of Argentina.
Still, Ford's fortunes in South America have begun to improve. The company is starting to benefit from cost-cutting and from a $2.6 billion program to rebuild factories. It is also introducing new models previously sold only in Europe.
Ford's market share in Argentina jumped four percentage points in the first quarter, making it the market leader after finishing in fourth place last year. The company's losses in Brazil have also narrowed. Rival auto executives credit Ford's new models here and to the company's decision to send in what one analyst called a "S.W.A.T. team" of star managers.
Mr. Padilla used to head manufacturing and engineering at Jaguar, a Ford subsidiary whose quality problems he is widely credited with fixing. Mr. Silva was one of the few marketing executives at Autolatina to try, if unsuccessfully, to persuade Ford officials that they were making a mistake in ignoring the small-car market. And James L. Solberg, the new manufacturing director for Ford's Latin American operations, used to be the president of Ford's joint venture with Mazda at Flat Rock, Mich., a test ground for the application of Japanese management principles in the United States.
Their first step has been to lay off nearly a third of the work force, because Ford's factories here have not been operating at full capacity; employment in the two nations is now about 11,000.
New models, three years in the planning, are also selling well. The subcompact Ka, designed for sale in countries where many people can barely afford any vehicle, has been an immediate hit. Less than 12 feet long, the Ka has better handling and performance than larger but older models like the Fiesta and the Escort, and sells for $10,000 to $14,000. Mr. Nasser, a collector of antique watches, personally designed the oval, analog clock on the dashboard, an elegant improvement on the digital readouts in most small cars.
As Ford's market share starts to recover, particularly in Argentina, even some Volkswagen dealers have envied their Ford rivals. "They have the models that people want at the prices they want," said Roberto Senese, the sales manager at a Volkswagen dealership in Buenos Aires.
Narrowing losses in South America are one reason that Ford posted sharply higher worldwide first-quarter earnings on April 16. Yet while the losses here have become less horrendous, Ford officials do not expect their South American operations to break even until next year.
So while less gloomy than a year ago, Ford executives remain rueful that the breakup of Autolatina has produced so many problems. "The dissolution was very difficult," Mr. Padilla said. "More difficult than we ever anticipated."

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Murdoch Bids for Dodgers Simply to Bolster a Lineup

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
If Rupert Murdoch's Fox Group is able to acquire the Los Angeles Dodgers, the team would move from the hands of the O'Malley family, whose only business has been baseball, into the embrace of an aggressive conglomerate that wants to use the team to enhance its domestic and global media interests.
Fox is now in exclusive negotiations with Peter O'Malley, the Dodgers' owner, and Murdoch said in Tokyo on Wednesday that he hoped to complete a deal in a month for a $350 million purchase price. 
 "I think of this as network-building and empire-building," said Andrew Zimbalist, a sports finance expert and a professor of economics at Smith College, "because at the price being quoted, it's not understandable as an investment in a baseball franchise."
Financial World has placed a value of $178 million on the team and stadium, but did not calculate the value of the land beneath and around the stadium, some of the most valuable in Los Angeles, or the team's training facilities in Florida and the Dominican Republic. Still, Michael Ozanian, the magazine's deputy editor, said that ownership by Fox would be a huge coup. "It's not such a crazy price," he said. "The Dodgers already make a ton of money, but it's an old stadium."
Dodger Stadium, which opened in 1962, was built for $18 million.
Fox is the antithesis of the O'Malley-run Dodgers. Murdoch loves to ski and sail, and accumulate media properties like The New York Post, sometimes for profit, sometimes for political power. Murdoch's bid for the Dodgers shows more his lust for acquiring content for his empire than his love for American sports. And it is cheaper than the $395 million yearly fee Fox is paying for National Football League TV rights.
The Dodgers, and nothing else, comprise the entire business realm of the low-key O'Malley, last of the baseball scions. Forty-seven years ago, Peter O'Malley's father, Walter, paid $1.4 million to take control of the Dodgers; at $350 million, Murdoch would be paying 250 times more.
It is a very different world now, where only the richest people or corporations can afford the indulgence of a sports franchise, and where multinational companies like Murdoch's or Time Warner see a baseball team as software, not a public trust.
"The Dodgers always kept their prices low and their business simple," said Peter Bavasi, a former executive with the Dodgers and other clubs. "They were just in the baseball business. But when you pay $350 million, you have $35 million in cash flow to generate, so you have to maximize your returns by maximizing your revenues."
Dodger Stadium, now in its 36th season, would likely be Fox's first outpost of change, with the first-time construction of luxury suites and club seats and the possible expansion of signs beyond two Coca-Cola signs atop the Mitsubishi electronic scoreboards. Ticket prices, which average $11.16 this year, below the $11.98 major league average, are usually among the lowest in baseball. They could increase in time under Fox.
"The family has jealously guarded the look of Dodger Stadium since the day it opened," said Tom Villante, a former head of broadcasting for Major League Baseball, and now a consultant. "But Murdoch would be foolish not to test some new ideas."
More than anything else, Fox's bid for the Dodgers is a television play, one that would create the kind of vertical integration enjoyed by Time Warner and the Tribune Company. Time Warner owns the Atlanta Braves and TBS, the cable superstation that carries 125 Braves games. Tribune owns the Chicago Cubs and WGN, another cable superstation, which telecasts 140 Cubs games.
Fox already televises major league games through the Fox Network, one of baseball's national broadcast partners, and through FX and the Fox Sports Net, its national cable outlets.
Traditionally, the Dodgers have avoided selling the TV rights to the majority of their games, reasoning that they should not sacrifice attendance, usually among baseball's highest, for viewership. This season, only 48 games are available on KTLA-TV, a broadcast station, and 40 on Fox Sports West 2, Fox's regional cable sports network.
That would certainly change with Fox as the owner. "No question, there would be more games," said Marc Ganis, the president of SportsCorp Ltd., a Chicago-based consulting firm. "It would be more Tribune-like, with virtually every game on TV. More programming -- and that's what the games are -- means more commercial inventory. The more it makes from advertising, the more valuable the cable network becomes."
Murdoch undoubtedly has designs for his potential acquisition beyond Southern California, where he could market the Dodgers, with Asian stars like Hideo Nomo and Chan Ho Park, and Hispanic stars like Raul Mondesi, to his growing international satellite sports television holdings in Japan, Asia, Latin America, Australia and Europe.
Murdoch would not enter baseball without some corporate enemies. Ted Turner, the Time Warner vice chairman, has likened the Australian-born Murdoch to Adolf Hitler because of his business practices and once promised to squash Murdoch "like a bug."
And Murdoch is at legal odds with the Walt Disney Company, which owns 25 percent of the Anaheim Angels with an option to buy the rest. Several months ago, Disney sued Fox to stop the movement of games of Disney's hockey team, the Mighty Ducks, from Fox Sports West, an established regional sports channel, to a new offshoot with fewer subscribers, Fox Sports West 2. Fox countered with a lawsuit alleging that Disney had conspired with cable systems to keep Fox Sports West 2 from being carried.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Rupert Murdoch's Fox Group would likely seek some changes in Dodger Stadium. (Elsa Hasch/Allsport)

HEADLINE: After a Veto, Pataki Offers His Own Solar-Panel Plan

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
Seven months after he vetoed a similar bill, Gov. George E. Pataki offered his own proposal yesterday to allow New Yorkers to install rooftop solar panels and sell excess electricity back to their utilities, earning credit on their electric bills.
The Governor's bill also offers a tax credit to spur homeowners to invest in the expensive technology. Mr. Pataki also added requirements for safety features that could prevent electric shocks to line workers during a power failure. 
 Last October, the Governor said the lack of these requirements was the basis for his veto, which was sharply criticized by environmentalists.
New York State residents currently may use solar panels only if they are not connected to the main power grid. About 15 states, including California and all of New England, already allow homeowners essentially to become small-scale solar power plants, running their electric meters backward and sending the power back to their utilities when they generate more than they use.
"Clean solar energy can and should play a more significant role in meeting New York State's energy needs," Mr. Pataki said in a written statement.
Legislators who back the concept said they were optimistic that a solar-power bill would win passage this year. But some environmentalists expressed concern that the tax-credit provisions in the Governor's plan might stir opposition and hurt the measure's chances.
Steven C. Englebright, a Democratic Assemblyman from East Setauket, who sponsored the vetoed bill, said, "I'm pleased that the Governor has belatedly come to the position that was made available to him last year."
Mr. Pataki's bill -- like the versions passed by the Legislature last year -- would cap at about 30,000 the number of households that could have solar panels connected to the grid. Even so, energy experts said such a law could help cut energy costs and avert blackouts on scorching summer days.
Photovoltaic cells produce the most power at just those times of the day and year when demand for air conditioning drains existing supplies in New York City, Long Island and much of New England, said Thomas Thompson, the executive director of the Northeast Sustainable Energy Association, a private group based in Massachusetts that represents users and installers of solar cells.
"You don't think of New York when you think solar power, but it's really ideal," Mr. Thompson said. Energy costs in and around New York City are far higher than the national average, making solar panels -- despite the initial high cost -- a boon in the long run, he said.
Allowing reversible meters for solar power in a big state like New York is also likely to increase the demand for photovoltaic panels, spurring mass production, which could then lower the price of the systems, said Larry Sherwood, executive director of the American Solar Energy Society, in Boulder, Colo. Probably fewer than 1,000 households across the country send solar power back to their electric companies, he said. But that number could quickly swell if the cost of a panel of photovoltaic cells and related equipment -- now around $15,000 -- continues to drop.
Mr. Pataki's bill would lower the initial investment further by offering a personal income tax credit for 25 percent of the cost of a system, up to a ceiling of $3,750.
Mr. Englebright said that the tax credit would have to be carefully studied by the Assembly Ways and Means Committee to see if it made economic sense. He added that the benefit from a tax credit appeared to conflict with another provision of Mr. Pataki's bill that would allow a utility to collect up to $350 from a customer for the cost of connecting such a system to power lines.
But some environmental groups expressed concern that the tax provisions could hurt the bill. Larry Shapiro, a lawyer for the New York Public Interest Research Group, a private organization, said, "It's the kind of thing he knows the Assembly will reject. It makes me think it's an attempt to posture rather than getting something enacted into law."
But others sided with Mr. Pataki. Ashok Gupta, a lawyer and energy expert for the Natural Resources Defense Council who helped write the new bill as well as last year's version, said, "This is a very important step in getting clean energy sources into New York."
New York's electric utilities, although not yet privy to details of Mr. Pataki's new proposal, continued to oppose the idea of allowing metered solar power, said Howard Shapiro, president of the Energy Association of New York, a lobby representing the state's eight largest investor-owned power providers. He said utilities would in essence be subsidizing expensive solar-power systems for wealthy customers, passing on costs to poorer customers.

HEADLINE: $25 Million In Endowment To Be Sought By A.C.L.U.

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER 

 BODY:
The American Civil Liberties Union, the nation's oldest and largest civil liberties group, is preparing to announce on Sunday its first endowment campaign, with the goal of raising $25 million by 1999, $10 million of which has already been raised.
Joining thousands of other nonprofit groups trying to take advantage of a strong economy and booming stock market, the A.C.L.U. is seeking the endowment, or what it calls a "trust for the Bill of Rights," to insure future financial stability and end what the group acknowledges is its extreme vulnerability to shifts in the nation's political and economic climate. 
 "Even a 1 percent drop in annual contributions creates a $350,000 gap that can be met only by reducing program and staff," the group says in its "gold book," which describes the campaign to prospective donors. At its high point of annual cash flow, the group has only a six-week reserve in its current annual budget of $35 million, the gold book says.
The largest contribution to the endowment so far has come from the LuEsther T. Mertz Charitable Trust, which last November gave the campaign $2 million. Robert Crane, president of the Joyce Mertz Gilmore Foundation, which administers the trust, said an endowment would enable the A.C.L.U. "to continue taking on the tough and often unpopular issues it has taken on in the past."
The civil liberties group, like so many advocacy organizations, has tended almost by definition to think more about programs than fund-raising, Mr. Crane said.
"And because it is a principled organization that has taken on some very controversial issues -- from defending gay rights to freedom of speech for Nazis in Skokie, Ill. -- it has been even harder to raise money," Mr. Crane added. "So launching this endowment drive is an important maturation point for the A.C.L.U."
The organization, with its headquarters in New York, has more than 300 chapters and some 275,000 members whose contributions, along with foundation grants, provide virtually all of its annual budget, 80 percent of which supports litigation, lobbying and public education programs. Fund-raising accounts for about 12 percent of the budget, and administration costs for the remaining 8 percent. Members pay $20 in annual fees, but the average contribution is about $50 a member.
The group will formally announce the new campaign in a full-page newspaper advertisement on Sunday. But Woody Kaplan, a member of the A.C.L.U.'s national board and one of the campaign's six co-chairmen, said that he and several others active in the group began asking about 50 supporters for endowment gifts a year ago.
"We've got an overwhelmingly positive response, perhaps because people feel that their rights and liberties are under systematic attack," said Mr. Kaplan, a real estate developer in Boston who has pledged $1 million to the campaign, the largest gift so far from an individual.
The group has enlisted celebrities as honorary co-chairmen and co-chairwomen. Among them are Whoopi Goldberg, Phil Donahue, Rob Reiner, Marlo Thomas and Barbra Streisand, as well as scholars like Henry Louis Gates Jr. and politicians like Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the former Governor of Connecticut.
The A.C.L.U., founded in 1920, has been a litigant in most of what became landmark civil liberties cases, from the Scopes "monkey trial" over the teaching of evolution in 1925 to its victory last year in the Supreme Court decision in Romer v. Evans, involving equal rights for lesbians and gay men. Last year it challenged the Clinton Administration's Communications Decency Act, contending that the Federal Government has no right to censor ostensibly "indecent" material on the Internet.
The group's low point came in 1977, when it defended the rights of neo-Nazis to demonstrate in Skokie, a heavily Jewish suburb of Chicago. Though the court upheld its argument, thousands of A.C.L.U. members resigned in fury and contributions plunged, leaving the group nearly $500,000 in debt in 1978.
But the crisis was what Samuel Walker, a professor of criminal justice at the University of Nebraska, called in his history of the group "a blessing in disguise" in that it "exposed a host of organizational problems" and forced the A.C.L.U. to overhaul its operations.
Membership, now at a record high, is still growing, but slowly.
Ira Glasser, the A.C.L.U.'s national director since the furor over the Skokie case, called the campaign "the culmination of the rebuilding that began after Skokie." The climate is now right for a successful endowment drive, he added, because "we are in the midst of a 15-year siege to reverse the gains in civil rights and liberties of the Warren Supreme Court."

HEADLINE: WHITE HOUSE CALLS FOR MINIMUM WAGE IN WORKFARE PLAN

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 15

 BODY:
Weighing in on one of the most contentious issues from last year's landmark welfare bill, the White House said today that most of the recipients being placed in work programs should be covered by minimum-wage laws.
The long-awaited legal interpretation drew surprised and angry response from governors of both parties and from the authors of the welfare law, who said it had the potential to gut the legislation's work requirements. 
 Applying the minimum wage, they said, would vastly increase the cost of running work programs and leave most states unable to enroll the required number of recipients. Critics say it could also reduce the incentive for workfare participants to leave the rolls for private jobs.
"This could really hamper what we're trying to do," said Representative E. Clay Shaw Jr., Republican of Florida, the main author of the bill. "It could drastically cut back the hours that welfare recipients are required to work."
Gov. Thomas Carper of Delaware, a Democrat, said that if the interpretation held, states would either have to raise their benefits or reduce their work programs at the risk of Federal penalty. "It's an untenable position to put a state in," he said.
The issue, which has been the subject of lengthy, behind-the-scenes discussion, arose from what amounts to an oversight in drafting the legislation. While previous welfare laws explicitly outlined when minimum wage laws applied, the current law is silent.
Focusing on the issue months ago, labor leaders argued that workfare recipients were covered by the Fair Labor Standards Act, which requires the minimum wage in most cases. In late February, the Labor Department drafted a confidential report backing the unions' interpretation, and after months of study, the White House has agreed, although with what may be limited enthusiasm.
"Our reading of the Fair Labor Standards Act is that it covers workfare recipients," Bruce Reed, the White House domestic policy adviser, said today in an interview.
Mr. Reed, a strong supporter of work requirements, disagreed with those who said the interpretation would leave states unable to put welfare recipients to work. "Most recipients would be earning the minimum wage anyway," he said.
The decision is the second in recent weeks in which the White House has sided with union leaders on issues arising from the welfare bill. On May 2, the Administration barred a Texas plan that would have given private corporations a broad new role in providing social services.
That decision was made by President Clinton himself, after an Oval Office appeal from the leaders of public employees' unions, whose jobs would have been at risk. It was widely interpreted as an effort to repay the union leaders who have supported the Democratic Party.
By contrast, it was unclear whether today's development stemmed from political considerations or mostly from a technical reading of the nation's labor laws.
While expressing concern about the decision, Mr. Shaw declined to interpret it as a sign of waning Presidential support for work requirements. "I still feel the President is a full partner on welfare reform," he said. "If the White House thinks their hands are tied by the current labor laws and wants us to fix it, we'll do that."
Mr. Reed declined to comment on whether the White House would support legislation that exempted workfare programs from minimum wage laws.
The debate over the Fair Labor Standards Act is being closely watched because it may offer clues about whether welfare recipients are covered by other labor laws as well. In some states, for instance, workers covered by the labor act are automatically eligible for workers' compensation and unemployment insurance.
Mr. Reed said a similar issue had delayed a formal announcement of Administration policy. He said he was waiting for the Treasury Department to decide whether workfare participants qualified for the earned income tax credit, a wage supplement that offers low-wage workers cash payments of up to $3,300 a year.
Applying the fair labor law may also set precedents that make it easier for labor leaders to organize recipients into unions.
Among the issues remaining to be clarified is how the wage would be calculated. The average cash welfare benefit is about $370 a month, meaning recipients could not be required to work more than 77 hours a month -- or 19 hours a week -- at the minimum wage of $4.75 an hour.
But the welfare law requires most recipients to work 20 hours a week in 1997, rising to 30 hours by 2000.
But Mr. Reed said that under some circumstances, states could also include the value of food stamps when calculating the effective wage. That would increase the estimated "wages" paid to welfare recipients by hundreds of dollars a month. But a confidential background paper prepared by the Department of Labor suggests that food stamps could be counted only in certain limited circumstances.
Since welfare recipients also receive Medicaid, Mr. Shaw said the value of that program should also be considered part of the wage. But the Labor Department paper said the value of Medicaid would not apply.
Mr. Reed's comments came in an interview today, and the White House has not publicly released the pivotal, technical details.
The fair labor law would require the minimum wage to apply when workfare participants are engaged in a traditional "employee-employer" relationship. While that would appear to cover most work programs, it would not apply if recipients were engaged in educational or training activities.
In March, the American Public Welfare Association passed a unanimous resolution urging that workfare programs be exempt from the labor act. The organization represents the state officials who run welfare programs.
Public employee unions have long opposed workfare programs, in part because of concerns about worker displacement. They fear that local governments would be less likely to hire union members to rake leaves or sweep streets if workfare participants could be forced to do the same work at much lower wages.
Today's announcement marked the second union victory on that issue this week. In New York, a state judge ruled on Monday that participants in a city workfare program must be paid not only the minimum wage, but the "prevailing wage" paid to other public employees, or as much as $8 or $9 an hour.
While today's decision may ease some of the union's concerns, it may make private employers less enthusiastic about hiring welfare recipients.
"It adds terrific costs," said Gov. John Engler of Michigan, a Republican who helped design the welfare law. "If we're going to tell every employer, 'Oh, by the way, we're going to have a Federal auditor here,' that's going to be a terrific disincentive" to hiring recipients.
Robert Rector, an analyst at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative research organization in Washington, said the decision to apply minimum wage laws would cripple the work requirements. "That's a gangland execution of welfare reform," he said. "You want to make welfare less attractive than low-skilled jobs. You want to increase the incentive for people to get off the rolls as quickly as possible."
But the founder of one influential work program disagreed. Peter Cove, the founder of America Works, said treating welfare recipients as traditional workers "tells them that they're being valued, and that's terribly important."
 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (92%);

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Lower Against Yen, But Manages to Stabilize a Bit

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar ended mostly lower yesterday but steadied against the yen for the first time since its frenetic slide began more than a week ago, helped by rumors of central bank sales of the Japanese currency.
Although the dollar still finished with a slight loss against the yen for the day, traders were buying dollars as the week drew to a close, a sign that some believe the dollar may be stabilizing. 
 "There was talk that the Bank of England was buying dollars against yen, or selling yen against other currencies on behalf of the Bank of Japan," said Dieter Bluhm, vice president of foreign exchange at Wells Fargo Bank in San Francisco. "It came from various sources, and it isn't completely out of the question that they have indeed done that."
Central banks typically do not comment on whether they have intervened in the foreign-exchange markets.
In New York, the dollar finished at 115.55 yen, down from 116.10 yen on Thursday, but up from its intraday low of 114.85 yen. It was the first time in more than a week that the decline was less than one yen. The dollar fell to 1.6925 marks from 1.6988 marks. The pound fell to $1.6367 from $1.6426.
The dollar received a temporary boost from a Commerce Department report of surprisingly strong housing construction in April, which contributed to speculation that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates at its policy-making meeting on Tuesday. Doubts that the Fed would raise rates had been contributing to the dollar's decline.
But the dollar faded as the stock market reacted badly to the Commerce Department report, and pushed the Dow Jones average down nearly 140 points.
Since hitting a four-and-a-half-year high of 127.46 yen May 1, the dollar has dropped about 11 yen, or nearly 9 percent.
Much of that decline came after May 8, when signs of higher interest rates in Japan, a slower United States economy and warnings from Japanese officials about an undervalued yen caused the biggest dollar selloff in nearly two years.
Japanese officials have since toned down their comments, a sign they fear the dollar's decline has gone too far.
