HEADLINE: Entrenched Problems in the Emerging Peruvian Market

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru

 BODY:
Bruce Heafitz made and lost a $50 million fortune in the oil business in the United States in the 1980's and then regained much of it, only to sink millions into an ill-fated venture to look for sunken ships, ancient Egyptian tombs and other lost treasures.
For those setbacks, he had only himself and the uncertainties of the marketplace to blame. Now, though, he said he was discovering a daunting new challenge to his entrepreneurial ambitions: bureaucracy and high-level cronyism in countries that are emerging markets. 
 Two years ago, Mr. Heafitz said, he settled on Peru as the ideal target to export one of America's hottest businesses of the 1990's -- gambling. The Government had recently relaxed restrictions on gambling, and private casinos, bingo parlors and slot-machine houses were springing up throughout the country. With a group of investors, he opened an entertainment complex in the affluent Miraflores district of Lima in 1995, and it became an immediate hit.
But what initially appeared to be a royal flush has turned out to be one of the worst wagers of Mr. Heafitz's career. Soon after the complex -- a bingo parlor and nightclub -- opened, he become embroiled in legal disputes because of what he regarded as corruption and intimidation.
The upshot? Mr. Heafitz has closed the bingo parlor and may have to shut down the disco, too. He said he stood to lose $5 million in start-up costs and was accused of what he said were a variety of trumped up charges.
When Mr. Heafitz started going about setting up his gambling emporium in Peru -- with a group of investors who ran a fleet of casino ships off Florida -- it seemed that the venture would go smoothly. He quickly cut a deal with Augusto Miyagusuku, head of the Government insurance company and a close friend of President Alberto K. Fujimori, to find space for his business in a prime location.
Mr. Miyagusuku showed Mr. Heafitz five properties owned by the insurance company, known as Popular y Porvenir, and Mr. Heafitz agreed to lease a building for $50,000 a month. After spending his "last pennies" to refurbish it, he said, he opened the American Bingo parlor and the adjoining disco in 1995. The entertainment complex quickly started to pull in 30,000 people a month and to make a hefty profit, he said.
But even as the venture seemed to be headed for business success, legal problems cropped up. First, Inca Tursa, the insurance company's real estate affiliate and Mr. Heafitz's partner in the leasing contract, informed him that he was in violation of their joint operating agreement and instructed him to vacate the building.
A letter from the state insurance company followed, saying he had no rights to be in the building because the company had canceled its contract with Inca Tursa. Then, a Peruvian court ordered him to vacate. A legal battled followed, with both sides suing for breach of contract.
Though Mr. Heafitz is appealing the court's ruling, he has already discharged 100 employees after shutting down the bingo parlor. He plans to close his disco, one of the most popular nightspots in Lima, if the case is not resolved soon.
Meantime, he said, he is being harassed by the Peruvian military and the police, who follow him, linger near his apartment and sometimes cut the electric power to the disco during prime hours. And he has been indicted on charges of fraud and violating city building codes by a prosecutor who he says is friendly with Mr. Miyagusuku.
What went wrong? By Mr. Heafitz's account, which is supported by officials of the United States Embassy here, the Government simply saw how much money he was making and decided to take over his business. And, he added, he has had little recourse because the leasing agreement the Government drew up is convoluted and, more to the point, because no one in Peru, not even the courts, is willing to cross a friend of the President.
"We've crapped out because the odds were stacked so heavily against us," Mr. Heafitz said. "This should serve as a warning to investors seeking to do business in Peru. You are very, very vulnerable because there is no justice."
The state insurance company declined to respond to repeated requests for its reaction to Mr. Heafitz's accusations. Mr. Fujimori's office and the Peruvian military likewise refused to comment.
But senior officials at the United States Embassy, speaking on condition of anonymity, confirmed the main outlines of his story. They said his case underscored the risk American companies, especially small and midsize concerns, face when doing business in countries with weak judicial systems.
And the Peruvian justice system is notoriously corrupt, with many judges quick to accept or demand bribes and most judges vulnerable to pressure from the Government, the embassy officials said.
"We appealed to Government officials and trade associations on Mr. Heafitz's behalf, but it was too hot a potato for anyone in Peru to pursue," one official said. "The response to our appeals was always the same: 'Miyagusuku is the godfather of Fujimori's kids, and the President's mother lives in one of his apartments. What do you expect me to do?' "
The embassy's commercial section said it spent about 25 percent of its time helping American companies resolve legal disputes, mainly involving accusations, by Peruvians, of fraud or late payments.
The embassy said Peru remained a good place to make medium- and long-term investments, but it recommended that American businesses get an agreement to resolve any legal disputes in another country.
And such situations are not unique to Peru or Latin America. Variations of the Heafitz case are known in emerging markets in Asia, Eastern Europe and Africa.
Mr. Heafitz partly blamed his own naivete for his troubles. Because he was introduced to Mr. Miyagusuku by a former Governor of Florida, Bob Martinez, he said, he looked on the Peruvian official's involvement as a guarantee of smooth sailing.
And he signed a complicated leasing contract he did not fully understand because Mr. Miyagusuku assured him it was standard procedure in Peru, he said. Embassy officials agreed that Mr. Heafitz should have exercised more caution about the agreement.
For his part, the 56-year-old American entrepreneur said he was not about to give up. "If eventually we have to close up shop here," he said, "I'm taking all these fancy disco lights and slot machines and opening up across town."

HEADLINE: An African Tyrant Departs

 BODY:
President Mobutu Sese Seko no doubt fled Kinshasa yesterday to save his life and his fortune rather than to spare Zaire a final spasm of violence as rebel forces closed in on the capital. Anything else would have been out of character for a man who misruled his country for nearly 32 years, impoverishing his people as he skimmed millions, perhaps billions of dollars from the Government to enrich himself.
His was a destructive and flamboyant dictatorship, sustained with the cynical assistance of the United States and France. Few cold-war alliances reflected so poorly on those involved. Mr. Mobutu ran his resource-rich country like a satrap, smothering political opposition, selling off its minerals for the benefit of a few and demanding a fawning allegiance that often bordered on parody. Washington accepted the abuses as the price of maintaining a cold-war ally, and France was happy to use Mr. Mobutu to retain its influence and economic links in Central Africa. 
 Zaire deserves better, but may not get it. Rebels who have fought a successful seven-month campaign will assume power in the days ahead without governing experience or a clear commitment to democracy and the rule of law. Their leader, Laurent Kabila, has conducted a scorched-earth offensive, permitting the killing of Hutu refugees from Rwanda by his Tutsi commanders. Mr. Kabila has assured Western diplomats he does not intend to copy Mr. Mobutu's methods, but the brutal behavior of his followers in recent months belies those words.
Mr. Kabila can set a different pattern by dealing humanely with the remnants of the Mobutu court and moving quickly to demonstrate that he is more interested in governance than revenge. Thousands of Rwandan refugees remain trapped in Zaire, and Mr. Kabila must do everything he can to prevent his troops from attacking them and impeding the work of international relief organizations.
It will take years for Zaire to recover from the Mobutu regime, even under enlightened leadership. An immediate effort should be made to freeze Mr. Mobutu's assets in Europe and anywhere else he placed them. His fortune alone could give Zaire an economic boost. The only pity is that his sacking of Zaire did not end years ago.

HEADLINE: About New York;
News Vendors Face Prospect Of Last Stand

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
ADAM PETRELLA'S newsstand sits on the northwest corner of Canal Street and the Bowery. He calls it Petrella's Point and gussies it up with bright red paint and drawings of Bruce Lee, Marilyn Monroe and the Shroud of Turin.
"This corner is like the end of the world," said Mr. Petrella above the rude roar of the trucks rumbling past. "If you stood here for 10 minutes, you'd see that every other person who comes here is completely lost." 
 To help, he painted a sign with handy directions: "Essex Street, Where Jewish People Used to Be -- Seven Blocks East. Little Italy, Where Italians Used to Be -- Two Blocks North."
Those tips might be replaced by a final one: "Petrella's Point -- Where Adam Used To Be -- You're Standing On It."
Yesterday Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani signed into law new rules governing sidewalk newsstands, increasing the annual fee charged the city's 330 vendors from $538 to as much as $5,000, depending on the location. The law also provides for 100 more stands to be put out for competitive bids. Current renters will have five years before the city decides whether to continue renting the stands or to seek bids.
The law is part of the initiative to replace current street furniture (newsstands and bus shelters) with new streamlined versions that will be built by the company that wins a 20-year city contract. The new items and 30 public toilets will be financed by selling advertising space on them, generating hundreds of millions for whoever gets the contract.
MR. PETRELLA wonders when he'll become a victim of design and progress.
"That's what I'm afraid of," he said. "I was going to put a sign above the stand saying 'Endangered Species.' "
Supporters of the move said it will lend a sense of style and order to sidewalks marred by ramshackle stands, as well as bring the city millions in revenue. Administration officials also said it would maximize the income earned by the city for limited public space.
"We suspect there are locations that can bring in over $100,000 a year," said Craig Muraskin, director of policy for the Deputy Mayor for Economic Development and Planning. "We hope to show that the people of the city are best served by a free market-based competitive system that will bring in an appropriate amount of money."
The group representing most of Manhattan's newsstand operators is content with the agreement. But Steven Stollman, a former newsstand builder and operator with a soft spot for newsies, has rallied a small number of them who are afraid for their livelihoods and alarmed by what they see as a process in which too many details have yet to be explained.
"For many people, this has been a marginal living," he said. "If the dealer's rent is regulated at $5,000 a year, his landlord can dispute him and create a situation where he might have to pay thousands more. You're talking about a huge prize to get rid of these stands."
TAI LEE, who spends 12 hours a day at a stand in Chinatown, said that the Chinese-language papers he specializes in do not make him enough money to pay the increased fees. Lotto sales help, but winning it would probably be the only guarantee for his future.
Mr. Stollman thinks the whole process has been entered into too quickly, a point he has made at numerous forums. And while the city touts the free and improved street furniture, he is worried about a blizzard of advertising on look-alike stands.
"This is mall furniture," he said. "New York should strive to maintain its uniqueness. We shouldn't accept these things that are the same like Des Moines or even Paris."
Mr. Stollman said the outsides of stands and shelters could be improved, and you don't have to look overseas, either.
"We're in Fort Knox when it comes to design, and we are rich beyond belief," he said. "We could do it in a New York kind of way. We have so many artists and designers who can render objects in our common spaces. Each could be unique and it could be the result of what each community decides is best in its judgment."
Mr. Petrella and eight other vendors joined Mr. Stollman yesterday at City Hall to protest the law. Nothing changed.
"This just means a headache in trying to figure out a way to make a living," Mr. Petrella said. "In fact, today I was wondering if I should begin looking for another job." He has a stack of classifieds he could thumb through, gratis. He has a newsstand.

HEADLINE: Starts of Housing Up 2.6%, But Key Category Is Weak

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
Construction of single-family houses was weak last month, providing another sign of economic slowing. But a survey found that consumer confidence remained strong.
The Commerce Department said today that housing starts over all rose 2.6 percent in April, to an annual rate of 1.473 million, exceeding analysts' expectations. But almost all of the gain came in the volatile category of apartment construction. Starts on multifamily projects increased 10.9 percent from March, while single-family housing starts rose just three-tenths of 1 percent. 
 Moreover, the number of applications for construction permits fell.
"This is really another sign of moderation in the economy," said Eileen Neely, manager of economic forecasting at Fannie Mae. "Single-family starts were a little bit weaker than most analysts expected."
Still, real estate markets have been bolstered by the highest levels of consumer confidence in the economy in decades, the lowest unemployment rate in almost a quarter- century and record gains in the stock market. The University of Michigan said today that its preliminary index of consumer sentiment for May climbed to 104.6 from 101.4 last month; the rise is the fourth consecutive monthly increase.
The gain in consumer confidence suggested that the March decision by Federal Reserve policy makers to push up interest rates "hasn't diminished household spirits," said Kevin Flanagan, money market economist at Dean Witter Reynolds.
While that might give the Fed pause, other economists pointed to the housing numbers as an indication that growth has moderated. "When you look at the level of starts, we are right in the range that the Fed would like," said Mark Vitner, an economist at the First Union Corporation in Charlotte, N.C. "It doesn't look like home building is going to be an engine of growth."
Taken together, today's economic reports added to the uncertainty about whether the policy makers will raise interest rates when they meet next week. Recent data have provided a mixed picture of the prospects for an acceleration in inflation.
The 2.6 percent increase in housing starts in April followed a decline in March, which was revised today to a 7.7 percent drop from the 6.4 percent reported previously.
Though construction this year may not beat 1996's level, which was the highest in eight years, starts remain strong because demand in parts of the country is exceeding the supply of new homes, analysts said.
Additionally, the Midwest flooding restrained starts in March and April, possibly setting the stage for the "mother of all rebounds in May or June," said Ian Shepherson, an economist at HSBC Securities Inc. in New York. Permits for new construction will also rebound, he said.
By region, housing starts rose 11.3 percent in the South and seven-tenths of 1 percent in the Midwest. Starts fell 7.4 percent in the Northeast and 6.5 percent in the West.
Looking ahead, home builders expect the housing industry to hold its own, according to a survey by the National Association of Home Builders, although their optimism slipped a bit this month. The trade group's housing market index, released on Thursday, declined to 54 in May from 56 in April.
"We are optimistic," said James Martell Jr., president and chief executive of Fortress Group Inc., a home builder in Vienna, Va., that has reported a 70 percent increase in revenue for the first quarter. "Working through our backlog will result in strong closings and revenues in the second half of 1997."
Relatively low mortgage rates are helping the market. Although the average rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage rose to 8.14 percent in April from 7.9 percent in March, rates are below last summer's levels.

HEADLINE: Bond Prices Off as Traders Warily Await Fed Meeting

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
With the Federal Reserve's meeting on interest rates drawing near, bond market participants became more sensitive to economic data yesterday and sold off after reports showed strength in housing and a rise in consumer sentiment.
The data kept alive market concerns that the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's policy group, was likely to raise short-term rates on Tuesday to slow growth and keep inflation from heating up. Despite yesterday's market action, dealers, traders and investors remained split over what the Fed would do. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 15/32 , to 96 17/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.90 percent from 6.86 percent.
Treasury prices fell after the Commerce Department reported that housing starts rose 2.6 percent in April, more than the rise of one-tenth of 1 percent that analysts had been expecting. But nearly all of the gain came in apartment construction, and the number of building permits fell.
"This mixed report on housing starts and building permits does not indicate the sort of strength that would lead the Federal Reserve to tighten short-term rates" next week, said Maury N. Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber Inc. "What should be more important to the Fed is the recent reported softness in April retail sales and industrial production, which represent far larger slices of the economy than housing."
Kenneth J. McCarthy, founder of the Economic Intelligence Company, a consulting firm, said housing starts were healthy, but not excessive. "For the Fed, this is the last piece of economic information before next week's F.O.M.C. meeting," he said. "The data of the past six weeks have been a mixed bag, with a lot of indications that the economy has slowed after the December-through-February spurt, including slower sales and employment growth, declining orders and low inflation and labor-cost increases. But there have been some signs of continuing growth, including housing's persisting strength and high levels of consumer confidence."
Indeed, bond prices weakened further after the University of Michigan's preliminary index of consumer sentiment for May showed a reading of 104.6, up sharply from a reading of 101.4 in April, traders said. (The report is released only to paying subscribers.) The jump suggested to some investors that the Fed's decision to raise short-term interest rates on March 25 by a quarter of a percentage point had not diminished the enthusiasm of consumers.
Kathleen Camilli, director of economic research at Tucker Anthony Inc., said the bond market had paused over new evidence that economic growth might not be decelerating as rapidly as previously anticipated.
"However, I wouldn't be surprised to see a strong rally in the bond market after the F.O.M.C. meeting, because if the Fed tightens, then market participants will perceive the move as the last tightening for a while, and thus the bond market will rally," she said. "And if they don't, market participants will perceive it as a window of opportunity until the next meeting on July 1 and 2."
"So after the knee-jerk reaction, the market will rally regardless of whether they tighten or not," Ms. Camilli added.

HEADLINE: Liberties;
Waiting For Lefty

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD 

 BODY:
It was probably over the minute Jane Fonda married Ted Turner. But liberalism has continued its free fall out of fashion.
The Hollywood Women's Political Caucus has shut down. Mario Cuomo is reduced to debating Dan Quayle. The third generation of Kennedy men has muddied the liberal banner with swinish treatment of women -- in an era when the women are no longer willing to bury themselves in their church, their cups and their credit cards. 
 Embracing the rich and ignoring the poor is good politics. Richard Riordan swatted radical-turned-liberal Tom Hayden in the Los Angeles mayoral race, just as Rudolph Giuliani will swat liberal-still-liberal Ruth Messinger in New York.
Tony Blair says his generation of leaders has moved beyond ideology, beyond left and right. His first act as Prime Minister was to turn over Britain's monetary policy to the banks.
Bill Clinton, whose legacy will be doing away with welfare, preaches volunteerism instead of government. He struck a budget deal that analysts say will snuff out the big government spending without which liberalism is just nostalgia.
So liberals are definitely in spotted-owl land. Of course, there are still a few hardy souls left who are happy to call themselves left. And there is one who is even willing to prop up the fading ideology.
After investing with others in the liberal magazine The Nation in 1995 to revive it, Paul Newman has now become a kibitzing owner, writing the occasional rant. "Longhand on a yellow pad," he says.
His role as the last liberal suits him. In his movies he often played a guy fighting the system.
"If government is unable to give us government, it ought, at least, to give us a few laughs," Cool Hand Luke wrote recently. His first piece was a whimsical look at what would happen if Jesse Helms had to answer questions at his own confirmation hearing. His second mocked Newt Gingrich for proposing that rich people in Hollywood finance the N.E.A.
So far, he says dryly in a telephone interview, his liberal voice has amounted to "two hiccups." "But unless there's a noisy, vibrant voice on the left, people will think the center is to the right of Genghis Khan," he says. "We just got rid of Dornan and now we get Burton. They just keep popping out of rat holes."
He scorns the Republicans on culinary grounds as well. Al D'Amato's mother has a line of Mama D'Amato spaghetti sauce coming out that will compete with Newman's Own. "If D'Amato thinks he's getting into the spaghetti sauce business, he has another sauce coming," the actor/director/chef/race driver/philanthropist/journalist taunts. "Sinatra tried to run us out of the business with spaghetti sauces. It was not successful. D'Amato should stick to potholes. D'Amato and I ought to face off with meatballs at 15 feet."
Although Mr. Newman and his wife, Joanne Woodward, are friendly with Bill and Hillary Clinton, the actor was not full of praise for the President or other Democrats.
"Everything is about what's winnable, not about the morality of issues," he says. "They can't do anything courageous because they're protecting themselves for the next election. They come up with baby steps when they should be taking strides on core issues -- inner cities, race relations, the growing and stunning gap between rich and poor.
"With brave leadership, you might be forced to take positions on moral issues, even if there are adverse economic and political consequences. I've been contemplating racing cars again. I stopped because I was afraid I was too long in the tooth, that I wasn't quick enough. And then I decided, you can do anything if you are prepared to deal with the consequences."
He despairs at the failure to fix campaign finance, and at the White House's permanent campaign apparatus. "There's an old statement that disease protects itself," he says. "The system will go to any length to maintain its foothold, with cholesterol, alcohol, cocaine and pollsters."
He advises me to go see "Waiting for Lefty," an Off Broadway production of the archetypal proletariat play of the 30's, directed by Ms. Woodward. "The play is elemental and naive, but the passion is so focused, so relentless and uncompromising, that you're up yelling 'Strike!' at the end."
Uncompromising passion is a wonderful thing, but Lefty never met Dick Morris.

HEADLINE: For Market, a Rate Rise Now May Be Better Than None

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Will the Fed just wait?
That's the nagging question for investors ahead of Tuesday's meeting of the Federal Reserve's policy-making committee. 
 Indeed, for many on Wall Street, the only thing worse than the Fed's raising rates next week is the Fed's deciding not to raise rates. Why? Since many investors believe that at least one more rate increase this year is inevitable, it makes sense to them to get it out of the way now.
In contrast with March, when analysts were overwhelmingly convinced that the central bank would raise short-term interest rates rather than hold them steady, sentiment on Wall Street today is split about what the Fed will do. Inflation is practically nonexistent and the robust growth of the first quarter appears to be fading -- reasons for the Fed to hold off.
But if the Fed leaves its target rate at 5.5 percent on Tuesday, uncertainty may dog the financial markets and stocks and bonds are more likely to experience sharp ups and downs this summer, extending the roller-coaster ride of recent months.
"It makes for a more uncertain market and, therefore, the possibility of a more volatile market," said Richard Berner, the chief economist at the Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh.
Unless the economy slows much more than expected, every new economic report will be scoured for hints of what the Fed's policy makers will do when they gather again in July. And given the erratic nature of a lot of the Government's statistics, markets could be in for some wild swings.
What would be especially tough is a string of economic reports indicating that the slowdown in consumer spending in April was simply a pause rather than a genuine downshift in the exuberant pace of earlier this year. Traders would conclude that the economy was too strong for the Fed to feel confident that inflation would remain under control, reversing the sentiment underlying the recent rally. Interest rates would move higher and stock prices lower.
With a rate increase next week, the outlook would be different, even if stocks and bonds tumble initially.
On one hand, if the slowdown is confirmed in economic reports for May and June, then a Fed rate increase next week would clear the way for a market rally. With two Fed rate increases already in the bag, investors could fairly conclude that the central bank would wait quite a while before acting again.
On the other hand, even if the economic news turns out to be less comforting to Wall Street, the Fed's back-to-back rate increases would help squelch speculation that the central bank would try a third rate increase so soon. And the confidence that the Fed was ahead of the curve would help cushion any fall.
The Fed, of course, has to take a lot more into account than just the markets. And perhaps the biggest force weighing against an immediate rate increase is the one Fed officials never like to talk about: politics.
The criticism of the Fed from politicians and commentators has been sharp enough since its quarter-point increase in March that Alan Greenspan, the Fed's chairman, went out of his way last week to deliver an unusually detailed defense of the central bank. The sniping would certainly increase if the Fed lifts rates again next week, especially because it is so hard to persuade elected officials of the need for acting before a new inflationary surge is detected.
"Launching a pre-emptive strike against inflation has to be difficult in any political context," Mr. Berner of the Mellon Bank said. The Fed wants to be pre-emptive but not premature. "If the Fed is premature," he said, "it erodes its public support and its political support for what they do and their independence."
Moreover, the underlying economic rationale for a rate increase, in the eyes of some Wall Street economists, has weakened in the last two weeks. William Dudley, the chief United States economist at Goldman, Sachs & Company, just changed his view on Thursday, saying that "the odds favor the Fed standing pat." Citing the Fed's decision last summer not to raise interest rates despite a burst of growth in the spring, Mr. Dudley said that Mr. Greenspan "has shown a willingness to be patient when the economy is slowing."
Indeed, even analysts who lean toward a rate increase acknowledge that the Fed has plenty of reasons to be patient. The Producer Price Index has fallen four months in a row, including a six-tenths of a percent decline in April. The Consumer Price Index is up just 2.5 percent in the last 12 months, while the more closely watched Employment Cost Index rose less than 3 percent. The decline in April retail sales is also a sign that the opportunity to raise prices remains limited. And the balanced budget agreement in Washington helps ease fears. The Fed has already moved once this year to brake the economy by raising its Federal funds target -- the rate banks charge each other for overnight loans.
But others contend that the weight of evidence tilts slightly in the other direction. They start with the exceptionally low unemployment rate. Since last May, it has dropped to 4.9 percent from 5.5 percent. While most experts applaud an economy capable of generating jobs for almost everyone who wants one, the fear is that the jobless rate is so low that it is just a matter of time before inflationary pressures bubble over.
The average unemployment rate for the last 12 months of 5.3 percent is the lowest since the year ended February 1990, when inflation was clearly on the rise and the economy was only a few months from falling into recession. Other than that brief period, unemployment has not been so low in nearly a quarter of a century.
As for real growth, which has averaged about 4 percent in the last year, the economy has not expanded at such a rapid pace for a full year since 1987. Before that, the last three quarters of 1984 and the first of 1985 added up to another strong year. But at that time the economy was still rebounding from the severe 1981-82 recession and labor markets were not tight. Unemployment averaged 7.4 percent and was still at 6.2 percent in 1987.
So for all the talk of a new economic era, it is no surprise that Mr. Greenspan is worried that conditions today are simply too good to last. In defending the Fed's March 25 rate increase in his speech last week, the Fed chairman said the move was "taken not so much as a consequence of a change in the most probable forecast of moderate growth and low inflation for later this year and next, but rather to address the probability that being wrong had materially increased."
To Robert Barbera, the chief economist of Hoenig & Company, that means the Fed's job is "to make sure that growth isn't so brisk over the next 12 months that it lowers the unemployment rate." But even with that in mind, he says, next week the Fed could still leave Wall Street waiting.

By one measure, monetary policy is almost as restrictive as it has been this decade. Graph shows the Federal Reserve's taret rate minus the year-to-year change in the monthly Consumer Price Index, from 1990 to 1997. (Source: Haver Analytics; Merrill Lynch)

HEADLINE: U.S. Lays Out Its Fraud Case Against Governor of Arizona

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr. 

DATELINE: PHOENIX, May 16

 BODY:
Opening the Government's fraud case against Gov. Fife Symington of Arizona, a Federal prosecutor told jurors here today that Mr. Symington had concocted an elaborate web of financial lies in a desperate effort to salvage a crumbling real estate empire.
Mr. Symington's lawyer countered that his client was an honorable developer who took risks and sometimes suffered as a result but that he had never acted dishonorably. 
 The prosecutor, David Schindler, showed blowup after blowup of bank statements and other financial documents to the jury. That evidence, Mr. Schindler argued, showed that when Mr. Symington fell into financial trouble, he falsely inflated and deflated his true net worth time after time to obtain new development loans or have old loans forgiven from 1986 to 1991.
At one point in 1990, he added, Mr. Symington told one lender that he was $5.3 million in the black and another that he was $4.1 million in the red.
"The defendant is a very smart and clever man who told lies," Mr. Schindler declared as he opened the prosecution's attack in Federal District Court here. "To get loans, he portrayed a man with millions. In financial trouble, he portrayed a different person."
Mr. Symington's lawyer, John Dowd, himself a former Justice Department lawyer, countered that the Governor had done no more or less than make estimates of his worth at various points. Mr. Dowd said the lenders knew they were estimates and accepted them as such because they understood the extremely fluid nature of the real estate market.
"They were highly subjective figures," Mr. Dowd argued. "There are many different kinds of values in real estate -- short-term values, long-term values, liquidation values, fire-sale values. There is no hard-and-fast rule."
The Government prosecutors, Mr. Dowd asserted, did not understand the nature of risk or the fluidity in the real estate market.
Mr. Symington, a 51-year-old descendant of an Eastern family long involved in big business and politics, faces 22 counts of fraud, perjury and extortion. Most of the charges date back before he became the Governor in 1991. If convicted he could be sent to prison for dozens of years, depending on the charges proved.
Specifically, Mr. Symington is charged with giving false statements to federally insured financial institutions, with lying about his financial affairs during a bankruptcy hearing and with trying to extort less onerous terms for a loan, after he became Governor, by threatening to use the power of his office to steer business away from the lender.
"The defendant abused his office by trying to force one of his lenders out of a promise to pay a $10 million loan," Mr. Schindler declared in enumerating the various charges against Mr. Symington.
Mr. Dowd countered that Mr. Symington had made no effort to extort but had simply pointed out to the lender that the business climate was bad and growing worse.
"That was not threat," he added. "That was just common sense."
The trial here is the second time in a decade that an Arizona governor has been accused of felonious wrongdoing, and the current case, even though the trial is just getting started, has already created turmoil in the state's political scene and interrupted in the day-to-day flow of decisions and actions from the Governor's office.
In the earlier case, Gov. Evan Mecham, Mr. Symington's predecessor, was accused of accepting illegal campaign money. He was acquitted, but not before being impeached.
Throughout much of the 1980's, Mr. Symington was one of booming Arizona's most successful land developers. He built some of Phoenix's most expensive office parks and shopping malls. But like many other developers in the Southwest, he was laid financially low by the recession. Eventually, he was forced to declare bankruptcy.
"Fife Symington was a risk-taker just like the pioneers who settled the valley here," Mr. Dowd said early today in defense of his client.
In the prosecution's opening statement, Mr. Schindler charged that Mr. Symington had kept a special list of which lenders were to get which estimates. Mr. Schindler said some Symington aides and employees not only knew of the list but also, when instructed, "fixed" the figures on financial statements to reflect whatever Mr. Symington instructed.
"He would tell which figures to fix, which to add to and which to subtract from," Mr. Schindler said.
He also accused Mr. Symington of repeatedly overstating the share he held in various developments, as well as the value of those shares.
The case is expected to take the better part of several months to try. Testimony and presentation of evidence are to resume on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Champions Of Breakfast;
Pop-Up Pastries Growing As First Meal of the Day

BYLINE: By FLORENCE FABRICANT 

 BODY:
No food defines the baby-boom generation like Pop-Tarts. When they came on the market in 1964, they were newfangled, convenient, sweet-tooth friendly and relatively cheap. Children grew up eating them long before the advent of the harried family with two working parents.
So it is perhaps no surprise that Pop-Tarts and their imitators have turned out to be a durable habit, an icon of popular taste -- if not culture -- that is proving extremely difficult to outgrow. 
 The Pop-Tart "was really a product that came on the market before its time," said Jon Wilson, former head of the convenience foods division and now an executive vice president at the Kellogg Company, which introduced it. "It's more relevant today than it was 30 years ago."
And it is more successful. Led by Kellogg, whose sales of Pop-Tarts totaled nearly $330 million in 1996, the market for toaster pastries -- the industry's generic term -- has steadily expanded. And though Americans still eat more cereal, eggs and toast in the morning, over the last decade toaster pastries have been the fastest-growing breakfast product, with consumption tripling, according to NPD Group, a Chicago market research firm.
Makers of toaster pastries declined to disclose profit margins, but Eric Katzman, an analyst for Merrill Lynch Equity Research, said Pop-Tarts were extremely lucrative. For Kellogg, they represent 27 percent of profits but just 19 percent of sales. The company sells more Pop-Tarts than Frosted Flakes, its leading cold cereal and the No. 1 cereal in the United States.
From the beginning, Pop-Tarts were a hit because of their appeal to children, whose tastes continue to drive sales, not only on the American market but also internationally. But food companies are hoping that as baby boomers age, they take this acquired taste with them.
"Few Pop-Tarts are consumed by people over 50," Mr. Wilson said. "But as the core consumers get older, I can see the market expanding."
Indeed, there are signs that toaster pastries are changing in pursuit of older eaters.
About a year ago, Nabisco introduced toaster pastries in its successful Snackwell's low-fat line. Until then, said Ann Smith, director of communications for Nabisco, the food business of RJR Nabisco, "there were no products for health-conscious families." Since 1995, she said, "the wellness segment of the market has expanded by 150 percent."
Snackwell's has zoomed to No. 4 among toaster pastry brands, behind Kellogg, which introduced low-fat Pop-Tarts last summer; private-label offerings, and Pillsbury Toaster Strudels, a premium-priced frozen pastry aimed at adults.
The leading "natural food" brand is Nature's Choice Toaster Pastries, introduced in July by Barbara's Bakery Inc. in Petaluma, Calif. They have none of the chemical additives or artificial colors used in the leading brands and far less sodium. As junk food goes, they are definitely less junky. But at nearly double the price of the leading brands, they still go light on nutrition, providing slightly more fiber but fewer vitamins and minerals and about the same calories as brands such as Kellogg and Nabisco.
Kellogg did not invent Pop-Tarts. The company developed its version of the toaster pastry after a competitor began marketing something similar in the early 1960's. "With our expertise in cereals and grains, we saw this as an opportunity for the company to become the market leader," Mr. Wilson said.
It did not take long for Pop-Tarts to become a breakfast Band-Aid. And now the rest of the world is discovering them. Outside the United States, sales of Pop-Tarts amounted to $75 million last year.
"Convenience foods are making a bigger contribution to our overall business around the world," said Karen Kafer, the director of communications for Kellogg.
Some industry analysts put Kellogg's share of the toaster pastry market at nearly 70 percent. But that is only for those sold in the cereal aisle. When sales of the frozen pastries made by Pillsbury, a unit of Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., are included, Pop-Tarts accounted for a little more than 50 percent of the $617.6 million market last year, according to the Nielsen Scantrack survey of supermarkets.
Over the last five years, sales of toaster pastries in dollars have increased nearly 50 percent. But last year they slipped a bit -- less than 2 percent -- mainly because of price-cutting. Volume increased, however, in large part because Kellogg in June started packing eight pastries in a box instead of six without raising the price. This came in response to the eight-count package used by Nabisco for its Toastettes.
As a result, Toastettes, which had been coming on strong, dropped 45 percent in sales volume last year, though the rapid growth of Snackwell's eased some of the company's pain. Nabisco is still positioning Toastettes as the "quality value" brand, as Ms. Smith put it, but is spending heavily to promote Snackwell's.
Kellogg also reduced the suggested retail price of the larger 12-pastry package by almost 20 percent, from $3.21 to $2.59. Price has always helped sell toaster pastries. At 20 to 30 cents each, they provide a lot to eat for the money.
Who eats Pop-Tarts and other toaster pastries? Until recently, they were aimed mainly at children younger than 15, with customers fairly evenly spread across geographic, economic and ethnic lines. When children with one or more working parents have to fend for themselves, or when a parent needs to come up with a breakfast within minutes, what could be easier than a self-contained food that can be heated in a toaster and requires neither fork nor plate?
Americans ate an average of six toaster pastries apiece last year, compared with two in 1986, according to the NPD Group. The average 6- to 12-year-old ate 18 of them last year, while those older than 45 managed just three.
Studies have shown that about half of American households buy toaster pastries, with children typically driving the purchase -- though adults are easily tempted, too.
And while attention is now being paid to older consumers, children are still being aggressively courted through advertising and promotions. This summer, Pop-Tarts will be sold with special flavors and decorations coordinated with characters from the new "Batman and Robin" movie, including a Mr. Freeze flavor with ice-blue frosting and cherry filling and a strawberry Batgirl variety that has purple icing and yellow bat signals.
Ms. Kafer of Kellogg would not disclose the cost of the promotion but said it was a first for Pop-Tarts.
Never mind that most toaster pastries are highly processed, full of additives, overly sweetened and lately, like the Batman line, increasingly garish. Those characteristics have certainly never deterred the children of America.
Kellogg just introduced a "wild watermelon" flavor with flashy pink and turquoise icing, a novelty with the Power Ranger set in mind. The company has teams of researchers concocting new flavors, which are tested in focus groups and at stores. Watermelon was a winner, it seems, but apricot, a popular flavor in Australia, did not tempt Americans. Strawberry remains the all-time favorite.
Kellogg has more than 20 flavors, including six in its new low-fat line. And choices for the adults who might shudder at the sight of turquoise and pink icing are increasing.
Like the customer for Nature's Choice, the Snackwell's consumer is older and may not necessarily have children at home. Pillsbury Toaster Strudels are also designed to appeal to adults in addition to children. Some of the Pillsbury pastries have cheese fillings, also aimed at a more mature consumer.
Mr. Katzman, 32, may be typical. He said he had grown up eating Pop-Tarts. "I still like those Pop-Tarts," he said. "I'll eat any flavor."

Pop-Tarts were first introduced in 1964. Although there were no reruns of Gilligan's Island to watch while I sampled an assortment of iced strawberry toaster pastries, I did put on some Beatles music to get in the right mood. HEADLINE: Case of Jitters Trims the Dow By 138 Points

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Oh, what a jittery, volatile market.
After reaching two new highs this week and capping off a rally of nearly 15 percent in just over a month, the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 138.88 points, or 1.89 percent, yesterday. 
 More than a fifth of this year's sessions -- 14 -- have seen moves of a hundred points or more in either direction, with two just this week. There have been eight such surges and plunges, five up and three down, since the market rebound began April 14, a reflection of the fact that investors' overall optimism is subject to sudden bouts of doubt as everyone waits for the Federal Reserve to make its next move on interest rates.
The decline in the Dow yesterday, to 7,194.67, was part of a broad retreat led by a sharp selloff of computer and technology stocks combined with declines in drug, banking, soft drink and household product stocks.
Selling was also generated by a jump in interest rates in the bond market, which has been bouncing up and down as economic reports shift views on whether the Fed's policy-making committee will raise its target for short-term interest rates when it meets Tuesday.
A rise in housing starts in April and reports that consumer confidence climbed to a record level in the University of Michigan survey suggested that the economy might not be slowing as much as Fed officials think is necessary after a first-quarter pace of 5.6 percent, a nine-year high. Other data reported earlier this week, including April retail sales, suggested that consumer spending had dropped sharply in the beginning of the quarter.
Although all the economic reports for the week do not give a clear picture of how quickly the economy is slowing, Douglas R. Cliggott, the United States equity strategist at J. P. Morgan & Company, said that any indication of strength was upsetting to investors because "the expectation of a Fed tightening has ground its way out of the financial markets."
Hugh Johnson, the chief investment officer at the First Albany Corporation, said that much of the selling yesterday could probably be attributed to profit taking after the furious rally of the last several weeks. A sign of this, he said, is that many of the big gainers in the last two weeks, including I.B.M., Hewlett-Packard and General Electric, fell yesterday. Among the winners were the stocks of retailers, truckers and toy makers.
Hewlett-Packard, which disappointed expectations when it reported fiscal second-quarter earnings of 75 cents a share, dropped 6 1/8, or 10 percent, to 52 3/4, while I.B.M. fell 3 7/8, to 170. Together, the two accounted for a quarter of the Dow's decline. Other technology leaders also suffered, including Intel and Microsoft.
Merck, off 2 3/8, to 91 1/4; Procter & Gamble, down 3, to 130 5/8, and Johnson & Johnson, off 1 1/4, to 60 1/4, accounted for another 16 percent of the Dow's plunge.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 12.13 points, or 1.4 percent, to 829.75, while the Nasdaq composite index dropped 12.85 points, or 0.95 percent, to 1,340.73. The Nasdaq 100, which is dominated by technology stocks, fell 1.8 percent, or 16.5 points, to 915.29.
But stocks of smaller companies seemed to fare a little better, probably because even though they have had a sudden rebound they are still underperforming the bigger issues over the last year. The Russell index of 2,000 stocks slipped 0.63 point, or 0.17 percent, to 365.28.
Analysts said the selling yesterday was also accentuated by the monthly expiration of stock and index options. According to Birinyi Associates of Greenwich, Conn., there were six computer-driven sell programs and just one buy program. Together the computer selling equaled a 104-point decline in the Dow.
With the Fed meeting set for Tuesday and the surprisingly strong earnings reports for the first quarter of this year already digested, the near-term outlook for the stock market is likely to hinge on the bond market and interest rates.
The decline in interest rates since mid-April is the factor that has brought the market back, many analysts say. At the bottom of the selloff that pushed the Dow down 9.8 percent, the yield on the 30-year bond was around 7.16 percent; yesterday, it stood at 6.90 percent.

HEADLINE: Baltimore's Poor Brace for Round 2

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE, May 16

 BODY:
In an unmowed courtyard of the Flag housing project, two little boys and a girl crawl over the steel jungle gym, its white paint worn down to rust. The mother of one, Sharron Sturdavant, watches from the stoop of the apartment she rents for $96 a month. From the window behind her wafts the distinctive odor of leaking gas.
Living in the project is neither cozy nor comfortable, but it is home. Soon, though, Ms. Sturdavant, 38, an unemployed mother of six, and the 254 other families in Flag Court Houses will be leaving. 
 "I've been here for 22 years," Ms. Sturdavant said. "And it's a known fact that these places are supposed to be torn down."
With the project scheduled for demolition in 2000, pressure is escalating on public housing residents like those here, particularly Ms. Sturdavant and other welfare recipients. They are under the gun to get a job because they will lose their monthly checks under the welfare bill passed last year. Once they find work, they also must find child care. And for families with two or three children, that service can cost as much as they earn.
This week, the House of Representatives tightened the vise again, passing legislation that seeks to dismantle a 60-year-old system of public housing for the poor.
Among other provisions, the House bill would close more public housing to the poorest while opening units to working people who can pay closer to market rates. As in the overhaul of welfare, the goal is to goad more people to go to work and pay more of their own way. Some Flag residents pay as little as $5 a month for their apartments.
While the Senate and the Clinton Administration have yet to put their stamps on the House bill, the direction is clear. Federal and local officials hope to overhaul programs that have fostered a network of decrepit buildings and, many public housing critics argue, a culture of dependency.
Because of Congressional budget cuts in public housing support, the nation's 3,400 local housing authorities have already taken steps that narrowed options for residents. Currently about 1.4 million Americans live in public housing.
The Baltimore Housing Authority recently tore down two projects, and another will be razed next year. Flag Court Houses, a mix of 3-story and 12-story brick structures, will be last.
Baltimore's housing authority, the nation's fifth largest, with 40 projects and 18,000 tenant households, is wrestling with the new economics of trying to maintain a housing safety net. The city was set to receive $108 million from the Department of Housing and Urban Development in 1995. Instead, it got $96 million, and this year the amount fell to $81 million.
"Our whole purpose is to attract higher-income people," said Daniel Paul Henson 3d, executive director of the Baltimore Housing Authority.
To cope with the cuts, the city is replacing projects like Flag with town houses and more scattered housing, for which it is charging much more. In the place of a project demolished earlier, where the average rent was $150 a month, the housing authority expects the average for the new housing to reach $350 within two years.
Flag tenants are not optimistic about their prospects.
Malinda Ragg and Trina Thomas, both 26-year-old mothers on welfare, work part time as maids at a Holiday Inn as part of a job-training program called Project Independence.
"We get paid $60 every two weeks," Ms. Ragg said. Her monthly rent is $101., and the women cannot see how they will afford homes that the city is building, including some for sale, once they have to move.
"They tell us they're going to tear it down and we'll have first priority to come back," Ms. Ragg said.
"But that can't be true," she said, pointing to what happened after another project was demolished. "They tore Lafayette down, and they're building houses over them and they're selling those houses for $30,000 apiece.
"The rent? The rent's something like $474 a month! You have to be making $18,000 a year and have $900 in the bank just to get one."
The bill in Congress does eliminate the rule that rents must rise as tenants' incomes rise.
Among those who will be affected is Charles McFadden, 37, who was visiting from another project with his 7-year-old granddaughter, Ashley. Mr. McFadden went to work as a janitor last July and takes home $190 a week. His rent of $350 is about to be raised above $400, he said.
And going to work poses a new problem for him.
"I need a second job," Mr. McFadden said. "I need day care for her," he said of Ashley, whom he and and his wife are rearing. Quality day care starts at about $75 a week.
One feature of Congress's housing bill, a requirement that unemployed, able-bodied tenants do volunteer work in the community, has stirred much more dust among the lawmakers than among people here. The bill requires eight hours of community service work a month, like helping out at the Big Boys and Girls' Club, and requires the eviction of those who refuse.
In return for all the years she has received welfare, Ms. Sturdavant said, the volunteer work "is worth doing."
It is the crescendo of pressure from public housing and welfare authorities to get real, paying jobs that weighs on people most. Robin Mack, manager of Flag, said she was beginning to detect a shift in attitudes. Tenants, Ms. Mack said, are acting more responsibly, like showing up when they are summoned when they do not pay their rent.
"This is really, really serious," Ms. Mack said. "They can't stay on the street. There's a no-loitering law here now, and not everybody can get along with relatives and friends."
Mr. Henson of the housing authority acknowledged that some of the poorest poor -- those who cannot find jobs or cannot pay the higher rents -- would lose access to public housing and be forced into shelters for the homeless. To help them over the short term, the city is expanding construction of transitional housing, including 200 units that will open within nine months. As Mr. Henson put it, they will become part of the city's "continuum of care" program.
Ms. Sturdavant takes in all these changes with acquiescence, fear and defiance as she faces the loss of her three-bedroom apartment.
"God said it will come a time and day when the wealthy man will press the poor," she said. "The Government just started a new program saying you got to go out to work. Most of us are not well educated and all. Jobs want you to have degrees. For me, it would be janitorial. We all know that's something I can do."
People have a way of getting by, Ms. Sturdavant said. "The Government can do what it wants. We're still going to make it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Public housing residents are feeling the squeeze as financing dwindles. From left, Dannielle Simpkins, Sharron Sturdavant and her niece Temikia Everhart will have to move because their building is going to be razed. (Dennis Drenner for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Charges Against Danish Mother Are Dropped

BYLINE: By JOHN SULLIVAN 

 BODY:
A state judge dismissed charges yesterday against a Danish tourist who was arrested for leaving her baby in a stroller on the sidewalk while she ate inside an East Village restaurant. Charges against the baby's father, who lives in Brooklyn, are still pending.
The charges against the tourist, Annette Sorensen, were dropped at the request of the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, and prosecutors noted that the dismissal was not opposed by the City Administration for Children's Services. Ms. Sorensen, an actress, had been charged with endangering the welfare of a child, a misdemeanor. 
 "No purpose would be served by the prosecution of this case at this time," said David Austen, the assistant district attorney prosecuting the case.
Judge Michael Gross of Criminal Court told Ms. Sorensen, 30, that charges would be dropped and that the record of the charges would be sealed if she remained out of trouble for six months. The judge said that Ms. Sorensen would not have to remain in the United States or return to court at the end of the six months.
On vacation in New York, Ms. Sorensen left the child on the sidewalk while she ate just inside the window with the child's father, Exavier Wardlaw, 49. Mr. Wardlaw was also arrested and charged with endangering the welfare of a child and disorderly conduct.
Yesterday, his lawyer attacked the Manhattan District Attorney's office for failing to dismiss the charges against his client.
"If you have the choice of being a Danish television actress with the support of the Danish Government behind you or of being an unemployed black playwright, the choice is obvious when you are dealing with the city," said Ronald L. Kuby, Mr. Wardlaw's lawyer.
A spokeswoman for the Manhattan District Attorney said that Ms. Sorensen's case had been heard quickly at the request of her defense lawyers. She said that no action has been taken on Mr. Wardlaw's case because it is being handled on a normal schedule.
In a brief press conference on the courthouse steps, Ms. Sorensen, who was reunited with her 14-month-old girl on Wednesday, said she planned to return home with her daughter as soon as possible.
"I am very happy with the result and I will now go home to my daughter," she said. "As soon as possible, I will return to Denmark."
Ms. Sorensen's arrest created a brief international contretemps, stunning many in Denmark, where mothers often leave children outside while they shop and eat. However, the authorities here noted that what was appropriate in Copenhagen, a city of 1.3 million with a low crime rate, was not always so in New York.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani defended the action of officers who arrested Ms. Sorensen after people complained that the child had been left alone on the sidewalk for some time.
In Denmark, Ms. Sorensen is featured in a television show about police officers on a small island. The name of the show, translated from the Danish, is "Cops on Samsoe."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Starts of Housing Rise, But Weakness Is Seen
Housing starts rose 2.6 percent in April, exceeding analysts' expectations of an increase of one-tenth of 1 percent. But most of the gains were in the volatile category of apartment construction; single-family housing starts rose just three-tenths of 1 percent. Moreover, the number of applications for construction permits fell. 
 A separate survey found that consumer confidence remained strong, even though the Federal Reserve raised interest rates in March. The two reports added to the uncertainty about whether the policy makers will raise rates again on Tuesday. [Page 34.]
 
Bond Prices Fall
The housing report and consumer sentiment survey helped pull down Treasury bond prices. The yield on the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose to 6.90 percent from 6.86 percent. Despite the nervous selloff, dealers, traders and investors remained split over what Fed policy makers would do next week. [34.]
 
2 Utilities Call Off $6 Billion Merger
Two big Midwest utilities, Wisconsin Energy and Northern States Power, canceled plans for a $6 billion merger, citing Federal regulators' refusal to approve the deal. While the regulators did not reject the deal outright, they asked for a new merger plan that would include the sale of some generating plants. The companies said that the regulatory commission's offer of a further review showed that its polcies were unsettled. [34.]

A Step Toward a Balanced Budget
The House Budget Committee took the first legislative step yesterday toward enactment of a balanced budget bill. It voted 31 to 7 to approve a resolution that will serve as a guide for future tax cuts and spending. The Senate Budget Committee is to vote on its resolution on Monday, and Republican leaders said they expect both branches of Congress will give final approval by the end of next week. [9.]
 
Dollar Stems Slide Against Yen
The dollar fell against the yen again, but for the first time in more than a week, the loss was less than 1 yen. Traders were buying dollars, indicating that they believe the dollar may be stabilizing after its nearly two-week slide. In New York, the dollar finished at 115.55 yen, down from 116.10 yen on Thursday. [32.]
ADT in Talks to End Hostile Bid
ADT, the security system company, said it was in talks with Western Resources on a possible end to Western's hostile bid. ADT has already accepted a $5.6 billion friendly offer from Tyco International. [35.]
 
Aetna's President to Resign
Aetna's president, Joseph Sebastianelli, said he was resigning, citing personal reasons. Mr. Sebastianelli, 50, had been on the job a little more than two months. [35.]
 
A Casino Owner's Travails in Peru
A bingo parlor and disco that was opened in Lima, Peru, in 1995 by an American who made his $50 million fortune in the oil business was headed for success. That is until problems cropped up from what the businessman, Bruce Heafitz, above, at his disco, says is an attempt by the Peruvian Government to take over the business. Variations of that case are also appearing in emerging markets in Asia, Eastern Europe and Africa.[35.]
 
Coffee Prices Retreat
An increase in United States coffee inventories helped push coffee futures lower. The report of the increased inventories helped ease worries that stockpiles would begin a steep decline that might result in a scarcity of supply and even higher prices. On other commodity markets, corn rose. [32.]
 
Business Gifts to Governors' Group
Some of the nation's biggest corporations have given millions of dollars to the National Governors' Association and an affiliated research arm in the last several years. In return lobbyists for the corporations have gained access to the governors' policy-making apparatus and can rub shoulders with governors and their staffs. [1.]

HEADLINE: CORPORATE GIFTS HELP GAIN ACCESS TO U.S. GOVERNORS

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
In the past several years, a select group of the nation's biggest corporations have given millions of dollars to the National Governors' Association and an affiliated research arm. In return for their tax-deductible contributions, the corporations' lobbyists have gained unusual access to the governors' policy-making apparatus.
They take part in the governors' plenary meetings, attend receptions with governors, get briefings from the group's leaders and staff, are offered private work spaces and meeting areas at its annual gatherings and attend other events to help them "become better acquainted with governors' staffs and to share common interests," an association fact sheet says. 
 They also frequently attend staff meetings that develop many of the governors' policy recommendations, giving them a chance to influence the formulation of state and Federal regulations that can mean billions of dollars to participating companies.
Among them are corporations as diverse as AT&T, Exxon, General Motors, Dow Chemical, Pfizer, Blue Cross/Blue Shield, Philip Morris and Goldman, Sachs & Company.
The bipartisan governors' group defends the practice as perfectly legal and aimed only at getting the best advice on important issues. But critics say it gives the corporations a lobbying advantage unavailable to their adversaries on major policy issues.
The corporate "fellows" were actively recruited by the governors' group. Membership was restricted to no more than 100 big companies. Other interest groups, like labor unions and policy advocacy organizations, were not invited.
The results were vividly illustrated at a meeting of the governors' natural resources committee on April 16, when the corporate fellows joined in a daylong discussion on issues including electricity policy, environmental regulation by the Federal Government and pending legislation on the cleanup of toxic waste dumps.
In the afternoon, the committee asked Gregory F. Wetstone, legislative director for the Natural Resources Defense Council, a leading environmentalist group, to join a panel discussing the Clean Air Act.
Mr. Wetstone, who said he had not been invited to attend the full day's program, said later that he was surprised to find himself facing not just the state environmental officials he had expected but also officials from big corporations that have been lobbying hard against tighter air quality standards proposed by the environmental agency. "It is very troubling that corporations are able to buy a much greater level of access than the public in general or the public-interest community," Mr. Wetstone said in an interview later.
The corporate donations -- about $786,000 in 1996, the association's records show -- support an entity known as the Center for Best Practices. Founded in 1974 as part of the governors' organization, it was renamed last year and is a legally distinct nonprofit corporation, but is still run by a board of four governors. The center also receives financing from philanthropic foundations and from the Federal Government.
Under a program set up in 1988, for an annual payment of up to $12,000, a company can designate one or more "corporate fellows" who work on the center's research into social and economic policies.
As a side benefit, the participants, who are most often senior lobbyists for the corporations, rub shoulders with governors and their staffs in a way that few others can match.
The governors' group describes the program as "an unparalleled opportunity to serve as catalysts to change."
Ann McBride, the president of Common Cause, the public affairs lobby, called the arrangement "just another permutation in the way that access is being purchased in the political process."
"They are so far off base that I can't tell you," responded Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin, chairman of the center and former chairman of the governors' association. "We are raising money for a foundation in order to allow the Center for Best Practices, which is currently held hostage by just Federal dollars, to do more things to help the environment, help the economy, help the governors do their job better."
The organization has played an increasingly influential role in shaping Federal policy, especially by urging that Federal social and regulatory programs be delegated to state governments.
Gov. Bob Miller of Nevada, the association's chairman, said the group was beyond being swayed by special interests because it usually operated by consensus among 50 governors.
But the corporate fellows do frequently attend meetings of specialized committees of the association that recommend policies on issues of intense interest to big business, like environmental rules, tax policy and health insurance.
Association officials insisted that every meeting attended by corporate fellows was open to anybody else who wanted to attend. But because the meetings are not publicized, almost nobody but lobbyists ever attends even the open meetings.
While lobbyists for industry trade associations, Federal officials, environmentalists and other interested parties are sometimes invited to present their views at such meetings, few outsiders are involved to the extent that corporate fellows are.
One example of the policy-making sessions where corporate fellows have taken part is an association committee's deliberations over a newly drafted policy about restructuring the electric utility industry, one of the biggest economic issues facing the Federal and state governments.
Among those on the governors' list of corporate fellows are William Lhota, executive vice president of the American Electric Power Company, Steven J. Kean, senior vice president for the Enron Corporation, and Roger Schwarz, director of Federal affairs at the Public Service Electric and Gas Company of New Jersey, all corporations with major financial stakes in restructuring the electric utility industry.
But Raymond C. Scheppach, executive director of the governors' organization, said the corporations mostly supported a broader, public interest in issues like job training. "There is very little work that you would argue is business oriented in any sense of the word," he said. "A lot of it is education, early childhood education. There is very little we do that has business implications."
Corporate fellows "do sit in and listen to the discussions, and at times they do in fact give presentations," he said, but their role in policy making is modest.
But the association's fact sheet describing the program to potential participants says that the program gives "a unique opportunity" to present industry's views to governors on specific issues.
"Corporate fellows are often asked to provide private sector input on current and emerging policy issues in panel discussions, meetings and written reports," it says.
"Sure, on the marketing side, we probably have made that pitch," said the director of the center, John B. Thomasian. "It is a lot less than it is cracked up to be."
But Bill Hogan, director of investigative projects at the Center for Public Integrity, a nonpartisan research group that examines political finance issues, said that this kind of participation could be very valuable to a lobbyist. "At the simplest level, you are privy to their thoughts, deliberations, et cetera," he said. "At a higher level, perhaps you can influence them, nip something in the bud, or whatever."

HEADLINE: House Panel, 31-7, Advances the Balanced-Budget Deal

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 16

 BODY:
Using the tax-cutting and spending deal struck by President Clinton and Republican leaders as a blueprint, the House Budget Committee took the first legislative step today toward enactment of a balanced-budget bill.
"We've been struggling with this for a long time," Representative John R. Kasich, the Ohio Democrat who heads the Budget Committee, said as it voted 31 to 7 to approve a resolution that will guide future action on tax cuts and spending. 
 The Senate Budget Committee is to vote on its resolution on Monday, and Republican leaders said they expected both the House and the Senate would give final approval by the end of next week.
After two weeks of haggling, Republican leaders and the White House announced on Thursday night that they had agreed to a written deal on a five-year budget plan. The final deal, whose broad outline follows the agreement that the political leaders announced earlier this month, includes $115 billion in savings to the Medicare program and an $85 billion package of tax cuts. Among them are a $500-a-child tax credit, broad-based and permanent reductions in the capital gains tax, "significant" reductions in the inheritance tax and an expansion of Individual Retirement Accounts.
Thursday night's deal locked in place what earlier had been only spoken agreements. In the end, the Republicans won guarantees that they would have the controlling say in how the tax cuts would be distributed, the specifics of which will be left to the Ways and Means Committee. And the White House won assurances that it would get roughly $35 billion in tax credits for post-secondary education, as well as protection against cuts in education and social programs it considers most important.
"This agreement includes the most significant increase in education funding in 30 years," Mr. Clinton said. "Even more important, it provides the largest single increase in higher education since the G.I. bill in 1945, more than 50 years ago."
But even as some Republicans and Democrats were toasting one another today in a spirit of bipartisanship, Speaker Newt Gingrich's office was boasting in a private memorandum that Republicans had prevailed over the Administration and Democrats in many important areas.
The memorandum said Republican negotiators had been able to thwart White House efforts to increase welfare spending for legal immigrants who entered the country after August, when the new welfare law took effect. And the memo said Republicans had won language in the final deal that provisions reducing capital gains and estate taxes could include indexing for inflation or losses on sales of residences.
"The agreement substantially scales back the President's insatiable appetite for more Government spending programs," the memorandum continued, listing 40 programs that it said the Administration had failed to protect.
Those programs include several of Mr. Clinton's favorites, including Americorps, the volunteer service organization, and Goals 2000, the President's education improvement program, as well as some perennial Republican targets like the Legal Services Corporation, the National Endowment for the Arts and the National Endowment for the Humanities.
The agreement calls for $1.69 trillion in spending for fiscal year 1998, which begins on Oct. 1, with a deficit of $90.4 billion. Although that will probably represent an increase from this year's anticipated deficit of $75 billion, the negotiators said deficits would decline in each of the succeeding years, ending with a surplus of $1.3 billion by 2002.
The agreement was signed off by President Clinton, Speaker Gingrich, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, and Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the minority leader.
Some Democrats in the House have raised objections in the past over cuts in capital gains taxes, criticizing the idea as a tax break for the wealthy.
Drawing up a budget resolution is the first step in the legislative process toward a budget. The resolution, which does not require the President's signature, sets spending limits and certain other conditions for the committees that will actually write the legislation that will become law.
But before that happens, the full House and Senate must approve their respective resolutions, reconcile any differences and then vote again on identical bills.
Mr. Lott said on Thursday night that he expected that entire process to be completed by the time Congress breaks for the Memorial Day recess starting on May 23.
Most of the budget and its details will still be shaped by the Republican-controlled tax-writing and spending committees. But the deal between the Clinton Administration and the Republican leaders is meant to insure that each side's top priorities will be protected.
Republicans made the tax cuts a priority item. But the only specifics they laid out in the budget deal was that the per-child tax credit should be $500. It will be left largely to the tax-writing House Ways and Means Committee, led by Representative Bill Archer of Texas, to decide the size of the reductions in capital gains taxes and inheritance taxes and who will receive the benefits.
The White House and Congressional Democrats argued for and won a much more expansive list of priority items, the largest of which was the $35 billion the President wanted for post-secondary education programs, including a tuition tax credit.
In addition, the Administration was able to protect about a dozen domestic spending programs, some of which have been frequent targets of Republicans. All of the protected programs are to receive the spending that Mr. Clinton proposed in his 1998 budget. Among those are Head Start, Job Corps, bilingual and immigrant education and Pell grants for college students, which are to increase by $300, to a maximum award of $3,000.
