HEADLINE: MASTER OF RUIN -- A special report.;
An Anatomy Of Autocracy: Mobutu's Era

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: KINSHASA, Zaire, May 16

 BODY:
In more than three decades at the center of his country's political stage, Mobutu Seso Seke was nothing if not an extraordinary survivor. But his tenacity and resourcefulness finally failed him today as he stealthily left his capital, a defeated man.
Mr. Mobutu has been called one of the world's wealthiest heads of state, a brutal dictator, an inveterate meddler in the affairs of neighbors and a colossal ego. His style, at once bold and vainglorious, was for an entire generation the very model of an African autocrat. 
 Resplendent in his signature leopard-skin cap and carved wooden scepter topped with an eagle, Mr. Mobutu -- through his canny courtship of Western support, destabilization of his neighbors, systematic corruption and grandiose economic schemes -- left Zaire teetering on the brink of economic collapse. His cult of personality rose to such heights that for weeks at a time, Zaire's official press was forbidden to mention the name of any other Zairian than the President himself.
Mr. Mobutu almost singlehandedly invented Zaire, even giving the country its name in replacement of the colonial name, Congo. But his personal appetite for luxury and wealth spawned a system of official corruption so rapacious that he leaves behind a country in ruin, where revenue from lucrative mines has been squandered or squirreled away in foreign bank accounts. Life in a vast country deprived of roads, health care, electricity, telephones and often education has reverted to a brutishness unknown since the 1940's. Still, even many of Mr. Mobutu's harshest critics acknowledge one achievement, and it is a major one in an Africa of artificially drawn states riven by ethnic animosities.
Inheriting a land of more than 450 ethnic groups that had French as an official language but no commonly spoken tongue, Mr. Mobutu managed to forge a sense of nationhood in Africa's third-largest country as strong as exists anywhere on this continent. This was accomplished, in part, by successfully promoting the use of three major African languages -- Lingala, Swahili and Tshiluba -- to draw citizens together across ethnic lines.
At the same time, Zaire experienced a period of extraordinary cultural creativity, in song, in dress and in art. This came about partly as a result of deliberate efforts to favor local influences over foreign ones, and partly because of the need of Zairians to survive by their own means in the absence of a functioning Government.
Throughout a career that began at independence from Belgium, during the height of the cold war, Mr. Mobutu seemed to thrive on crises, buying off enemies when he did not kill them outright, and currying favor with Washington by allowing his country to be used as a base in wars against Soviet influence in central Africa.
But the rebel leader Laurent Kabila's seven-month fight revealed Mr. Mobutu's army to be toothless and his Government an empty shell. In the end, the undoing of a man known as a master calculator resulted from a long series of costly misjudgments of a sick and aging politician well past his prime.

Rising Star
A Helping Hand From the C.I.A.
Mr. Mobutu's ascent began in September 1960, at the dawn of Zaire's independence, when he seized power during quarrels between the pro-Western President Joseph Kasavubu and the nationalist Patrice Lumumba, the country's first Prime Minister. Mr. Mobutu, a journalist and army sergeant, had been picked by Mr. Lumumba as chief of staff and prodded toward the center of the political stage by the Central Intelligence Agency, which had chosen him as its best tool for keeping the nation out of the socialist orbit. Although he has always denied it, many scholars believe that Mr. Mobutu helped organize the 1961 execution of Mr. Lumumba at C.I.A.'s urging.
During the early independence years, the C.I.A. called most of the shots in Zaire. Nonetheless, Mr. Mobutu often frustrated his C.I.A. handlers. In the words of Smith Hempstone, the former American diplomat and journalist, Mr. Mobutu was in the 1960's "one of the weakest strongmen in history, a black Hamlet, plagued by indecision, unwilling to assume power himself."
But when Mr. Mobutu finally seized power outright on Nov. 24, 1965, after American help enabled him to extinguish a series of regional uprisings by followers of Mr. Lumumba, he wasted little time putting his stamp on Zaire.
By Zairian standards, Mr. Mobutu's early years in office were a period of relative calm, even if sporadic troubles continued here and there, notably in the Fizi-Baraka mountain range of South Kivu Province, where a sputtering rebellion led by one Laurent Desire Kabila refused to die.
Beginning with his first speech after seizing power, Mr. Mobutu set a dictatorial tone, telling a large crowd gathered in a Kinshasa stadium that it had taken five years for the politicians to lead the country to ruin.
"This is why on Nov. 24, 1965, the stupid struggle for influence in which political parties were engaged was ended," he said. "For five years, there will be no more political party activity in the country."
Almost immediately, Mr. Mobutu established a brand of unchallenged one-man rule that lasted until 1990.
Mr. Mobutu ordered the creation of a sole, powerful political party, the Popular Revolutionary Movement, making membership obligatory for all Zairians. In the early years, at least, he set out to attract the best and brightest of Zaire's small university community, eagerly soliciting their advice.
With time, however, the effects of flattery and a growing taste for power took over, and the President's style of rule became both insular and absolute. Challengers, both imagined and real, often paid with their lives, like the four former Cabinet ministers whom Mr. Mobutu had publicly hanged before 50,000 spectators six months after he took office.
As an unmistakable Mobutu style began to emerge in the late 1960's and early 1970's, it became clear that the Zairian leader's ambition was to fashion a great African state. Mr. Mobutu began to study other dictatorships, drawing freely from them.
"This man has spoken; he has written, set forth orientation and decrees," Mpinga Kasenda, a former Prime Minister, said in a characteristic speech of the period praising Mr. Mobutu. "The sum total of his actions constitutes Mobutism, just as the sum total of Mao's actions constitutes Maoism."

All-Powerful Leader
From Mobutu To Mobutism
Mobutism quickly became the new national ideology, and since a constitution written expressly to please him provided the President unlimited powers, Mr. Mobutu's words took on the force of law.
By 1970, with mineral revenues growing fast, Mr. Mobutu felt secure enough in his rule to make known his grandiose vision for Zaire. At an extraordinary party congress that year, he announced a bid for national greatness called Goal 80.
The plan consisted of a 10-year program to double copper production, industrialize the country with steel mills and deep-water ports, and undertake a program of huge investments in Kinshasa, Kisangani and around the southern mining capital, Lubumbashi.
The largest project of all was the Inga dam, near Kinshasa, at the time one of the world's largest hydroelectric dams, followed by the 1,110-mile-long Inga-Shaba power grid, spanning dense forest and empty savanna on its route to the copper-producing, independence-minded Shaba Province, which Mr. Mobutu's project aimed to make dependent upon electricity supplied from afar.
When the World Bank refused to finance the project, believing it to be far too costly, the United States Export-Import Bank stepped in, in a gesture of political support for a man considered to be a vital cold-war ally. But within a few years, the heavy debt incurred for the $1 billion project, which has been operating since 1977, became a crippling economic burden.
In 1971, Mr. Mobutu unveiled a new twist on the official ideology with a program known as "authenticity." Zairians were obliged to change their Western names to African ones, drop titles like Mr. and Mrs. in favor of "citizen" and abandon European dress for tunics for men and wraps of printed cloth for women.
Mr. Mobutu sought to set the tone by replacing his given name, Joseph Desire Mobutu, with Mobutu Sese Seko Kuku Ngbendu waza Banga, which has often been translated as "the all-conquering warrior who, because of his endurance and inflexible will to win, will go from conquest to conquest leaving fire in his wake."
Authenticity was followed, in 1973, by "Zairianization," a program that expropriated farms, factories and businesses belonging to foreigners, from Belgians who had remained since the colonial period to the Greek, Jewish and Pakistani traders who had dominated much of the country's small-scale commerce.
As might have been expected, the nationalizations and handing out of businesses to politically selected Zairians were initially popular. It was not long, however, before things began to go badly wrong. With almost no prior experience in the businesses they inherited, many Zairians quickly sought to lure foreigners back to run them in their place. Others simply sold off their goods and failed to re-stock.
Soon Zaire's economy was near collapse. One group of people, however, benefited far more than others, and in lasting ways, from the Africanization program: Mr. Mobutu and a small circle of relatives and friends.
Takeovers under Zairianization were, in fact, but one of Mr. Mobutu's many sources of wealth. The scholars Crawford Young and Thomas Turner quoted 1978 Bank of Zaire estimates that 50 Zairian companies had illegally secreted some $300 million abroad. Eight of the largest of these companies were owned by Mr. Mobutu or his immediate family.
The collapse of the economy under Zairianization did not force Mr. Mobutu to backtrack; instead, he rushed ahead into ever more radical measures that over time helped undo him. Returning home from a state visit to China and North Korea in 1974, Mr. Mobutu announced a 10-point program to eliminate what he called the country's 10 scourges. A food shortage, he said, would be ended by organizing agricultural brigades. Unemployment was to be ended by decree. Every community was ordered to begin building nursery schools, and employers were told to provide free uniforms and supplies for their workers' children.
Marked by his experience of the Communist east, Mr. Mobutu grew ever more grandiose, and his cult of personality ever more intense. President Mobutu began to affect titles like the Helmsman and the Guide, and the news on state television opened with images of Mr. Mobutu descending from the heavens.
While the economy continued to decline, it was not until the collapse of copper prices in the mid-1970's that Mr. Mobutu reluctantly began to change economic course.
But by then, no one would lend to Zaire any longer, foreign aid programs were bring cut back sharply, inflation was galloping and the grand state that he had set out to build entered a long period of decay.
According to histories of this period, Mr. Mobutu, seeing no way out of his country's economic and political crisis, briefly considered abandoning power when he took his family to Switzerland in March 1976.
But he returned home to confront a series of major new crises, the most serious of which were invasions of Shaba Province in March 1977 and May 1978 by remnants of the Katangese rebel force that had sought independence for that region shortly after independence.
The two Shaba invasions, both from Angolan territory, quickly revealed the battlefield ineptitude of the Zairian Army, and in both instances, foreign troops and American transport planes had to be summoned to put down the rebellions.

Regional Meddler
A Finger in Affairs Of His Neighbors
 The tremendous mineral wealth of Shaba, with 80 percent of the world's cobalt reserves and 20 percent of its copper supplies, helped Mr. Mobutu secure international military and financial support. The West, and Washington in particular, also had been using Zaire as a weapons supply and staging area for support of the anti-Communist Unita rebel movement fighting the Marxist Government in Angola.
Mr. Mobutu, acting with strong C.I.A. encouragement, had been assisting rebel movements fighting Angola's Marxist Government. The first involvement was a disastrous C.I.A.-backed effort to seize Angola's oil-producing Cabinda enclave, which began in 1975, the day before Angola achieved independence from Portugal.
Mr. Mobutu's meddling in Angola, at the behest of Washington, set a pattern for the rest of his rule. He constantly kept a finger in the crises of neighboring countries, from Chad and Congo to Uganda and the Sudan. With its borders with nine other countries, Mr. Mobutu marketed his country to Washington and Paris -- obtaining economic aid and political support in exchange -- as a platform for interventions and covert operations throughout central and southern Africa.
With the end of the cold war, Mr. Mobutu's relevance to Washington and most of the West declined sharply. In 1990, as a wave of democratic change swept much of Africa, Mr. Mobutu was forced to allow multiparty politics.
A tumultuous national conference that drew from many parts of Zairian society convened and obliged Mr. Mobutu to accept his most determined political rival, Etienne Tshisekedi, as Prime Minister.
When Mr. Tshisekedi sought to assert his control over state finances, however, Mr. Mobutu removed him from office, setting off a crisis that led to the first of two outbreaks of killings and looting in the capital by Government soldiers.
Popular support for Mr. Tshisekedi was so overwhelming that Mr. Mobutu retreated from the capital, living for a time on his luxurious houseboat on the Congo River, and eventually in his palatial home in the northern town of Gbadolite.
After the swift end of a second stint in office by Mr. Tshisekedi, officials in Washington, Paris and Brussels in 1994 engineered the appointment as Prime Minister of Kengo wa Dondo, a long associate of the President and former Finance Minister. Mr. Kengo was supposed to govern for a year, and his mandate was to organize national elections, rein in galloping inflation and restore the authority of a decaying state.
Despite unstinting Western support, Mr. Kengo's administration was widely seen as a disaster. Civil servants were unpaid for months at a time, no progress was made toward elections and corruption continued as blatantly as ever.
Mr. Mobutu experienced a brief and unexpected return to international relevance with the 1994 civil war and mass killing in neighboring Rwanda. More than a million Rwandan Hutu, many of them participants in the killing of members of the Tutsi minority, fled into Zaire after a Tutsi-led insurgency seized power.
Foreign governments and international aid organizations were obliged to deal with Mr. Mobutu, ending a period of diplomatic isolation. Relations with France, which had been a major backer of the defeated Hutu Government in Rwanda, nearly returned to their historic warmth.
The end for Mr. Mobutu came with surprising speed, after Rwanda's Tutsi-led Government supported an uprising by Zairian Tutsi who had come under attack in eastern Zaire.
In three weeks in October 1996, what had been a Tutsi uprising turned into a full-blown political rebellion against Mr. Mobutu led by Mr. Kabila.
Once Mr. Kabila's newborn Alliance of Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Congo seized the major cities of Zaire's far east, African patrons with scores to settle against Mr. Mobutu lined up to help the rebels with money, men and arms.
The anti-Mobutu coalition came to include Rwanda, Uganda, Burundi, Tanzania, Zambia, Zimbabwe and, with major support provided toward the end of the war, Angola, where Mr. Mobutu had interfered the most in three decades of rule.
When Bill Richardson, the United States delegate to the United Nations and President Clinton's special envoy, visited Zaire early this month to engineer Mr. Mobutu's resignation, the aging, cancer-ridden President asked him why, after years of loyal service and friendship with the West, he had been abandoned.
"I said the mess you are in is not our mess," Mr. Richardson said. "You just didn't govern your own country."

(CameraPix); A comic book from the 1980's, one of the tools of Mr. Mobutu's personality cult, presented him as a superhero in his leopard hat; Mobutu in 1987. (pg. 7)
 
Chronology: "An African Dictator's Rise and Fall"
 
1930-1959: THE EARLY YEARS
 
OCT. 14, 1930 Joseph Desire Mobutu is born in Lisala, a town in the northern Belgian Congo. Adopted in infancy by a cook for local Belgian missionaries, he goes to missionary schools.
 
1950 Joins the Belgian-controlled colonial army, where he works as a journalist. He rises to sergeant major, the highest rank open to Africans.
 
1956 Leaves army and works as a newspaper columnist in Leopoldville, the capital.
 
1959 Takes part in conference determining independence of the Congo from Belgium. Returns to Leopoldville as riots for independence take place.
 
1960-1973: POWER AND CONSOLIDATION
 
1960 Congo is declared independent from Belgium on June 30. Joseph Kasavubu becomes President and Patrice Lumumba the Prime Minister. Mobutu is named Secretary of State for National Defense. Within days of independence, the Government's control is compro 2/3mised by mutinies and local disturbances. Mobutu returns to the army, given the rank of colonel. On Sept. 14, Mobutu leads a coup removing both Kasavubu and Lumumba.
 
1961 Lumumba is killed under mysterious circumstances in January. Mobutu returns power to President Kasavubu in February.
 
1965 Mobutu ousts civilian Government in a bloodless coup and declares himself President. The next year he has four former Government ministers hanged for treason.
 
1970 Presidential elections are held; Mobutu is the only candidate.
 
1972 The year after Mobutu changes the name of his country to Zaire, he changes his own name to Mobutu Sese Seko Kuku Ngbendu waza Banga and urges all Zairians to assume African names.
 
1973 The Government seizes 2,000 economic enter 2/3prises owned by foreigners, with Mobutu profiting the most.
 
1978-1994: DICTATORSHIP AND DISARRAY
 
1978 French paratroopers help Mobutu defeat exiled Zairians invading from neighboring Angola.
 
1990 Mobutu orders a massacre of students at the University of Lubumbashi to quell growing unrest. Belgium, the United States and France cut off assistance and demand democratic reforms. Mobutu ultimately agrees to national conference on reforms but openly bribes supporters and sends the army after opponents.
 
1991 Appoints Etienne Tshisekedi, an opponent, Prime Minister after rioting in the capital but dismisses him 12 days later.
 
1994 Mobutu dissolves legislature.
 
1995-1997: ISOLATION AND DEFEAT
 
1995 Opposition increases; Mobutu spends most of time at palace in Gbadolite in northern Zaire. Mobutu's troops battle opposition supporters, killing nine civilians and one army officer.
 
1996 Mobutu leaves for cancer treatment in Switzerland in July. In eastern Zaire, ethnic Tutsi led by Laurent Kabila rebel in September after local officials try to expel them. Mobutu returns to Zaire in December.
 
1997 Kabila's rebels sweep westward across Zaire. Mobutu-Kabila peace talks in May fail, and on May16, Mobutu gives up power. (pg. 7)

HEADLINE: Without a Parachute

BYLINE: By Anne Matthews; Anne Matthews's most recent book is "Bright College Years: Inside the American Campus Today."

 BODY:

THE CLIFF WALK
 A Memoir of a Job Lost and a Life Found.
 By Don J. Snyder.
 265 pp. Boston:
 Little, Brown & Company. $23.95. 
 At 41, Don Snyder thought he had earned the right to an exceptional life. He'd edited a newspaper and published three books. As an assistant professor of English and creative writing at Colgate University, he threw himself into college teaching, volunteering for extra courses, toiling over student recommendations for weeks and hectoring senior colleagues on their lack of literary passion.
But after three years, his contract was not renewed. Mr. Snyder assumed he could move on and up, as he always had -- to Princeton, perhaps, or another of the Ivies. His wife and children would adjust, eventually. But "when it came to telling Colleen that I had been fired, I could never seem to find the right time, or the right room in our house," he recalls. "There was always her with her lovely pregnant belly and her faith in me, and then there was me with my pink slip."
Ninety-six rejection letters later, Don Snyder's world had shrunk to the back bedroom of a tiny rented house on the coast of Maine. As savings dwindled, he gulped sleeping pills while Colleen kept their young family afloat with heroic economies. After nearly two years of denial and distress, Mr. Snyder jettisoned his many illusions. Hired first as a greenskeeper, then as a construction laborer, house painter and cottage caretaker for the summer rich, he reluctantly embraced the kind of hard work he had evaded all his life.
"The Cliff Walk" is Mr. Snyder's first-person account of life after campus. It blends several genres of memoir: the Orwellian literature of class slide, the lament of the disillusioned academic and the downsizing tale of the midlife executive. Like G. J. Meyer's "Executive Blues" or Jon Katz's corporate-revenge novel "Sign Off," Mr. Snyder's book is a cautionary fable, a scarred survivor's warning to "the class of managerial mercenaries of my generation who moved anywhere for money, who called places home when we had no attachment to the land or the people, but where the opportunity for advancement was high."
Mr. Snyder's middle-class melodrama is strengthened by novelistic pacing and detail. When the author discovers that during his years of false security the work world has mysteriously split into two alien realms -- computer jobs versus mall/prison/hospital jobs -- he starts waking up angry and placing crank calls to former colleagues (asking one, for instance, "how in God's name you ever got through graduate school"). Sitting in the unemployment office, he ostentatiously thumbs a copy of Bellow's "Herzog." He broods on conflicting advice from equally stressed friends: max out your credit cards, buy real estate and declare bankruptcy, grow up.
The book's most memorable scenes record the effects of job loss on family affections and marital trust. While his children count food stamps and keep the thermostat low, their reality-impaired father makes grand gestures: expensive bikes all around, new clothes, binges at McDonald's. His self-pity and their bewilderment are convincingly drawn, as are the glimpses of relatives and friends whose burdens (divorce, brain tumor, multiple sclerosis) often outweigh the narrator's lost-Paradise angst. Many readers would give a lot at this point for an uncensored 20-minute talk with Colleen Snyder. But her husband's domestic portraiture is affectionate and clear; one would recognize her on the street, and the kids too. You wish them well throughout, even as you wish Mr. Snyder would get a grip, especially on his new life.
Unlike thousands of academic exiles before him, he does not try for positions in campus administration, secondary-school teaching, journalism or publishing. He does not become a temp, or scrounge any job he can to feed his family, or even take a computer class during the extra paid year that Colgate gave him. Instead, he lies a lot to insurance companies and collection agencies; brings a mentally ill former student home as a boarder; dramatically tosses his American Lit texts into the town dump; blows a month's food budget on a natty tweed jacket; takes a halfhearted overdose of pills; fantasizes about selling his unborn child; then hands the family savings to a stranger dying of cancer.
"I know that it takes a very weak man to lose his way when he has a beautiful wife and four healthy children living under his roof, no debt, over $3,000 left in the bank, and he's not in a war or facing anything even close to real peril," Mr. Snyder writes dolefully, "but I was so lost. . . . There were too many people, too many talented and driven people waiting at every slot for a way in."
Over the last decade, millions of Americans pushed out of good jobs have largely left in stoic silence. But Mr. Snyder is a natural protester and contrarian. His testament of loss makes grim, instructive reading for upwardly mobile baby boomers, elected officials, academics on both sides of the tenure line and women tied to men whose employment is in jeopardy, or could be.
As a victim of academic oppression, Mr. Snyder is less convincing. He universalizes his experience by casting himself as a stereotypical ambitious yuppie; actually, he was a professional Quixote who transferred late and unsuccessfully to academe. No one put a gun to his head and said, Go teach in college. He reveled in the perks and privileges of professordom, but (like many before him) arrogantly misjudged the realities of faculty work at century's end, especially the pressure to fit in, the absolute need to produce and the desperate competition among the nation's million surplus Ph.D.'s for even the most thankless teaching posts.
Though formerly a journalist, he never asks the classic questions of a reporter in a strange environment: Who runs this place? What do these people really want? Narcotized by comfort and status, seeing only the beauty and not the Darwinian ruthlessness of the campus world, he clung hard and fell hard. In this respect, Mr. Snyder's adventures recall that other popular brand of memoir, the story of addiction and detox. Fortunately, on his journey to another life he took good notes. By book's end, writer and reader have relearned the lessons that both academe and manual labor efficiently teach: (1) Do the work. (2) Think of others. (3) Life is unfair.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

HEADLINE: An Old-Fashioned Modernist

BYLINE: By Bruce McCall; Bruce McCall's memoir, "Thin Ice: Growing Up Canadian," will be published next month.

 BODY:

Between Worlds
 The Autobiography
 of Leo Lionni.
 Illustrated. 295 pp.
 New York: Alfred A. Knopf.
 $35. 
 Leo Lionni was born in 1910. The story of his career over the 87 years from then to now traces not so much the familiarly described arc as one long and smoothly flowing upward curve. Closer inspection reveals this curve to be a dense and intricate pattern of zigs, zags, loops, spikes, dips and almost no long straight stretches -- the spoor of a Renaissance man of the arts restlessly shuttling between Europe and America, among disciplines from graphic design to architecture to painting to illustration to sculpture to writing, and between one esthetic and artistic salon or movement or cohort and another. He fit into every succeeding era as it unfolded, and into every creative milieu. Through his prolific and varied work he left emphatic evidence from the 1920's onward that "Lionni was here." He's still at it today in his studio in Tuscany, generating -- among other things -- further books in a series of fables for children that have sold in the millions worldwide.
They don't offer training for careers like Leo Lionni's in any college. Indeed, to follow in "Between Worlds" his delightfully meandering, serendipitous, utterly unplanned path to fame and fortune is to be reminded that a life so peripatetic, so varied and so powered by pure chance -- no degrees, no grants, no sinecures -- would stun the average young careerist of today.
Leo Lionni was born in Amsterdam in that now mythical age before World War I, and one of this autobiography's charms is the author's keen atmospheric sense, evoking everyday life and customs in gentler times. The Lionnis were a close-knit clan of modest means, proper Dutch burghers, but shot through with culture. Mr. Lionni's father was an accountant, his mother a modestly accomplished concert singer, and his traveling Uncle Willem not only avidly bought up masterworks of then-provocative and affordable modern art but stockpiled them in the homes of relatives. Young Leo had a Chagall hanging in the hallway just outside his childhood bedroom. His imagination being a tinderbox, combustion occurred early; he was already prowling the galleries of Amsterdam's Rijksmuseum with his drawing pad while his contemporaries in knee pants were out kicking soccer balls around. His parents' restlessness for a better life uprooted Leo early and often. He traded Amsterdam for Brussels, Brussels for Philadelphia, Philadelphia for Genoa, Genoa for Zurich before he moved to Milan and then back to Philadelphia as an unemployed 29-year-old. Along the way, despite often precarious family financial straits, a formal education that was spotty at best and a series of soul-deadening clerical jobs, he managed to pick up four languages and fan a rising passion for art, music, architecture, poetry and radical politics. He was from the outset a modernist, full of the fission of Futurism, and wherever he happened to be he seemed to land among young firebrands being geniuses together on the leading edge, as if they had been saving him a seat. This laid the basis for a lifelong network of friendships and contacts with the great and near great in the arts in Europe and America.
By the mid-30's fascism was making the ground shake underfoot for Europe's Jews, and when Hitler marched into the Sudetenland, Leo Lionni, half Jewish himself, was gone. To Philadelphia, of all places, and to a lowly assistant art director's job in a huge and famously staid advertising agency. He was only warming up. His avant-garde sensibilities almost immediately whisked him out of obscurity and onto the "Great Ideas of Man" campaign for the Container Corporation of America -- probably the most ambitious advertising effort dedicated to the intellectual uplift of the masses -- and he soon found himself dispensing patronage to a who's who of artists, from Man Ray to Willem de Kooning to Piet Mondrian to Saul Steinberg, during the long-running campaign.
These lofty connections segued into others and then others, until he was on a first-name basis with Buckminster Fuller, Alexander Calder, Josef Albers, Louis Kahn, Walter Gropius and even Andy Warhol. He was in high demand as a lecturer, teacher, panel member and idea man (he was deeply involved in organizing the first International Design Conference at Aspen, Colo.). In the late 40's, he left Philadelphia to become art director of Fortune magazine and to swim tirelessly in New York's deep cultural waters. Stirrings of inner restlessness could no longer be suppressed, however, and in the early 60's Leo Lionni finally bolted the 9-to-5 commercial life -- and America -- for a farm in Italy and full concentration on creative fulfillment.
His story is that of a man with an exquisitely fine-tuned creative imagination, a clear mind, perfect taste and mercilessly high standards, besotted by the arts to the exclusion of most of quotidian life, which it was his beloved wife Nora's task to handle. His two sons, one of whom died of cancer in his 40's, appear only in rare cameo. This is the story of Leo Lionni, period. His best friends in America were the advertising man Ed Zern and Robert Osborn, the artist. These key figures remain vague -- for example, though Mr. Lionni reproduces a series of his long letters to Osborn, he reproduces none of Osborn's to him.
A confessional tell-all this isn't. Throughout the story the aristocratic good manners and old-fashioned European self-restraint that keep a tight lid on gushing are evident. If Mr. Lionni doesn't have something good to say about someone, he leaves a kind of icy pause in the narrative and moves on to someone worth praising. This is a wise, mellow, richly populated and satisfying autobiography that reviews his life without pettiness.
 

CORRECTION-DATE: Sunday, May 18, 1997

 CORRECTION:
The biographical note on a review of "Between Worlds: The Autobiography of Leo Lionni" on page 13 of the Book Review today misstates the subtitle of the forthcoming book by the reviewer, Bruce McCall. Its full title is "Thin Ice: Coming of Age in Canada."

HEADLINE: Sometimes a Great Nation

BYLINE: By Fareed Zakaria; Fareed Zakaria is the managing editor of Foreign Affairs. His book "Strong Nation, Weak State" will be published this winter.

 BODY:

The American Century
 The Rise and Decline of
 the United States as a World Power.
 By Donald W. White.
 551 pp. New Haven:
Yale University Press. $35. 
 In the summer of 1960, Life magazine organized a symposium on what it called "the most crucial debate of our generation." The question that Henry Luce, the editor in chief, posed was "What is the national purpose of the U.S.A.?" Is the nation great enough? Is it great in the right way? But most of all, what should it do with its greatness?
This kind of talk had been in the air for some time. The Rockefeller Brothers Fund had commissioned a vast project to "clarify the national purposes and objectives" in 1956. Four years later President Dwight D. Eisenhower appointed his Presidential Commission on National Goals. Harvard's eminent historian Oscar Handlin edited a volume on the subject. Even Hans Morgenthau, the theoretician of national power, published a book on "The Purpose of American Politics."
Why does this intellectual atmosphere seem so very different from our own? What made the self-confident superpower of the early 1960's the doubt- ridden and purposeless colossus of today? At some level this is the question Donald W. White asks in his interesting book, "The American Century." The volume is a cultural and intellectual tour of America as a world power, focused mainly on the years after World War II. Mr. White, who teaches history at New York University, looks carefully at the foreign-policy writings of the time, but also at the sociology, literature, movies and even the poetry. While not astounding in its insights, this is a first-rate work, a kind of inner history of the cold war.
Mr. White's answer to the question of what changed the American psyche is essentially that failure, at home and abroad, did. Recognition of problems at home unsettled the happy consensus about American greatness that had formed in the postwar era. By 1962 and 1963, only a few years after Henry Luce's symposium, the Students for a Democratic Society had written the Port Huron Statement and Betty Friedan had published "The Feminine Mystique." From an international perspective, American power declined steadily from the 1960's onward.
There is something incomplete about Mr. White's intelligent answers. Though every society has had dissent and dissenters, compared with most others America has been optimistic and confident for much of its history. And while the United States has declined from the towering heights of the 1950's (when it accounted for over 40 percent of world output), it is still the world's greatest military power, dominates the new international economy and remains the prime example of the political system now sweeping the globe. (With regard to economics, Mr. White's analysis seems curiously dated, as if the book had been written 10 years ago, when Japan and Germany seemed invulnerable and the United States an indebted and unproductive giant.)
So why the ennui? Perhaps our current drift is a product not of failure but rather of success: success in three great projects that began in the 1930's and continued for almost three generations. Having defeated poverty at home (for the most part) and fascism and Communism abroad, we are left with no great national crusades. We stand on the eve of the 21st century all dressed up and with no place to go. Commenting on the mood in the 1950's, the columnist Arthur Krock observed, "The news from the aquarium suggests that what this country really needs is a good 5-cent national porpoise." Adjusting for inflation, that is still true.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 4; Column 5; Travel Desk

LENGTH: 1172 words

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Study Abroad On the Rise

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
BESIEGED with exams and spring fever, college students yearn to be out. It is a likely season for the idea of a semester or a year abroad, possibly in Bora Bora, to take root in underclass minds. And colleges support such dreams, as an asset to graduates' employability and to ease pressure on dormitories.
Many colleges develop and staff their own overseas programs, or link up with an overseas university for a joint project. The colleges are likely to channel their undergraduates to programs where they play a role, but many programs provide credits accepted by colleges other than their sponsors or co-sponsors. 
 At Middlebury College in Vermont, for example, so many students take semesters abroad that the freshman class of 550 to 575 students receives a supplement of 100 additional students in February, who occupy space left by those who take the spring semester abroad. According to Phil Benoit, a spokesman, the college's strong reputation in languages and in overseas study helps to propel this trend, but student awareness of the global economy is a rising factor.
In the expiring academic year, 305 Middlebury students participated in 95 programs in 36 countries; this was 55 percent of the junior class (a rise from 51 percent the year before, and 48 percent the year before).
Internships are now greatly prized, and directors of study-abroad programs are increasingly trying to help students secure work overseas, unpaid if need be.
Connie Horak, the director of overseas studies for the University of Southern California, said that the expense of studying abroad was not much different from that in the United States, except for the irresistible extracurricular travel.
Overseas study by American students is on the rise. In the 1994-95 academic year, 84,403 college students from the United States studied for credit in a foreign country, a jump of 10.6 percent from the year before, according to Richard M. Krasno, president of the nonprofit Institute of International Education. The climb has continued steadily since the organization began keeping records in 1985, except for a plateau in 1991-92 in a time of tension over the Gulf war. In addition, high school students join spring and summer exchange programs, and unnumbered thousands of students and others study everything from languages to viticulture without matriculating.
The Institute of International Education shows a 30 percent rise in students going to China, where 1,257 students matriculated in 1994-95, and a rise of 42 percent for Australia, with 3,346. Europe, however, is the destination for two-thirds of United States students studying abroad, although its market share is decreasing. Britain is far and away the leader, with 19,410 students, which represented a 16 percent rise.
Ms. Horak noted an increase in one-semester tours; many students, she said, cannot afford the time for a whole year away. Mr. Krasno said that the increase in one-semester offerings paralleled the increased diversity of all overseas courses: more places, more schools, more subjects. His organization's current "Academic Year Abroad" is indeed formidable; its 670 pages weigh almost four pounds.
 
Finding the Right Program
College students shopping for overseas courses can usually find "Academic Year Abroad" and the other major reference, Peterson's 1997 "Study Abroad," in libraries or college exchange offices.
The Peterson book, with 1,966 pages, lists 1,500 programs, all affiliated with or sponsored by accredited United States or foreign universities. The International Education book lists 2,430 programs, 60 percent of them sponsored by accredited United States colleges; the rest are offered by nonprofit agencies and cultural organizations like museums. Reading the sections for Florence, Italy, is like reading a seed catalogue: Peterson's has 36 offerings; the International Education list totals 54.
Happily, "Academic Year Abroad" reprints the invaluable 1970's essay "How to Read Study-Abroad Literature" by Lily von Klemperer, who died in 1988. Here is an example, leading off with a quote from a typical ad: " 'Write for a Fully Illustrated Brochure.' Even organizers of high-quality programs love to publicize them with attractive photographs of breathtaking scenery, lively cafe scenes, marble columns and Gothic spires. Unless the brochure devotes equal space to academic facilities, one may well question whether there is any provision at all for serious study," she advises.
"Academic Year Abroad," $42.95, plus $5 for shipping and handling, may be ordered from I.I.E. Books, Post Office Box 371, Annapolis Junction, Md. 20701; (800) 445-0443. Peterson's "Study Abroad," $26.95, plus about $7 for shipping and handling, is sold in bookstores or may be ordered by calling (800) 338-3282 or writing Peterson's, Post Office Box 2123, Princeton, N.J. 08543.
 
High School Programs
The resources for high school students are thinner. The Council on International Educational Exchange, the 50-year-old nonprofit parent of Council Travel and Council Charters, has stopped producing its two books, "The High School Student's Guide to Study, Travel and Adventure Abroad" (1995) and "Smart Vacations, the Traveler's Guide to Learning Adventures Abroad" (1993). But if you can find them in a library, they might provide some valid descriptions.
The high school area is particularly difficult because the programs seldom bear the name of a university, a fact that would provide some guidance to a parent. An excellent but narrow resource is the "Advisory List of International Educational Travel and Exchange Programs." The 1997-98 edition is in preparation because programs are not complete until early in the calendar year and must be evaluated by a committee after that. The 1996-97 edition lists 55 organizations that sought evaluation from the nonprofit Council on Standards for International Educational Travel and were approved. The organizations pay a fee of $1,100 to $16,000, depending on the number of students, for the evaluation. The booklet lists organizations that bring foreign students to the United States as well as those that operate programs overseas, with the emphasis on inbound students.
The standards by which programs are judged are given in the book, and this material can help parents looking at organizations that have never sought listing. The guidelines emphasize the parents' need to know who has direct, hands-on control of a program. The booklet costs $10, postage included, from C.S.I.E.T., 3 Loudoun Street, S.E., Leesburg, Va. 20175; (703) 771-2040.
 
Guide for the Nonstudent
Eclectic, even eccentric, and wide-ranging choices are given in the 1997 Transitions Abroad guide, "Alternative Travel Directory." This 400-page book includes adult education courses, teaching opportunities, and volunteer programs; $19.95, plus $4 shipping and handling. It may be ordered from Transitions Abroad, Post Office Box 1300, Amherst, Mass. 01004; (413) 256-3414.

SECTION: Section 5; Page 6; Column 1; Travel Desk

HEADLINE: FRUGAL TRAVELER;
Along the Grand Canyon, and Down to Its Floor

BYLINE: By SUSAN SPANO

 BODY:
HIGHWAY 89 north of Flagstaff, Ariz., slices straight over the flat, scrub-covered Colorado Plateau. When I drove it, late one Wednesday afternoon in early April, there were snow clouds up ahead. Across the Navajo Reservation to the east, I could see the Echo Cliffs reaching all the way into Utah, and my rear view mirror framed Arizona's crown, 12,655-foot Humphreys Peak in the San Francisco Mountains to the south.
Invigorating sights, all. But somewhere to the northwest lay the region's most remarkable feature: the Grand Canyon. 
 I wished I didn't know it was there, so that I could come upon the great, 277-mile gorge of the Colorado River as the Spanish explorer, Garcia Lopez de Cardenas, did in 1540 -- by surprise. Given all I'd heard and read about America's most vaunted beauty spot, from "Brighty of the Grand Canyon," the children's book by Marguerite Henry about a wild canyon burro, to Wallace Stegner's version of John Wesley Powell's landmark 1869 expedition down the Colorado River in "Beyond the Hundredth Meridian," this was clearly impossible.
Still, I tried to follow Cardenas's path by approaching the Grand Canyon from the east, along Highways 89 and 64, a drive of about 250 miles from Phoenix, as opposed the busier, slightly shorter route to the national park's south entrance near the touristy hamlet of Tusayan. When I reached the scenic turnout on Highway 64 for the gorge of the Little Colorado River, which joins the greater Colorado about 60 miles southwest of Glen Canyon Dam, I decided that if I were Cardenas I'd have looked into the 3,100-foot sheer-walled chasm and turned back, thinking I'd seen all there was to see and missing the Grand Canyon. Colorado River tributaries like the Little Colorado and Bright Angel Creek seem to many almost as impressive as the big river, whose gorge is up to 18 miles across, defining a canyon country rather than a narrow slot.
It was starting to snow, leading me to wonder whether I should have come to the Grand Canyon in early spring at all. The week before I arrived, three feet of snow had fallen on the North Rim (closed until May 15); the South Rim got a foot.
I had never been to the Grand Canyon before and was traveling alone, so I'd resigned myself to the fact that it wouldn't be wise to try anything too adventurous, like backpacking from rim to rim, or to the falls in the Havasupai Indian Reservation. This would be a beginner's trip. I'd stick mostly to the South Rim, where tourist-friendly facilities cluster, including two scenic drives with myriad turnouts, seasonal shuttle bus service, a main visitor center, six lodges, nine restaurants and snack bars, a big grocery store, bank and post office.
If I'd waited until the high, hot summer season, I probably wouldn't have been able to reserve a room in the park; those are booked as much as a year in advance. It seemed important to stay close to the rim; I couldn't see commuting to the canyon from a chain motel outside the park. When I called Amfac, the company that manages the park's lodges, about a month before my visit, I felt lucky to get a historic cabin at Bright Angel Lodge; it had no chasm view but was close to the rim and cost $66 a night.
Apart from camping or a $59 cabin (open seasonally) at Maswick Lodge, about a 10-minute walk from the canyon's edge, the tidy little wood, stone and adobe cottages at Bright Angel Lodge appeared to be the cheapest lodging option in the park. However, the reservations agent didn't mention that Bright Angel also has about 19 equally well-situated rooms with shared baths priced from $38 to $46.
As a lark, I asked about overnight mule trips to Phantom Ranch at the bottom of the canyon, assuming that these would have been booked up, too. But there was space available for a Friday morning (returning about noon the next day), and even the $265 price didn't stop me. I wanted to be among the 1 percent of the millions who visit the Grand Canyon to get to the bottom.
The rate includes the services of a wrangler guide, transportation by mule, lunch, a steak dinner, breakfast, a leather water flask and lodging at Phantom Ranch, set in a cottonwood grove on the banks of Bright Angel Creek, which hatchets through some of the oldest rock in the canyon on its way to the river from the North Rim. Brighty's old stomping ground, and my idea of paradise on earth.
It would have been a lot cheaper to walk down (nine and a half miles on the winding Bright Angel Trail or seven via the steeper South Kaibab) and camp or stay in a hiker's dorm at Phantom Ranch for $22 (though campsites and space in the dorms can be hard to come by). Next trip that's what I plan to do. But this time, I packed my bandanna and boots, and imagined the views I'd get from the back of a big, sure-footed mule.
AT the eastern entrance to the park (admission $20 a car), I told the attendant I'd never seen the Grand Canyon before. He sent me straight to Desert View, a scenic point overlooking the park's eastern precincts. It enjoys a sliver of a view of the Colorado River, mint green when I saw it, curling behind the 70-foot Watchtower, an imitation Anasazi kiva designed in 1932 by Mary Elizabeth Jane Colter. Four other Colter structures (including Bright Angel Lodge), built to resemble Hopi dwellings, Navajo pueblos and mountaineers' cabins, line the South Rim and vie for attention with the natural wonder 4,500 feet below.
The canyon wins, even with clouds dimming the brilliance of its palette and fingering into hard rock valleys between buttes with names like Jupiter Temple and Wotan's Throne.
At every turnoff I tried along the pinon- and juniper-lined East Rim Drive it was the same: light snow, thin crowds and astonishing views. From Lipan Point, I could see how the broad Tonto Platform separates the wide outer gorge from the narrow inner one just above the river. At Grandview, a sign pointed the way down the trail to a mine operated around 1890 by Pete Berry, who found that bringing tourists to the canyon by stagecoach was more profitable than taking copper out.
Since then, tourism in the Grand Canyon has grown, resulting in traffic jams and pollution. To solve the problem, the 78-year-old national park is rebuilding roads around the village, keeps the West Rim Drive closed to private vehicles from mid-April to mid-October and runs a free shuttle service in those months. Other shuttles take visitors around the village or out to Yaki Point, near the popular South Kaibab trailhead, with new routes (plied by electric buses) starting this year. The goal is to ban most cars from the South Rim.
Construction work had made a mess of the village when I was there. Still, I had no trouble driving right past the grand old El Tovar Hotel, built like a Swiss chalet in 1904, around the time that a spur of the Atchison, Topeka & Santa Fe railroad reached the canyon from Williams. The hotel remains the top of the line in the national park ($112 to $168 for doubles, $20 for a steak dinner accompanied by canyon views in the restaurant and $5 for a manhattan at the snug bar), with the modern, motel-like Kachina and Thunderbird Lodges on the rim next door (doubles $102 to $112) running a close second.
Scruffy but endearing Bright Angel Lodge, built in 1935, is just to the west of them: a single-story, wood and stone building with a big fireplace, busy lobby, gift shop, two restaurants, a snack bar, tour desk and an information board bearing forecasts for the following day.
The cabins surround the lodge in a somewhat haphazard way, and look a little poky from the outside. Mine lay rather too close to the main road. But inside it was spacious and quiet, with effective radiators at the base of three walls, a spotless private bath providing plenty of hot water, a hurricane lamp, television, nice double bed covered with a Navajo print spread, and lots of windows. Had one of them opened onto the canyon, the cabin would have been heaven.
I had a filling plate of chicken and beef fajitas in the Bright Angel Restaurant for dinner ($10), and attended the evening ranger program on John Muir, even though I was about to drop. But ranger programs are free; I planned to take in as many as I could during my one full day on the South Rim.
My alarm went off at 6 on Thursday. I jumped into my jeans and ran the 50 steps to the canyon's brink, where the new light was seeking out all the canyon's hidey-holes; joggers pounded by on the Rim Trail, and men with cameras on tripods were talking about f-stops. Then I bought a muffin and a banana (for about $2) at the Fountain snack bar and walked over to the north porch at the El Tovar for coffee with a Navajo ranger named Alice Malatke. She explained how the building of Glen Canyon Dam in 1964 changed the canyon, sweeping away beaches, lowering the river's temperature and attracting non-native plants and animals. But she ended on a decided upbeat, with a Navajo singsong, bidding us to "always travel in beauty."
I attended two more programs led by inspiring, articulate rangers in the course of the day -- a short rim walk and a geology talk at Yavapai Observation Station, during which I learned that almost every day in the summertime someone has to be rescued from trails by helicopter, and that modern science hasn't yet come up with a completely convincing theory to explain the canyon's creation.
My mule trip orientation meeting met at 4 at the rim by Bright Angel Lodge. Our little group was shown how to keep our mules from snitching grass by thrashing them with leather switches, and warned that we could get our money back only if we lost nerve before heading into the canyon. After that we'd be given water flasks and put on the trail to walk back, with our credit cards charged for the full amount.
I wasn't about to wimp out, even though I could barely get my legs around the barrel-chested mule named Connie I was assigned to in Stone Corral the next morning. Marilyn Williams, the tall wrangler from Texas who led my seven-member group, helped me at every turn and was particularly attentive to an elderly lady from Connecticut who'd decided the trip was one of the things she wanted to do before she died.
I'm glad I did it, even though it's tough on the knees, and all along the way down Bright Angel Trail and back up the South Kaibab the next day hikers kept giving us superior looks. They hate the mules, which foul and clog the trails but have been used in the Grand Canyon since the turn of the century.
WE had box lunches, packed with rolls, sausage, cheese, apples and cookies about halfway down at Indian Gardens, where the redbud trees were beginning to flower. Then we squeezed through Tapeats Narrows and ricocheted down the Devil's Corkscrew, reaching the two bridges that span the river near Phantom Ranch in the early afternoon.
Mary Jane Colter designed the four oldest cabins there too, and the Civilian Conservation Corps had a hand in renovations. But I hope no one changes a thing at Phantom Ranch, because when I go back I want it to be exactly the same -- a small cabin enclave with a canteen and dining room, shower house, plenty of benches and river boulders for cogitating, and the swift-flowing creek, named Bright Angel by John Wesley Powell, as a foil to a much muddier stream farther upstream he called the Dirty Devil.
My cabin had a double bed, toilet, sink and windows opening onto fields of blooming beavertail cactuses. In T-shirt weather at canyon bottom, I walked up North Kaibab Trail and put my feet into Bright Angel Creek, returning just in time for a dinner of steak, baked potato and chocolate cake (which cost the hikers who joined us $28 each). Then I watched the setting sun strike the beautiful pink Zoroaster granite along the Colorado River -- wondering where in the world I'd been as happy.
My sleep was as deep as the canyon that night. But before I knew it, there were flapjacks, bacon and scrambled eggs at 6:30, followed by mount-up. Going up is easier on the knees than going down.
On the top, Marilyn shook my hand and gave me a certificate declaring that I'd made it to the bottom of the Grand Canyon by mule. A little hokey, I thought.
I'd rather have her job.
 
The bottom line in the canyon
 
Logistics
I spent about $90 a day on the South Rim of the Grand Canyon, not including car rental and mule trip.
To reach the Canyon in early April, I flew from New York to Phoenix on USAirways, (800) 428-4322; because I planned to drive from Phoenix to Los Angeles, my return was from L.A., with the round trip fare coming to $268. I purchased the ticket through Preferred Holidays, (800) 990-1919, as part of a fly-drive See America package.
I rented an economy car at the airport in Phoenix from Value Rent a Car, (800) 327-2501; the weekly rate was $109, with unlimited mileage, but I also got a 5 percent A.A.A. discount.
 
Excursions
For basic tourist information on the canyon, contact Grand Canyon National Park, Post Office Box 129, Grand Canyon, Ariz. 86023; (520) 638-7888. (To save time, the Park Service suggests marking the envelope "Attention: Trip Planner.") Information about backcountry hiking and camping is available from the Backcountry Office, at the same address, (520) 638-7875; fax (520) 638-2125.
Another way to explore the canyon, in depth and economically, is to take a multiday field seminar offered by the Grand Canyon Field Institute, Post Office Box 399, Grand Canyon, Ariz. 86023; (520) 638-2485.
Train travel to the Grand Canyon is available year round on the Grand Canyon Railway, (800) 843-8724, which makes one round trip from Williams, Ariz., daily; coach class tickets cost $60, including the park entrance fee.
Information on hiking, camping and horseback riding in the Havasupai Indian Reservation, on the South Rim west of the park, is available by calling (520) 448-2141 or 448-2121.
 
Lodging
Amfac Parks and Resorts, (303) 297-2757, fax (520) 638-9247, handles reservations for the seven lodges within Grand Canyon National Park, and Moqui Lodge at the south entrance. Bright Angel, El Tovar, Kachina and Thunderbird are on the rim; Maswik and Yavapai are back from it. At Phantom Ranch, in addition to the dormitories, just two of the 11 cabins are set aside for hikers; they cost $59 a night and can be reserved 11 months in advance. Anyone who can get to the bottom of the canyon can eat there, by reservation (breakfast $12, sack lunch $6, hiker's stew dinner $18 and steak dinner $28).
Amfac takes reservations for the mule ride, too. Participants must weigh under 200 pounds, be at least 4 feet, 7 inches tall and speak and understand English.
Inside the park, call the lodging office, (520) 638-2631, to find a room; in the fall, winter and spring it is not uncommon, because of cancellations, to get space at the last minute.

HEADLINE: Special East End Issue;
The Hamptons' Real Estate Market Is Surging

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT 

 BODY:
THE Hamptons are back.
Their timeless appeal never went out of fashion, of course. But the recession put a crimp in the real estate market even in this gilt-edged enclave. The bottom of that cycle, about 1991, seems like a dim memory to real estate experts now. 
 Today's thriving Hamptons market -- fueled by low interest rates and the marathon bull run on Wall Street -- is at its highest since the frenetic peak of the late 1980's. Parts of the Hamptons have even surpassed the record prices of that era and are setting new benchmarks.
Vacant land is selling so fast that the big worry is how to slow it down -- lest the East End lose the fabled rural look and feel that made it popular. Town, state and Federal programs have set aside millions of dollars to buy open space, but critics fear the funds are too little.
"We're in a race to preserve this place from becoming the same as every other place," said Edwin M. Schwenk. Last year he quit as director of the Long Island Builders Institute to join conservationists in seeking to control growth. Since then, the market's continuing rise has only underscored the issue.
While the Hamptons have long prospered from their proximity to New York City, their cachet has now spread across the nation and overseas, drawing renters and even buyers from afar. Savvy brokers are hiring bilingual agents.
"We have a lot of people coming from London, Italy, France, Germany, South America -- all over," said Peter L. Hallock, president of Allan M. Schneider Associates realty.
Another striking sign of the soaring demand is a new Hamptons trend known as tear-downs. Some buyers are acquiring older, modest houses only to demolish them to make way for their dream country homes.
"People buy these incredibly expensive properties and take down the houses to do what they want to do," said Christopher J. Coy, an architect at Barnes Coy & Associates in Bridgehampton. "Ten years ago you would have seen people working with the house that's there. Now it's almost not a decision to demolish."
At Sotheby's International Realty, Paul C. Brennan, vice president, said: "Sometimes they buy two adjacent lots, knock down both houses and build one new, spreading out for more land and a bigger home." Sotheby's own recent entry into the Hamptons, by taking over the Braverman Newbold agency, is itself an indicator of the market's allure.
In the resale arena, prices of existing homes in parts of the Hamptons have not only reached their prior peaks but now exceed them. High-end properties run into the millions of dollars.
Southampton's Town Supervisor, Vincent J. Cannuscio, said: "We're seeing dramatic escalation in home values and vacant land east of the canal -- and I mean increments upwards of 100 percent since 1992."
The Schneider agency cites a three-bedroom house on 1.2 acres near the ocean in East Hampton. After selling for $1.05 million last year, it is back on the market at $1.7 million, and prospective buyers are said to be making serious inquiries. The property has a spring-fed pond, a newly installed 50-foot pool -- and an appraisal backing up its heady asking price.
New construction is booming so much that building permits in the Hamptons now outnumber those in Brookhaven, the giant suburb to the west. Renovations and additions are also keeping contractors busy.
"Just look at Montauk Highway between 8:30 and 9:30 on a weekday morning," said Stuart A. Epstein, co-owner of Devlin McNiff Real Estate, "and it's literally bumper to bumper with pickups, trucks and vans of guys coming out here to work on renovations, new construction, tear-downs, fix-ups, you name it."
East Hampton's Town Supervisor, Catherine Lester, said: "It seems to be booming on the East End."
Seasonal rentals are also strong, although brokers say the market has softened a bit this spring, perhaps because so many people have been buying and building their own places.
"Rentals were off the wall last year, but people are still raising their prices and getting them," said Frances S. Nill of Cook Pony Farm Real Estate. "We had one client who rented out for $29,000 last summer. This year he put on a tag of $50,000 and got it, almost doubling."
The Hamptons resurgence cuts a sharp contrast to the market for much of the rest of Long Island. There, battered property values are still struggling to recover from the region's devastating loss of jobs at Grumman and other aerospace companies during the recession.
For decades the Hamptons have established themselves as an elite world apart from the conventional suburbs that characterize most of the island.
The natural beauty of the East End's ocean beaches, dunes, bays, harbors, ponds and woods, the picturesque villages and centuries of fishing and farming have all made the South Fork an exclusive retreat and playground for the powerful, talented, rich and famous.
Among the many celebrities who live or summer in the Hamptons are Calvin Klein, Christie Brinkley, Ronald O. Perelman, Alan Alda, Kurt Vonnegut, Tom Hanks, Paul Simon, Cindy Crawford, John F. Kennedy Jr. and Alec Baldwin, to name a few.
"The dynamics of this market is Wall Street, the entertainment business, advertising, the fashion industry, the arts," said Mr. Epstein. Thus the Hamptons market moves in tandem with luxury areas like the Upper East Side of Manhattan, not with the Island's middle-class communities like Valley Stream and Deer Park.
Several demographic, economic, technological and social trends are also converging in the Hamptons.
People who began as occasional summer visitors are staying longer, into the "shoulder seasons." Part-time residents are becoming year-rounders. Renters are becoming owners. Established residents are stepping up to bigger, better places. Recent retirees are settling here permanently. Formerly single boomers now arrive with families in tow, seeking more room.
Telecommuters are spending more time out east and less in the city.
"A literary agent friend of mine moved out here and started out taking the jitney back to the city three days a week, then two, now one," said Mr. Epstein.
Mr. Hallock said: "A lot of people have gone from summer to year-round country homes, or coming out every weekend except maybe in the dead of winter. You have writers and financial people, and as long as you've got your computer, fax and telephone, you're all set."
The national economic recovery has benefited the Hamptons.
"A lot of what fuels this market is Wall Street, and Wall Street has done fabulous," said Pattie A. Romanzi, owner of Par East Mortgage Company in East Hampton. "People are getting big bonuses and commissions and have money to spend. New York is always going to be the financial capital, and this will be the playground.
"This has also become a new home for Hollywood. In the summer a lot of them set up shop and work here, and some stay year-round. Billy Joel has been here for ever and ever, and Steven Spielberg for a long time. We just got a head writer for 'Another World' who just gave up everything in L.A. and moved here. He works by phone and fax and goes to L.A. when he needs to."
Ever since 21 families of English settlers bought Southampton from the Shinnecock Indians 357 years ago -- for 16 thick cloaks and a promise of 60 bushels of corn -- local real estate has proven to be a winning investment, the experts say.
"The Hamptons are like a blue chip stock -- although it may go down, it will always come back," Miss Romanzi said. Her reasoning is simple: "They can never take the ocean away."
An appraiser, Peter N. Davidson of East Hampton, said: "The East End is always going to remain strong, the last market to lose value in a recession and the first market to gain value coming out of a recession. As the so-called megalopolis has developed from Washington to Boston, this has to remain a prime vacation destination."
But the Hamptons are not a monolithic community, and not all parts are sharing equally in the boom.
"I live in the poor Hamptons -- Hampton Bays," Supervisor Cannuscio said. "We have not seen the big price escalation there and in East Quogue and Westhampton as elsewhere, but more in line with general inflation."
The Hamptons offer an enormous variety of housing, from modest prefabricated homes in out-of-the-way corners to magnificent country estates and oceanfront mansions.
"We're selling everything from $150,000 houses to $15 million properties," said Mr. Hallock of the Schneider agency.
The Cook agency recently sold a four-bedroom bayfront house for $375,000 -- up from its previous sale price of $270,000 just two years before. Cook also was the broker for a stone castle in Southampton, complete with a moat and suits of armor, that went for a king's ransom of $1.45 million.
"The term 'the Hamptons' is a beef for a lot of us," said Mr. Brennan of Sotheby's. "Every Hampton has its own flavor and ambiance." Miss Romanzi said: "When people hear 'the Hamptons,' they invariably think of the rich, but there are a lot of regular people, too."
At the top of the Hamptons pecking order, brokers agree, is East Hampton, with Southampton not far behind. As usual, the high end is doing the best.
"There is what I call the astronomical market, in the $900,000 to $10 million range, like Lily Pond Lane and Further Lane, where you have celebrities like Lee Radziwill, Jerry Della Femina and Martha Stewart," said Michael G. Pavlakos, owner of East Coast Appraisal Services. "It's not uncommon to see a $10 million listing there go for $10 million. That market is rated excellent."
Although some traditional price boundaries still hold -- property east of Shinnecock Canal, for example, fetches bigger price tags than parcels to the west -- others are blurring. While homes south of Montauk Highway have always sold for a premium, now expensive new homes are being built across the road as well.
"I'm amazed that north of the highway there are pockets of homes selling between $700,000 and $1 million," said Miss Romanzi, the mortgage broker.
Another 1990's wrinkle has been the advent of the Atlantic Golf Club in Bridgehampton, pushing up home prices on lots bordering its course.
"Spec builders are back," Mr. Hallock said, referring to speculative developers. "Back in the 80's they would build three or four at a time, competing with themselves. Now it's mostly one at a time, and it's usually sold by the time the foundation gets poured."
Although the current market is robust, brokers agree that volume has not reached the frenzied extreme of the late 1980's, when people bought properties without even seeing them, bid more than the asking price and flipped properties for resale profits without ever occupying them -- all symptoms of a market bubble threatening to burst.
Much of today's market comes from Hamptonites themselves as repeat buyers.
"I've done business with some people who have bought and sold four times in six years," Miss Romanzi said. "They're smart people who always buy right. Typically, they're moving up in size and location or changing architectural styles."
Brokers say that buyers' tastes have shifted from modern designs back to traditional cedar shingle or wooden clapboard styles -- and to a synthesis that some call post-modern. "It's got the traditional exterior but a modern inside with wide open spaces and cathedral ceilings," said Ms. Nill of Cook Pony Farm Real Estate.
One verity has endured through all fads. "There's a tremendous clamor for anything on, or near, or within sight of water -- be it ocean, bay, harbor or pond," Mr. Epstein said. "There's a lot of it here, but they're not making any more of it, so the value is increasing tremendously."
Growth has fostered a flourishing cultural and social life, which has only added to the Hamptons' charm and spurred commercial real estate with art galleries, antique shops, boutiques, chic restaurants and nightclubs of the moment.
"The Hamptons are more exciting," Mr. Epstein said, ticking off such items as the film festival, a new musical festival and a major improvement in restaurants. "The library has a $3 million addition," he added, "Guild Hall is thriving, the vineyards, and there's an equestrian thing happening with polo."
Supervisor Cannuscio added: "We see a tremendous number of summer events using the mantle of charitable causes."
Strict town and village zoning requirements for large lots are credited with keeping standards -- and property values -- high. Mr. Epstein said: "The Hamptons retains its beauty -- you don't feel you're living in a suburb or subdivision."
Yet growth has brought problems like traffic congestion and a scarcity of parking.
And the old ways continue to disappear. "Where I used to look out at potato fields, now you look out at homes," said Dennis F. Deuel, owner of Do-Well Construction in Southampton. "The open space is less and less each year, but the quality of life is still good."
Mr. Epstein views the changes as positive. "If you're an old-time Bonacker who made a living fishing or farming, you might not see it the same way," he said, using the traditional word for a South Fork native. "But that's what happens with the march of time. This is no longer a farming and fishing community, but we're trying to preserve remnants of both."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Home construction is encroaching on East End farmland. New homes, top, with farmland in the foreground, along Route 27A. A house under construction in East Hampton. (Tapp Franke for The New York Times; Vic DeLucia/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Q. & A.

 BODY:

Stabilized Rent Rise Still Rising
 
Q. I am a rent-stabilized tenant in Manhattan. My current lease was due for renewal on Oct. 1, 1996. Last summer, before the renewal date, my landlord offered me a new two-year lease with a 4 percent increase. I signed and returned the lease on June 5, 1996, and it was signed and returned to me by the landlord on June 21, 1996. On June 24, 1996, the Rent Guidelines Board voted to allow a 7 percent increase for two-year lease renewals beginning Oct. 1, 1996. In February, the landlord suddenly demanded the 7 percent increase. I claim that the fully executed lease at 4 percent was a binding contract. Who is right? . . . Joseph Roberts, Manhattan.
A. Gary H. Schatsky, a Manhattan real estate lawyer, said that all lease-renewal forms for rent-stabilized tenants have a box that can be checked if the applicable guideline increase is unknown at the time the lease is executed. When that box is checked, Mr. Schatsky said, any rent increase in the lease is subject to adjustment when the new increase is ordered. 
 Assuming that the form was filled out properly, he said, the tenant would have been on notice that the increase would be adjusted when the new rates were set. In such a case, Mr. Schatsky said, the landlord could have notified the tenant of the new increase prior to the lease commencement date and adjusted the rent accordingly.
In the case described, however, it appears that the landlord did not notify the tenant of the increase for seven months, and, in fact, accepted the 4 percent increase for four months before requesting a change. Under those circumstances, Mr. Schatsky said, the tenant can argue that the landlord has waived his or her right to an adjustment. If the landlord continues to demand the increase, he said, the tenant can file a lease violation complaint with the Division of Housing and Community Renewal or he can continue paying the lower rent and assert the landlord's waiver as a defense to any legal action filed by the landlord.
 
Condo Renter Calls Elevator Fee Unfair
 
Q. I am a rent-stabilized tenant in a condominium and the board of managers is now imposing a $100 fee plus a $500 security deposit on residents who wish to use the building's elevators for delivery or removal of bulky items like furniture. I have been using the elevators for the last 20 years for free and there is nothing in my lease that permits the imposition of a fee. Is the board of managers exceeding its authority? If so, what recourse do I have if building employees physically prevent the delivery of furniture because of failure to pay the fee and security deposit? . . . Melvin Schechter, Manhattan.
A. "The board of managers can impose reasonable fees upon members of the condominium association," said Paul Gulielmetti, a Manhattan lawyer who specializes in real estate. "But the real question is: Can they pass those fees on to a rent-stabilized tenant? I think the answer to that is no."
The letter-writer, Mr. Gulielmetti said, is someone's tenant. As such, he said, the tenant is entitled to a continuation of the services he has enjoyed for the past 20 years. And while the board of managers may impose reasonable fees upon condominium owners, he said, they cannot change the terms of the letter-writer's tenancy. If fees are required, Mr. Gulielmetti said, they are most likely the responsibility of the owner of the apartment.
The tenant, he said, should advise the owner, in writing, that he will not be responsible for payment of any fees or deposits required by the board of managers. If building employees interfere with a furniture delivery, Mr. Gulielmetti said, the tenant can then either withhold his rent or file a complaint with the Division of Housing and Community Renewal demanding a reduction of rent based upon decreased services.
