HEADLINE: Special East End Issue;
'Titanic' Adds Another Feather to His Cap

BYLINE: By WILLIAM GRIMES 

 BODY:
NEVER let it be said that Peter Stone shies away from the big subjects. In a Broadway season packed with new musicals, "Titanic," for which Mr. Stone wrote the book, dwarfs the competition in bulk, weight, height and cost. The big gets the big treatment onstage, with 43 named parts, a budget of $10 million and an attention to historical detail that betrays Mr. Stone's hand.
"I'm a political person, although I don't mean that in the Washington, D.C., sense," said Mr. Stone, sitting in the Lunt-Fontanne Theater several hours before the play opened, oblivious to the banging hammers and whirring drills onstage. "I'm interested in the dissemination of information." 
 No question, theatergoers get a thorough history lesson along with the drama in "Titanic," a show that spends as much time on the Edwardian class structure, the development of the wireless, and the economics of trans-Atlantic shipping as it does on the scramble for the lifeboats.
"This was the first failure of the Industrial Revolution," said the erudite Mr. Stone, who also has a reputation as a wit. "It didn't work because man forgot that there will always be icebergs. People like that, the sense of nature as a force that humbles man and puts him in a proper perspective."
With the opening-night reviews looming, Mr. Stone had every right to be in a lather, but with 13 Broadway shows under his belt, he has achieved the slightly world-weary manner of someone who knows that the creators of a musical cannot control its fate. From here on in, what happens, happens.
For Mr. Stone, what happens has tended to be good, which is why, for the last 26 years, he has lived a reasonable approximation of the good life in a house in Amagansett surrounded by 20 acres of woods.
Mr. Stone, who has written dozens of musicals, films and television movies, is best known for "1776," a musical that allowed him to indulge his passion for history and make a dollar or two in the process. The play won three Tony Awards, including best musical, and ran for 1,217 performances. "I did it because I realized I didn't know anything about the American Revolution, which was strange, because I was a good history student," Mr. Stone said. "I knew about Franklin, this foxy old guy with the kite, but Hancock, no. He was just a large signature on an insurance policy."
Not everyone would look at the writing of the Declaration of Independence and see singing and dancing, but Mr. Stone liked the idea of displaying what he calls "a kind of impudent affection"' for the old boys who drafted the thing. "I wanted to de-cardboardize them," he said.
More recently, he pressed Will Rogers into service, weaving the life story of the humorist into a naughty Ziegfeld revue in "The Will Rogers Follies," a show that bagged six Tonys. In between, he picked up a Tony for his book for "Woman of the Year"' in 1983. Broadway can be a cruel taskmaster, but Mr. Stone has skated down the street without hitting too many potholes.
Destiny intended him for a different career. His father, a history teacher, moved his family to Los Angeles in the 1920's and, after working as a script reader, became a producer and a screenwriter at Fox studios, where he turned out Tom Mix pictures. The script, it would seem, was written, but Mr. Stone took a wayward path. In the world capital of the movies, he discovered the theater.
After studying at Bard College and the Yale School of Drama, Mr. Stone headed for Paris, where he spent 13 years working for CBS radio and television. It was a nice life, hanging out with Art Buchwald, working with "Murrow's Boys," the journalistic heirs of the Edward R. Murrow era. When Mr. Stone was not busy writing and reading straight news stories for radio, he did television features on subjects like the Arc de Triomphe horse race, the Cannes Film Festival or Princess Grace's wedding. In other words, he fearlessy took on the really tough assignments.
"I was getting a sentimental education and letting Hollywood rub off me," he said. His first venture into the commercial theater was odd. His agent, as it happened, represented the venerable actor Alfred Drake, whom he envisioned in the lead role of a musical version of "Kean," Jean-Paul Sartre's play about the 19th-century Shakespearean actor Edmund Kean. The agent figured that Mr. Stone, who knew French, could handle the assignment of writing the musical's book. He could, he did, and the play opened at the Broadway Theater in November 1961. It achieved, as the French say, a succes d'estime. Translated, that means "nice reviews, no box-office coin."
Mr. Stone was hooked. He had the good fortune to strike up an acquaintance with Frank Loesser, the creator of "Guys and Dolls" and "Most Happy Fella."
"He gave me a crash course in musicals," Mr. Stone said. "He knew everything, and he was articulate and precise."
Mr. Stone went on a tear. He picked up an Emmy in 1962 for an episode he wrote for the television drama "The Defenders." Drawing on his Parisian experience, he wrote a mystery called "Charade," which became a film starring Cary Grant and Audrey Hepburn. Mr. Stone's screenplay for the film led to a five-picture deal with Universal. His follow-up film, "Father Goose" (yes, Cary Grant again), earned Mr. Stone and his fellow screenwriter Frank Tarkoff an Oscar for best screenplay.
Mr. Stone stumbled with "Skyscraper," a musical about a plucky reporter who tries to stop predatory developers. The musical's main contribution was to throw Julie Harris and Charles Nelson Reilly together. The result was marriage, and Mr. Reilly is now directing Ms. Harris in "The Gin Game" on Broadway, so something came of the effort. "A terrific idea, but it never gelled," said Mr. Stone of "Skyscraper." On Broadway, no one has ever admitted to a bad idea.
But then came "1776," and a Tony Award for Mr. Stone, who rolled right along, writing "My One and Only," "Two by Two," "Sugar," "Woman of the Year," "Will Rogers Follies," and a half dozen other musicals. With "Titanic," he joins forces again with the composer and lyricist Maury Yeston, who worked with him, behind the scenes, to patch up "Grand Hotel" a few years back.
In "The Season," his classic study of Broadway, William Goldman described the plight of the musical book writer in piteous terms. People come to musicals to hear the music and watch the production numbers, he argued, while the hapless book writer simply sets up the transitions into the singing and dancing. Mr. Stone thinks otherwise.
"People don't know what a book is," he said. "They think it's the jokes. Well, everybody knows the actors make those up as they go along. A book is a concept and a structure, and dialogue is the smallest part." The Law of Stone is simple: no book, no musical. "You can have the best score in the world, but if the book is weak, it won't work. On the other hand, if the book is good, it can carry a mediocre score."
Misconceptions about the role of the book annoy Mr. Stone. So does the term "Hamptons."
"Anyone who calls it the Hamptons doesn't live there," he said. Mr. Stone and his wife began spending time on the East End of Long Island a little more than 30 years ago, when they rented a summer house in East Hampton that once stood on the grounds of Steven Spielberg's estate. They have been year-rounders since buying their Amagansett house and tend to socialize with old pals like Sidney Lumet, Nora Ephron, Alan Pakula, Ben Bradlee, Avery Corman or John Leo. During high season, he hunkers down, pulls up the drawbridge, and, buffered by his woods, tunes out the honking horns and Type-A behavior that signal the migratory influx from Manhattan.
At the moment, "Titanic," which opened to mixed reviews, awaits the benediction that a fistful of Tony awards can confer. Six new musicals are fighting it out, and Mr. Stone's big baby could use a lift. In the meantime, the pot continues to bubble. The Roundabout Theater is presenting a revival of "1776" this summer, and Mr. Stone has two projects on the drawing board. The first is "Curtains," a collaboration with John Kander and Fred Ebb that has been marinating for a long time. The second is "Love Me, Love My Dog," a show with music by Jimmy Webb. "It's relatively modest," Mr. Stone said. "But then, any show would be after this."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Peter Stone, who wrote the book that has become the new Broadway musical "Titanic." (Jack Manning/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: MUSIC;
When the Performance Is a Prize

BYLINE: By ROBERT SHERMAN 

 BODY:
THE concert season is winding down but several musical enticements remain. Today at 3 the Connecticut Valley Chamber Orchestra concludes its year at Trinity Episcopal Church, Hartford, with the group's music director, Tibor Pusztai, leading the all-volunteer ensemble in Ralph Vaughan Williams's "Fantasia on a Theme by Thomas Tallis" and Schumann's "Spring" Symphony. Also featured are two soloists: the orchestra's principal clarinetist (and teacher in the Torrington Schools), Gwendolyn Winkel, playing the Nielsen Concerto, and Erin Keefe, a junior at Williston-Northhampton School and winner of Hartford Symphony's Young Artists Competition, who collects her performance prize with Saint-Saens's Violin Concerto No. 3.
The recent explosion of interest in medieval music has spawned many new groups and hundreds of recordings, but few ensembles have caused a greater stir than the women known as Anonymous 4. Their a cappella vocal blend has given ancient music a fresh intensity, and their compact disks (half a dozen of them so far) have been longtime residents on Billboard's classical best-seller charts. 
 Anonymous 4 (Ruth Cunningham, Marsha Genensky, Susan Hellauer and Johanna Maria Rose) will be in South Church, New Britain, today at 4; the program celebrates "Vespers of 1210," which the ensemble describes as "a solemn vespers service for the Feast of Mary's Assumption, from the golden age of medieval music at the Cathedral of Notre Dame in France."
At 3 o'clock this afternoon a free program at the Rye High School in Westchester County features the United States Military Academy Band under the direction of Lieut. Col. David Deitrick. Among attractions of the 3 o'clock concert are performances of Ronald Lo Presti's remembrance of J.F.K., "Elegy for a Young American;" David Amram's "Rondo alla Turca," with the composer playing the wood flute solo; show tunes sung by Sgt. Mary Kay Messinger, and a lively demonstration of close-order musical drill by West Point's Hellcats Fife and Bugle Corps.
Then at 4 this afternoon, a free open house at Caramoor offers previews of the summer festival. Among those expected to attend are the singer Barbara Cook, the pianists Misha Dichter and Stella Simakova, the violinist-conductor Peter Oundjian and the conductor Will Crutchfield. More information, including driving directions, can be obtained by calling (914) 232-5035 or (914) 232-1252.
And also in Westchester County this afternoon is a 5 o'clock recital by the pianist Earl Buys at Wainwright House (260 Stuyvesant Avenue); Mr. Buys's program includes Shostakovich's Prelude and Fugue in C Major as well as sonatas by Chopin and Beethoven.
The Hartt School of Music in West Hartford held its commencement concert last night, but the school's community division still has a few more events scheduled. On Friday evening at 7:30, William Willett presides over the Greater Hartford New Horizons Band, an ensemble of older musicians performing marches and concert pieces in Millard Auditorium.
The following week, string honors winners offer 7 P.M. recitals at Millard on May 27, 28 and 29. Two more concerts, in Berkman Auditorium on May 30 and 31, also at 7, will be performed by woodwind, brass and percussion honorees. All the events are open to the public without charge; more information can be obtained by calling (860) 768-4451.
Also ready to call it a season are the Armstrong Chamber Concerts. The oboist Gerard Reuter, the violist Louise Schulman, the cellist Michael Mermagen and the pianist Jonathan Feldman join the violinist and artistic director Helen Armstrong in quartets by Mozart and Dvorak as well as Charles Martin Loeffler's "Two Rhapsodies." The ensemble will play in a private home in the Greenwich area on Friday night at 7; a public performance takes place in First Congregational Church on the Green, Washington, next Sunday afternoon at 3. (860) 868-0522.
They called Bill Monroe "the father of bluegrass," and several of his former band members -- the banjo master Bill Keith, Clarence (Tater) Tate at the fiddle and Ernie Sykes Jr. on string bass -- are getting together for a tribute. The 8 P.M. Saturday concert at the Quick Center for the Arts, Fairfield University, will be preceded by a free jam from 5 until about 7:30, with outdoor picnic sites available. Normally, audiences are lectured about taping professional performances but in this case audience members are invited to tape the segment called "I Remember Bill." (203) 254-4010.
The group also gets together at 8:30 P.M. next Sunday at the Emelin Theater in Mamaroneck. A 5 o'clock screening of "High Lonesome" and a barbecue at 7 are part of this get-together. The Emelin's box office number is (914) 698-0098.
Falls Village is alive with the sounds of folk, as the New York Pinewoods Club arrives in Connecticut for its annual Spring Folk Music Weekend, from Friday through May 26. Bob Malenky, Bill Amatneek, Roy Harris and Michael O'Leary Johns are among the guest performers at all sorts of workshops, concerts, dances, group sings and more; the cost (averaging a little under $200 for a three-day weekend, $250 for all four days) includes kosher meals; the number to call for more details is (718) 575-1906.

HEADLINE: WESTCHESTER BRIEFS

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:

Student Killer
Judge Peter M. Leavitt of Westchester County Court has revoked a controversial sentence he imposed for a fatal stabbing inside Mount Vernon High School and instead ordered the killer, Hopeton Minott, 20, to state prison for three to nine years. 
 On Oct. 16, 1995, a Westchester County jury convicted Mr. Minott of first-degree manslaughter in the 1994 stabbing death of a fellow student, Shebuel Jackson, 17.
Judge Leavitt originally sentenced Mr. Minott to five years' probation as a youthful offender.
But last week, the judge vacated the earlier sentence after finding that the defendant had obtained it by making untrue statements to the court about his participation in a separate crime, a Brooklyn holdup, which occurred two months after the killing.
Mr. Minott, who was indicted for the gunpoint robbery of a Brooklyn restaurant, said he was not guilty and claimed that it was a person wearing his coat who committed the robbery.
Later, Mr. Minott accepted a bargain in that case and pleaded to a reduced weapons-possession charge. He is serving a sentence in that case of one and a half to three years.
Judge Leavitt was criticized by Westchester District Attorney Jeanine Pirro and others for his lenient treatment of Mr. Minott in the killing.
 
Welfare Developments
Westchester's Medicaid Managed Care program for welfare recipients, the first of its kind in New York, has been chosen as a model for other counties in the state. Also, another Westchester initiative, a pilot proposal to identify and treat Home Relief recipients suffering from drug or alcohol addiction, has won state approval.
The State Health Department is asking Westchester to help it introduce the Medicaid Managed Care Program in 31 counties.
"As the first in the state to introduce a managed-care system on a countywide basis, Westchester is leading the way for other counties throughout New York," said County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke.
He estimated that the county's program saved Westchester taxpayers more than $12 million last year. Managed care for welfare recipients was first put into place last year, using a competitive bidding process to select managed-care plans. Currently, five managed-care plans are serving 29,000 Westchester welfare recipients.
Under the program, health care providers guarantee a rate ceiling, unlike Medicaid, which is based on a fee-for-service system.
The other project -- a joint effort of the county's Departments of Social Services and Community Mental Health -- will assess all Home Relief applicants and recipients and enroll those with drug or alcohol problems in the Coordinated Care Program.
It is estimated that drug-addicted welfare recipients cost taxpayers $18 million a year.
"We know that 10 percent of the Home Relief population is using 77 percent of our Medicaid dollar resources," said Mary E. Glass, the Social Services Commissioner.
The program has been approved as a demonstration project by the State Department of Health.
 
Bartender Law Sought
County Legislator Paul J. Noto has sponsored a resolution calling on the state to raise the minimum age for bartenders to 21 from 18.
Mr. Noto said he was prompted by the recent death of a 21-year-old Fordham University student from Port Chester, which is in his district. Mr. McNeil disappeared in March after leaving a bar on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. The student, a junior who was studying accounting, was later found drowned, but no foul play was suspected.
"The tragic loss of young Patrick McNeil Jr., who was allegedly served alcohol by an 18-year-old bartender in Manhattan, has highlighted a long-existing problem of bars not enforcing drinking laws," Mr. Noto said. "It is no surprise that many bartenders under the age of 21 are having difficulty saying no to their peers who come into a bar looking to be served. The law as it exists today doesn't make sense, and it just doesn't work."
Mr. Noto called it a loophole in the law to allow someone too young to drink to serve liquor. The resolution will need at least 9 votes in the Board of Legislators before going to Gov. George E. Pataki.
"To the extent that some good can come of a tragedy, I think this is a step in the right direction," Mr. Noto said.
 
Running for Governor
Myron R. Schoenfeld, the Scarsdale cardiologist who ran for President in 1995, has announced his candidacy for the Democratic nomination for Governor.
The 68-year-old doctor said his platform, based on idealism and pragmatism, includes a plan to use landfill to build islands in the Atlantic Ocean for airports, garbage incinerators, prisons, casinos and high-rise apartments.
Dr. Schoenfeld said he dropped out of the Presidential race at the end of November 1995 because he ran out of money.
He is optimistic about this race, however, and said last week that he thought he stood a 60 to 75 percent chance of winning, "because people are dissatisfied."
To get on a statewide primary ballot, he would need 15,000 signatures on nominating petitions. He said he expected to do that and to raise $10 million to $20 million for the campaign.
"This is atrociously expensive, but I think it's doable," he said.
He said he decided to become a candidate one morning in 1991 when he was reading the newspaper and expressed frustration over the way the country was being run.
His platform includes decentralization of state government and private corporations, diversification of the economy, improvement of the quality of life in rural areas and aid to small, independent farmers, among other things.
 
'Bear Club Med'
The 195-pound black bear that had 25 police officers, a handful of State Department of Environmental Protection biologists and newspaper reporters in hot pursuit on May 7 is now reportedly lolling in the Catskills, happy to be free of the cares of civilization, secondhand pizza grabbed surreptitiously behind restaurants and immobilizing dart guns.
Dick Henry, a big-game biologist for the state, said the bear, finally caught on the 16th hole of Ridgeway Golf Course in White Plains, was released last Saturday in a 500,000-acre area that his captors described as "Bear Club Med." It is a heavily forested area upstate that is home to 600 other bears -- many of them unattached females looking for a furry Prince Charming, Mr. Henry said.
The pudgy bear is believed to be not more than 18 months old, even though he is larger than most his age. It was suspected that his mother, probably a resident of the Berkshires, tossed him out because she was getting ready to start another family.
Still small by bear standards, Westchester's wandering bear may be having temporary trouble attracting a member of the opposite sex because older, larger bears get the best females, Mr. Henry said.
The bear had wandered for a week through Mount Pleasant, Greenburgh and north Yonkers without success in his mating mission before being caught.
Mr. Henry had hoped to chase him up a tree and then immobilize him, but the bear refused, probably because a mostly healed wound on his side was still sore and made climbing painful. ELSA BRENNER

HEADLINE: For Junior Achievers, Volunteers Are Key

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
ALL the emphasis recently focused on the importance of volunteers comes as no surprise to Junior Achievement, the organization that has been relying on volunteers for 78 years. Since Junior Achievement's founding in 1919, its partnerships with volunteers in the business community have been a major strength.
"We're the largest and oldest economic education organization in the world that gives young people practical knowledge and experience in the competitive private enterprise system," said Angela D. Giustino, president of Junior Achievement of the Hudson Valley in Elmsford, which serves Westchester. 
 "Through the volunteer efforts of more than 700 teachers and business people, we have 9,000 students involved in our school-to-work programs, teaching them how business works," Ms. Giustino said. "But we need more volunteers. Schools all over the the county are waiting. We're looking for energetic people, willing to give an hour a week as a consultant to a Junior Achievement class at one of our local schools."
Maureen Walker, controller for the city of Mount Vernon, has been a classroom volunteer for Junior Achievement for four years.
"I don't have the time, but I make time because teaching my three classes every week is the most rewarding thing I do," said Ms. Walker, who besides her demanding job runs a household that includes three children. "I feel my work in the program impacts on students' futures in a very positive way. For instance, my 15- and 16-year-olds need to know how adults handle money. I show them the importance of budgeting, how to divide a salary so that something is left for emergencies. Most of my students aren't familiar with checks or checking accounts. But by the end of the program they know how to balance one."
Ms. Walker, who is also a member of the Junior Achievement board, said her personal goal is to make sure every school in Mount Vernon has a Junior Achievement program. "That means we have to find 25 new volunteers," she said. "The students love the program, and volunteers soon realize that they are the people who can inspire them to develop positive attitudes toward work."
According to an independent study made by Formative Evaluation Research Associates of Salt Lake City, economics students in Junior Achievement scored significantly higher than did students in traditional high school economics classes.
"The Junior Achievement component is an extremely important addition to my teaching," said Jeffrey Roberts who teaches a mandatory economics and government course for 12th graders at Gorton High School in Yonkers. "The consultants bring real experiences to the classroom and make economics come alive."
Every Tuesday Oscar Melendes, an International Business Machines executive who works with I.B.M. global customers on price bids, teaches students in Mr. Roberts's economics class about business practices.
"It's a hands-on class," Mr. Roberts observed. "With the help of Mr. Melendes, the students formed Senior Inc. -- an honest-to-goodness company -- elected officials, chose a product, Senior T-shirts, and then sold stock."
Each of the 27 students bought three shares of stock at $2 a share. The president's salary was set at $5. Other officials were paid $4, and it was decided that the sales staff would receive a 10 percent commission.
"The T-shirts, designed by the students, feature our mascot, a wolf, on the front and Gorton High School '97 on the back, with every graduating student's name woven into the '97' ", Mr. Roberts said. "They mounted a good marketing campaign and the T-shirts appear to be a good product choice. Sales are brisk. The company will be dissolved at the end of the school year with the profits to be divided among the student shareholders."
Such a firsthand business experience, Mr. Melendes said, gives students an understanding of the free enterprise system and prepares them for the work force.
"This is my first semester as a volunteer, and I am committed to the Junior Achievement concept," Mr. Melendes said. "I see how the program fosters positive attitudes toward work. For me, it has also been personally rewarding. My public-speaking skills have been much improved."
In addition to working as a consultant to the Senior Inc. company, Mr. Melendes has introduced his students to the mysteries of the stock market.
"I have turned the Dow Jones Industrial Average into an assignment, an exercise in buying and selling stocks," he said. "Students pick three stocks in different industries and track them for a couple of weeks. They then write a page on each stock, commenting on its performance, why they selected it, and so on."
The time commitment to the program, required of volunteers, is 45 minutes a week for 8 to 10 weeks. "Some time for preparation is also necessary," Mr. Melendes said, "but the rewards are great."
John Sahm agrees. Mr. Sahm, vice president and general manager of Royal Insurance in Elmsford, has been a Junior Achievement volunteer for seven years.
"I probably learned as much from my kids at Lincoln High School in Yonkers as they did from me," he said. "They are future consumers, and they had a very different approach to the marketplace. I got a fresh look at how business is regarded by the up-and-coming generation, which was extremely valuable to me. In turn, I gave future employees insight as to what the workplace will demand of them."
Mirroring the growing interest of businesses in international markets, is the Junior Achievement International program.
"In the last two years, Junior Achievement programs were set up in 90 countries around the globe, despite the fact that volunteerism isn't big abroad," Ms. Giustino said. "What is interesting is that with the breakup of the Soviet Union, Russia, which came to us for help in setting up a program, now has the largest Junior Achievement operation outside the U.S."
The international aspect of Junior Achievement, Ms. Giustino said, was recently demonstrated at an economics symposium involving 25 countries.
Using computers to make economic decisions on how to run a global company, 12th graders from 25 countries competed for market share.
"Russia won; Japan came in second," Ms. Giustino said, "which shows that Junior Achievement International is giving students in other nations a firm understanding of the role of business in a global economy."
For information on how to become a volunteer, the number to call is 592-6040.

HEADLINE: Bias Still a Concern At Private Golf Clubs

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
LAST weekend at St. Andrew's Golf Club in Hastings-on-Hudson, Wall Street brokers and corporate executives took time out from their daily pressures to commune with nature on the links and possibly break 90 -- all for the price of a $20,000 initiation fee and about $9,000 a year.
At the county-owned Saxon Woods Golf Course in Scarsdale, Ray Gutierrez was also listening to the birds and smelling springtime in the air. And he was likewise hoping for a score that he could brag about, but for less than $20 a day and no initiation fee. "I love this game!" the retired bus driver said. 
 George and Arlene Rosenberg were similarly enthralled with both the sport and the countryside at the private Ridgeway Country Club in White Plains where, like their counterparts at St. Andrews, they had paid dearly for the privilege.
While the golfers at the three courses shared a common passion, they were different in most other respects, and that was reflected in where they teed off. The membership at Ridgeway, where the Rosenbergs belong, is mostly Jewish and white; at St. Andrews, it is predominantly Christian and white. By contrast, many of Mr. Gutierrez's fellow golfers at the public course are blue-collar workers representing ethnically diverse backgrounds.
Despite the passage in 1989 of the New York State Human Rights law -- which made it illegal for organizations serving the public to discriminate on the basis of skin color, sex, church affiliation or national origin -- the homogeneity of private golf club memberships persists.
And while golf officials acknowledged that private clubs continue to be exclusive, they observed that the reasons for that had changed and insisted that nothing unlawful persists.
"Race, ethnicity, gender or religion are not issues anymore and have not been for some years," said William Rose Jr., president of the 75-year-old Winged Foot Golf Club in Mamaroneck, where the 79th P.G.A. Championship will be held this summer from Aug. 11 to 17.
"It's a matter of economics now," he said.
In 1990, four national professional golf organizations made integration a prerequisite for a club's being a host of their tournaments, and Winged Foot counts several black members.
In fact, many private clubs today proudly mention their black and Hispanic members, although the numbers remain small. Similarly, some predominantly Christian clubs boast that they have Jewish members, and vice versa. And more private clubs -- not all, however -- appear proud of the role women play on their governing boards.
As Marc C. Bergschneider, chairman of Hudson National Golf Club in Croton-on-Hudson, Westchester's newest and most expensive club, explained it: "We're open to females, blacks, Hispanics, Jews, Catholics and Protestants. What we're looking for are good golfers with good character and good money."
Equity memberships at Hudson National cost $150,000, and yearly dues are $10,000. Initiation fees at other private clubs range from $20,000 to $150,000, and yearly fees start at $5,000.
"At those prices, private club memberships are not for your average Joe," said Colin Burns, the general manager at Winged Foot.
Economics may be the reason, but that is little consolation to black leaders like Winston A. Ross, the Westchester Regional Director for the New York State Conference of N.A.A.C.P. branches.
"We don't even get to be discriminated against because a lot of minorities can't afford memberships to begin with," he said.
Those kinds of concerns are especially troubling in light of the success of Tiger Woods, the Masters golf champion whose heritage is a mixture of black, Thai, white and American Indian.
While some view Mr. Woods's success as a milestone for civil rights and believe it will open doors for youngsters inspired by his example, others call attention to the limitations of what has essentially been a wealthy white man's game.
Indeed, the tradition at places like Winged Foot -- the interior of its stone club house is decorated with plush blue and gold carpeting, wood paneling and understated, elegant furniture -- appears steeped in an old-money heritage established by a white upper class.
And although the admission standards have changed over the years, clubs like Winged Foot and St. Andrew's continue to be exclusive -- although in ways different from the past.
For example, at St. Andrew's, the oldest golf club in the United States, admission until the 1970's was limited to Scottish Presbyterians, Michael P. Beckerich, the club's president, said.
That proved to be an economically unsound policy for the club, which eventually reached out to a broader membership to stay in business. Laws prohibiting discriminatory policies had little to do with it, the president said.
Nevertheless, St. Andrew's continues in spirit to be what Mr. Beckerich unapologetically described as clubby -- attracting like-minded players to its fairways.
"When choosing members, we ask, 'Is this a person I would have fun being hooked up with on the first tee?' " he said.
Jay Mottola, executive director of the Metropolitan Golf Association, an Elmsford-based nonprofit group representing 400 clubs, said it was not surprising that the changes in legislation had made little difference in the basic exclusivity of many private golf clubs.
"Sometimes they are painted as trying to keep out some groups, but I don't see that," Mr. Mottola said. "Clubs basically are groups of friends, so you can expect that one may be predominantly Jewish and another predominantly Christian, for example."
In recent years, Florida, Kansas, Maine, Michigan and Montana have enacted legislation redefining many private clubs as public institutions. Also, Maryland and Minnesota bar discrimination at country clubs if they accept state-property-tax deductions under open-space laws.
In 1994, New York's Human Rights Law was amended to make it applicable to any club that has more than 100 members, regularly serves meals and receives money directly or indirectly from nonmembers for business purposes.
Even though most private clubs now comply with the law, civil rights leaders are questioning whether the former discriminatory policies have only gone undercover. Are clubs inviting a few token minority members into their ranks and thereby complying with the letter of the law but not its spirit? they ask.
Lawrence Otis Graham, the author of the recently published book "Proversity: Getting Past Face Value and Finding the Soul of People" (John Wiley & Sons), said clubs now engage in polite forms of bigotry that in essence have the same impact as earlier forms of discrimination.
"In other words, they just found another way to say that they only want to be around people who remind them of themselves," said Mr. Graham, who is also the author of "Member of the Club," an investigation into discrimination at Greenwich Country Club.
Looking to the future, some minority leaders are optimistic that Mr. Woods's recent victory and the media attention it has garnered will eventually serve as a catalyst for clubs to become more inclusive, despite the problems of the past.
"I think that golf will eventually undergo a change, which will probably scare some white people to death," said Ernest Prince, president of the Urban League of Westchester.
"This is one of the last sports to be integrated, and private clubs are one of the last bastions where some whites still don't have to look over their shoulder to see if they shouldn't say something," he said.
In the immediate future, the most likely venue for young minority golfers is the public course.
"The passion for golf is no less on a public course," said Salvatore A. DeSantis, Westchester's Commissioner of Parks, Recreation and Conservation, who estimated that there were about 275,000 rounds of golf played on Westchester's public courses last year. He said that golfers often line up in the very early morning hours to be the first to tee off.
The county operates five public courses and is negotiating to acquire a sixth. The county courses, where greens fees with a Parks Department pass range from $11 to $19, are Dunwoodie in Yonkers, Maple Moor in White Plains, Mohansic in Yorktown Heights, Saxon Woods in Scarsdale and Sprain Lake in Yonkers.
Some golfers like Anthony G. Azrak, a Wall Street trader from Bronxville who was playing at Saxon Woods last week, said they prefer the public venue, even though the price of admission at a private club was not a deterrent. They said they were happy not to be dealing with the social pressures and snobbery that one often encounters at private clubs.
"It's relaxing here," Mr. Azrak said. "Why should I have to pay big money to be outside with nature and play a good game of golf?"

LENGTH: 1734 words

HEADLINE: F.Y.I.: English At Work

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

DATELINE: RAHWAY

 BODY:
WHEN the 3:15 buzzer sounds at the Guest Packaging plant, most of the first-shift workers leave their soap-cutting machines, their enormous mixing vats filled with raspberry fragrance, their stacks of boxes of ginseng body lotion, and head for home. But six men and four women -- packers, compounders, label operators -- climb a flight of metal stairs past a towering silver tank of propylene glycol and file into a windowless room isolated from the chugs and beeps of the factory floor.
It is time for English class. 
 "Today, we're going to learn how to fill out an actual Guest Packaging accident report," says the teacher, Bonnie Finkelstein, "because, God forbid, anything happens to you, you need to know how to tell people about it."
For the next two hours, Ms. Finkelstein and her eager pupils, who hail from seven countries, discuss the dangers of bypassing safety devices and working on moving parts and the distinctions between "inhalation," "ingestion" and "absorption." Frank Alcindor, a machine operator from Haiti who has his eye on a supervisor's job, volunteers to explain the importance of clearing all the bottles off the production line before starting the next run. "This class helps a lot," he says afterward. "It gives me better communication with my workers and my boss."
Lots of people have come to the same conclusion as Mr. Alcindor. And not just at Guest, where 120 of the plant's 470 workers have signed up for English classes that cover subjects such as how to fill out work order forms and follow the Federal government's designated good manufacturing practices. Across New Jersey, more and more workers are preparing for the 21st Century by studying English on the job, thanks in part to a program run by the state Labor Department that has brought teachers into more than 200 workplaces since it started in 1995.
Here in the state that a recent Princeton University study tabbed as the one with the nation's most diverse immigrant population, companies from screw makers to hospitals to hotels are finding that they need their employees to speak a common language in order to grow, meet tougher safety standards and -- counterintuitively -- stay competitive in the global marketplace.
And employees need to improve their English to hold onto their jobs in the face of workplace changes requiring blue- and white-collar workers alike to know how to perform their colleagues' tasks, do more paperwork, feel at home at a computer keyboard and simply communicate more.
Though the surge in employee language training is happening at the same that immigration reforms have thousands of people scrambling to learn English in order to be allowed to stay in the country, it is a separate phenomenon, said Paul Scherbina, who runs the state program.
"This whole thing is being pushed more by economics than immigration," he said.
Often as not, workers signing up for English courses are veteran employees, many of them already citizens, said Nancy Fisher, education director for Jewish Vocational Service of Metrowest in East Orange, which is Ms. Finkelstein's employer and one of the state's steadiest suppliers of English teachers.
"What we're finding is that employees who have been around 15 or 20 years -- good, productive employees -- are not able to keep up with changes in the workplace," Ms. Fisher said. "A lot of hospitals, for instance, are going to patient-focused care, where somebody who was once just a cleaning person is now in charge of dietary, housekeeping, maintenance and transport for a cluster of rooms, and she has to have a lot more contact with patients and be able to answer their questions. Her job orders are coming through on a computer now. In a factory, you have more interactions between line workers and supervisors, and people have to do more advanced computations. All that requires language skills."
Many other factors are making English an increasingly essential tool in the workplace:
* International standards like the quality-control specifications known as ISO 9000, which many manufacturers are adopting. The system requires written documentation of every task in the production process.
* Business practices like Total Quality Management that require workers at every level of a company to become directly involved in making decisions.
* The fact that New Jersey's immigrant population is growing more ethnically diverse even as the rest of the country's is growing less diverse, according to Thomas Espenshade, a Princeton University sociologist who recently published a book about the state's immigrants. The Census Bureau says the percentage of New Jersey residents who speak little or no English increased by 25 percent from 1980 to 1990. And while most of those people speak Spanish, 40 percent of them speak neither English nor Spanish. For supervisors, that means being bilingual is often not enough.

Have Curriculum, Will Travel
In the big-government scheme of things, New Jersey's workplace English program -- one of fewer than half a dozen in the country, Mr. Scherbina said -- is still relatively small. It began in 1995 with a budget of $100,000 and will cost $900,000 this year, almost all of which goes to pay teachers. But Mr. Scherbina said the program's size made it nimble. He prides himself on starting classes within two or three weeks of meeting with a company. And the teachers -- who come from the staffs of community colleges or nonprofit groups like Jewish Vocational Service, which has been sending English teachers to job sites since 1992 -- will set up shop anywhere.
At a wholesale rose company, for example, classes were held after work on the tables where the the roses were cut.
The 10-week, 40-hour courses, at beginning, intermediate and advanced levels, are tailored to each company's needs and particular vocabulary.
"It's not conversational English," Mr. Scherbina said. "It's more important to be able to say, 'Stop the press, Jose, hand caught,' than 'Nice weather out there.' " (Nevertheless, he said, the courses help workers off the job, too. "One woman told me she overheard her kids say, 'We better be careful because Mama's beginning to understand us.' ")
Mr. Scherbina encourages companies to pay employees for at least half their class time. Workers often have to make considerable sacrifices to attend, he said, and the fiscal and symbolic support cuts the dropout rate. But many companies, including Guest Packaging, do not.
Barbara Texeira, the training manager at Guest Packaging, where English lessons have just started, said she hoped they would pay off for employees and management alike. Safety needs to be improved -- "We've had a lot of accidents in the past," she said. Workers have complained that their suggestions are not listened to.
And satisfying the company's biggest customers is getting harder. "Procter & Gamble is getting stricter and stricter with their requirements," Ms. Texeira said. "Every single person who works on a P&G line needs to be able to read their Standard Operating Procedures. And when P&G audits us, we have to be able to go to every person on the line and ask them to describe their job."
Some companies find that the benefits of English training build up over time. In 1991, the H&H Swiss Screw Company in Somerset brought in consultants to teach Total Quality Management to a work force that spoke mostly Spanish, Russian and Serbo-Croatian. But the company controller, Diane Lucas, said it became clear that while the workers were picking up new mathematical techniques, softer concepts like team-building were not getting through.
When the state program started in 1995, H&H jumped at it.
Now, "if we're conducting a tour and our customer wants to see their parts being produced, we bring them right out to the floor, and the setter and the operator explain the process to them," Ms. Lucas said. "It's great for our customers."
H&H is so encouraged that it is now looking to be certified in ISO 9000, the paperwork-intensive manufacturing protocol set by the International Standards Organization and accepted around the world.
"This ISO registration and certification that we're now reaching for is like the icing on the cake," Ms. Lucas said. "It's the culmination of many years of education of the work force, and at its base is E.S.L."
Another force driving the need for a lingua franca in the workplace is the demographic fact that companies have often been settled like cities, with a few pioneers from one ethnic group setting up a foothold in one department and recruiting friends and relatives as jobs open up. The result is linguistically isolated "neighborhoods" that can function as long as they are self-sufficient, just as someone in a cohesive ethnic neighborhood can survive without learning English. But cross-training and other attempts to integrate a company can lead to chaos.
Take Gar Products, a restaurant furniture maker in Lakewood that held its first English-class graduation last month. Gar, which has grown from a few dozen employees to 85, recently decided to introduce a new tier of management between the supervisors and the line workers.
"We needed someone to be in charge of three or four people, to handle paperwork and give people someone to report to when they finish a job to keep work flowing," said Elaine Garfunkel, an officer of the company. "What we found was that the support people we felt were responsible enough to do this didn't have the English."
It gets more complicated.
"In our upholstery department, the supervisor speaks only English," Ms. Garfunkel said. "Her lead person speaks Polish and English, so he had no trouble communicating with the Polish workers in his group, but he couldn't communicate with the people in his group who spoke Spanish. And if people who needed seat pads for assembly came over to the upholstery area to look for seat pads, they couldn't ask the supervisor where the seat pads are, and so they would need a translator, which means pulling somebody away from their work."
No one becomes fluent in English in 10 weeks, but Ms. Garfunkel said the course had already had a big impact. "Morale is better," she said, "and I think we're seeing an easing of possible tensions between people from different backgrounds. We're looking at a more harmonious workplace, and I think that in itself is going to benefit us."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
In Oakland, 400 Homes on 303 Acres, 203 Open Space

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

DATELINE: OAKLAND

 BODY:
A 303-ACRE tract of woodlands edging the Ramapo River in this Bergen County borough is beginning its transformation into a residential enclave that will have 400 homes, but still preserve much of the site's natural setting.
The detached houses and town homes will be laid out on 100 acres, mostly in clusters of three or four, so that the rest will remain open. They will be set against the Ramapo Mountains off Ramapo Valley Road (Route 202) in this community, where 20 percent of its nine square miles is parkland. 
 Model homes are now taking shape and roads are being installed for the first 95 detached homes at Ramapo River Reserve, as the project will be known. The complex will be built at a cost of more than $70 million over the next four years by Baker Residential, a subsidiary of the Baker Companies of Pleasant Valley, N.Y.
The company is using its own equity and bank financing to build the project. It is the first sizable development in Oakland in a dozen years and is rising on one of the few large tracts left for residential development, said Michael F. Kauker, the borough's planning consultant.
The project is proceeding at a time when the housing market in Bergen County, as in the rest of suburban New Jersey, is strengthening, said Randolph L. Wine, president of the West Bergen Association of Realtors.
Factors in the improving market, he said, are increased demand coupled with a low inventory of existing homes, heightened consumer confidence in the economy and reasonable mortgage interest rates. He said home prices, which dropped by as much as 30 percent during the housing downturn in the late 80's and early 90's, have also stabilized and begun to move up.
Those market conditions, along with what John W. Dolan Jr., project manager, said his company viewed as a rare site just 40 minutes from midtown Manhattan in a natural setting, were crucial in its decision to move ahead with the project. Other factors were existing state approvals for the site and access to the final link of Interstate 287, which was completed three years ago through the center of Oakland and is two miles from the entrance to the project.
Baker's development plan is not the first for the site, 189 acres of which was the former estate of the late Pulitzer Prize-winning playwright Sidney Kingsley, who purchased the property in the mid-30's as a summer retreat. Though Mr. Kingsley lived there until his death two years ago, he sold the property in 1985 to River Bend Associates, New York and New Jersey investors.
Initially, the investors proposed building 364 residences, most of them town houses on the 189-acre site. But the borough rejected the proposal in 1986 contending it was too dense, even though the special cluster zoning at the time for that part of Oakland permitted two units an acre.
The developer sued and then bought 108 adjacent acres. A year later River Bend reached an agreement with the city to build 394 units in what is the current tract. The 1987 settlement called for the developer to give the borough $1.3 million, including $500,00 toward meeting the borough's Mount Laurel obligation to provide 220 units affordable to families with low or moderate incomes and to construct a sewage treatment plant to service the new community. Most of Oakland is not now served by public sewers.
Then the recession hit and River Bend ultimately chose not to develop the site.
Mr. Dolan of Baker said his company had purchased the site in 1994 and agreed to meet the terms of the settlement, despite the fact that the property is laced with wetlands that under state law cannot be developed and require buffer zones around them.
"We felt we could come up with a responsible development plan that would conform with the state approvals and take advantage of the site's natural beauty," added Ian R. Jones, project development manager. The site includes rock outcroppings, a lake and estuaries that feed into the river, which borders the site on the east. The mountains border it on the west.
The company presented its site plan to the Oakland Planning Board for review in 1995. It was reconfigured from River Bend's plan to include detached homes and town houses with garages, which Baker considers more viable in today's market. It also has six more homes than River Bend's plan because Baker purchased six additional acres.
After a year of negotiations, the company was granted preliminary approval for the entire site last July and final approval for the first phase three weeks ago.
Most of the 400 homes in the project, designed as a homeowners' association, will follow the site's topography, placing them on flatlands or natural plateaus and tucking them amid thick woodlands. Some homes will overlook a six-acre lake, but most of the land along the river as well as most of the mountainside will be left untouched.
MR. KAUKER, Oakland's planning consultant, said Ramapo River Reserve implements the zoning the borough put in place in 1985 and recognizes areas of the site that are amenable to development and those that should be preserved. As such it is consistent with the planning objective of local officials to maintain Oakland's semirural character, he said.
Mayor J. Peter Kendall added that though the project would increase Oakland's 4,000 homes by 10 percent it was not expected to overburden municipal resources because the borough's population had dropped in the last 15 years to just under 12,000 from 14,000. He also said traffic along Route 202 in the part of town near the project has decreased since I-287 was finished.
Baker also is in the final stages of negotiations with the county on improvements from Route 202 into the site, mainly widening the road for a left-turning lane into the project.
"We would have liked to have put the site into parkland," said Mr. Kendall, "but it was in private hands for over 50 years and we couldn't afford to buy it." The current plan "is the best we could do," he said.
Work is proceeding on the first 95 homes, which will be in clusters of three and four. The three- and four-bedroom detached houses, with 2,250 to 3,305 square feet of space, will have two-car garages.
The homes, designed in seven styles by E.D.I Architecture Inc of Houston, will sit on 5,500-square-foot lots and be fee simple, meaning buyers own the land under the houses. Preconstruction prices will range from the high-$200,000 to the mid-$300,000 range. Sales are to begin next month.
As of the first quarter the average sales price for existing detached homes in the county was $278,729, up from $265,861 the same time last year, according to the New Jersey Multiple Listing Service, which covers Bergen, Passaic and Hudson Counties.
Construction is also under way on an outdoor pool and clubhouse, with meeting space and an exercise room. The lake will have a beach and floating dock and nature trails through the property are also planned. The monthly homeowner's fee is expected to be $150.
Down the road, Mr. Dolan said, the plan also calls for 39 larger and more expensive detached homes on bigger lots on a plateau 500 feet up the side of the mountain. The zoning also permits town houses, the size and price of which have not yet been determined, he said. He said they would be developed according to market demand.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 3421 words

HEADLINE: Preserving a Delicate Balance

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS 

 BODY:
TO drive along South Orange Avenue as it crosses from a frayed section of Newark to the neatly tended village of South Orange is a jarring experience. Within a single block, an urban landscape of littered streets, roll-down security gates and graffiti-scarred apartment buildings gives way to the leafy charms of gas-fired street lamps, proud Victorians and pampered front lawns. That the owners of the gaslit Victorians and Tudors include both whites and blacks is a fact that residents of South Orange, and its sister township, Maplewood, see as a crucial part of their suburban identity. But as more and more black families replace whites in parts of their communities, there is growing concern about whether this balance can be maintained.
Maintaining diversity, local residents and officials have learned, does not happen on its own. Treading warily along the delicate fault lines where race, idealism and property values meet, the two towns have set up a Racial Balance Task Force to publicly confront the kind of issues that many communities might prefer to keep closeted. 
 Thirty years ago this summer, race riots devastated Newark and sent much of its white population packing for newer suburbs to the south and west. But as New Jersey's largest city fell victim to urban decay and racial ghettoization, South Orange and Maplewood held the line against white flight, islands of integration in a largely segregated sea.
Once a single municipality -- Maplewood seceded after World War I -- the towns are linked in innumerable ways, including a combined school system, recreation programs, and what Bob Klein, a local realtor, calls "a sense that we're in this together." The South Orange/Maplewood school district remains the envy of surrounding communities, and many homes in both towns sell for well over $300,000.
Like numerous other municipalities that border largely black urban areas, South Orange and Maplewood, with 38,000 residents, can no longer ignore shifting demographics. Their black populations, less than 5 percent in 1970, have grown to 19 percent in South Orange and 13 percent in Maplewood, according to the 1990 census, the most recent figures available. More telling, however, is the racial makeup of the towns' shared school district. In 1990, the student population was 22 percent nonwhite. Today that figure is 45 percent, reflecting the fact that many white empty-nesters are being replaced by minority households with school-age children.
Perhaps more troubling to many residents is the pattern of demographic change. Sections of South Orange and Maplewood that abut Newark and Irvington have become predominantly black while the more expensive neighborhoods that hug South Mountain to the west remain largely white. Adjacent communities like Millburn and Short Hills that sit on the other side of the forested ridge are 99 percent white, a fact that some black home-seekers say deters them from looking beyond South Orange and Maplewood.
Town officials and local residents charge, while declining to name specific brokers or agencies, that some real-estate agents steer whites and blacks to different parts of town, creating new albeit relatively affluent ghettos. A dozen agents who were interviewed for this article denied charges that they steered clients by skin color, saying that it is economics that largely determines where blacks and whites buy homes; the agents said that segregated enclaves serve no one.
Many residents agree that the integrated character of South Orange and Maplewood ranks with the excellence of the schools as attractions for them. "I moved here so my kids could grow up in a microcosm of the real world," said Brian O'Leary, 40, an executive at Maplewood's Hammond map company who lives three blocks from Newark in South Orange's Tuxedo Park section. "No one benefits when people of different races live separately."
Residents of both towns, after a decade of apprehension and rancorous debate, formed the 30-member task force and hired an integration specialist to help them grapple with what sociologists refer to as "resegregation." Their hope is to turn South Orange/ Maplewood into a model of diversity, much like Shaker Heights, Ohio, the Cleveland suburb that pioneered engineered integration 30 years ago.
"If we could freeze this moment in time, the mix we have now would be perfect," Donald L. DeMarco, the task force's consultant, told 300 residents last month during a public forum at the towns' shared high school, Columbia. "But the problem is momentum and to not make an effort is to give in to segregation. Ignoring the issue will not make it go away."
WHILE most Americans approach the discussion of race with caution, people here have begun to talk about the topic with increasing ease. In classrooms, town meetings and during casual encounters at the new Starbucks in South Orange, people broach the subject without reluctance. "By openly discussing race, people realize that we all cut our lawns, take care of our homes and want a good education for our kids," said Celia King, 36, a hospital administrator and Maplewood's only black elected committeewoman, as her two children played in the backyard. "It's inspiring to hear people talk about something as delicate as race for the first time in their lives."
That talk has also led to action. Since November, when it hired Mr. DeMarco, a veteran of Shaker Heights, the interracial task force has begun working to identify brokers it believes engage in steering. Last month, the group began advertising their communities in metropolitan area newspapers, featuring a toll-free number for potential home buyers who will be referred to participating real-estate agents. This list of "preferred brokers" will be determined, committee members said, by sending people of various races to real-estate offices and seeing what neighborhoods they are offered as prospective home buyers.
The task force has other goals as well: promoting racial harmony, encouraging blacks and whites to socialize more freely and increasing minority participation in civic life. But they also believe that their communities' ultimate well-being is tied to a robust real-estate market in which people of all races can compete for housing in every part of town. After careful evaluation, both white and black residents have come to the same conclusion: Once a neighborhood becomes predominantly black, white demand dries up and property values fall.
Shirley Matthews has a first-hand understanding of that equation. When she and her husband, who is white, moved from Park Slope, Brooklyn, to Maplewood 10 years ago, she was the first black on their block. But since then, nearly every house that has come on the market has been sold to a black family, she says. "Brokers claim they weren't steering but why is it I never saw a white person looking at these houses?" asked Ms. Matthews, a doctoral student in psychology whose husband is an executive at Christofle Silver in Manhattan.
Now that the couple wants to move to a larger house in town, they have been told by their broker to set the asking price below what they paid. "It's devastating," said Ms. Matthews. "This street is as beautiful as it was when we moved in. It's obvious to me that once the racial makeup of a neighborhood goes beyond the comfort level of whites, the value of that neighborhood goes down."
While housing prices in both towns declined during the late 1980's and early 1990's, which may partly account for the decreased value in Ms. Matthews's home, they have begun to rebound, say brokers, thanks in part to the region's improving economy, but also because speedier train service to Manhattan via a new rail link, Midtown Direct, has started to draw a growing number of young professionals from New York City, Hoboken, Jersey City and even the postwar suburbs further to the west. The service, which New Jersey Transit inaugurated last summer, has shaved travel time by a third, allowing commuters from South Orange and Maplewood to reach Penn Station in under a half hour.
There is an unmistakable pride in the town's cosmopolitan citizenry, its municipal art gallery, its spirit of volunteerism and the fact that interracial families and gay couples have begun flocking here in recent years. Income levels in the two towns are comfortable; in South Orange, according to the 1990 Census, household median income for blacks was $73,327, and for whites, $63,688; in Maplewood, for blacks $59,306 and for whites, $57,947.
Even South Orange's commercial center, once plagued with 17 vacant storefronts, has come back to life. In the last year, a dozen new businesses have opened, and town officials have ambitious plans to build a performing arts center, a movie theater and a small hotel adjacent to the train station. A $2.5 million redesign of South Orange Avenue, which will widen sidewalks and slow speeding traffic, is scheduled to begin this summer. "These are the kinds of improvements that will increase competition for housing," said William Calabrese, South Orange's chief elected official. "Sometimes I think all this talk about race might just exaggerate the problem."
But physical improvements alone, Mr. DeMarco and task force members agree, may not be enough to overcome white reservations about sharing neighborhoods with blacks. Douglas S. Massey, a professor of sociology at the University of Pennsylvania and the author of "American Apartheid: Segregation and the Making of the Underclass" (Harvard University Press, 1993), says that in a series of recent surveys black respondents describe a neighborhood as ideally integrated when the racial composition is equal parts black and white. Whites, on the other hand, see the ideal mix as no more than 20 percent black. "It's the sad reality of our country," said Dr. Massey. "Unfortunately, most communities fighting resegregation will find it an uphill slog."
Those towns that have kept a change from comfortably integrated to largely black at bay have done so by making racial balance something of a crusade. For Shaker Heights, that mission has been an intrinsic part of the town's psyche since the mid 1960's. Sixth graders take racial sensitivity classes and a loan program entices whites to move to black neighborhoods.
But despite its stable mix of race and class and a vigorous housing market, there are still parts of the Ohio town that are overwhelming white or black. The job of staving off separateness, say Shaker Heights officials, is never done.
"While not perfect, Shaker Heights is an example of the possibilities for promoting integration and better race relations in a community," said John Yinger, author of "Closed Doors, Opportunities Lost: The Continuing Costs of Housing Discrimination" (Russell Sage Foundation, 1995). "At the very least, discrimination is relatively low and people of all races have equal access to housing."
But few communities have the political will to take on racial issues so boldly, says Mr. DeMarco, who has worked with a dozen towns around the country. In many cases, a municipality will act only after panic selling has begun, when people realize they can't sell their homes.
"There is a very brief window of opportunity, when property values are strong and people are willing to do the hard work that's required," said Mr. DeMarco, executive director of the Fund for an Open Society, a nonprofit organization based in Philadelphia. "You can count on both hands and a few toes the number of places in this country that have maintained true integration."
Freeport, L.I., Teaneck, N.J., and West Mount Airy, a suburb of Philadelphia, he said, are among the few East Coast communities that have sustained racial balance.
Many newcomers say that the diversity of South Orange and Maplewood is what attracted them. When Kerry and Philip Robinson, both white, began looking to move from their Brooklyn Heights apartment last year, they initially avoided South Orange and Maplewood because friends and brokers intimated that the towns "had problems." Instead, they searched for a home in western New Jersey communities that until recently were mostly farmland. Ms. Robinson, 33, said she was dismayed by what she found.
"All we saw were treeless tract developments with vinyl siding, not the kind of houses where you'd want to put a candle in the window at Christmas," she said.
MORE troubling was what she called the "stifling sterility" of the newer suburbs, the sense that everyone was the same. "My biggest fear about leaving Brooklyn was losing the rich culture, the diversity," she said. "I didn't want my daughter to grow up in a white-bread community."
At the insistence of a friend, she and her husband, a vice president at Smith Barney, toured South Orange and fell in love with a 1929 Tudor on Mayhew Drive with cathedral ceilings, a back staircase and "no wood veneer anywhere," she said.
The fact that a number of black families live in the neighborhood was part of the draw. "When a child grows up with people who are all the same, race eventually becomes an issue," she said, as her 5-year-old daughter tugged at her hem. "In a place like South Orange, there's a better chance that race will be irrelevant."
George Robinson, (no relation to Kerry and Philip) who moved his family from Manhattan to Maplewood in 1984, was also drawn by the town's racial mix. "I have no interest in living in a cocoon," he said. But that same diversity, he believes, also frightens some older residents, many of whom fled Newark a generation ago when things there began to change. "They may have come here because there wasn't anything 'offensive' about the towns," said Mr. Robinson, a member of the board of education who is white, "and to some that may mean there weren't many African Americans."
While the integration of the community is a draw to many, a more crucial factor to young families is frequently the schools, where a decline in scores on standardized tests in recent years has been a cause of concern. Dr. Ralph Lieber, the superintendent of schools, says the slump in standardized test scores has convinced some people that the education system, consistently ranked among the nation's top 8 percent, is on a downward slide.
That decline, he said, reflects that many new students transferred from less rigorous schools. After a few years in the South Orange/Maplewood system, he said, the scores of recently arrived students have increased. Last year, state test scores at Columbia High School rose 6 percent, he said.
"The education we offer is still among the best in the country," he said. "We regularly send students to Harvard and Yale. But if we have to play the test score game to prove the perceived worth of our education system, we'll focus on raising test scores."
For some, the changing hue of Columbia's student body is in itself a source of alarm. "People see groups of African American kids leaving school and they make assumptions about the quality of education," Dr. Lieber said. "It's frustrating to have to battle stereotypes."
And that, say task force members, is at the heart of South Orange and Maplewood's problem. To combat negative perceptions, the task force has created a program to reach out to brokers, corporate relocation consultants and potential home buyers. It also hopes to push for new local ordinances that, for example, would ban "for sale" signs from front lawns.
The governments of both towns have each contributed $50,000 toward the cost of promoting their communities, hiring a coordinator to oversee the entire effort, including the testing program aimed at both identifying real-estate agents that the committee will designate as "preferred" and determining those who engage in racial steering.
Many real-estate brokers reject accusations of racial steering and say they are being unfairly blamed for forces beyond their control. Linda Firestone, director of education for the North Central Jersey Association of Realtors, says sales agents know that steering is a violation of the 1968 Fair Housing Act, and that even talking about race to prospective buyers can cost them their real-estate licenses.
"For brokers, the only color they know is green," she said. "If I won't show you a house in a more expensive neighborhood, it has everything to do with your finances. Oftentimes discrimination is in the eye of the beholder."
Harold Carillo, who owns the Coldwell Banker brokerage in Union, says that many agents engage in steering without realizing it. "Sometimes we figure, 'Italians want to live with Italians and Greeks with other Greeks,' " he said. "I think I was guilty of that kind of thing until people told me it was wrong."
During his 30 years in the real-estate business, Mr. Carillo has seen dramatic change in Essex County. Since the late 1960's, towns like Orange, East Orange and Irvington, all of which border Newark, have become more than 75 percent black. A former resident of Newark, Mr. Carillo joined his neighbors in a hasty exodus shortly after the riots subsided, taking a $12,000 loss on his house. "Once the National Guard and the tanks left, nearly every house on my street was up for sale," he said.
He believes that Maplewood and South Orange are poor candidates for wholesale resegregation, largely because property values remain high. "It's all about economics," he said. "Most blacks simply can't afford to live in these towns."
According to figures compiled by the task force, the average sale price for homes in South Orange, $203,600 in 1992, rose to $219,000 last year. In Maplewood, average prices rose from $176,000 to $185,000 in the same period. In the last six months, brokers say, interest in the towns has soared, thanks in large part to the new train service.
"This is the busiest we've been in years," said Roy Scott, the owner of the Re/Max Village Square agency in South Orange. "We're swamped, especially with people from the city who want to live in the suburbs without giving up the cosmopolitan lifestyle they're used to."
One sign of the booming market is the six-bedroom Colonial that Mr. Scott recently sold in South Orange's historic Montrose section, a few blocks from the Orange border. After just a week on the market, the house sold for $425,000. Three years ago, it sold for $340,000. "Bidding wars have become standard fare," he said.
It is in moderately priced neighborhoods, however, where homes sell in the $100,000 to $160,000 range, that resegregation is more of a concern.
Last year, when Mr. Carillo sold a foreclosed house to a black family on a predominantly white stretch of Williams Street, just a few blocks from Newark, the sale had a startling impact. "Within a few months, there were five or six 'for sale' signs," he recalled. "I guess some things never change."
LONG before she knew what the term resegregation meant, Suzanne Ryan was trying to change the status quo. An elementary school teacher who moved from Ozone Park, Queens, to Maplewood in 1985, Ms. Ryan was raking the leaves on her front lawn several years ago when she noticed that only black families were being shown the house next to hers.
"When I called up the broker and said, 'Don't you know that steering is illegal?' he slipped and said, 'No it isn't.' " Outraged by what she saw, Ms. Ryan and a group of neighbors revived a local organization that had been formed in the mid-1980's to deal with an outburst of racist graffiti that began appearing on the homes of black residents. "I realized that if we didn't do something, we would lose our town," she said, sitting on the front steps of her house surrounded by a blaze of flowering azaleas.
Although the group was unsuccessful in enlisting the support of town officials, at least the issue was brought into the open, she said.
"It was a bittersweet experience," said Ms. Ryan, 38, recalling the spate of angry phone calls from brokers, the hate mail, the cold glare of neighbors. "Some people thought I was a bigot, others thought I was just nuts. There's still plenty of hard work ahead of us, but the hardest part was just bringing the issue out of the closet."
"As a society," said Dr. Lieber, the school superintendent, who lives in South Orange, "we have so many stereotypes and built-in anxieties to overcome. We're on the cutting edge here because these are the kinds of problems the whole nation will eventually have to face. And if we can't succeed, I'm afraid no one can."
