HEADLINE: MEDIA: PUBLISHING;
Beijing goes for the benefits of financial news without any of the downside.

BYLINE: By Seth Faison 

DATELINE: SHANGHAI

 BODY:
WHEN Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, met recently with China's senior leaders, he delivered what was essentially a primer on fundamental characteristics of a market economy, a topic of endless fascination for the engineers of this nation's half-achieved shift from a state-run to a market system.
One of the elements Mr. Greenspan raised, United States officials said afterward, was the critical importance of free-flowing financial information for the development of capital markets, which China is in the midst of starting up. 
 Mr. Greenspan specifically warned about the damage that could be caused by China's plans, not yet in force, to control the distribution of financial information by international news organizations. His Chinese hosts listened carefully, but apparently did not respond in detail.
Information flow in China has followed economic and trade growth -- sharply upward -- over the last decade, so the New China News Agency stunned news organizations when it announced in January 1996 that it would assume new powers to supervise the content and sales of international news organizations that offer financial information here.
Now, after 16 months of negotiations, the issue is at a critical stage. The New China News Agency recently demanded that news organizations agree to its restrictions or lose the right to sign up new customers.
The issue of access to financial information cuts to the root of concerns among leaders of developing nations, who are interested in the benefits of the market but afraid of its limits on the role of government.
Chinese leaders seem especially perplexed by this. They are enthralled with the way capital markets raise money, but are nervous about the free-flowing information that comes with markets.
In recent years, however, the amount of available news and financial information has risen exponentially. There has not been the challenge to the legitimacy of the Communist Party that many old-school leaders feared, but its authority over the day-to-day lives of ordinary people is gradually diminishing.
By early 1996, Reuters and Dow Jones Markets, a unit of Dow Jones & Company, already had several hundred customers each, mainly Chinese banks and financial institutions that trade on international commodity, currency and other markets.
Executives at these news companies were shocked at the way the New China News Agency was trying to become both a regulator and a competitor -- last year it started its own financial news service, New China Financial Information -- in an era when China's leaders continually proclaim their determination to separate government from business.
The agency's officials apparently won approval from the Government to expand their role by portraying themselves as a necessary lifeguard at the swelling pool of electronic information available in China.
But during subsequent negotiations, foreign executives said, agency officials seemed most interested in learning about the commercial and technological operations, apparently for use at New China Financial.
In addition to wanting to learn who exactly the customers were and how much they paid, and how software and hardware operated, the press agency also asked Reuters and Dow Jones to pay a large percentage of their revenues in China.
Unfortunately for the New China News Agency, China's leaders are intent on joining the World Trade Organization, and the agency's desire to restrict rather than free the operations of international companies seem to go against W.T.O. principles.
By late last year, foreign executives believed their negotiations with the New China News Agency would effectively be postponed during China's efforts to gain entry to the organization this year.
But last month agency officials informed Reuters and Dow Jones that they would have to accept the agency's new regulations, or they would be denied any new customers.
"This issue is now larger than Xinhua and a few foreign information companies," said James McGregor, chief representative for Dow Jones in China, referring to the New China News Agency by its name in Chinese. "It's a W.T.O. issue. We don't want to do anything that would hurt China's chances of getting into the W.T.O."
Mr. McGregor said he and Reuters executives accepted the desire of China's leaders to check the information that foreign companies bring into the nation. But he held that the New China News Agency's double role as a regulator and a competitor goes against every principle of fair business competition.
The New China News Agency has modified its stance, dropping its original demand to be paid a percentage of each news agency's revenue in China. The initial request of 40 percent dropped to 15 percent, and later to 7 percent, and last month was dropped altogether.
It is even questionable whether the central Government would again approve the news agency's request for an expanded role if the decision were to be made today, a measure of how the political and technological atmosphere has changed in China over the last 16 months.
When the restrictive regulations were announced in early 1996, Chinese leaders were alarmed that the arrival of the Internet in China was threatening to bring in information they could not control.
Yet after blocking many Web sites of international news organizations last year, including The Wall Street Journal but not The New York Times, the authorities lifted the ban around the first of the year. Although some Web sites with politically sensitive content remain blocked, most news sites are openly accessible.

HEADLINE: Rains Come to Wall Street And With Them, Godzilla

BYLINE: By RICK LYMAN 

 BODY:
Several hundred somberly dressed people, black umbrellas bobbing over their heads, splayed across the steps of Federal Hall and into the intersection of Wall and Broad Streets. In an instant, they turned, screamed, dropped their umbrellas, bumped into one another, fell to the pavement or scrambled away in terror. A few stared, wild-eyed, into the empty sky, as though they saw something there.
"O.K., O.K.!" Greg Hale shouted to them through a cloth-covered bullhorn on Saturday afternoon. "That was good. Listen, people. We need to be safe. We don't need to be running people over." 
 Mr. Hale, an assistant director on the new American version of "Godzilla," reassembled the throng of a dozen stunt people and several hundred extras. The production spent Saturday and yesterday on Wall Street, filming scenes of "mayhem, lots of mayhem," said Dean Devlin, a producer and co-writer of the film.
A hundred yards down Broad Street, the director, Roland Emmerich, and a dozen sound and video technicians sat beneath a blue tent watching the rehearsal. Just out of camera range, specialists in mechanical special effects caused a line of taxicabs to bounce with each Godzillan footfall.
Two 170-foot Condor cranes held aloft a pair of rainmaking grids, ready to drench the set. A 72-foot crane held a camera at its tip, shooting what would eventually be Godzilla's point of view as he stomped toward the Stock Exchange, swooping down for a closer look at the fleeing extras.
A production assistant explained to a car-driving extra what was expected of him: "You drive up, see all the people running past your car, stop, look over your shoulder out of the window, see Godzilla, register it, then get out of the car, look up, turn and run away. Got it?"
He got it.
Location filming began in early May in Jersey City (where actors stared across the harbor toward what will be a Godzilla-ravaged lower Manhattan), moved to the Fulton Fish Market (boat crashes into pier, debris falls from sky) and the busy intersection at the foot of the Flatiron Building on East 23d Street (soldiers and armored vehicles blasting away) before moving to Wall Street. Beginning today, they will shoot on the Franklin D. Roosevelt Drive, on the Manhattan Bridge and in Central Park before moving to Los Angeles.
As with other recent Hollywood productions in New York, the movie drew complaints, this time from residents near the Flatiron building, concerned about the congestion, noise and lights. The production had permits to film for three nights at the site, from the Mayor's Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting, which expects Godzilla to bring more than $500,000 into the New York economy.
On Thursday, sensitive to the complaints, the film makers decided to fire a blank round from one of the tanks in Madison Square Park near 23d Street, to see how loud it was.
"It was really loud," Mr. Devlin said. "It was too loud."
So the film makers shot the scene without firing from the tanks. "We'll just add a computer-generated muzzle flash later," Mr. Devlin said.
Godzilla will not make an appearance at any of the New York locations. Instead, said William Fay, another producer, he will be added later, too, a combination of computer-generated images, mechanical animatronics and a fellow in a Godzilla suit, whatever will work best.
As with other extraordinarily expensive Hollywood action films, many of the details are being kept under wraps. The plot? "Well," Mr. Devlin said. "Obviously, Godzilla attacks New York." Other than that, it's a secret. Godzilla's size? A secret. His look? A secret. The names of some of the characters? Secret. The actual shooting budget, variously reported to be $90 million to $100 million? Also secret.
All of this secrecy has spawned several Web pages dedicated to Godzilla rumors, forcing Mr. Devlin and Mr. Emmerich to create their own rumor-bashing Web page, with a flashing headline that reads: "Jennifer Anniston is not in Godzilla!"
Is the new Godzilla only as tall as a man? No, they say. Will he change size and shape? No again. Do laser beams fly from Godzilla's eyes? "If you see one laser beam shoot out of Godzilla's eyes in our movie," the Web answered, "you can mail us your ticket stub and Dean and Roland will come over to your house and bake you a Key lime pie."
Not everything can be secret, though. Matthew Broderick will star as Nick Tatapolous, a biologist. He will be joined by Jean Reno as Raymond, an insurance investigator; Michael Lerner as the beleaguered Mayor of New York, Hank Azaria as a television cameraman named Animal, Harry Shearer as a nasty television newsman and Maria Pitillo as an aspiring young reporter.
The movie will be dark and wet and smoky, taking place largely at night and during an unrelenting rainstorm. "It pretty much rains most of the time in the movie," Mr. Devlin said. The extras on Wall Street were all dressed in dark clothes, the umbrellas all black. A smoke truck passed back and forth along the set, maintaining a proper level of murk.
Hoping to elbow aside the competition for 1998's summer movie season, Tri-Star Pictures announced it would release "Godzilla" on the Wednesday before Memorial Day.
The film-making team, which made the 1996 summer hit "Independence Day," inherited "Godzilla" from Jan De Bont, the director of "Speed" and "Twister." Mr. De Bont left the project a year ago when Tri-Star balked at the $130 million budget. Mr. Devlin and Mr. Emmerich had already turned down an earlier version of "Godzilla," fearing that it would be too campy. This time, though, they accepted, keeping the notion of Godzilla's attacking New York while rewriting the script in a darker direction.
"We didn't want to do a 'Mars Attacks!' " Mr. Devlin explained. "We felt it could be done straight and still have a lot of humor and a lot of thrills."
Godzilla made his first screen appearance in 1954, in the Toho Films production "Gojira," its name a combination of "gorilla" and the Japanese word for whale. The radiation-breathing, 400-foot, dinosaurlike creature has appeared in 22 films.
Despite the inevitable difficulties, the film makers decided they had to shoot some scenes in Manhattan.
"New York has a very specific look and a very specific energy that you really can't duplicate from some other location," Mr. Fay said.
Mr. Emmerich gave the producers his "wish list" of locations and it was whittled down, depending on what was available and what was possible.
Under the tent on Broad Street, Mr. Emmerich decided there had been enough rehearsal. One last water truck moved up Broad Street, spraying the cars and the buildings. The smoke truck moved through again. "We need rain," a production assistant shouted and a drenching downpour fell from the grids.
"Action," Mr. Emmerich said.
Footfall: Thump! The taxis jumped. Thump! The crowd raced up Broad, slipping on the water, clambering over one another, umbrellas flying. Thump! The crowd at Federal Hall dissolved in terror.
"O.K., cut," Mr. Emmerich said. Assistant directors shouted into bullhorns: "Cut!"
But the extras kept running.
"They can't hear us with all the noise from the rain machines," Mr. Fay shouted. "Somebody stop them before they get to Greenwich Village!"

SECTION: Section B; Page 1; Column 1; Metropolitan Desk 

LENGTH: 811 words

HEADLINE: Metro Matters;
Left for Last: Overhauling Welfare

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT 

DATELINE: ALBANY

 BODY:
THESE are critical days for New York's welfare system. At least in theory.
The state has just six weeks, or until July 1, to revamp its entire welfare system to bring it into compliance with the new Federal law. This means it must come up with a plan to identify the fathers of children on welfare, to find work for an increasing proportion of the adults and to nudge almost all of them off the rolls within five years. 
 Practically every aspect of the new Federal law poses an enormous challenge for New York, which is, after California, home to the largest welfare population in the country. And no matter what shape the state's eventual plan takes, it is bound to be one of the most consequential pieces of social legislation to come out of Albany in a generation.
And yet, welfare is a virtual nonissue here these days, a victim, it seems, of the can't-walk-and-chew-gum syndrome that so often afflicts state government.
At the start of the year, welfare was expected to dominate this legislative session. But then the State Senate majority leader, Joseph L. Bruno, announced his plan to scrap New York's rent laws. The Capitol has talked about almost nothing else since.
By the time Gov. George E. Pataki and the legislative leaders do finally get around to focusing on welfare, presumably sometime after the rent issue is resolved, it will be crammed into the usual end-of-session crush, when hundreds of bills are slapped together in a few frantic days.
As one lobbyist who closely monitors the issue lamented: "You are talking about the greatest overhaul of our social services since they were created 60 years ago. But we could get a welfare law written in two days by people who have had very little sleep. That's a little frightening to think about."
ALL the delaying comes at what is actually an unusually opportune moment for New York to be reconsidering its welfare policies. For along with the new Federal requirements comes a huge gift of cash.
This cash, known in Albany as the "windfall," stems from the formula the Federal Government is using to distribute welfare dollars for the coming year. The formula bases payments on states' welfare caseloads in 1995, but since that time caseloads in most states have significantly declined. In New York, the difference translates into a surplus of $730 million.
Advocates for the poor contend that the windfall should be used to insure genuine welfare reform rather than mere welfare reduction. It should be spent, they say, to educate welfare recipients, improve child care and provide effective job training.
"Here's a chance to really make some major investments, to make sure every kid gets high-quality child care and every mother who is supposed to get off welfare has the wherewithal to do so," said Anne Erickson, legislative coordinator for the Greater Upstate Law Project.
The Democratic-controlled Assembly is urging much the same thing, proposing that most of the windfall be reinvested in the system. But the Governor has taken a different tack, recommending that more than half the windfall be used for what he calls state and local "fiscal relief" and what really amounts to general spending. The Republican-controlled Senate, meanwhile, has yet to take an official stand on the windfall, or for that matter, on any other welfare-related issue.
The question of how to use the windfall is expected to be enormously contentious -- once, that is, negotiations actually get under way.
ALBANY'S dilatory attitude is very much in keeping with past practice.
While many other states, including New Jersey and Massachusetts, have spent the better part of the last decade moving aggressively to redesign their welfare systems, New York has mostly confined itself to incremental steps. So riven has state government been by partisan and geographical disputes that bolder initiatives barely seemed worth the paper they were printed on.
Indeed, the state's one real effort at innovation, the Child Assistance Program, or CAP, has largely stalled.
The program, instituted as a pilot project under Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, is supposed to encourage welfare recipients to work by, among other things, allowing them to keep more of their earnings. According to a five-year study of the program that the Pataki administration reluctantly released a few months ago, CAP has been a solid success in the handful of counties where it has been tried.
But the administration has shown only marginal interest in expanding CAP, arguing that it has little relevance in the new world of welfare. And so New York finds itself, with the deadline looming, scrambling to catch up with the changing times.
As Gary Burtless, a labor economist at the Brookings Institution, put it: "Even little old Arkansas has been thinking about this since the early 80's. New York does seem way behind."

SECTION: Section D; Page 5; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 963 words

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY: DIGITAL COMMERCE;
Profiting as a business-to-business middleman on the Internet is tricky.

BYLINE: By Steve Lohr 

 BODY:
THE idea seemed to be a winner. An on-line shopping mall for manufacturers, using the power of the Internet as a low-cost medium of communications to link industrial buyers and sellers. It was a classic application of technology to an economic inefficiency -- the often Dickensian business chore known as procurement. It still means thumbing through hulking directories for part numbers and product specifications and consumes millions of hours and billions of dollars a year.
A company deploying the Internet to streamline the procurement process would be tapping a gold mine. That was the vision that attracted Jim P. Manzi, the former chairman of the Lotus Development Corporation, to Nets Inc. in early 1996. Last summer, Fortune magazine selected the Internet commerce service as one of "25 cool companies" to watch. 
 Ten days ago, Nets filed for bankruptcy protection. The business had clearly not developed as quickly as Mr. Manzi had hoped, the private company was losing money at a torrid pace and a scramble to secure additional capital was unsuccessful.
The Nets bankruptcy, it seems, carries two lessons. First, playing the middleman role on the Internet is going to be a tricky way to make a living. The essence of the Internet, after all, is that it enables people and businesses to connect directly -- sidestepping intermediaries like distributors and retailers.
Second, the early opportunities for Internet market makers are going to be defined narrowly in specific industry sectors as opposed to the across-the-board manufacturers' mall formula of Nets.
"Nets was way too broad," said Bill Doyle, a senior analyst at Forrester Research Inc., in Cambridge, Mass., who worked briefly at Nets. "They bit off a lot more than a start- up can chew."
In recent months, Mr. Manzi had tried to narrow the focus of his company's on-line service, called Industry.net. Since February, Nets focused on the basic goods used to run businesses from office supplies to mops -- called maintenance, repair and operations, or M.R.O. -- instead of the more complicated parts and components used in products made by manufacturers.
Yet the multi-industry on-line malls will probably be the bailiwick of a few major companies with deep pockets and patience. The General Electric Company and Thomas Register, a leading publisher of industrial parts directories, are working jointly on an Internet commerce offering.
Someday, the Internet will be able to handle on-line blueprints and even allow industrial buyers to test how parts perform using simulation software distributed over the Net. But not yet.
"Someone like G.E. has a shot at creating a broad Internet mall for manufacturers, but everyone else is going to have to satisfy themselves with smaller vertical market communities," Mr. Doyle of Forrester said. "To run a successful on-line mall, companies are going to have to capture the gestalt of a market segment, really narrow stuff like plastic injection molders."
This, of course, is not to say that business-to-business commerce on the Internet is going to be insignificant or grow slowly. Just the opposite will be the case, analysts predict. Business-to-business sales on line, estimated at $600 million last year, are expected to reach roughly $66 billion by 2000, Forrester projects.
Most of the early traffic is businesses dealing directly with each other, with no intermediaries. Cisco Systems Inc., for example, is selling $5 million a day worth of its networking gear from its Web site to corporate customers. The savings in paperwork and labor costs, Cisco estimates, are running at $535 million annually. The Dell Computer Corporation has just begun Internet selling and is making sales of more than $1 million a day on line. Eighty-five percent of Dell's customers are corporations, and its goal is to handle nearly all its sales on the Internet eventually.
"It's going to be very difficult to make money as a middleman on the Internet, as opposed to using the Net to cut costs," observed Esther Dyson, editor of Release 1.0, a technology newsletter.
The kind of electronic mall with the best chance of success is probably one like Digital Market Inc. of Sunnyvale, Calif. The start-up was founded by Scott Hammond, a 35-year-old electrical engineer who worked at Xerox, Hewlett-Packard and Oracle. The company grew out of his frustration with inefficiency in finding and buying electronic components over the years.
Digital Market, with 30 employees, focuses only on electronic components. It is a field, Mr. Hammond explains, that is deep and fast-changing -- his service tracks 1.5 million different electronic components whose prices and availability change constantly. He believes the field should be ripe for the application of Internet technology, which makes it easy to quickly update a data bank.
The Government apparently agrees. Last November, Digital Market received a grant from the Government's Defense Advanced Research Project Agency to develop electronic commerce technology.
The problem at Nets, as one analyst said, was that it was "a mile wide and an inch deep." Digital Market will not take the same tack, Mr. Hammond said. "We're an inch wide and mile deep," he said.
Even the International Business Machines Corporation, a deep-pocketed company familiar with many industries, is cautious about trying to be an Internet middleman. Beyond selling software for business-to-business commerce, I.B.M. is becoming a hub for information and on-line transactions. Yet it focuses on industry niches like one for oil-exploration engineers, Petroconnect.
"We're going to be very selective about stepping into the middleman role," said Irving Wladawsky-Berger, general manager of I.B.M.'s Internet division.

SECTION: Section B; Page 9; Column 3; Metropolitan Desk

HEADLINE: Dana C. Creel, 84; Headed the Rockefeller Brothers Fund

BYLINE: By KIT R. ROANE 

 BODY:
Dana C. Creel, whose philanthropic hand helped mold the Rockefeller Brothers Fund into an eclectic charitable organization, died last Thursday night at his home, Haisdan Farm in Sharon, Conn.
He was 84, said Fraser P. Seitel, an adviser to the Rockefeller family. 
 Mr. Creel, who headed the Rockefeller Brothers Fund from 1950 to 1975, began his career as a banker after graduating from Emory Law School in 1939. He quickly found a calling in philanthropy when representatives for the Rockefeller family invited him to become the fund's financial adviser later that year.
During his tenure as president and director of the Rockefeller Brothers Fund, Mr. Creel dispersed $150 million to a variety of causes, many of them contentious at the time.
Among the biggest beneficiaries were groups working for integration in the South. Money was given to the Southern Regional Council to study ways of integrating communities and to the National Urban League for the development of the Skills Bank, which recruited blacks for industry and government. Grants were also set up for members of minority groups wanting to attend law school.
He also gave to groups that furthered women's education at a time when many people opposed it, and he championed birth control and cancer research. His choices of charities and his low-key style made him a maverick among directors of groups like the Ford Foundation and the Carnegie Endowment.
A $6 million donation helped create the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.
Mr. Creel, who was born in Smyrna, Ga., and also attended Harvard Business School, joined the Army in World War II, becoming a second lieutenant in a counterintelligence unit in Asia. Economic development programs in devastated areas of Asia, Latin America and Africa also benefited from his largesse.
"Dana Creel was an innovative giver who directed money to places that were not particularly prominent or popular at the time," Mr. Seitel said. "These were not the typical interests of wealthy people, and he helped change the focus of giving."
Mr. Creel is survived by his wife, Jane Haislip Creel of Sharon; a sister, Virginia Creel Clark of Tucson, Ariz., and a nephew, David Clark of Concord, Mass. Mr. Creel had no children.
